column2: BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 -- Soviet-West German negotiations for a new trade agreement broke down tonight over the issue of West Berlin.
MILLIONS of snowbound fathers spent an extra day with their wives and children in an unexpected family holiday yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Louisiana's devices to block desegregation of New Orleans schools were legally worthless.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Despite the four days of bloodshed in Algeria, Government sources predicted today that President De Gaulle would maintain the course he had set toward peace and self-determination there.
The ancient Jewish festival of Hanukkah will be observed for eight days beginning at sunset tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Grain futures prices started off on a steady to firm range generally today, and except for some pressure on near-by wheat, held the higher trend to the close.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Soccer players today considered the use of a "slow-freeze strike" in their battle over wages and contracts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter is prepared to tell the North Atlantic Treaty Organization members that the United States may have to consider a "material redeployment" of its troops in Europe unless its dollar troubles are substantially alleviated.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Texas Republicans lost today their Federal court fight to force state officials to order a recount of more than 1,250,000 paper ballots cast in the Nov. 8 Presidential election.
UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 12 -- Morocco and Guinea announced today that they had decided to withdraw their troops from the United Nations force in the Congo.
The typewriter -- one of the most widely used mechanisms in modern society -- is undergoing a marketing revolution.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy selected Dean Rusk as his Secretary of State today.

A LIVE, fat black-and-white, man-eating Brazilian fish called a Piranha occupies stage center during the three acts of a thing called "The Summer Pygmies" that opened at the Jan Hus House last evening.

A SHOW that has been tried out of town is always the better for it. And the same can be said for the performance of Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus" that the Little Orchestra brought to Town Hall last night.
Snow put a wet blanket yesterday on the stock market rally that had brought high enthusiasm on Friday, Even so, the market made good gains.

The Boise, Idaho, Independent School District yesterday sold $2,150,000 of bonds, due from 1962 to 1980, to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, and associates. The group bid 100.016 with 3 1/2, 3 and 3 1/4 per cent coupons, to establish a net interest cost to the school district of 3.2575 per cent.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company of the United States made its long-awaited formal offer today to buy all the publicly held shares of its British subsidiary, the Ford Motor Company, Ltd. British Ford directors advised stockholders to accept.
Snow drifts up to ten feet high, intense cold and forty-mile winds immobilized central and northern New Jersey yesterday in one of the worst storms within memory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The average discount rate on the Treasury's weekly sale of short-term securities was virtually unchanged today for the second successive week.
LOS ANGELES Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The loss today to Italy by the United States Davis Cup team was not too great a shock to two leading tennis authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- If President-elect Kennedy offers his Treasury portfolio to C. Douglas Dillon, as many expect, and Dillon accepts, as it is generally believed he would, very important Republicans here envisage political implications which even in contemplation anger and/or embarrass them.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday the formation of two companies. The move was part of a plan for realigning its corporate structure so as to separate its regulated gas pipeline business from its oil operations and other non-regulated activities.

Figuring about one furlong to the round, Gale Kerwin of Ottawa chased Eddie Jordan of Brooklyn about a mile and a quarter in a ten-round welter-weight bout that ended in a draw at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

PERTH, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A new era in tennis dawned today, with Italy, the surprise conqueror of the United States, headed for Sydney as the first European nation to crash the Davis Cup challenge round in twenty-four years.
The Comedie Francaise, which is scheduled to begin its second visit here Feb. 21, has decided on the plays it will present at the New York City Center.

WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The coming year will be a relatively good one for the automobile industry and the economy as a whole, Ron. W. Todgham, president of the Chrysler Corporation of Canada, Ltd., said in a year-end statement.

The fate of Indochina again hangs in the balance as a result of direct Soviet military intervention in the three-cornered civil war in Laos, the strategic gateway to South Vietnam and Cambodia. Within hours after a turnover of four Governments in four days had put the Leftist in power in the administrative capital of Vientiane, Soviet planes began to fly in arms and ammunition to them, including artillery.

The tears shed by high school basketball coaches would float the city's swimming teams, and none has greater cause to weep this season than Mickey Fisher of Boys High, Roy Rubin of Columbus and Howie Rosenstein of Wingate.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Pakistan Cabinet at a special meeting today formally approved and authorized Pakistan-Soviet talks on the proposed exploration for oil and other mineral wealth in Pakistan by Russian technicians and experts.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Following is the transcript of a joint news conference today by President-elect John F. Kennedy and Dean Rusk, his appointee as Secretary of States:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Cheap nuclear power for running factories and trains and lighting and heating homes is still about ten years away, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency told the General Assembly today.
DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) -- American auto makers apparently are going to build about 6,700,000 passenger cars this year, second only to the 1955 record of 7,900,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The polluted state of this country's streams was called a "national disgrace" today by Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney of the Public Health Service.
DON HUTSON sounded as boyishly enthusiastic as a college freshman who had been swept away by the old school spirit.
A GIFT to the home might well be a gift of art. With collecting so popular, many Yuletide shoppers may find their shopping expeditions lead to museums, art galleries and auctions.

"Nights in the Gardens of Brooklyn," a new collection of short stories by Harvey Swados, will be published Jan. 24 by Little, Brown. The stories, according to reasonably good authorities, are set against their urban setting in moods of sympathy and compassion.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Asian and African delegates led the praise here today over the appointment of Dean Rusk as Secretary of State.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 12 -- The Congolese military government disclosed today that it had made a formal protest to Belgium against the extent to which she had recognized separatism for Katanga Province.
In the deep snow of the Alaskan winter, buses waited to take military personnel to the nearest midnight church services on a Christmas Eve at the U. S. O. in Fair banks.
DON HUTSON sounded as boyishly enthusiastic as a college freshman who had been swept away by the old school spirit.
A GIFT to the home might well be a gift of art. With collecting so popular, many Yuletide shoppers may find their shopping expeditions lead to museums, art galleries and auctions.

"Nights in the Gardens of Brooklyn," a new collection of short stories by Harvey Swados, will be published Jan. 24 by Little, Brown. The stories, according to reasonably good authorities, are set against their urban setting in moods of sympathy and compassion.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Asian and African delegates led the praise here today over the appointment of Dean Rusk as Secretary of State.

A committee of sponsors has been formed for a theatre party to benefit the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students. The party will be held at the Dec. 30 performance of "Camelot," now playing at the Majestic Theatre.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday the appointment of Elliott M. Sanger as general manager of The New York Times International Edition, published in Paris.
The source of most great real estate fortunes -- land -- is being neglected by too many of present day realty investors, according to a national broker.
The worst snowstorm in thirteen years crippled transportation and disrupted the lives of millions yesterday in the metropolitan area.

The middle tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was closed to cars and trucks all day yesterday to accommodate pedestrians. Hundreds of commuters walked the 8,216-foot tunnel after traffic stalled in the storm.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The season's first blizzard disrupted activities at the United Nations today.

"The roughest and most frustrating snowstorm we've had to combat in my twenty-four years in the Sanitation Department" was the grudging tribute paid by Sanitaton Commissioner Paul R. Screvane yesterday to the blizzard that ripped through the city.

More than one hundred members of the Republican County Committee from the Ninth Assembly District overrode telegraphed objections from Senator Jacob K. Javits last night and endorsed him for Mayor in 1961.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court left standing today a lower court ruling that President Eisenhower acted improperly in raising the tariff on imported bicycles five years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The United Nations received an appeal from Ferhat Abbas today to take "urgent measures" to deal with the crisis in Algeria.

DURING the last several months Marya Mannes has contributed four articles to The Reporter magazine on the decay of human values in New York City. She is concerned chiefly with the amenities of living.

The rioting and carnage in Algeria indicate that a decisive showdown is beginning. It is obvious that the present state of affairs cannot continue. Neither Algeria nor metropolitan France can long stand such tension and bloodshed.
HILLSIDE, N.J., Dec. 12 -- "Don't worry about calluses. Just apply the hand lotion."

GREENFIELD, Mass., Dec. 12 -- The Northeastern deer seasons just ended appear to have been generally poor ones from the hunter's standpoint because of weather conditions, though the final result won't be in for a long time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- A Federal court rejected today a petition from three major meat packers to modify a forty-year-old antitrust consent decree so that they could enter certain other food and nonfood fields.
Large numbers of workers at the huge industrial complex the Soviet Union is building near Bratsk in Eastern Siberia are said to be deserting their jobs because of poor living conditions.

DALLAS, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Abner Haynes of Dallas saw limited action yesterday in the Texans' 34 -- 0 victory over the Boston Patriots, but gained enough yards rushing and returning punts to retain the American Football League lead.

The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Jan. 30 performance of "Wildcat," the new musical starring Lucille Ball that is scheduled to open at the Alvin Theatre Thursday.

The snow storm limited trading in fixed-interest securities yesterday. United States Governments were unchanged or slightly mixed. Corporates continued firm on a fair amount of retail demand. Tax-exempts showed modest gains.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The British Government hopes to discuss with the new United States Administration the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

DEAN RUSK is a six-foot, 200-pound, smiling moonfaced man who "takes a good moral stand on issues, always intelligently," as one former State Department associate puts it. He has impressed conservatives and liberals as warm and effective, and also tough -- "tough in the sense of good spring steel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy will become chief administrator of a big operation when she moves into the White House next month.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Rutgers quelled Columbia's rally and then posted a 75-62 victory over the Lions in basketball tonight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- While New Yorkers dug their way out of their blizzard's aftermath today, Muscovites were complaining bitterly about the opposite extreme -- warm winds and springlike rains in mid-December.

The body of a man was found in air upper West Side rooming house yesterday in a room cluttered with animal cages including one containing a python twenty-two and a half feet long. In other cages were three more snakes, a small alligator, six parakeets and two cats.
Ohio State held a commanding lead yesterday in the weekly basketball poll of sports writers and broadcasters conducted by The Associated Press. The poll was the group's first of the season.

Since the Boston Celtics had been stumbling regularly in recent games, they were welcomed to Madison Square Garden last night by the resident New York Knickerbockers, who had stumbled into a four-game losing streak.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- Robert S. McNamara, 44-year-old president of the Ford Motor Company, will be giving up one of the most lucrative positions in the auto industry to become Secretary of Defense.

ANY woman who has grown up in the twentieth century considers as memorable her first lipstick, her first pair of silk (or nylon) stockings and her first black dress. In the current fashion world, two new stepping stones have been added -- scoop necks and shoestring straps.

"THE Play of the Week" continues to go its refreshingly independent and experimental way. Its current attraction, "Rashomon," which began Monday and which will be seen on Channel 13 through next Sunday, is characteristic of the program's distinction, something different for the theatre and certainly something unduplicated on TV.

The Northrop Corporation has arranged to have its radiocontrolled target drone manufactured in Japan under a licensing agreement with the Nippon Electric Company, Thomas V. Jones, president of Northrop, reported at the annual meeting in Hawthorne, Calif., yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Senator Wayne Morse told the General Assembly today that a racist letter circulated among delegates here recently was "an affront to the American people'' as well as to the diplomats.

Dr. Mason W. Gross, the president of Rutgers University, sounded a ringing keynote for the same administration of college athletics the other night as the principal speaker at the Eastern College Athletic Conference's annual dinner.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union vetoed early today a Western resolution that would have given Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold more power to act in the explosive situation in the Congo.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 13 -- King Baudouin and Dona Fabiola de Mora y Aragon received today the best wishes of President Eisenhower and the American people on their forthcoming marriage. Secretary of State Christian A. Herter presented the American felicitations in a private audience at the Brussels Palace.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Britain's defense policy, based on what a Government spokesman said was the "closest consultation " with the United States, won a decisive endorsement in the House of Commons tonight.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 13 - Minister of Commerce T.B. Ilangaratne presented a bill in the House of Representatives (lower house of Parliament) today under which the Government would enter the petroleum business in Ceylon. The bill would establish a state petroleum corporation, which would be empowered to take over any property it needed to run the business.

The scholarly looking man who was chosen as Secretary of Defense yesterday is one of the country's campus rarities -- Phi Beta Kappa and a former professor who rose to the peaks of industrial success.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) up to 11 points (55 cents) off yesterday.
General Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had been awarded a patent for a special synthetic rubber, thus culminating a ten-year struggle over the discovery.
Cocoa futures lead a general price decline in commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday. Market trading, with few exceptions, was light.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Thousands of Britons face the prospect of dull and cheerless Saturday afternoons. Their soccer heroes have called a strike, effective Jan. 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Following is the transcript of a joint news conference held by President-elect John F. Kennedy and Robert S. McNamara today after Mr. McNamara's selection as Secretary of Defense:

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Isaac Foot, a former Member of Parliament, a former Lord Mayor of Plymouth and an author, died in his sleep during the night at his home in Callington, Cornwall. He was 80 years old.

Jim Lee Howell yesterday made what he considered a farewell speech at Yankee Stadium. But if Jack Mara, the president of the New York Giants, has his way, big Jim Lee will be with the organization for many a season.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Of your admirable Dec. 4 editorial concerning Soviet aggression in Hungary it may appropriately be said that if it had not been written it would have been necessary to write it. After reading it I could not help but think of George Santayana's penetrating observation that "those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it."

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Australian bowlers hit back at the West Indies cricket team today, taking nine wickets for 259 runs and raising the prospect of an Aussie victory on the final day of the five-day test match tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A Florida road inspector testified today that anonymous callers had threatened to blind his wife and ruin his reputation just before he was summoned before House highway investigators.

Patrolman John J. Cassese, the policeman with the broken toe, returned to duty yesterday and got a new assignment -- directing traffic at Eleventh Avenue and Eighteenth Street, one of the windiest and busiest corners in Manhattan.

A letter written about five months ago by President-elect John F. Kennedy has buoyed the hopes of coastwise and intercoastal shipping operators that the incoming Administration will help them regain their former stature in the nation's transportation picture.
DENVER, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A European economic leader assured American farmers today that Western Europe's expanding agriculture would not destroy their billion-dollar-a-year export market there.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Paul Arizin's 'twenty-five-foot jump shot with six seconds to play gave a 110-108 victory to 'the Philadelphia Warriors over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

"PEOPLE have complained about society not being what it used to be for 350 years," says Cleveland Amory, who has been writing about society, off and on, for thirteen years. His first and most amusing study of the folkways and tribal customs of American society was confined, as anthropological reports usually are, to a small speciman group, "The Proper Bostonians."
TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- Thousands of workers, including employes of United States military bases, marched through Japanese cities today in the annual winter drive for higher wages and bonuses.
The city's municipal college system -- proposed for university status yesterday -- spreads over all five boroughs and has more than 90,000 students.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -- Swedish interests tried today to prevent a British concern from getting the monopoly for the supply of Diesel trucks to Israel.

Los Angeles County, Calif., sold $7,000,000 of hospital bonds, due from 1962 to 1980, at competitive bidding yesterday to a group headed jointly by the Bankers Trust Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Central and northern New Jersey were slowly emerging yesterday from the effects of one of the heaviest early-season snowstorms on record, but conditions remained difficult.
"International Zone," a half-hour series about the United Nations, will start in New York at 1 P.M. Sunday over WNBC-TV.
FASHION in New York seems to be gone with the wind when a winter storm blows in.
Eight inspectors of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were suspended yesterday by Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of the department.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 -- Developments in the New Orleans school integration struggle today gave some hope for a peaceful resolution of some of this city's problems.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The problems that will face Robert S. McNamara when he becomes Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy Administration will be numerous and varied.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The new Washington and Los Angeles baseball clubs will dip into the bottom of the American League barrel for players tomorrow. They hope to come up with "respectable" teams from a collection made up chiefly of unproven youngsters and old-timers past their prime.
THERE are few cases in bridge in which it is mathematically proper to finesse for a jack, but there are many cases in which collateral circumstances make such a finesse, almost obligatory.

The reorganization of the municipal colleges into a city university was urged yesterday by the Board of Higher Education. The proposed set-up would give the city the largest university under single auspices in the country. The seven colleges now under the board's jurisdiction had a total enrollment this fall of 91,460 students, including 38,124 undergraduates and 7,583 graduate students.
Confident bidding dominated the bond market yesterday, pushing up values of prime debt securities all along the line.

Nicolas Darvas, author of "How I Made $2 Million in the Stock Market," and the book's publisher. The American Research Council Inc., moved in Supreme Court yesterday to vacate a court order obtained by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
Record cold, high winds and drifting snow kept transportation tied up yesterday and thwarted the city's efforts to shake off the seventeen-inch blanket of snow left by its worst pre-winter blizzard.
WHEN Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, set up the important Committee to Look to the Future a year and a half ago, he named as its head Mrs. Mary Shotwell Ingraham.

Sidney J. Ungar was sent to jail yesterday for ten days for criminal contempt of court. General Sessions Judge Joseph A. Sarafite sentenced him for his behavior as a witness in the trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

Jeannette Glass Co. The directors of the Jeannette Glass Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share on the $7 preferred stock. This dividend and a $28-a-share dividend declared in September will clear the arrearages on the stock and restore voting rights to common stockholders for the first time since 1949.
MONTREAL, Dec. 13 -- This city's new $30,000,000 air terminal in suburban Dorval, will be opened formally Thursday by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The sudden departure of three members of Uncle Sam's defeated Davis Cup team brought new tensions today to the fragile tennis relations between the United States and Australia.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Steady profit taking exerted a weakening pressure on the grain futures market today and prices were lower all along the line.

With Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's offer to exchange its common stock for that of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad scheduled to expire at midnight tonight, Walter J. Tuohy, president of the C. O., expressed full confidence that his company's offer would win.
Per Jacobsson, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, suggested yesterday that this country take two steps simultaneously in its efforts to strengthen confidence in the dollar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Eisenhower expressed the view today that a "couple of phone calls" had put the Negro vote in the Democratic column in the Presidential election. This came about, he indicated, despite his eight-year effort to protect Negro voting rights and to promote racial integration in public schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Western diplomats said today that they were puzzled and worried by the expected to cut the United States' troop strength in Europe.

The constitutionality of the Condon-Wadlin Law of 1947 forbidding and penalizing strikes by governmental employes in New York has been sustained by the State Supreme Court in perhaps the broadest of the few judicial tests yet made. Justice Jacob Markowitz could have avoided decision on at least some of the rather iffy, hypothetical questions put by the Secondary School Teachers Association of New York.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY Continued debate on colonialism. First (Political) Committee -- Continued debate on the question of Algeria. Special Political Committee -- Continued discussion of item on support of new nations' efforts to strengthen their independence.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Negley Farson, newspaper man, author and adventurer, died last night while sitting in an armchair in his home near Georgeham, North Devon. He was 70 years old.

The plight of the men, women and children who make up the New York Times Neediest Cases brought generous offers of help from readers yesterday. New Yorkers were predominant among the contributors, but responses came also in letters from New England to Virginia.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz denounced an assistant district attorney and a defense counsel yesterday for statements in a case that resulted in Judge Leibowitz's being reprimanded and overruled.
This week's snowstorm is hitting New-York's financially ailing railroads where it hurts -- in the pocketbook.

Robert Strange McNamara, selected yesterday by President-elect Kennedy as his Secretary of Defense, is a name almost unknown to most Americans. It would have been even more completely unknown had he not -- only a month ago -- been appointed president of one of the country's largest corporations, the Ford Motor Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Dean Rusk, newly designated Secretary of State, visited the State Department today, but provided no hints on how he planned to run it.

AVON PARK, Fla., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Teams led by Dow Finsterwald and Ernie Vossler grabbed the lead with 2-under-par 70's today in the 36-hole $15,000 mixed Scotch foursome golf tournament for men and women professionals.

The Amerace Corporation is holding negotiations to acquire the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America. Victor T. Norton, president of Amerace and William F. McGuinness, president of Elastic Stop Nut, said in a joint announcement yesterday that the proposed transaction was subject to approval of their boards and stockholders.

NEITHER snow nor cold stayed the Philadelphia Orchestra and its audience from their appointed rounds in Carnegie Hall last night. Hardly a vacant seat was noticed as Eugene Ormandy started the downbeat for Mozart's "Paris Symphony," a wonderful work that is not heard too often.

WASHINGTON, Dec 13 -- The Atomic Energy Commission issued today a statement assessing the status and prospects of the gas centrifuge technology -- its first public discussion of the once secret work started in World War II and resumed in 1953.

Two American novelists, both of whom are widely known for their historical-biographical works, will have books published next spring about artistic geniuses. In April "The Agony and the Ecstasy," by Irvirig Stone, will present a fictionalized account of the life of Michelangelo.
The championships in racing and rallying of the Sports Car Club of America have been resolved, after a year of the keenest competition in the organization's history.
New York will face a crisis of economic leadership if it fails to prepare adequate jobs for its booming young work force in the Sixties, speakers at a conference warned here yesterday.
Floyd Patterson, who became the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight championship, yesterday was named the winner of the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque as "fighter of the year" for 1960.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The old cities of Europe are very beautiful in the pre-Christmas glow. From the Grand Via in Madrid to the Corso in Rome, the Kurfuerstendamm in Berlin and Upper Regent Street in London there is a glitter and opulence unrivaled since before the war.

TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- The selection of Dean Rusk as Secretary of State and of Chester Bowles as Under Secretary appeared likely today to please both, the conservative Government and the Socialist Opposition in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Robert S. McNamara, a registered Republican with independ- ent voting habits, was chosen today as Secretary of Defense in the Democratic Administration of President-elect John F. Kennedy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Plans for a merger into the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago of the City National Bank and Trust Company were announced today. The combination would create this city's largest bank from the standpoint of deposits.

TWENTY-SIX Christmas trees located throughout the city will be lighted today at 5 P.M. Tree-lighting ceremonies will be held at City Hall, Manhattan; Cadman Plaza, Brooklyn; Joyce Kilmer Park, Bronx; Queens Borough Hall and Richmond Borough Hall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The failure of your Dec. 6 editorial on the Port Authority hearings to find cause for concern in the disclosed record of the malfeasance and nonfeasance of the authority involves a moral judgment which I cannot share.
George Arents, industrialist, inventor and philanthropist, died yesterday in his home at 6 East Seventy-seventh Street. He was 85 years old.

The Greater New York Safety Council voted yesterday to enlarge both its services and the territory it serves. It also voted to finance the expansion by increasing its budget from $100,000 now to $500,000 in 1962.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- President de Gaulle returned tonight from riot-torn Algeria and expressed his determination to push ahead with his policy to give the North African province autonomy and then self-determination.
WARSAW, Dec. 13 -- Optimism faded today in circles close to the Government that President-elect John F. Kennedy would modify United States policy along the lines recommended by Premier Khrushchev.

Dr. James R. Killian Jr. warned last night that the United States would soon commit itself to several billion dollars a year in additional spending unless the present man-in-space and big rocket booster programs were restrained.

Columbia Pictures, impressed by the critical and box-office reception of Roberta Rossellini's powerful war drama, "General Della Rovere," has agreed to finance three co-productions next year with the Italian film's young producer, Morris Ergas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A panel of safety experts advocated today that all the states set up traffic court systems using full-time salaried judges.
ALGIERS, Dec. 13 -- French forces fired on European demonstrators this afternoon in Bone in eastern Algeria, killing two of them and wounding at least fifteen, according to an official announcement.

It may come as a disappointing surprise to stock brokers on this side of the border to learn that only 35 per cent of United States families with income above $10,000 a year own stocks, compared with 51 per cent of Canadian families in the same income bracket.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The recovery of industrial share prices continued on the stock market here today.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk received the annual citation of the Salvation Army Association of New York yesterday for "his recognition of the needs of crippled, disabled and handicapped."

A Federal Court judge was told here yesterday that his decision in the case of twelve Negro children who want to transfer from a predominantly Negro elementary school in New Rochelle might set a pattern for similar cases in the South.

SCHOOLS Public schools in the city will open at 10 A.M. But no school buses will be running, and pupils who usually ride them may stay home. Roman Catholic grade schools also will open at 10 A.M., but each Roman Catholic high school will set its town schedule.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Health Commissioner from 1936 to 1947, died today in a hospital here after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A giant rocket stands ready for another attempt tomorrow to launch the first lunar satellite.

CHARLIE DRESSEN, baseball's greatest manager by his own admission, was still unable to win the world series for the Brooklyn Dodgers. So Walter O'Malley, the president of the ball club, yanked the rug from under him with such cleverness that Charlie was standing unsupported in mid-air before he was even aware of it.

COLRAIN, Mass., Dec. 13 -- There must be some reason besides venison to make people go deer hunting, but it is difficult to isolate. The suspicion is bound to grow that the strong, hardy American outdoorsman just likes to feel strong and hardy.

In the Congo, the first aim of the Soviets and their African and Asian followers is to restore to power the deposed ex-Premier Lumumba, now under arrest on charges of treason. This is in line with Communist purposes, as expressed in the latest Communist manifesto. But it is strange and potentially suicidal for African and Asian states to back such a move.

The prices of lead and zinc were reduced yesterday, reflecting the continued softness in demand for these and other key metals. The price of lead was cut by one cent a pound to 11 cents, delivered in New York City. This was the first change for the metal since December, 1959.
ANOTHER television program about the life and times of Sir Winston Churchill was shown on Monday night over WNEW-TV (Channel 5).

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of interference in the Laotian crisis and of using neighboring Thailand as a base for the overthrow of the neutralist Government of Prince Souvanna Phouma.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Dec. 13 -- Israeli, accused by Moscow of bringing militarism to African countries and of economic penetration of those countries on behalf of old colonial powers, made some accusations against the Soviet Union itself today.
The United States Lawn Tennis Association, its revenue from amateur tournaments steadily declining, is reported ready to seek financial assistance from Jack Kramer's touring professionals.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 -- Venezuela has indicated to the United States that she requires $900,000,000 in quickly available long-term loans to overcome the dangerous stagnation of her economy.
SEATTLE, Dec. 13 -- A novel radio hook-up for launching Minuteman intercontinental missiles from under the ground will save about $300,000 a missile, the Air Force disclosed today.
The Broadway-bound show, "Wildcat," was snowbound yesterday, forcing a one-day delay of the premiere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Gov. Luther H. Hodges of North Carolina, President-elect John F. Kennedy's nominee for Secretary of Commerce, said today that he expected to give primary attention to international trade.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The battle of Bedford, bitterly waged for the last year over where a new state Route 22 is to be built, will be carried to Albany tomorrow by advocates of a right-of-way on the west side of town.

Patrons have been announced for the sixth Viennese Opera Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 3. It will benefit the Margit Bokor Memorial Fund for cancer research of Columbia University.

Stocks fell and then snapped back in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The gain in the last half hour, in which the ticker ran behind the action on the floor for a few minutes just before the close, brought prices back to their opening levels.
Riots broke out yesterday at the Bronx Youth House for Girls and thirty girls escaped temporarily.
Because of communication difficulties, the following dispatch was filed jointly by correspondents in Vientiane and was relayed by the United States Information Agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Representative Chet Holifield, incoming chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, proposed today that President-elect John F. Kennedy set a deadline of early next year for a resumption of underground tests of nuclear weapons.
AN uncommonly thoughtful and provocative play, "Borak," arrived last night at the Martinique Theatre.

American marine underwriters are facing the prospect of paying one of the largest hull losses in the history of the market as a result of the loss of the Liberian supertanker Sinclair Petrolore off the coast of Brazil Dec. 6.
How to build a plant and what to put into it were topics discussed at a session of the Industrial Building Exposition and Congress at the Coliseum yesterday.
A hotel executive here has organized a management service for hotels throughout the country.
In what is believed to be one of the largest realty transactions here in recent years, Peter Doelger, Inc., has sold twenty-one parcels of property valued at $20,000,000 for all cash.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Secondary school principals joined today in calling for revision of the terms of a new state law requiring communities to furnish bus service to private and parochial school pupils.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Four baseball players whose average age is only 25 claimed the American League's major pitching honors in 1960.
Following, in translation, is the text of a Soviet note to the United States yesterday on the situation in Laos, as provided in New York by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Still more splendor has, if anything, been added to de Gaulle's splendid character by the brutal Algerian events. Nevertheless, as far as political reality is concerned, his stormy voyage did nothing save shatter illusions.
Many of the food staples, goods and services city residents take for granted still were in short supply yesterday as metropolitan New York slowly dug itself out of its heaviest snow in years.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of hatching a "monstrous scheme" against disarmament talks and against peace by proposing to convert the North Atlantic Treaty Organization into a unified nuclear power.
Can a television commercial prove to be an art form and yet serve its advertising purpose as well? Many knowledgeable people in the business feel that a good commercial can serve both ends.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Union charged today that United States U-2 reconnaissance planes were being sent over Algerian territory to "help carry out the military plans of the French colonialists."

TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- Field Marshal Mohammad Ayub Khan, President of Pakistan, told a national radio and television audience here today that he had found Premier Hayato Ikeda "very sympathetic" to proposals for heavy Japanese capital investment in his country when they met this morning.

Debt securities of a finance company, a utility and a railroad and preferred stock of another utility with an aggregate valuation of $118,255,000 were prepared for offering to the public yesterday and today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 -- Water pressure failed throughout a large area of this city early today after ice had clogged filters at the North Stamford reservoir.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 13 -- Antoine Gizenga, the Communist sympathizer who was Vice Premier under Patrice Lumumba, proclaimed in Stanleyville today that he represented the Congo's lawful government.
LOUISVILLE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The University of Louisville shook off an old jinx tonight, beating Western Kentucky, 86 -- 71, and won its own Blue-grass invitation basketball tournament.

Events today: Gala Performance for the benefit of the Welfare Fund, Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Orchestra of America, Richard Korn, conductor, Modern Jazz Quartet, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Frank Glazer, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; St. Cecilia Club, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Joel Ryce, pianist, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.
Michael H. Prendergast repeated yesterday his determination to remain as Democratic states chairman despite pressure from the incoming Kennedy Administration to replace him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor said today the National Water Pollution Conference must ask the chemical industry to create household detergents that can be destroyed in city, waste treatment plants.

AN extensive, absorbing and frequently humorous collection of works on food and drink goes on display this morning at the Grolter Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street. The admission is free and the exhibition is open to the public at 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday; Sundays it is open 1 to 5 P.M. The show runs until Feb. 12.
Monday's snowstorm taught many new mothers a lesson. With delivery of milk to homes and grocery stores sharply curtailed, many mothers were faced with the problem of lack of milk for their infants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate's boxing investigators heard testimony today from a talkative heavyweight and cleared the decks for questioning tomorrow of Frankie Carbo, the reputed undercover king of the sport.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 13 -- The Louisiana House of Representatives, meeting in special session, passed four bills today in its continuing fight against integrated schools and then adjourned until Thursday when the current thirty-day session ends.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- National Gypsum Company's earning this year will drop to around $24,000,000 or $3.70 a share from $25,500,000 and $4.56 a share in 1959, Melvin H. Baker, chairman, announced today.
Long Island and Westchester and Rockland Counties assaulted the snow with vigor yesterday, but achieved only a part victory.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Ministers of twenty nations of Europe and North America settled today the few outstanding disputes over the charter and functions of the new Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The United States warned Ecuador today against resort to force in her long-standing border dispute with Peru.

Operations of Dresser Industries, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 resulted in net earnings of about $9,000,000, compared with $9,171,000 cleared in the preceding fiscal year, the preliminary statement disclosed yesterday.

A Season for Little Children This is the season that belongs to little children. It is for them, Just as the whole city now is for them. One would think, on scanning advertisements and looking into shop windows, that the season is for grownups.
The American Tobacco Company observed an anniversary yesterday -- its thirty-fifth year with Lawrence C. Gumbinner Advertising Agency, Inc., one of its four agencies.
Many motorists who abandoned their cars on the streets during the blizzcard will find their autos in snow-cleared parking spaces today, thanks to assistance from the National Guard.
Mayor Wagner gave his full support yesterday to the Board of Higher Education's proposal to reorganize the municipal colleges into a city university.

Edward Mishkin, a man described by the District Attorney as "the largest producer and purveyor of pornographic material in the United States," was sentenced yesterday to serve three years in jail and to pay a fine of $12,500.

Prices of shares in most major groups declined in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, with nonferrous metals the only notable exception. At the end of the day, however, Standard Poor's 500-stock index and The New York Times' fifty-stock average were down by negligible amounts.
Two bright-eyed young snow leopards got their first look at snow yesterday at the Bronx Zoo and wanted no part of it, though their habitat is the high Himalayas.
Every country in Latin America will exhibit at the New York World's Pair in 1964, former Gov. Charles Poletti reported yesterday.
The two top executives of Revlon, Inc., are disposing of equity shares that have been valued by underwriters at $10,140,000.

Richard Korn is an inquisitive and courageous conductor who is bringing out for inspection America's musical heirlooms, some of which were relegated to our cultural attic many years ago and are dusty from neglect.
One of the smallest, smokiest, noisiest, coziest and most cheerful of all the small, smoky, noisy, cozy and cheerful cabarets in town is a place called Gbldie's, at 232 East Fifty-third Street.

The six-story building at 185-87 Canal Street, northwest corner of Mott Street, has been purchased for investment by the Saltway Realty Corporation. It contains a jewelry exchange, offices and showrooms. Assessed at $205,000, the property was sold by the Irving R. Raber Company, broker, for Jack Blumenstein and Murray Waynthal.

The bond market continued strong and active yesterday. United States Government interest - bearing obligations gained from 2/32 to 12/32, and the discount bills were similarly in good demand, with rates of discount declining from three one-hundredths to four one-hundredths of 1 percentage point on representative issues of both the 01-day and long-dated one-year series.

BRIDGE players who represent their countries on international teams and who play for the world championship are temporary celebrities, win or lose; but the glory is ephemeral. There is no more forgotten man in bridge than the player who once was an international star but no longer is.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 14 -- An Air Force B-52G jet bomber completed a record 10,000-mile nonstop flight today without refueling.

HAVANA, Dec. 14 -- At least twelve leaders of Cuba's Electrical Workers Union were reported tonight to have taken refuge in Latin-American embassies here as Premier Fidel Castro's Government crushed their attempt to resist Communist control.

The dachshund was developed for combat underground and every part of him was designed through breeding for that purpose. That's what Laurence Alden Horswell of East Elmhurst, Queens, told the Washington Dachshund Club last month.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders agreed today to press in 1961 for renewed rent control and more liberal election laws.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Diplomatic sources in London reported tonight that they had received word from Addis Ababa of a broadcast by Crown Prince Aswa-Wossen announcing that there was now a new Government, of which he was a member.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union denounced France tonight for "criminal acts toeing committed against the people of Algeria" and said that the head of the Algerian rebel Government had asked Premier Khrushchev to do "everything possible" to end the "genocide."
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Britain's trade deficit, the excess of imports over exports and re-exports, was considerably smaller last month than in October.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- J.D. Marquette's Harvest Moon, turning in a spectacular stretch run for the second straight time, today won the Florida Endurance Handicap at Tropical Park before 7,663 fans.
Prices for commodity futures on the New York exchanges declined yesterday on a broad front for the second day, Trading was generally light and featureless.

YESTERDAY'S coup against Emperor Haile Selassie by Crown Prince Asfa - Wossen marked the second time the ruler had been involved in an attempted ouster. The first succeeded temporarily, but Haile Selassie's power had been unchallenged since 1941.
Mayor Wagner called upon the Legislature yesterday to close "glaring loopholes" in the rent control law. He said they had permitted "rent spirals" based on speculative real estate sales.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Australia and the West Indies battled to a tie today in the tightest finish in the history of international cricket.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The nation's public elementary and secondary schools will spend $16,476,135,000 this school year -- more than $91 for every man, woman and child in the United States.

MIDDLEBURY, Conn., Dec. 14 -- A fire hero today destroyed a $100,000 home and killed its owners, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon B. Hurlbut. Mr. Hurlbut, 62 years old, was a former president of the Plume Atwood Company, manufacturers of cosmetics containers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Emperor Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia was overthrown today by Crown Prince Asfa-Wossen, his son.

SEBRING, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Jim Turnesa of Rye, N.Y., and Gloria Armstrong of Oakland, Calif., shot a ten-under-par 62 in the final round of the Scotch foursomes golf today to tie for first place and won the tournament on the first extra hole.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming advised today against taking the control of water pollution out of the hands of the Public Health Service.
The Wagner administration is planning a crackdown on contractors and other business men who bribe city inspectors.
BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox won the 1960 American League fielding championship -- their fourth in five years -- according to the official statistics released today.
THE hardest thing for a professional to do is to follow one spectacular success with another. Norman Norell has done it.
Hoerner Boxes, Inc., reported a dip in net profits in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 despite a rise in sales from the year before.

Seventeen of the Metropolitan Opera's biggest stars contributed their services last night for a fund founded ten years ago to give members of the company emergency aid in case of accident, illness and death.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Lawrence R. O'Brien's Trojan Jewel won the Templeton Purse today when Pimlico Race Course resumed its program after two days of idleness because of heavy snow.
Spanish melons on Pier C. Hoboken, got the Florida treatment yesterday and Tuesday with "imported smudgepots" to keep the fruit from freezing.
The lighting of a huge Christmas tree on the snowy front lawn of City Hall yesterday officially brought the holiday season to New York City.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Failure to deal with highway transportation as a total system is seriously hampering accident prevention, a Harvard psychologist said today.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 14 -- Bill Madden led Yale to an 82-57 victory over Wesleyan tonight. Madden scored 22 points. Yale led from the start and was ahead, 47 -- 32, at half time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Justice Department moved today to stop economic reprisals against Negroes who had registered to vote in Fayettc County Tenn.
For nearly six hours yesterlay no beds were made, no drinks poured, no meals served and no tips collected at the Biltmore Hotel.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- Brussels and adjacent Laeken were aglitter tonight on the eve of the wedding tomorrow of King Baudouin and Dona Fabiola de Mora y Aragon.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 14 -- A Constituent Assembly will hold its first session in Ankara in January. The National Unity Committee published today a law providing for creation of the Assembly in twenty-one days.

THE head Angel for the new Los Angeles Angels of the American League is Bill Rigney. When last seen, Rig wore no wings and was not endowed with supernatural powers. But in his most recently acquired role as manager or Archangel, he will need all the heavenly help he can get in order to induce his not-too-angelic ball club to flutter even a little bit.
The Copacabana's cabaret license was suspended yesterday for four days for violating police regulations. The suspension will start next Tuesday.

THIS recent unpleasantness that dislocated transportation and tempers also has interrupted the night - time activities of The Last of the Froat Fishermen. But not for long: Frost fishermen are not comfort-lovers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The General Assembly called today for "immediate steps" toward complete independence for trust and non-self-governing territories.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Britain upheld the Algerian policy of President de Gaulle today as "consistent and courageous" and cautioned the United Nations against interference.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 14 -- A New York builder turned Santa Clans today when he announced he would distribute $124,674 in tax rebates to 1,200 service men around the world.

Major topics of discussion among oil men these days are imports and the dumping of oil by the Soviet Union. Yesterday Augustus Long, chairman of Texaco, Inc., discussed these and other problems before the New York Society of Security Analysts.

The nation's steel production for the first eleven months of 1960 totaled 93,436,820 tons, against 81,456,813 in the 1959 period, when strikes halted production for 116 days, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
Ethiopia is one of the oldest independent states in the world. Her monarchs claim descent from the Queen of Sheba and King Solomon of Biblical fame.
Jobs have been found for 1,100 New York City teen-agers by a special state agency designed to fight youth unemployment.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 14 -- Latin-American diplomatic and intelligence sources report that Cuba and Ecuador have been developing closer ties in the wake of Ecuador's denunciation of the frontier treaty with Peru.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The following conditions were reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

The Wall Street Club, a financial district luncheon group, has leased the fifty-ninth floor in the new Chase Manhattan Building, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza. It will move about May 1, 1962, from its present quarters at 40 Wall Street.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Stock market prices again advanced here today, with demand centered on leading industrial shares.

ONE of the most appetizing of seasonal foods is currently available on the New York scene. These are the chestnuts, which may be found not only hot roasted on the push-carts of street venders, but also fresh in the shell in grocery stores.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Arlen Bockhorn contributed 35 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals scored a 121-114 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter arrived today to represent the Eisenhower Administration at the close of its eight years of major consultations with the Western Allies.

VIENTIANE, Dec. 14 -- Pro-Communist forces commanded by Capt. Kong Le captured the center of this Laotian capital after confused and scattered firing Tuesday night, according to a dispatch filed jointly by correspondents here.

Labor will press for temporary forgiveness of Federal withholding taxes as an antirecession measure. The tax-suspension plan is part of an emergency program put forward by union leaders to combat unemployment by pumping more purchasing power into the economy.

The problem with many economic indicators is that people disagree over what they indicate. The steel industry's weekly operating rate is a case in point. To many economists and investors, the present 48.7 per cent rate means that more than half of the industry's productive facilities are lying idle. Not so, steel executives say.
BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- In a setting without parallel in baseball history, two major league ball-cirbs came into their full existence today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Dec. 4 letter of G. Radow which deplores the banning from hospital practice of some 2,000 foreign-trained medical internes and residents reflects a complete naivete concerning the issues involved.

Chessie got a good clawhold on the old and venerable Baltimore and Ohio Railroad yesterday. Chessie, of course, is the famed sleeping pussy-cat used as the corporate symbol by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Army opened its home basketball season today with a 62-to-52 victory over Baltimore University.
The State of Michigan borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market for the Detroit Express way yesterday at an interest cost of 3.6932 per cent.

The fifth in Maurice Druon's series of historical novels about medieval France, called "The Accursed Kings," will be published next month by Scribner. The new volume, "The She-Wolf of France," tells the story of Isabella, daughter of Philip IV, "The Iron King," and sister of Charles IV, who married Edward II of England.

THE mother who takes her child from art lessons to music lessons to ballet lessons in a hectic swirl of weekly activities is not necessarily caught up in a "rat race," according to Mrs. Lydia Sandier, membership secretary of the United Parents Association.

New York City put 10,000 men and 3,000 pieces of heavy snow removal equipment yesterday into the job of clearing its 6,045 miles of streets. The work was aided by a bright sun and milder weather, although the high temperature for the day, 27.1 degrees at 3 P.M., was still short of a thaw.

Twenty-five public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $97,615,000 on serial bonds yesterday for the permanent financing of low-rent projects. The bonds bear interest rates ranging from 3 3/8 to 3 5/8 per cent.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich heard arguments yesterday in a suit brought by the Board of Higher Education challenging the right of the State Commission Against Discrimination to investigate personnel practices at city colleges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Fewer families were planning to buy automobiles and major household appliances in October than a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A device that promises to make possible the production of amplified and coherent light in continuous beams was described here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Hubie White, with 33 points, paced Villanova to a 92-54 victory over Fordham in the second half of a basketball double-header at the Palestra tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks peppered Gump Worsley for three second-period goals tonight and beat the New York Rangers, 4-0, in a National Hockey League game. The victory broke a four-game losing streak.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company urged today that prolonged administrative proceedings not be permitted to delay the development of communications satellites.

Long Island University sent City College to its thirteenth consecutive basketball loss last night. The Blackbirds won a Tri-State League game at the Beavers' Wingate Gymnasium, 73-59, despite a 30-point performance by Tor Nilsen of C.C.N.Y.

WHILE the snow fell on Monday morning, paralyzing the city, an intrepid little boy climbed into Santa Claus' lap and piped, "I want a Fighting Lady battleship by Remco." This youngster was one of four who defied the weather to confide their Yuletide requests to the man in the recsuit in his office at Gimbels Valley Stream, L.I., store.

Inventories of light fuel oil, used mostly in heatiing homes dropped 5,604,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, reflecting the drop in temperature throughout most of the country. At the week-end supplies, however, were 6,551,000 barrels more than a year ago at 167,038,001 barrels.
DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- Speakers at a public hearing today before the United States Commission on Civil Rights called for stronger and more positive leadership at the national level.

The obligation of a Government to its citizens -- and particularly to the men in uniform who obey its commands -- is at issue in the case of two Americans who have been jailed for the last five months in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- President de Gaulle may put out new peace feelers to the Algerian rebel organization if France and Algeria give him big majorities in a referendum on his policy for Algerian autonomy and self-determination.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The rich, industrialized nations of the North Atlantic world launched themselves today on a new experiment, to the accompaniment of such words as "historic" and "major advance."
YESTERDAY (Dec. 14, 1960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Approved forty-three-nation motion for immediate steps to end colonialism.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The State Public Works Superintendent hoard three hours of arguments over a new Westchcster location for Route 22 today, but remained noncommittal.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's statement to the Security Council at a session that ended early today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Declining business activity and narrowing profit margins reduced corporation earnings to a rate of $42,200,000,000 a year in the third quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Three of the nation's major electrical equipment manufacturers said yesterday that they would investigate voluntarily whether recent violations of antitrust laws by some of their employes had caused financial damages to buyers of their equipment.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- The Blue Shield medical-surgical plan of New Jersey applied today to the state Department of Banking and Insurance for an increase averaging 80 cents a month in its basic contract rates.

With the Soviets launching intensified cold-war offensives on all fronts, the North Atlantic Council of Ministers meets in Paris tomorrow to cope with the dangers ahead. It is the last such meeting for the Eisenhower Administration, which can claim credit for having kept the North Atlantic alliance intact and the Soviets in check without war.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- Two items in the official party press today indicated serious trouble in Soviet agriculture and the possibility that a major shakeup in the organization and operation of the nation's farm system was in the offing.

I Now the year's ending, what have books to offer Posterity and this month's cheerful giving? Why everything: great art (undraped but proper), World politics and tales of violent living; Lyrics and epic's from the poets' coffer, High-thinking novels, primers to skin diving And mass-produced tirades against mass media, Whose tones, I fear, grow wearier and seedier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The cabinet-making deliberation of President-elect John F. Kennedy continued today, with two or more appointments promised for announcement tomorrow.
Bronx Youth House for Girls was settling down yesterday to an uneasy and uncomfortable peace following two days of fire and rioting.

"New Frontier" legislation may be delayed because of pre-occupation by the incoming Federal Administration and Congress with the business recession, the nation's gold loss and foreign affairs, Eugene M. Thore, vice president and general counsel of the Life Insurance Association of America, said yesterday.

ALGIERS, Dec. 14 -- The calm that seemed to have returned to Algeria was marred this afternoon by an incident in Bone in which at least two Moslems were killed and several wounded. The only other agitation involved Moslems in Algiers' ancient Casbah, or Arab quarter, who staged sporadic nationalist demonstration from late last night until this evening.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The United States and West Germany resumed financial talks today, with the trickiest issue involving the "public relations" aspect of a proposal for a large advance debt repayment by the Germans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- At the climax of the election campaign the Justice Department prepared a statement for President Eisenhower to issue on the jailing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
The Census Bureau will not revise its final population count for New York City. The total of 7,781,984 was 109,973 below the city's population in 1950, a loss of 1.39 per cent.
The Martin Company increased its common share holdings in the Nuclear Corporation of America, it was disclosed yesterday by the American Stock Exchange in its latest, report on trading by insiders.
One of the advantages of maintaining a permanent acting company can best be illustrated by the Phoenix Theatre's decision to bring back Oliver Goldsmith's "She Stoops to Conquer."
One of the last of the major independent engineers' unions voted yesterday to affiliate with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 14 -- About fifty men.are missing following a collision between two large tankers early today in the Bosporus. Both ships caught fire on impact and one later drifted across the strait and set fire to a third ship.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Space scientists hope to try again tomorrow to launch an instrument-packed spacecraft toward an intended orbit around the moon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Elwood R. Quesada, head of the Federal Aviation Agency, said today he was trying to revoke the license of an airline captain who turned his plane over to an unqualified pilot.

A drug believed to be the first available to alter rapidly the acidity or alkalinity of cells in the human body has been the subject of a three-day conference sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences.
Thirty-nine persons who lost $1.88 worth of coins on the side walks of New York this year have unwittingly contributed to the Neediest Cases.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower will submit a precariously balanced budget to Congress next month with spending and revenues estimated at close to $82,000,000,000, according to reliable sources.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 14 -- Outside aid is beginning to flow to the forces in Stanleyville supporting Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier, according to information reaching here today.
ATLANTA, Dec. 14 -- Mayor William B. Hartsfield today told the story of the phone calls that might have had a decisive influence in President-elect Kennedy's victory.
The Princeton freshmen took advantage of the game's only penalty and beat St. Paul's School, 3 -- 1, in their Christmas vacation hockey game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Senator Clifford P. Case called today for a fight on the opening day of the new Congress to restrict the Senate's right of unlimited debate.

Today being the 169th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights, it is a particularly appropriate time to note with relief that the year's jail sentence of Dr. Willard Uphaus has now terminated, and that he was released a few days ago from the New Hampshire prison where he had been incarcerated for contempt.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The University of Georgia struck back today at charges that its officials had mapped a path to its doors for white transfer students while barring admission to Negro applicants.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d will temporarily add the job of president to that of chairman of the Ford Motor Company, filling the spot to be left vacant by Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense designate in the Kennedy Cabinet.

SINCE drama critics are reputed to be a low breed, without friends or gratitude, the opportunity should be seized to hail "Critic's Choice." But once a critic, always an ingrate. Ira Levin's new comedy, which opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore, is not much of a play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. has directed the military services to review their requirements abroad with a view to closing some installations, terminating the lease of others and canceling plans for new construction.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Albany County was depicted today as an improbable sort of fiscal paradise where a man could safely realize a tidy profit by not paying his taxes.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your news and editorial columns of Dec. 9 are eloquent refutations of B. Leo Schwarz' letter of Dec. 8 hailing De Sapio's leadership of the Democratic party.
Dean Rusk said yesterday that Adlai E. Stevenson would "play a key role in the formulation of foreign policy."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Britain, Switzerland and the Netherlands took almost three quarters of the $631,600,000 of gold that flowed out of the United States last summer, the Treasury reported today.

The relocation of more than 10,000 households facing displacement by the $100,000,000 West Side Urban Renewal Project is to begin next spring under procedures designed to guarantee tenants first call on the dwelling units to be built.
Spring flowers donated and arranged by leading florists will adorn the Seventh Regiment Armory for the seventh annual winter antiques show, opening Jan. 19 for six days.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Dr. Edward Teller called today for a "thorough, effective study" of the cost of placing future nuclear power reactors underground.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Discovery of life on other worlds could cause the earth's civilization to collapse a Federal report said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Senator Estes Kefauver proposed today a temporary Federal boxing commission to eliminate racketeers from the sport.
A score of the pilots on strike against Southern Airways since June 5 have set up their own airline and plan to start scheduled passenger service today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 14 -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro said today that agreement had been reached in principle to pay $6,000,000 in settlement for the nationalization of the mining properties of the former tin baron, Antenor Patino.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a program under which supplementary payments of $17,200,000 will be made to 28,000 city pensioners in the next eighteen months.
EVANSTON, 111., Dec. 14 (AP)-One-year fellowships for study abroad have been awarded to seven New York State college students by Rotary International, it was announced tonight.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 14 -- The five-member state electoral board unanimously certified today John F. Kennedy's hair-line victory in Illinois, where twenty-seven electoral votes were at stake.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points off to 5 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The city was asked yesterday to give $2,345,277 to help solve some medical puzzles. The City Health Research Council, in urging the grants, proposed them for studies to determine among other things, if the illness a person suffers is related to his race and income.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The General Assembly will begin an urgent meeting on the Congo Friday at the request of India and Yugoslavia.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Precision-approach radar equipment was a lifesaver the first day it was commissioned at Weir Cook Airport here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices rallied strongly today from early weakness on the Board of Trade and finished with moderate to good gains on a late flurry of short covering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The rollcalls in the Eighty-sixth Congress on legislation which split the parties and which President Eisenhower opposed supply ample evidence that one of President-elect Kennedy's prime necessities is to unite the large Democratic majority on his programs, also attracting as many "liberal" Republicans as he can.
