Leaders of opposing faction in the New Orleans school integration crisis will appear on "Open End" at 10 P.M. Sunday over Channel 13.

Prince and Princess Tomislav of Yugoslavia were guests of honor last night at the annual Imperial Ball held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
New York has become a symbol of freedom, justice and compassion because of its tradition of voluntary philanthropy in caring for the sick and needy, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Evidence that Albany residents of substantial means were permitted to settle delinquent real estate taxes for far less than their legal obligation was presented today to the State Investigation Commission.

The Ford Motor Company's bid to obtain 100 per cent ownership of its British subsidiary showed up as part of a $204,000,000 drain on the United States monetary gold stock in the week ended on Wednesday. At $17,973,000,000, the gold stock was down $1,483,000,000 from the first of the year.

Chiefly to meet quarterly Federal tax payments due yesterday, businesses increased their borrowings from the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York by $148,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.
New Yorkers faced the prospect of renewed cold weather today, following a brief thaw yesterday that helped in the continuing clean-up of last week-end's seventeen-inch snowfall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to make what I think is a worthy observation regarding the dramatic architectural change that has been taking place before our eyes along Park Avenue between Forty-sixth and Fifty-ninth Streets these last few years.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $70,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose 115,000,000 to $716,000,000.

The Brown Shoe Company in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 had the highest sales in its eighty-two-year history and the second largest earnings, the annual report of Clark R. Gamble, president, disclosed yesterday.

The Princeton University Triangle Club's sixty-ninth annual production, "A Midsummer Night Scream," was given last night at the Hunter College Playhouse. It was the first of two performances starting the troupe's tour.

Stockholders of the CrowellCollier Publishing Company and the Macmillan Company approved a merger of the companies at special meetings here yesterday. Crowell-Collier now holds 174,466 shares Or 52.8 per cent of the 330,553 shares of Macmillan stock outstanding.
While the rest of the New York Giants were frolicking in sneakers on the frozen turf at Yankee Stadium yesterday, Ray Wietecha rested at home in bed, under doctor's orders.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 15 -- In a spectacle that flashed brightly on a dark, freezing day, King Baudouin of the Belgians married Dona Fabiola de Mora y Aragon of Spain today. They were married twice, first in a civil ceremony required by law and then in the Roman Catholic ritual.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The so-called Food-for-Peace program assigned today to Representative George McGovern has never attained the noble grandeur suggested by its name.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- While a small army of workers was shoveling snow out of the towering stands of Philadelphia Stadium, Oregon's football squad worked out long and Hard on a fast, dry field today for its Liberty Bowl game against Penn State on Saturday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Following is the text of the resolution on Algeria approved tonight by the General Assembly's Political, Committee:

It being generally agreed the Yankees were hit harder than any of their seven American League rivals in the Best draft that stocked the new Washington and Los Angeles clubs with players last Wednesday, the Bombers yesterday set themselves to the task of mending their battered fences.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's speech on city affairs over WCBS-TV last night as recorded by The New York Times:
C. Itoh Co. (America), Inc., Japanese importers and exporters, have leased a floor in the new I.T. T. Building at 320 Park Avenue, corner of Fiftieth Street, from the Chemical Construction Company.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15 -- Harvard's hockey team won from Northeastern, 5 -- 3, at the Crimson's rink last night.
CAIRO, Dec. 15 -- According to reports reaching here by diplomatic channels today, Ethiopian Crown Prince Asfa-Wossen yielded to an ultimatum to save the throne.

J. Harvey Rosenthal, realty Investor and builder, has bought two four-story store and apartment buildings at 1449-51 Third Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-second Street. One of the buildings is vacant. The property, which is 42 by 70 feet, will be altered into modern apartments.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Representative Chester Bowles told a conference on international development today that foreign aid was not a panacea for all the ills afflicting under-developed nations.
A Staten Island ferryboat crashed into a slip at the St. George Pier yesterday, injuring at least twenty persons, hospitalizing five of them.

DURING the last few years one book by Robert Payne has been reviewed in this space each year. Although no official policy has been established, it seems the least we can do. After all, Mr. Payne always has seveval books published annually and sometimes as many as six. Without question the most prolific of serious modern writers, Mr. Payne has written more than fifty books and he is not yet 50!

THE woman who became Queen of the Belgians yesterday is a complex personality whom no one has yet succeeded in classifying. She is religious and serious. She loves movies and dancing. She has impressed the diplomatic set with her intelligence.
Dr. Willard Uphaus said last night that study and meditation during his imprisonment in New Hampshire had convinced him that world peace was impossible unless civil liberties were preserved.
Industrials declined yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Rails and utilities just about held their own.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Bill Nieder, the Olympic shot-put champion and world record-holder, said today he must retire from the sport because of an injured right knee.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 15 -- The Atlanta Chamber of Commerce refused today to meet with Negro leaders to seek to end sit-ins. Demonstration leaders said they would keep them up through Easter.
Democratic leaders of the Legislature said yesterday that they regarded restoration of former income-tax exemptions as the main issue for the session starting Jan. 4.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures was virtually at a standstill most of the time today, but old-crop wheat futures shifted over a broad range on an early active demand and a late flurry of selling.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court refused today to grant an injunction against pickets who had kept the world's largest ore-ship tied up here since Oct, 21.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, renewed today a call for a Presidential Executive order forbidding discrimination because of race or religion in all Federally financed and insured housing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Final official tabulations of the Presidential election showed today that John F. Kennedy scored a popular-vote plurality of only 112,801 over Vice President Nixon.
DENVER, Dec. 15 -- Mandatory land retirement as a condition for farmers to receive price supports became part of the American Farm Bureau Federation policy today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Folowing are the transcripts of news conferences by Presidentelect John F. Kennedy on the appointment of Arthur J. Goldberg as Secretary of Labor and Gov. Orville L. Freeman as Secretary of Agriculture and the text of a statement by Senator Kennedy on Mr. Goldberg:

Sales of the nation's leading retail chains continued their upward trend in November. A survey yesterday by The New York Times found that last month's volume was 2.8 per cent higher than that of November, 1959.

For thirty years Arthur Joseph Goldberg, an intense, articulate and persuasive labor lawyer, has devoted his talents to finding solutions for the disputes that divide labor and management 'and labor and labor.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Fighting broke out today in Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, following the attempt to overthrow Emperor Haile Selassie I. Reports reaching here indicated that forces loyal to the Emperor were in combat with those trying to unseat him. But the situation was by no means clear.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- A resolution calling on the United Nations to conduct a referendum to decide Algeria's future was approved tonight by the General Assembly's Political Committee.
President-elect John F. Kennedy is expected to set up a permanent White House council of labor-management advisers to foster industrial peace and national economic growth.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Arthur Chambers, a 21-year-old rider from Brooklyn, finished first in six races at Pimlico today, but received credit for only five winners in the record books.
Sidney J. Ungar failed yesterday in two court actions to win release from jail before he completes the ten-day sentence he began serving on Tuesday for contempt of court.
For those who have not yet heard the story, here are the details of the bout between a temperamental French artist and the mighty Chemstrand Corporation.

Dame Edith Evans will make her American television debut by 'starring in Jean Anouilh's "Time Remembered." Other principles in the cast are Janet Munro, also from England, and Christopher Plummer, a Canadian.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy told the British Ambassador to the United States today that he hoped to confer "in the not too distant future" with Prime Minister Macmillan.

THE north wind did blow and we did have snow -- and sharply curtailed food supplies. Early in the week many stores in the metropolitan area were short, or entirely devoid, of such commodities as eggs, milk and bread. However, the situation is improving every day and no one should go hungry this week-end.

Pleasure boatmen learn early in their days afloat to treat gasoline with caution and great respect. A boat never takes on gas at a fuel dock until all hands' on board have doused their cigarettes and cigars and emptied their pipes overside.
VOYAGING through the garden, Peck Peck selected oranges, citrus yellows, lilac and watermelon as the colors for its resort and cruise collection.
GIVEN any kind of decent weather, the whiting fiends will be at it again this week-end at Hangar Dock on Fort Pond Bay at Montauk Point.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 15 -- Coach Bill van Breda Kolff cleared his bench as Hofstra's Flying Dutchmen romped to an 89 -- 53 basketball triumph over the West Chester Teachers in Calkins Gymnasium today.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- President de Gaulle and his Government struck back hard today at French and Algerian extremists attempting to wreck the President's program for reform and self-determination in Algeria.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Britain's shipbuilding industry was criticized in a Government report today for not devoting enough effort to research and development
Periodically, the New York Stock Exchange puts a microscope to one day's business on its trading floor -- and pulls it apart with analytical pincers.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Now that President-elect Kennedy has picked his top team for the State Department, he is confronted by his campaign promise of backing them up with a corps of Ambassadors picked solely on merit.
Mayor Wagner denounced as 'pure bunk" last night recent charges that his administration was riddled with corruption and scandal.
Four new films will open in first-run theatres here today.
BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Republic, Dec. 15 -- Heads of state and delegates of fourteen African countries met here today for talks on Algeria and the Congo.

In his forthcoming book, "The Lotus and the Robot," Arthur Koestier concludes that "neither Yoga, Zen, nor any other Asian form of mysticism has significant advice to offer." A rebuttal to that view is given in part in "The World of Zen," an anthology edited by Nancy Wilson Ross, which is published today by Random House.

Michael H. Prendergast will probably have been replaced as Democratic state chairman by the time John F. Kennedy is inaugurated President next month, according to reports among influential Democrats yesterday.
A comprehensive new zoning resolution went onto the city's statute books yesterday by unanimous vote of the Board of Estimate.
A promising new type of fuel cell is being developed into an experimental power plant for classified use by the Navy, a New York concern announced today.
Union photoengravers anounced last night that they were making a formal request o their parent union for permission to call a strike against even daily newspapers in this city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Whenever a steel or rail strike reaches an impasse, the Secretary of Labor gets the thankless task of fact-finding or behind-the-scenes mediator.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States Government said today it would give full support to the new anti-Communist Government in Laos.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 15 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors took the first steps today toward increasing its spending powers and giving new authority to the County Executive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A spokesman said today the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was no longer urging a cut-off of Federal funds to Louisiana for aiding children.

A $500,000 mall fraud conspiracy involving the bribing of postal employes and the duping of large advertising'clients by a direct-mail advertising company was charged by a Federal grand jury yesterday in a 100-count indictment.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. GLACIER in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica, Dec. 12 -- This largest and most powerful of nine American icebreakers is nearing the end of what its skipper called "an extraordinary passage" to the Antarctic Continent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- If any further proof was needed that the reach of American scientists into space still exceeds the grasp of their rockets, it was provided by the explosive failure of the moon shot at Cape Canaveral early this morning.
Most department stores and many specialty shops in the city's major shopping areas announced yesterday that they would stay open late tomorrow night for Christmas shoppers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Foremost Dairies, Inc., the largest nation-wide dairy company, was ordered by the Government today to sell nine companies that it acquired in 1952 and 1953.

Bell Howell Co. A 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend was declared yesterday by the directors of the Bell Howell Company. The dividend, in addition to the 40 cents a share in cash declared during the year, will be paid on Jan. 27 to holders of record of Jan. 6.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 -- Premier Fidel Castro told members of Cuban labor unions today that their duty "as a class" was to win and hold political power, not to pursue "selfish" interests at the expense of other citizens.

Doda Conrad, bass, last night gave the first American performance of Henri Sauguet's "Le Cornette," in the last of three recitals at Carnegie Recital Hall. In each, he has presented a major song cycle.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings and the New York Rangers, stressing cautious defensive play throughout, battled to a 1-1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game.
Prices of domestic bulk sugar futures fell on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday in the second biggest trading session of the year.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 15 The United States Embassy in Vientiane reported to Bangkok by radio at 4 P.M. today, local time, that fighting inside the city had intensified and that many buildings had been set afire.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The advance in industrial share prices was halted in the stock market here today and prices turned dull as buying dried up.

An issue of $7,000,000 of bonds of the Greater Baton Rouge Sewerage District, East Baton Rouge, La., was sold yesterday to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 3.6015 per cent.

IN making the 1960 Art in America annual award to Edward Hopper, this quarterly magazine honors the dean of American realist painting, an artist whose work through many years has succeeded in getting under the skin of American life in a unique way.
Three leading publishers announced here yesterday that they would jointly produce the first new encyclopedia of the social sciences in a quarter of a century.
The precise details of what has been happening in Ethiopia the last few days are still unclear. However, in broad outline the events fit only too well into the general African picture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower's physicians reported today that his "general condition continues excellent."
KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 15 -- King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva dismissed the Government and suspended Parliament today after arresting Premier B. P. Koirala and other officials.

A Reform rabbi who is also a practicing psychologist told a group of social workers here yesterday that the more authoritarian a man is in his religion the more aggressive he is likely to be toward others.
STRATFORD, Conn., Dec. 15 -- Two Sikorsky twin-turbine helicopters, designed for airline use, were demonstrated at the company's plant today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Representative Clifford Davis of Tennessee, the chairman of a special House Elections Committee, said today he would recommend that future Presidential campaigns be limited to a month or six weeks.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 -- A special session of the Louisiana State Legislature at Baton Rouge adopted today a bill setting up a state-appointed school board for New Orleans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- The atmosphere was more off-Broadway than Hollywood in the Little Theatre just off Hollywood Boulevard. Brightly colored flats for the sets were stretched across the tops of seats.

The attempt to cure what Secretary General Hammarskjold has called "the sickness from which the Congo is suffering" was at least temporarily abandoned by the Security Council early Wednesday morning when a Western resolution and a Russian resolution were in turn voted down. Today the General Assembly is expected to have a go at it.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies, in a swap of pitchers today, sent Gene Conley to the Boston Red Sox for Frank Sullivan, resolving a bitter player-manager dispute.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Stratford-on-Avon Company, which performs from April to November in Shakespeare's home town, moved to London tonight to open a new repertory theatre.
PARIS, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Vera Clouzot, actress wife of Henri Georges Clouzot, motionpicture director, was found dead in her hotel room here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Army is planning to permit most of its married military men who are sent abroad to have their families with them much of the time, despite reductions ordered in the number of dependents overseas.

Price rises in gilt-edge bonds generaly came to a halt yesterday as blocks of investmentgrade obligations came in for sale, most of them representing the cashing in of profits generated by the market's recent rally.

St. John's basketball team will seek to extend a streak and New York University will attempt to break one in a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. N.Y.U.'s task is considered a bit more formidable.

ON Monday evening Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society will give their tenth annual performance of Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ" at Town Hall. Last Monday evening, in the bleak aftermath of a blizzard, they saluted Hanukkah with Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Agriculture Department is viewed today in political circles as a dead-end street for a politically ambitious Secretary.
High Cost of Parading There is bad news for booklovers in the year-end statistics. The cost-of-living index is rising and now the cost of being well-read has risen to an all-time high.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Gov. Orville L. Freeman of Minnesota faces one of the most difficult tasks, if not the most important, in the Cabinet of President-elect John F. Kennedy.

ALGIERS, Dec. 15 -- Moslem agitation is continuing in Algeria despite dragnet arrests and stringent house-to-house searches and identity checks throughout the day in the Casbah, the old Moslem quarter of Algiers.
A tradition of giving to New York's Neediest Cases begun by an immigrant who arrived in this country at Christmastime thirty-nine years ago is being continued by his son.

Considerable strengthening of business pension plans to make sure that workers are eventually able to collect on them was urged yesterday by a leading insurance expert. Dr. Dan M. McGill, Professor of Insurance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance, said that the present structure of private pension plans 'does not assure participants of the ultimate enjoyment of the potential benefits."

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 15 -- A union-management agreement calling for new production rates has cleared the way for an investment of $8,000,000 to $10,000,000 by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in modernizing a big tire plant here.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Glenn Felkner's Sarah James, who had failed to triumph in twenty-four previous starts this year, won with a rush in the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today, and returned $120.30 for $2.
THE winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today and will last through Sunday.

Ski conditions in New York State ranged from good to excellent yesterday, according to the operators of the winter resorts. Pennsylvania also offered fine running, but New England generally reported only fair to good conditions throughout the area.
The New Jersey State Senate committee investigating the Port of New York Authority toured authority installations gathering fiscal data yesterday and announced it would resume hearings Jan. 26.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- The retiring president of the Atomic Industrial Forum indulged in some plain speaking to his colleagues in private industry today as he ended two years in office.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he had directed that a study of the city's policy on promoting its employes be started "at once." Acting Personnel Director Theodore H. Lang and Budget Director Abraham D. Beame will make the survey.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 -- In a city not easily given to gaiety or emotionalism, thousands of Belgians muffled to the ears stood on a raw stinging day to watch and cheer one of the most fashionable events. Europe has seen in twenty-five years.

Sponsors have been announced for the Jan. 12 performance of "Wildcat," which will benefit the Bargain Box. The musical starring Lucille Ball is scheduled to open this evening at the Alvin Theatre.
Bob Fosse, the choreographer-director, is attempting to forestall possible changes in the two ballet numbers that he created for the forthcoming Broadway musical, "The Conquering Hero."

With Ohio State leading the way for the sixth time in the last eight years, college football attendance this season passed the 20,000,000 mark for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy named his Secretaries of Labor and Agriculture today.
Karl Boehm, German conductor, left for Vienna last night for an emergency eye operation necessitated by an ailment that developed while he was rehearsing the New York Philharmonic yesterday morning.

Rogers of Colorado, published Dec. 14, in order that your readers be correctly informed. With the appointment of Douglas Dillon as Secretary of the Treasury, President-elect Kennedy has now filled his three top Cabinet positions with outstandingly able men who are technicians and administrators rather than nationally known politicians. Wells Fargo Co. has purchased the operating assets of Coin Auditing Systems, Inc., New York, from the Johnson Farebox Company division of Bowser, Inc., Chicago, it was announced yesterday by Howard L. Clark, president of Wells Fargo.

After two weeks of bitter debate, the United Nations General Assembly has adopted without opposition an African-Asian resolution calling for "immediate steps" toward a "speedy and unconditional end of colonialism in all its forms and manifestations." The resolution denounces the "subjection of peoples to alien subjugation" and urges freedom and independence for all non-self-governing territories on the basis of self-determination.

Cotton futures opened 2 to 16 points up, and closed with gains of 3 to 28 points (15 cents to $1.40 a bale) yesterday. Most contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at their best levels of the day.

Great numbers of policemen, firemen, civil defense teams, Coast Guardsmen, doctors and nurses, Red Cross and Salvation Army personnel, Boy Scouts and volunteers flocked to the two sites of the airplane crashes in Brooklyn and Staten Island yesterday.
Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose about nine-tenths of 1 per cent yesterday in an advance to which all the major groups save airlines and aircrafts made good contributions.
QUAIL hunting in the Deep South, for both native and stocked birds, is going to be just fine all this winter. We have the word of Charley Dickey for it.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Anent migratory labor and the C.B.S. showing "Harvest of Shame," you spoke editorially on Dec. 4 of "the shocking conditions under which the migrants work and live * * * tragic injustices from which the migrants suffer."
The New York football Giants put in fifty minutes of hard work at the Yankee Stadium yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's contest with the Cleveland Browns here.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser, the Wimbledon and American champion, and Rod Laver, the Australian titleholder, were named today to lead the Australian Davis Cup tennis team against Italy in the challenge round that starts a week from Monday.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 -- Gov. Jimmie H. Davis made a surprise appearance in Federal Court this morning at a school integration hearing.

The benefit committee for Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys, Millington, N.J., encouraged by twenty-five successful annual theatre parties, contracted last spring for the first time a whole theatre. It is the Majestic Theatre taken for the Jan. 14 matinee of "Camelot."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Plans for creating "new jobs and new growth" in the eleven-county tri-state Philadelphia metropolitan area were mapped today by business and civic leaders of the area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Industrial production has fallen 5 per cent since midsummer, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today. That is less than it fell in the early months of the last three recessions.
Wall Street took a mixed view yesterday of President-elect John F Kennedy's appointment of Douglas Dillon as his Secretary of the Treasury.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 16 -- There was one thing about today's air disaster in New York that, from a cold technical point of view, appeared to overshadow all else. It was the first time, as far as experts could recall, that planes involved in a midair collision had both been under firm control of "traffic cops" in control stations on the ground.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has made an offer to acquire all of the outstanding stock of the Lehigh Valley Railroad and the bid was approved by Lehigh Valley's directors at a three-hour board meeting yesterday.

ANYONE who relies on window shopping for Christmas present inspiration will miss the host of interesting gifts that are hidden away at Pampered Kitchens on the eighteenth floor of 220 Fifth Avenue. There is something for everyone.
The flags of the United Nations were featured last night in the decor of the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the seventh International Press Ball of the Foreign Press Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- For a society as legal-minded and litigious as this country's, the legal arm of the Federal Government is remarkably small in terms of statistics.

Rocco Milo has purchased the Bellport Shopping Center at Merrick Road and Atlantic Avenue, Bellport, L.I., for cash over a mortgage of $110,000. The sellers were Louis M. Mancuso and the estate of Michael Savino of Deer Park.
Nat (King) Cole will make a second attempt to reach Broad-way in a revue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- An urgent meeting of the General Assembly heard a proposal tonight to grant blanket emergency powers to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold for 100 days to settle the growing crisis in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower told a group of White House visitors today that he would continue to work hard in the interests of world peace in the first year after he leaves the White House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Robert Francis Kennedy, the seventh child of Rose and Joseph P. Kennedy. was born in the family home at Brookline, Mass. thirty-five years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A new Secretary of the Treasury has been appointed, and thoughts turn naturally to high finance -- gold, interest rates, economic vitality and related matters.
The New York Yankees, in an effort to strengthen their depleted second-line pitching, yesterday purchased Danny McDevitt from the Los Angeles Dodgers for about $30,000.

The holiday season is now official, for the New York City Ballet last night gave its first presentation of "The Nutcracker" at the City Center. There will be eighteen more of them between now and Jan. 2.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Hank Van De Water scored 12 straight points in the second half tonight and led undefeated Lebanon Valley to a 59 -- 62 basketball victory over Upsala College.
Subfreezing weather and a chance of slight rain or snow vere predicted today for New fork City, which is still coping with the effect of last weekend's blizzard.

HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- A commuter was shot and killed at 7:45 A.M. today after parking his car at the New Haven Railroad station here to board a train for New York. Trains were leaving in each direction and no commuter reported seeing the shooting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- African States friendly to France sought today to soften a resolution on Algeria before it comes to a final General Assembly vote, probably Monday or Tuesday.

The Hygrade Food Products Corporation and its subsidiaries attained record sales of $417,000,845 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 29, compared with the previous peak of $414,216,351 reached the year before. Earnings, however, fell 6.3 per cent, the annual report of the meat packer disclosed yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Nichols School of Buffalo tonight qualified for tomorrow's final round of the Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament with a 2-1 victory over Belmont Hill of Belmont, Mass.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Kansas Jayhawks, sparked by Wayne Hightower's 25 points, coasted to a 93-69 victory over Michigan State's Spartans tonight.

Agonizing suspense and then grief filled a United Air Lines waiting room at New York International Airport yesterday as relatives and friends of passengers aboard United's Flight 826 from Chicago learned the plane had crashed in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bidding for control of the Kansas City Athletics today was narrowed to two potential purchasers, a Kansas City group, and a Gary (Ind.) insurance executive, Charles O. Finley.
Followers of the St. John's basketball team lounged in serene confidence at Madison Square Garden last night as the unbeaten Redmen routed Ohio University, 78 -- 50.

Two airliners collided over New York harbor yesterday in fog and sleet, killing 127 passengers and crewmen. One plane crashed in Brooklyn, killing five more persons on the ground, and the other fell on Staten Island.

The disaster in the city's history most costly of life was a fire aboard the vessel General Slocum on June 15, 1904 that killed 1,021 passengers. Included were many children on a Sunday school outing.
An 11-year-old boy, flying here to meet his mother and sister, was the only survivor of yesterday's airliner collision.

Ten four-story tenement buildings and an empty church were set afire when the United Air Lines DC-8 jet crashed and exploded in the populous Park Slope district of Brooklyn yesterday. More than 250 firemen and about fifty pieces of apparatus rushed to the seven-alarm blaze, which took more than two hours to bring under control.
Commodity futures prices on New York exchanges moved generally higher yesterday in light and dull trading.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Industrial share prices showed no definite trend in the stock market here today.

MADRID, Dec. 16 -- A Falangist youth shouted "traitor!" at Generalissimo Francisco Franco during a recent solemn mass at the Valley of the Fallen shrine near here, he cry has become a favorite topic of conversation in this censor-ridden city.
THE work of the prominent young French sculptor Cesar is better known in this country by its reputation abroad than by actual acquaintance.

The New York Harbor Railway Council, representing railroad marine employes of ten railroads active in the Port of New York, will resume negotiations with the New York Harbor Carrier Conference Committee on Wdnesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower extended today the ban on Cuban sugar imports through the first three months of 1961.

AS sure as Christmas is coming, more hostesses then ever and many of their guests will be trouser-clad this holiday season. Pants are already as much as part of a woman's wardrobe as the classic cardigan, but there are a few rules as to where and when pants should properly appear.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- When the Maryknoll Farm's Poppy Jay won the featured Greenspring Valley Purse at Pimlico today, it was the third winner of the day for Nick Shuk, who has triumphed twelve times at the twenty-seven-day-old meeting.

A $23,000,000 project to permit shipping of sulphur in liquid rather than in solid lump form has been started by Freeport Sulphur Company. The program will spell substantial savings for makers of sulphuric acid, fertilizer, rayon, steel and other items who until now have had to melt sulphur after delivery.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers are favored by 10 points to beat the injury-ridden Los Angeles Rams tomorrow and win the National Football League's Western Conference title.
Distances that can be paced off quickly -- 50 feet, 150 feet, 200 yards -- were the measure of life and death on quiet streets on Staten Island yesterday.
The aircraft in yesterday's crash represent two of the nation's biggest propeller and jet planes.
THE winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association continues today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with a two-session team - of - four contest and single-session pair games at 2 and 8 P.M.

VIENTIANE, Dec. 16 -- The troops of Gen. Phoumi Nosavan held the center of Vientiane this morning eighteen hours after they had captured it for a second time in a seesaw battle with tenacious pro-Communist defenders.

EVERYBODY wanted to love Lucille Ball, but her show didn't make it easy. "Wildcat," the new musical with which she arrived at the Alvin last night, had as much spirit and excitement as a tame, old tabby.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The nation's airline pilots today applauded a new Government order requiring voice recorders in the cockpits of all airliners to catch the last conversations on planes that crash.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Roger Maris of the New York Yankees beat out his teammate, Mickey Mantle, for the American League's 1960 slugging championship, according to official league statistics released today.

A sizable amount of new money for Christmas gift giving has been made available to banks in the metropolitan area, and many of the banks, as in other years, are making available for their customers decorative envelopes to contain the new money gifts.

A leading British advocate of expanded trade with the Soviet Union has published a blunt exposition of the problems and misgivings which have arisen among British business men with the rise in this trade.
THE shop set aside for men has reduced the wearying aspects of Christmas shopping for New York husbands.
The Avco Corporation announced yesterday the election of three officials to its top corporate posts.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16 -- The keel of a 10,500-ton cargopassenger ship, said to be the largest vessel to be built in Brazil, was laid today at Jacuacanga, sixty miles down the coast from this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The engineer who invented the air-conditioned suit has patented an air-conditioned umbrella. It is designed to drop cool air around the head and shoulders of the user as he sits in the garden or lolls on the beach.
ONCE again illness prevented a conductor from taking the podium at Carnegie Hall and gave young assistant conductors of the New York Philharmonic another crack at leading the orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Twenty-three men from twelve states, business men, labor leaders, college professors and state officials, completed preliminary work here today on an emergency program to aid the nation's depressed areas.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Auburn's Tigers, deadly from the free-throw line, nosed out Virginia Tech, 76 -- 73, in the opening game of the Birmingham Classic basketball tournament tonight.

A Frenchman's views on Britain and Britons is planned for publication in February by Atheneum, entitled "La Vie Anglaise." The author is Tony Mayer, a cultural attache at the French Embassy in London. He observes such "phenomena" as the weather, food, clothes, how the English are born and get married, their education, the theatre, the Royal family, sex and conversation.
Imaginativeness and flexibility were two qualities Clarence Douglas Dillon brought to the post of Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs when he was appointed early in 1957.

Cary Grant, concluding arangements to play the dramatic role of General Allenby in Sam Spiegel's screen version of 'Lawrence of Arabia," is simulaneously planning three contrasting projects -- a farce, a love story and a suspense melodrama -- for independent production under his own banner.
HAVANA, Dec. 16 -- Cuba and the Soviet Union plan to exchange goods valued at $168,000,000 next year, the Ministry of Commerce disclosed here tonight.

GENEVA, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today that industrial production behind the Iron Curtain in the first six months of this year exceeded expectations, except in East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Republicans must build a "party of the center" if they are to provide a "feasible alternative" to the Democrats, Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey said today.
SOURROUNDED by moder counters and twentieth-cetury goods at Franklin Simc is an anachronism called the General Store.
The Echo I satellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, eight times next week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

George Brezel and Stanley Rappoport, realty investors, have bought the six-story building containing thirty apartments at 840 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, from a client of Victor Whitehorn, lawyer. WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Farmers set a record in crop production this year, the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture said today.
George Arents, industrialist inventor and philanthropist, left more than $3,000,000 to public institutions, according to his will filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Army's undefeated hockey team warmed up for tomorrow's big game with Harvard by routing Ohio University, 7 -- 2, today at Smith Rink. The cadets scored five goals in the first period.

The classmates of a boy whose father died in last Monday's snowstorm gave to the Neediest yesterday "to keep someone alive and make this holiday a little more joyful" than it will be for their bereaved friend.

Factory sales of the electronics industry this year will reach a record of $9,750,000,000, L. Berkley Davis predicted yesterday. Mr. Davis is president of the Electronic Industries Association, to which most producers of all kinds of electronic end products and components belong.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16 -- Archbishop Joseph Elmer Ritter, who was elevated to the College of Cardinals today by Pope John XXIII, is a slender, almost frail-looking man whose mild appearance hides a will of iron and a gift for administration.

FATHER'S DAY Comes Once a Year and Then It Always Rains,"* by Harold H. Martin, is a cheering book of sketches concerning the casual problems parents face in bringing up children and the gigantic burdens children bear in trying to make their parents reasonably civilized.

Ralph E. Wilson, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, disclosed yesterday that he had a powerful Senate ally in supporting a more rigid approach by the agency in the use of its discretionary powers.

The lagging economy, unemployment, the farm problem and the controversy over Interest rates are the major domestic problems facing the new Administration, according to Dr. Marcus Nadler. He is Professor of Finance at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration and consultant to the Hanover Bank.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson and Jack Twyman combined for 75 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals scored a 130 -- 116 National Basketball Association, victory over Los Angeles.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa and two other Detroit men pleaded innocent today to a twelve-count indictment of mail fraud in the use of more than $500,000 in union funds.

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Adele L. Rand's Bourbon Prince, attempting a comeback after a seven-month lay-off, finished second to Countess Albie today in the featured eighth race at Tropical Park before a crowd of 6,626. Joy Joy was third.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy struck the first jarring note today in five weeks of masterly political orchestration.

State Controller Arthur Levitt announced yesterday plans for an offering of $56,200,000 of State of New York serial bonds during the third week of January to finance low-rent housing and urban renewal programs.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In its editorial of Dec. 9 "School Vandalism" The Times urges again -- as it has before -- new legislation to make parents pay for damage done by their children. As you know, laws already exist to hold parents financially liable when they can be shown to be responsible for causing damage.
The airline collision here yesterday was the second such disaster in the nation's aviation history involving commercial airliners in which fatalities occurred.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Colgate and Tennessee were knocked from the ranks of the undefeated tonight. The University of Pittsburgh downed Colgate, 78 -- 82, and Duquesne beat Tennessee, 79 -- 64, in the opening round of the Steel Bowl basketball tournament.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 16 -- All political activity was suspended in Nepal today following the dismissal of the Government and suspension of the Parliament yesterday by King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva.
HOUSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Alabama, a 1-point favorite, meets Texas tomorrow before an expected crowd of 70,000 in the Bluebonnet Bowl football game.

Price declines and a slowing in trading developed in the bond market yesterday, shading the sharp enhancement of values that had taken place early in the week.

A slum landlord case that had been in the courts for more than a year and a half ended yesterday with the sentencing of two Brooklyn attorneys and a former real estate broker.
Undefeated Louis Rodriguez of Cuba is an 8-to-5 favorite to win from Emile Griffith of, New York in the ten-round welterweight main event at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The expansion of graduate studies, including the introduction next fall of courses leading to the Doctor of Philosophy degree, was proposed yesterday by the administration of Hunter College.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 16 -- The University of Bridgeport downed Brooklyn College in a Tri-State League basketball game tonight, 91 -- 76. Fred Schack led the Knights to their second victory of the campaign in six starts with 20 points.

Some American scientists left the recent Sixth Pugwash Conference in Moscow with a strong impression that Premier Khrushchev had serious hopes of conducting meaningful disarmament negotiations next year with President John F. Kennedy.
POSSIBLY in a hopeful search for a new "Amahl and the Night Visitors," the Hallmark Hall of Fame came up with a new Christmas opera last night on the National Broadcasting Company television network.

A preliminary investigation of the air disaster here yesterday suggested that the two planes collided because one was off its course.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- We all remember Stevenson's grim chanty. "Fifteen men on the Dead Man's Chest -- Yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum!" This sardonic sentiment could well serve as a slogan for the current Paris NATO meeting.
A quiet Brooklyn neighborhood of brownstones and turn-of-the-century apartment houses became an inferno in a few quick seconds yesterday morning.

The directors of the Ralston Purina Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 35 cents a share on the common stock. It is payable on March 13 to stockholders of record of Feb. 20.
Mayor Wagner signed yesterday the controversial "rainy day fund" bill designed to avoid the imposition of any new or increased excise taxes in fiscal 1961-62, a city election year.

A 45-year-old Brooklyn lawyer, convicted of conspiracy in the switching of arrest records of gambling case defendants to obtain lesser sentences, received a suspended sentence of one year in jail yesterday in Special Sessions Court.
Three men accused of dealing in stolen money orders and counterfeit money were linked yesterday by the police to a $1,000,000 counterfeiting ring that has flooded the East Coast with bogus $20 bills.

John J. O'Rourke, the chief lieutenant of James R. Hoffa in the New York area, appeared last night to have won re-election in a hard-fought contest for the presidency of Teamsters Local 282.
Commissioner Vincent A.G. O'Connor is keeping his fingers crossed while he waits for five pier construction bids to come in tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A privately financed report on the White House staff recommended a number of changes today to help the President direct national policy more effectively.

Investigators looking into the cause of Friday's airline collision here are studying the possibility that the United Air Line jet overshot the point where it should have turned into a "holding" pattern over New Jersey.

The Board of National Missions of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. has leased property in Miami where it will establish a center to aid Cuban refugees. The board has also set aside $12,000 to acquire additional property when needed.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- Chancellor Adenauer has canceled his plans to visit the United States in February. He acted after word reached here from Washington that President-elect John F. Kennedy might make a quick trip to Europe next year.
Successful testing of a system of space communications using sunlight instead of radio waves was desclosed yesterday by Electro-Optical Systems, Inc., of Pasadena, Calif.
Week Ended Dec. 16, 1960 Foreign exchange market turned soft during the past week. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar were very active at times.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The Italian-language newspaper La Fiamma today supported American accusations of unjust criticism by Australians over the treatment accorded visiting Davis Cup tennis players.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy today called top Democratic Congressional leaders to a conference here to prepare his Administration's initial legislative program and strategy.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

The "post-modern" era has not spread a gospel of good news but rather "a message of blasphemy," the Rev. Vincent J.P. Fox said in his sermon yesterday at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- United States officials are studying with mounting concern recent evidence indicating that Israel, with the assistance of France, may be developing the capacity to produce atomic weapons.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Fellow-worshipers of President-elect John F. Kennedy at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church were admonished today by the pastor to mind their manners. Msgr. J. P. O'Mahoney looked out over his crowded church during 10 o'clock mass and observed that just because there was a "distinguished visitor", present, that was no excuse for noisy conversation and departure from the church before the priest had left the altar.
The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church, dedicated a new peal of five bronze swinging bells and a twenty-five-bell electronic carillon yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Lenny Lyles raced two kick-offs back 78 and 97 yards today and led the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 34-10 victory over Baltimore. It was the two-time champions' fourth straight loss.

LAST night's New York Philharmonic Pension Fund concert in Carnegie Hall might be subtitled "a perplexing evening with Sviatoslav Richter." And one might add Leonard Bernstein and the orchestra to the general puzzlement.

THE amateur who approaches pie making with a feeling of uncertainty may be confident of success when a crumb crust is used in place of regular pastry. The crumb variety requires no special skills. It is only a matter of mixing the selected kind of crumbs with butter and flavoring, if desired, and pressing the mixture into a pie pan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A balance of payments deficit and a recession at the same time is a double kettle of fish. Solutions to the two problems seem to have more in conflict than in common.
The public review board set up by the United Automobile Workers three years ago was praised in a report published yesterday by the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions.

Nathan Milstein makes the violin look too easy Saturday night at Hunter College, in his only New York recital of the season, he played with a deceptive effortlessness. Yet this was not just surface virtuosity, for the concert was alive with the compelling beauty of the interpretations.
The level of employment in naval shipyards lacks "any relationship" to the workload such yards have at hand, a newly published study says.
Governor Rockefeller has decided to reappoint a member of the Liberal party to the State Tax Commission, it became known last night.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Israel tonight called reports that her nuclear technology could allow it to produce an atom bomb within five years "very flattering * * * but untrue."

Plans for a $8,500,000 campus for the Staten Island Community College will be presented tonight to the Board of Higher Education. They call for the construction of three major buildings on a thirty-five-acre site in the Sunnyside section.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Western Ministers ended today a three-day meeting that pointed toward a new concept of military unity, but that produced flashes of anger and bitterness over the old political divisions on colonialism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Joint Economic Committee of Congress issued a study of Federal "subsidy and subsidy-like programs" today. Senator Paul H. Douglas, committee chairman, said this was a "first step" in determining the impact of Federal aid on the nation's economy.

The property at 228 to 238 East Forty-fourth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been leased by the Limon Building and Supply Corporation to the Forty-fourth Leasing Corporation, Harry Landes, president.

During the hard winter months, charitable organizations need money and taxpayers still have a few days this year to give til it hurts. For many taxpayers, it hurts the Government more than it does them.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- East Germany's Communist leader threatened today "serious disturbances" in Allied and West German rail traffic to Berlin after Jan. 1 unless the East-West German trade pact was renewed.

A mangrove swamp near Guayaquil has been converted into a deep-water channel to make available to Ecuador the finest natural harbor on the west coast of the Americas, excepting only San Francisco and Seattle.
Insurance awards exceeding $15,000,000 wore foreseen in legal and insurance circles last night as a likely result of Friday's aircraft disaster here.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 18 -- The next major effort by the Federal Public Health Service will be to get more medical care to the "consumer," Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney, head of the agency said today.
A program to send young Americans to work abroad under President-elect John F. Kennedy's "peace corps" plans was recommended yesterday by a committee of educational exchange experts.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 -- Premier Boun Oum moved into the Foreign Ministry building today and announced that his new pro-Western Government was in operation in this rubble-strewn city. The Government faces formidable rebuilding problems after having fought its way into the capital.

Inventory reduction by aluminum users is now nearing the bottom and, as a result, shipments during 1961 should be above those of this year, according to Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of Reynolds Metals Company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 -- Ecuador has reaffirmed in strong language what she considers her right to denounce the 1942 frontier pact with Peru.

The Giants tried their best yesterday to present Jim Lee Howell, their retiring head coach, with a seventh consecutive victory over the Browns. They failed, under the crushing impact of a fourth-period Cleveland onslaught that netted four touchdowns.
LAUREL HOLLOW, L.I., Dec. 18 -- Rare and exotic wild orchid plants from the jungles of South and Central America are being cultivated successfully on an estate here by a scientist and his wife.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The 537 Presidential electors wil meet tomorrow to make the result of this year's election official.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Ohio State's basketball team tonight overpowered Loyola of Chicago with a 59-point burst in the second half for a 90-65 victory. The triumph was the Buckeyes' fifth without a defeat.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Economic pressures threatened today to cripple the New Orleans school system by Christmas.
A record operating budget request of $50,568,999 for 1961-62 will be submitted to the city by the Board of Higher Education. The sum is 12 per cent higher than the current budget of $45,135,285.
The Alumni Association of City College yesterday extended its attack on the Heald Committee Report on Higher Education.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Mayor Wagner sent to the City Council yesterday two bills designed to strengthen and broaden the city's law that prohibits discrimination in private housing.
YESTERDAY (Dec. 19, I960) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Voted recognition of United Nations responsibility in helping promote independence for Algeria, but rejected proposal far a referendum on Algeria's future.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Don Petersen and Cliff Peterson, a pair of 6-foot 4-inch sophomores, sparked a second-half rally that gave Rutgers a 74-63 victory over Colby College tonight. Cliff scored 12 of his 14 points in the last half.
Thirty-five young women from seventeen countries will make their formal bows to society in the flag-decked main ballroom of the Astor Thursday.
Maine potato futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the heaviest trading of the season.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee recessed early today after having voted a record United Nations budget of $72,969,300 for 1961.

John D. Gray, president of Wallachs, men's clothing chain in this area, was named also president and chief executive officer of Hart, Shaffner Marx, clothing manufacturer, it was announced yesterday in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The venerable Electoral College, despite renewed criticism that it is inefficient and inequitable, worked well enough today to elect John Fitzgerald Kennedy as the thirty-fifth President of the United States, as decided by the people on Nov. 8.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- The course of international affairs has driven the cast of "The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" from Paris to Hollywood, where it is much easier to hide from the rest of the world.
What its sponsors believe to be New York's softest sell in the real estate market has been found successful for the sale of luxury apartments in a new cooperative building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The index of the average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.5 percent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended Tuesday, Dec. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

At least forty-six workmen were killed, more than 150 were injured and at least seven others were missing yesterday in a fire that swept the nation's largest aircraft carrier, the Constellation, at her pier at the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The body of Ethiopia's former security chief, a leader of the revolt last week against Emperor Haile Selassie I, was publicly hanged in Minelik Square today. He was Lieut. Col. Workineh Gebeheyo.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 19 -- A three-man advance party of the United Nations conciliation commission arrived here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States will begin immediately to resume military assistance to Laos, now ruled by the pro-Western Government of Premier Bonn Oum.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made a loan of the equivalent of $5,500,000 to Peru yesterday. The funds will be used to improve road transport between eastern Peru and Lima, and thereby accelerate development of the central part of Peru's Amazon region.
For centuries economists have argued about the meaning of the word value. What is the value of anything and how can it be measured? If the economists cannot agree, what can corporations do?
"Four fairly good statements" by eyewitnesses have corroborated radar evidence that Friday's airline collision occurred over Staten Island.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates are offering to the public today 250,000 Class A capital shares of Swingline, Inc., at $21.50 a share.

For thousands of underprivileged and handicapped person Christmas will be the merrier this year, as every year, because of food, toys, time and talent donated by church, hospital, welfare and service organizations.

The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday its members would refuse to handle cargoes for or from Cuba because of "repressive measures against labor" by the Government of Premier Fidel Castro.
BONN, Dec. 19 -- East Germany asserted today that the agreements lifting the 1948-49 Berlin blockade were contingent upon a trade pact between the two Germanys.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Representative Henry S. Reuss of Wisconsin said today the new Administration owed it to the voters to set up an American youth corps to work overseas for peace.
The first application of space technology to the uses of advertising has been announced by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's Missiles and Space division at Pale Alto, Calif.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United Air Lines jet involved in the collision over New York Friday was flying an unauthorized course, President Eisenhower was told today.
THE plot of "The Rules of the Game" is not much more than an extended anecdote, but in the diabolical brilliance of Pirandello's development it becomes a fascinating evening in the theatre.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19-By far the greatst impediment to the development of a machine tool industry throughout Asia is the lack of skilled workers and of experienced technical and managerial personnel. Hardly secondary is the absence of capital for investment.

The Republic Steel Corporation yesterday named Thomas F. Patton, a 57-year-old lawyer, to be chief executive officer. Mr. Patton succeeds Charles M. White, who is retiring at 70 as chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's third-ranking steel company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Navy views the fire today on the carrier Constellation as a serious blow to its plans to play a bigger strategic role.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since my first visit to North Africa in 1949, I have given considerable thought to the Algerian question Many Americans, including Senato Kennedy, seem to think of the problem in strictly political terms -- since the Moslems are in a preponderan majority, and irrespective of their contribution to its economic development, the country should be turned over to their rule or even misrule.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Dec. 12 -- If Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, Premier of the Sudan and strong man of its military regime, had to run for re-election tomorrow he might win on the slogan: "Business never had it so good."
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Industrial shares prices had more small gains than losses in the stock market here today. Trading was quiet and buying selective.

HAVING served a one-year jail term on a matter of principle, Dr. Willard Uphans is relieved but not bitter. He has done what he considers to have been his duty; his conscience is free and he harbors no ill will toward anybody.

The officials for the main bouts at St. Nicholas Arena continue to have difficulty agreeing with each other. Last night, for the second time in seven days, the ten-round feature ended in a draw, Billy Collins of Detroit and Tony DeCola, a Brooklyn welter-weight, going the distance.

The U.N. General Assembly is winding up one of the most dangerous three months in its history. The atmosphere has not been good or promising since Premier Khrushchev sailed into the East River on Sept. 19 for almost a month's stay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Once more, by the votes of the Presidenial electors recorded in the several states today, the American people have been spared the Government crisis which the defects of the method of choosing the Chief Executive could produce every four years.

IN the recent hullabaloo about Jacqueline Kennedy's wardrobe, it may have escaped general notice that young Caroline Kennedy, in her own small way, is as well turned out as her beauteous mother. One of the reasons for this is a designer named Phyllis R. Berens, the talent behind a thriving, ten-year-old children's clothing concern, Merry Mites, Inc.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 15 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The French Foreign Ministry denied today that France was aiding Israel in a nuclear program for military purposes.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller indicated today that he did not plan to press a fall-out shelter program on the 1961 Legislature.

The fire that raged inside the dark, almost airtight hull of the Constellation yesterday was sinister rather than spectacular. Flames licked out of the gray hull only briefly, but firemen had to penetrate a series of what seemed like ovens as they fought their way toward men trapped in steel compartments.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy sat down with three legislative leaders tonight to shape his Administration's Congressional program and strategy.

Shifting the stockholder vote evidently has become a favorite method to beat the heat of the Department of Justice's antitrust fervor and to lessen outside control. Now it comes out that the American Viscose Corporation soon will pass along to its own stockholders the voting rights on 3,540,000 shares of Monsanto Chemical Company.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Britain took several steps today to end the fighting in Laos, where pro-Western and pro-Communist forces have been contending for control of the government.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 19 -- The county Commissioner of Jurors was indicted today on charges that he changed seven police examination papers three years ago while he was execu tive secretary to the Suffolk County Civil Service Commission.
"Hollywood and the Movies," an hour-long documentary about the era of silent movies, is expected to be televised early next year on a national network.
The No. 1 item on Wellington Mara's shopping list, contrary to what some Sunday night Giant strategists may think, is not a head coach who can work miracles, but a halfback who can work miracles.

CHARLIE CONERLY dragged himself into the room, shoulders sagging and the weight of his years upon him. This was at the farewell party Jim Downey tossed for the Giants, their wives and their friends many hours after the Yankee Stadium tenants had succumbed to the closing rush of the youthful Browns in a spectacular regular-season finale.
Drugs, vending machines and most of the chemicals showed signs of life in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but most of the other groups were irregular or down.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate Subcommittee on National Policy Machinery released a highly critical report today on the functioning of the National Security Council.

Shortest Day, Brightest Night Tomorrow will have less daylight than any other day in 1960. The earth has an appointment with the sun at precisely 3:27 P. M. for the purpose of gradually lengthening the days again for the next six months.
PRESS agents who deal with hunting and fishing have been pretty busy lately, building up character for the Christmas holidays and carrying on about one thing and another.

Bobby Fischer, the 17-year-old defending champion, yesterday scored his second successive victory in the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship. Also at stake at the Empire Hotel is the Frank Marshall Trophy.
Ohio State was the unanimous choice yesterday in The Associated Press basketball poll as the No. 1 major-college team in the nation.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The New York State Electoral College cast forty-five votes today for Senators John F. Kennedy as President and Lyndon B. Johnson as Vice President.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- Two American defectors from the National Security Agency were quoted today as having expressed the belief that the United States would continue to spy on the Soviet Union, its allies and neutral nations during the Administration of President-elect John F. Kennedy.
Charles J. Bensley, a member of New York City's Board of Education, will go to Israel next month to advise authorities there on establishing a free, compulsory secondary school system.
The city moved on two opposite fronts yesterday -- one to combat graft and the other to make public year-end rewards to employes for fidelity and efficiency.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Dec. 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned the General Assembly last night that prolonged international bickering over the Congo might lead to his asking the Security Council to consider the withdrawal of the 20,000-man force there.
TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- The Legislature voted today to increase the state tax on cigarettes by 1 cent a pack and to submit to the voters a referendum on a $30,000,000 bond issue next November.

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange will consider on Dec. 29 the transfer of the membership now held by George J. Stockly to Edward A. Connelly, of that of William V. Stockdale to Leonard Young, of that of Eugene Norton to James Campbell 3d, and of that of John A. Dyer to Milton W. Holden.
COMMUNING was a word that often came to mind last night in listening to Abbey Simon's piano recital at Carnegie Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Informed sources reported tonight that Ireland and Liberia had agreed to share a two-year seat on the Security Council. The compromise would end a deadlock over the post.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that witnesses may be compelled to give incriminating testimony in Federal narcotics cases if granted immunity from prosecution.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The auto industry passed the 6,500,000 mark in 1960 production today and needs only about 150,000 more assemblies in the remainder of the month to make the year's volume the second largest in history.
Four hundred and eighty-one creditors of the bankrupt North Atlantic and Gulf Steamship Company received an unexpected but pleasant Christmas present yesterday in Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed new rules for the registration of investment advisers under the newly stiffened terms of the Investment Advisers Act.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the matters to which the new Administration and the new Congress will, we hope, give thought, is the future of Ellis Island.

The bond market entered the final fortnight of the calendar year yesterday in a state of firmness. The pace of business was slower than most trading sessions this month, but prices held well.
"L'Enfance du Christ" has become almost as indispensable at Christmas as Handel's "Messiah."
The fire that swept the aircraft carrier Constellation in Brooklyn yesterday had a dramatic New York Harbor parallel in the loss of the converted French luxury liner Normandie.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The Democratic state committee voted down overwhelmingly today four attempts by members of the party's reform wing to change the committee's rules.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to build one of the world's largest, most precise radiotelescopes to track future spacecraft hundreds of millions of miles into space.

WERE Shakespeare's plays written by Casey Stengel? Awkward problems of time and so forth forbid our discussing that idea today. A thousand years from now, however, savants caught short of other targets for attribution may make at least a smiling case for Old Case.

The Foreign, Defense and Treasury Ministers of the North Atlantic alliance have been meeting in Paris under the handicap of an outgoing American Administration that could make no commitments for the new one. Nevertheless, the meeting reached agreement on principles and on concrete measures to put them into effect.

COURMAYEUR, Italy, Dec. 18 -- Boxing may have its Archie Moore and baseball its Warren Spahn, but here, high in the northern Italian Alps, skiing's two ageless wonders are Prospero Bertholier and Francis Salluard.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Charles O. Finley, virtually penniless and near death thirteen years ago, capped his success story today with the purchase of controlling interest in the Kansas City Athletics.

Brooklyn's 255 Club, composed of twenty-eight volunteers who assist the city's firemen at major blazes, was on the scene at yesterday's Constellation fire. Other members had been on duty at Friday's plane crash site in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

For hours at a time last Saturday, it was so quiet in the Elmont High Gymnasium that one could hoar a tenth of a ton of iron drop. Breathing heavily, ninety-seven boys from twenty-two schools tried to jerk, press and snatch their weight in dumbbells during the nine-hour, Nassau-Suffolk invitation lifting tournament.

THERE is more than a slight touch of irony in modern American gastronomy. Consider the fact that much of the finest French cuisine may become commonplace in the nation, not through grand luxe hotels and restaurants, but through the world's largest restaurant chain.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19 -- A 1961 Westchester County budget calling for $49,944,833 in spending and a slightly reduced tax rate was adopted by a vote of 33 to 8 today by the Board of Supervisors.

A small plane carrying a free-lance aerial photographer over the naval shipyard fire in Brooklyn made a forced landing yesterday when its engine stopped. The pilot and the photographer were not seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Federal Food and Drug Administration announced today the seizure of 6,345 pounds of diet mixes offered for reducing weight. The value was put at $7,500. False labeling was charged.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) - The New England Council issued the following report on ski conditions and weather forecast today:

Milwaukee, Wis., is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $8,495,000 on Jan. 24.
CHRISTMAS vacation is the season when a mother, to keep her sanity, has to maintain two engagement books: her own and her children's.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- The ore ship Rio Orinoco, flying the Liberian flag, unloaded 20,000 tons of South American iron ore today at the Fairless works of the United States Steel Corporation in near-by Morrisville.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Thirty-four-year-old Bill McPeak was promoted to head coach of the Washington Redskins today. It will be his job to convert the last-place team into a National Football League championship contender.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Charles O. Finley's six-year campaign to buy a major league baseball franchise ended successfully today when Probate Judge Robert Jerome Dunne approved his purchase of majority control of the Kansas City Athletics.

From time to time, reports indicate that Milton Berle would like to return to the Broadway stage, from which he has been absent since the "Ziegfeld Follies" of 1943. Despite his wishes, however, nothing has brought him back.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, printed today charges that feuding and lack of cooperation between the neighboring Tatar and Bashkir autonomous republics in the Russian Federation had led to a loss of millions of rubles.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 19 -- The United States scored a major success today in its effort to place a man in space when an unmanned Mercury capsule traveled 235 miles out into the Atlantic Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- United States officials explained today that they were originally led to believe that a plutonium-producing reactor being built by Israel with French assistance was a textile plant.
The combined efforts of a typhoon, a Long Island professor and several score Koreans hare uncovered an ancient tomb filled with urns and with weapons that have turned to dust.

The six-story apartment building at 1425 University Avenue, near 172d Street in the Bronx, has been sold by the University Avenue Realty Company to a client of Goodman Mabel, lawyers. The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company was the broker in the sale, which was subject to mortgages of 5293,000.
WARSAW, Dec. 19 -- The Polish people will begin living on Jan. 1 under a new administrative code that is described in the Warsaw press as a step toward democracy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly adopted tonight a resolution that recognizes the United Nations' responsibility in helping to promote independence for Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs dropped this week. The average discount rate on this week's issue of six-month bills was the lowest in the two years that the bills have been marketed.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- A blueprint for a socialist type of economy for Ghana, embracing cooperative farming and a bigger role for cooperatives in retail trade, was published today.

HARRIED shoppers can take heart. There is still lots of lovely loot to be found around town to finish up the gift list. One place well worth looking into is the Charles of the Ritz Shop on Park Avenue at Fifty-seventh Street.

The new Secretary of Labor is planning an early start on efforts to promote labor-management cooperation for industrial peace and national economic growth.
A religious court, or Beth Din, has been formed here by the Orthodox rabbinate of this country to guide and counsel Jews having problems in marriage, divorce and family relationships.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- British European Airways put a third pilot on the flight deck of the Vickers Vanguard turbo-prop airliner that went into service on the London-Paris run today.
Steel production is expected to drop to 46.9 per cent of capacity this week, and a further reduction is on tap for next week, when mills sharply curtail operations during the Christmas holidays.

Ten alarms were sounded yesterday for the fire aboard the carrier Constellation, sending 120 pieces of regular equipment and 350 firemen to the scene.
