RENATA TEBALDI swept through her first full performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera, leaving a trail of satisfied customers in her wake. Also making its first appearance of the season was the opera in which she appeared, "Simon Boccanegra," by Verdi.
YONKERS, Dec. 19 -- Two armed men robbed a woman cashier outside the John Wanamaker store at the Cross County Shopping Center this morning and escaped with $30,000.

Activities of the State's Judicial Conference, recently outlined by its chairman, Charles S. Desmond, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, include new departures of great promise for the future. In fact, the items on its agenda read like a list of the most pressing problems of the state's courts now calling for solution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The final Government crop report of the year, issued after the close on Friday, sparked a fairly broad advance in soybean futures today, but the grains generally were under light to moderate pressure and declined.

Paul R. Screvane, the Commissioner of Sanitation, didn't show up for the Monday night bowling sessoin at the Douglaston Club in Queens last week. The admirable snow man was busy trying to knock down seventeen inches of the fluffy stuff on some other alleys in town.
Labor and industry spokesmen offered sharply divergent views yesterday on changing the state's Unemployment Insurance and Workmen's Compensation Laws.
The New Orleans school board received another offer of financial aid yesterday to help keep its newly integrated schools open.

The multi-million dollar air craft carrier Constellation which burned at a ship construction pier at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday, was an inert ship, in capable of helping herself.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A dozen task, forces, involving more than 100 consultants, are working for President-elect John F. Kennedy on foreign-policy recommendations.

The New York Knickerbockers will use Phil Rollins for the first time tonight when they meet the Syracuse Nationals in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.

The overwhelming sentiment in New York State for acquiring more park and recreation space before it is too late was demonstrated beyond doubt on Election Day. In a referendum on the ballot question to authorize state borrowing of $75,000,000 for buying acreage the yes vote was 2,390,585, the no vote only 889,284. For comparison it may be noted that a second proposition on the ballot, involving public housing, passed by a mere 184,283 votes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee called today for general agreement to suspend tests of atomic and hydrogen bombs and to restrict the spread of all nuclear weapons.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- The Soviet Union promised today to help Cuba build an iron and steel mill, an oil refinery, electric power stations and other "complete industrial enterprises."

Commercial Trust Co. of N.J. A directors' recommendation that the stock of Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey, Jersey City, be split on the basis of two and a half new $10 shares for each $25 share now outstanding will be submitted to the stockholders at the annual meeting on Jan. 10.
IN the heart of the battle to save lives and put out the fires aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation yesterday, one giant of a man in coveralls and hard hat stood out over everyone else.

Today is the eighty-ninth anniversary of the birth of the late Henry Hadley, and last night the National Association of American Composers and Conductors that Mr. Hadley founded gave its annual birthday program in the American composer's honor.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Yesterday morning, while the North Atlantic Council was finishing its work in Paris, some high United States naval officers played happily with elaborate working models of nuclear weapons that Washington hopes to give and sell to Europe.

NEWELL JENKINS, who spends a good deal of his time burrowing in European archives in search of old music that is worth resurrecting and presenting as "new," offered nothing of the sort in the Clarion Concerts program in Town Hall last night.

Some United States airlines have managed to block a part of Trans-Canada Air Lines' plan to introduce new fares, service and baggage allowances on Jan. 2 in Canada and between Canada and the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your excellent Dec. 4 editorial "Justice for Migrant Workers" one important point was overlooked. In fact, as far as I can ascertain, this oversight has been common to all students of this problem.
Four of the season's debutantes were honored at private parties yesterday.

If rent controls were lifted here would the city's already critical housing situation crumble into chaos, or would such an action hasten the return to "a normal market of free bargaining between landlord and tenant?"
A new snowstorm swept into New York City early today.
Injured workers who had close brushes with death aboard the burning aircraft carrier Constellation told stories yesterday of horror and heroism.
A scheduled all-day legislative hearing on mortgages and real estate was cut short yesterday when it became apparent that banking and insurance observers far outnumbered those willing to testify.
The Arthur Judson Foundation will pay for a special concert of the New York Philharmonic in order to give two young American musicians a chance to play with the orchestra.

An electrical service company that has annual contracts, of $5,500,000 with the city charged the State Investigation Commission yesterday with making a "fishing expedition" into its records under a threat of adverse publicity.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 4,407,850 shares on Dec. 15 from 4,135,870 on Nov. 15, the exchange reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Eisenhower has awarded the National Security Medal to Robert D. Murphy, a career diplomat who recently resigned as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The British Government will discuss a summit conference with, the Soviet Union in its first exchanges with the new United States Administration, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.
Reform Democratic leaders will tell Mayor Wagner today that they want the party rules in New York County changed at the same time a vote is taken to oust Carmine G. De Sapio as county leader.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Four bills for a state income tax rebate affecting returns to be filed next year were submitted by Republican Senators today.
A City administration-sponsored bill that would impose fines and jail terms for illegally dumping industrial wastes into city sewers was passed yesterday by the City Council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator,Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, the Republican national chairman, conceded today that Senator John F. Kennedy had been elected President.

THE ubiquitous chap in the flashy red outfit remains the season's number one attraction for small fry. He is avail-many of the city's leading department stores, where children may sit on his lap, make gift requests and otherwise be amused by his boundless good nature.

An appraisal of modern American scientific achievement and a study of those who have made it possible will be issued Jan. 30 by Prentice-Hall in a volume titled "Great American Scientists." The book, which was prepared by the editors of Fortune magazine, examines the work and careers of florty living scientists who, since 1920, have brought the United States to the forefront in .physics, chemistry, astronomy and biology.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The State Department has relaxed its policy restricting Government scientists in attendance at international meetings at which Communist China is represented.
Consideration of a state-wide sales tax was one of twenty-seven recommendations made yesterday to promote economic expansion and provide new employment opportunities in New York State.

Cuban Premier Fidel Castro's threat yesterday to ruin any new sugar producers who tried to take advantage of his exclusion from the United States market had little effect on world sugar futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
With a brand new team-mate and 10,337 fans to be impressed the New York Knickerbockers rallied to down the Syracuse Nationals, 122-112, at Madison Square Garden last night.
IS it possible that the producers of "Shunned," the new play by Judith Palestrant, which deals with the strict religious sect, the Amish are being literal about it all?
The entire faculty of City College heard its president, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, declare yesterday that the college "now stands at the most critical point of its history."

Morris Morgenstern, a real estate investment banker and philanthropist who grew up on the Lower East Side, returned to Public School 4 on Rivington Street yesterday to receive the diploma he could not stay to earn as a boy.

AS if there is need to remind anyone, there are four shopping days until Christmas. There must be several thousand shopping lists around town that are as yet incomplete and the thought occurs that few things are more welcome or easier to shop for than wines and spirits.
Some of the oilers on railroad Diesel tugboats who set a precedent last week by voting to abolish their jobs appeared yesterday to be having second thoughts.
The president of United Air Lines questioned yesterday whether something was wrong with the radio signals guiding the DC-8 jet in Friday's airliner collision here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Auto production will drop more next year than the industry has indicated, the Department of Commerce predicted today.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- President de Gaulle delivered tonight a new invitation to the leaders of the Algerian rebellion to negotiate peace and self-determination and to French voters to back that policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Railroads, which have faced a succession of charges of engaging in rate wars against shipping operators on the Great Lakes, inland rivers and coastwise ocean lanes, were accused today of extending their "same destructive tactics" against canal carriers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Chancellor Collins J. Seitz ruled today that Sol A. Dann, Detroit lawyer who is suing the Chrysler Corporation for alleged mismanagement, must name those giving him information but subject to three limitations, Mr. Dann brought the action as a stockholder.

OPENING its presents a little early this year, the Museum of Modern, Art has good reason to be pleased with the generosity of its family and friends. Their gifts for 1960 (excluding checks) go on exhibition today along with the things the museum has bought for itself in the last twelve months, and in combination they comprise a miniature museum of modern art within the larger one.

Great Eastern Associates, Inc., brokers specializing in ocean-marine insurance, have leased space at 80 Pine Street. David Baldwin of the Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker. The lessees will move from 39 Broadway about Feb. 1.
Mayor Wagner was accused yesterday by a Democrat of ignoring the sufferings of slum dwellers except to reply with press releases, chest thumping and buck passing to protests made on their behalf.

DEVEREUX COLT JOSEPHS, chairman of the commission that reported to Governor Rockefeller yesterday on how to expand the state's economy, once wrote in the preface to a similar report: "The road to inertia is paved with good reports."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- For the second time in three months, a 12,800-ton cargo liner built for American President Lines has slid down a way at a bay area shipyard.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy gave two major assignments to Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson today. He indicated that Senator Johnson would be assigned further working roles in major activities of the Executive branch.

Two leading trade associations of domestic manufacturers of electrical and electronic products took steps yesterday to persuade American business to buy more of their products. Statements issued by the groups emphasized the seriousness of foreign competition in the electrical and electronic fields.
Ohio State missed a perfect score by a single point in the United Press International college basketball ratings yesterday for the second time this season.

BERTOLT BRECHT'S "In the Jungle of Cities," which entered the repertory of the Living Theatre last night, is a bewildering play. It takes a long time to discover what the author is trying to say, and when he has reached his destination, you wonder whether the twisting, confusing journey was worth it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly voted approval tonight without opposition of a report calling for more cooperation to dispel world-wide anxiety over the effects of atomic radiation by learning more about it.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to be continuing to airlift supplies to retreating pro-Communist military units in Laos.
MIDDLE RIVER, Md., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- In 1909, only six years after Orville and "Wilbur Wright's frail flying machine wobbled into the air, the Martin Company offered its first airplane for sale.

IT is given to few authors to write an undoubted masterpiece and to fewer still to find their masterpiece recognized within their lifetime and rewarded by a shower of gold. Yet this is the happy lot of T.H. White, the bearded and fiercely individualistic Englishman who wrote "The Once and Future King."
The very young and the very old were among contributors to the Neediest Cases yesterday.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 20 -- The University of Connecticut basketball team scored its fourth straight victory by upsetting Brown University, 89 -- 71, tonight.

St. John's University's high-ranking Redmen warmed up for next week's Holiday Festival basketball tournament by walloping Pittsburgh, 87 -- 56, in the second game of a college double-header at Fordham Gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

A STUDY in depth of the sit-in movement in Nashville, Tenn., was presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company; it was one of the network's superior accomplishments, a vivid and exciting social document that contained well-organized factual data and enjoyed brilliant pictorial composition.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following reports and weather forecast at 10 A.M. today:

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- In his temporary State Department quarters Dean Rusk is finding a lot of permanent problems. These are the world headaches that transcend either the amassed briefing books placed at the Secretary-designate's disposal or the lists of ambassadorial posts to be filled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Eisenhower cleared the way today for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair, including "a very substantial and meaningful" exhibit reflecting the American ideal of individual freedom and responsibility.
The debate on Algeria in the United Nations, which was regarded with dread by some and hope by others, has come and gone without doing much harm or much good. Perhaps this was all for the best.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A proposal to invoke limited economic sanctions against the Dominican Republic will be placed before the Organization of American States tomorrow.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Neale Fraser, bulwark of Australia's Davis Cup hopes, gave his ailing knee a workout today and then left almost immediately to rejoin his teammates in Brisbane.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 20 -- Pratt Institute of Brooklyn registered its first basketball victory over Adelphi College since 1948 when it rallied for a 73-63 triumph tonight. Ed Mazria, with 14 points, was a standout for Pratt. Ed Cahill of Adelphi was the high scorer with 19 points.
DALLAS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A spectacular crop of rookies, led by Abner Haynes of the Dallas Texans, won four individual titles in the first year of play in the new American Football League.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures today was limited mainly to the expiring December contracts where the evening of commitments became brisk during the final few minutes of dealings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two proposals with respect to the gold problem deserve the most careful attention of the incoming Administration. To these I now wish to add still another suggestion. The two proposals to which I refer are as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The challenges of cost, noise, air traffic control and airport accessibility are pressing civil aviation into a hew "pioneer age," according to the editor of "Jane's All the World's Aircraft."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Traffic in the Orient, which for centuries kept to an ambling pace, has quickened. Only the existing gaps in highways and rail lines prevent it from breaking into a brisk trot, the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East indicated in its most recent report on transportation there.

New York City is planning the sale of $76,500,000 of serial bonds coming due from 1962 to 1991 and having an average term of slightly more than seven and one-quarter years. The sale will be held on Jan. 24, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.
Bobby Fischer, the defender, and Charles Kalme drew last night in the third round of the United States chess championship.

QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 19 -- Ecuador is determined to hold the Eleventh Inter-American Conference here starting March 1, despite Communist agitation against the meeting, Foreign Minister Jose Ricardo Chiriboga said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 10 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- Soviet planners announced today to the sixth session of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) that spending on defense would be decreased in 1961, but that allocations to science would go up 15 per cent over 1960.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A winter wheat crop of 1,034,406,000 bushels next year was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture. A crop of this size would help increase a record surplus already in existence.
HAVANA, Dec. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro threatened today to ruin any new sugar producers who attempted to take advantage of Cuba's exclusion from the United States market.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A Discoverer satellite designed to measure radiation to aid in detecting nuclear armed missiles was lofted into polar orbit today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Following are the roll-call votes by which the General Assembly rejected today a proposal a nthe Congo question sponsored by six Asian and African nations and Yugoslavia and Ceylon, and one by the United States and Britain. Both required a two-thirds vote for adoption.

Following is the official summary of the twenty-seven recommendations for maximun economic growth in New York State contained in yesterday's final report of the Temporary State Commission on Economic Expansion.
The City Council approved unanimously yesterday a $661,637,663 capital budget for 1961, about 58,000,000 higher than the current capital budget.

A plot 145 by 103 feet at 208 to 218 East Fifteenth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been assembled by William Marx and Jack Goodstein, realty investors and builders. They plan to erect a fourteen-story apartment house on the land.
City agencies disclosed yesterday that they had been finding housing for persons whose apartments were destroyed in the crash of an United Air Lines jet in Brooklyy last Friday.
NEW HAVEN, Dec.20 (AP) -- Heavy black oil washed ashore from Long Island Sound covered a portion of a beach area today.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) cleared $567,000,000, or $2.62 a share, in the ten months ended on Oct. 31, M.J. Rathbone, president, estimated yesterday in a year-end review. This represented an increase of 7.4 per cent over the net earnings of $528,000,000, or $2.46 a share, in the 1959 period.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, who failed to retain their National League baseball championship, still had the best earned-run pitching average in the league in 1960.
A $3,000,000 research and mass production facility for "second and third generation" transistors and other semiconductors was opened yesterday by the General Instrument Corporation.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Democratic county chairmen were nudged into line today behind their state chairman, Michael H. Prendergast.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, Dec, 21 -- The "African" session of the General Assembly adjourned early today as weary diplomats prepared for an eleven-week recess. They planned to return March 7.
The commercial banks found themselves in a "real old-fashioned money squeeze" yesterday as a large percentage of the outstanding reserve-creating checks in collection were paid off.

The annual speed weeks at Daytona Beach, Fla., have been expanded from three to four. This year's activities on the 2.5 mile international speedway will start Feb. 1 and conclude with the 500-mile race for late-model stock cars on Sunday, Feb. 26.
The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reportedly will name a new chief executive officer to replace Clarence Francis within the next few weeks.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- At an annual press luncheon of the Automobile Manufacturers Association here, fifty writers and broadcasters submitted estimates on 1961 auto and truck production. The consensus was 6,133,000 cars and 1,064,000 trucks and buses.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The Government announced today plans for a radical reorganization of the administration of the nationalized railroad system and other undertakings under control of the British Transport Commission.

The Constellation fire, following close on the heels of the airplane crashes, has brought tragedy and human suffering to the city that stagger comprehension. The hundreds of millions of dollars in property losses are a minor matter compared with the human losses involved. And there is bitter irony in the way the events came about.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- East and West German trade officials met in East Berlin for two and a half hours today in an attempt to break the deadlock over renewal of the East-West German trade pact. Another meeting in East Berlin was scheduled for tomorrow, a West German spokesman said.
The Beech Aircraft Corporation registered a 22.3 per cent gain in earnings for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 on a sales gain of 10.4 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of a Millburn housewife who did not yield a telephone party line to a physician in an emergency.

The directors of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., voted yesterday to resume payment of dividends on the common stock after a two-and-a-half-year interruption. They declared a dividend of 25 cents a share, payable on Feb. 15 to stockholders of record of Jan. 12.
The Temporary State Commission on Economic Expansion, which filed its final report with Governor Rockefeller yesterday, was authorized by the Legislature in January, 1959.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Bernie Geoffrion and Dick Moore of the Montreal Canadiens and Frank Mahovlich of the Toronto Maple Leafs are staging a mass bid for the National Hockey League's record for goals scored in a single season.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo. TWO months ago Leopoldville was a ghost town. Walking down the main street of town, one felt like stopping an occasional pedestrian and asking, "Pardon me, but where are the people?"

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Following is a transcript of a joint news conference conducted today by President-elect John F. Kennedy, Vice President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson, House Speaker Sam Rayburn and Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the prospective Senate majority leader:

TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- Most New Jersey residents who have automobile collision insurance will find their premiums reduced when their current policies expire, as a result of a rate revision approved today.
Scientists have taken the measure of earth's largest conceivable resonant cavity.

President-elect John F. Kennedy deplored yesterday what he termed the flabbiness of American youth. He called it "a menace to our security as well as our ability to live up to the challenges which lie ahead."

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Robert H. Morse, 82 years old, chairman of Canadian Fairbanks, Morse Co., Ltd., and a director for forty-eight years, has resigned from the family concern because of what he said was a conflict in interest.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Selective demand for industrial shares and a virtual absence of selling pressure gave the stock market here a cheerful tone today. However, the turnover was the slackest for a normal day since July 23, 1958.
"The Night They Raided Minsky's" is to become a musical. Leonard Key acknowledged yesterday he was on the verge of acquiring the rights to Rowland Barber's book, published last May by Simon Schuster.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly approved by a wide margin late tonight a resolution postponing elections in Ruanda-Urundi.
The huge new city-owned waterfront terminal under construction at Houston Street on the Hudson River will cost $19,041,030.44, within 1.5 per cent of original estimates made three years ago.

CONTRACT bridge was once most played as an after-dinner diversion of married couples and a time-killer of collegians. In recent years it has recruited almost as many disciples from the high-school set.
Eileen Farrell has withdrawn from "The Gershwin Years," a telecast scheduled by the Columbia Broadcasting System network for 8 P.M., Jan. 15. Maurice Chevalier has joined the cast of the production.

National League baseball fans, who have been suffering from a great void in New York these past three years, won't have to wait until 1962 to get their first glimpse of tfye Giants since their onetime favorites hightailed to San Francisco in 1958.
Long-term loans totaling $22,800,000 to Japanese steel interests -- including $13,000,000 advanced by the Internation Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- were announced here yesterday.
A meeting of the Bronx County Republican executive committee has been called for tomorrow to designate Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Joseph as county chairman.

OTTAWA, Dec. 20 -- Finance Minister Donald Fleming presented a supplementary budget tonight designed to stimulate Canada's economy through incentives. It also gave a tax advantage to Canadian companies over their United States competitors.

Redemptions of mutual fund shares are on the rise -- gradually. George A. Mooney, executive director of the National Association of Investment Companies, offers a reason why. The gradual increase in dollar amounts of redemptions is attributed by him to the fact that investors who purchased shares on ten or fifteen-year periodic plans have completed their missions.
The threat of an advertising tax has been posed in the battle over school integration in New Orleans.
Machinery to avert the biennial New Year's Eve transit labor crisis on city-owned bus and subway lines was created yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. F.E. Brown's Red Jack closed fast and scored an upset victory in the feature race at Tropical Park today. Crafty Skipper was second and the heavily favored Board Man finished third.

Consolidation of the State Street Bank and Trust Company, Boston, with the Rockland-Atlas National Bank of Boston has been agreed to by directors of both institutions. The union, which must be approved by stockholders and Massachusetts and Federal authorities, would create the second largest bank in New England.

The Rangers yesterday brought up Danny Belisle, a 23-year-old left wing, from Vancouver of the Western Hockey League. Belisle will make his National Hockey League debut tonight when the New Yorkers meet the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden.

THIS is the twelfth and final season as a pro football coach for Lawrence Timothy (Buck) Shaw. On Monday he will mastermind his Philadelphia Eagles against the Green Bay Packers in the championship play-off and call it a career. Thus, he will join in retirement another distinguished and admirable gentleman, Jim Lee Howell of the Giants.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 20 -- The military regime banned today all commercial flights to Stanleyville. The move was designed to tighten the military regime's blockade of Oriental Province, which is controlled by followers of Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20 -- Earnings of Webb Knapp, Inc., for 1960 will be somewhat higher than last year's, William Zeckendorf, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today. The realestate concern had net income of $1,026,984 in 1959, after allowing for a tax credit of $399,414.

SOME more fantastic stuff about the trout fishing in Southern Argentina has come to town, and it is getting pretty discouraging. How can a man get any fun out of a teninch brook trout after hearing about these monstrous, uneducated fish?

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 -- The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to hold the Louisiana Lieutenant Governor and two other top officials in contempt of court for having withheld salaries of teachers in New Orleans' integrated schools.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. charged, yesterday that slipshod safety precautions and the use of wooden planks on scaffolding had contributed to the forty-eight deaths and $75,000,000 damage in the fire that raked the aircraft carrier Constellation.
Following is the text of a radio and television address by President Charles de Gaulle yesterday as made available in New York by the French Information Service:
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A strike may close the Santa Anita race track the day after it opens its season next Monday.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 20 -- The Federal Government should make capital grants of $300,000,000 to $350,000,000 for urban renewal in each of the next six years, Senator Prescott Bush said today, and $200,000,000 more should be made available for distribution in the period at the discretion, of the President.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The General Assembly elected Liberia tonight to a seat on the United Nations Security Council. She will be the first sub-Saharan African state to serve in the Council.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The National Football League championship is at stake, but the Green Bay Packers, the champions of the Western Conference, are acting as if the play-off with the Philadelphia Eagles next Monday is just another game.

"The Tribe That Lost Its Head," Nicholas Monsarrat's best-selling novel of racial conflict in Africa, will be filmed next summer by Samuel Bronston, producer, Philip Yordan, writer, and Nicholas Ray, director, the three men responsible for "The King of Kings."

Some city planners and "narrow special interests" are effectively blocking the city's $52,000,000 mid-Manhattan garage program, the Automobile Club of New York charged yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Benjamin Atwood Smith 2d of Gloucester was selected as Senator from Massachusetts today to succeed his Harvard roommate, President-elect John F. Kennedy.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Edward Lamb said today his offer to buy 45,000 shares of Seiberling Rubber Company stocks at $13 a share was "well oversubscribed."
The Beekman-Downtown Hospital gave its Thirty-ninth annual Christmas party yesterday. About 400 underprivileged children who were patients there during the year attended.

The Columbia Broadcasting System is contemplating another change in format for "Face the Nation," a public affairs program televised on Mondays from 10:30 to 11 P.M.

THE Defense Department is acquiring a sailor, missile enthusiast and former Air Force official as its deputy secretary. He is Roswell Leavitt Gilpatric, who showed no hesitatation in speaking out with a directness that sometimes shocked politcally minded colleagueswhen he last held office in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A reply by the State Department to President Eisenhower's recent order to all departments to reduce overseas spending contains a negative answer to an awkward question implied by his directive.

The Portsmouth Corporation formerly the Portsmouth Steel Corporation, and the beneficial owner of more than 10 per cent of the common shares of the Detroit Steel Corporation, has reduced its holdings in the company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Grain futures prices headed for higher ground at the opening of the Board of Trade today and never changed direction. It was one of the broadest general advances of the month.
LAST night's half-hour film, "The Coming of Christ," is a work of permanence, a program of exceptional beauty and reverence that will rank as one of television's lasting accomplishments.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- In his last Christmas greeting to the armed forces as their Commander in Chief, President Eisenhower also sent thanks to them in behalf of their fellow Americans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration plans to ask Congress next month for technical tax legislation that may serve incidentally as an effective alternative to withholding levies on dividend and interest payments.

Signs of the approaching Christmas festival multiplied hourly yesterday in a city decked with evergreens and festive lights in most public places. For the city's children, especially those in need, the merriment mounted at holiday parties.

HOUSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- George E. Barnes, the president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said today that as long as Barry MacKay and Earl (Butch) Buchholz wanted to make a career of tennis he was happy they had a place to practice it.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Promoter Bill Fugazy said today that the third heavyweight title match between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson would be held between March 14 and April 3 at Miami, Los Angeles or New York.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- An automotive development that may portend the end of conventional accelerator and brake pedals was demonstrated here today by the Bendix Corporation.

One of four men suspended by the Department of Real Estate after being accused of taking graft has refused to give financial information to the State Investigation Commission and has resigned. He is Joseph Coulon, whose resignation as chief caretaker in the maintenance division was accepted and announced by Real Estate Commissioner Ferdinand Roth yesterday morning.
CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- The Begum A. Ali Khan fingered a corner of her sari and talked of editorials, type, circulation and a need for a printing press.

Many industrial stocks scored good gains yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and the word among many observers was that the "year-end rally is rolling again." The resumption of the forward movement came after a brief period of indecisive backing and filling.
Since early this month, community groups by the hundreds have been singing Christmas carols along the festooned malls and promenades of highway shopping centers in the suburbs.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- In the final intercollegiate athletic activities at the United States Military Academy until after the holidays, Army defeated De Pauw University in basketball, 78 to 68, and overwhelmed Pennsylvania, 11 to 0, in hockey today.
The Brooklyn Museum, which last month had the highest attendance for any November in its sixty-three years, will close two days a week beginning with the new year.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Warriors repulsed fourth-period attack and downed the New York Knickerbockers, 122 -- 117, in a pulsed a fourth-period attach National Basketball Association game at the Garden tonight.

Kim Stanley and Steven Hill have been tagged to co-star in "Far Country," which deals with Dr. Sigmund Freud and the origin of psychoanalysis. Miss Stanley will impersonate Dr. Freud's first patient to receive that particular form of medical aid, while Mr. Hill will portray Dr. Freud at the age of 35.
The final minutes of the two airliners that collided here last Friday were reconstructed last night with the publication of a moment-by-moment record of plane-ground radio messages.
Damage claims on the crash of two airliners here Friday may have to be paid by the Federal Government if investigations show that Government employes were negligent.

A contract for the building of a 23,000-ton, $15,000,000 passenger liner that will be the largest ship to fly the Israeli flag has been signed in Paris by the Zim Israel Navigation Company and a leading French shipyard.

SAN JUAN P.R. DRESSING the home for Christmas can be a problem on an island where snow is a fairy tale for children and winter is something the tourists come to escape. But the lack of a frosty landscape does not deter the Puerto Ricans -- for weeks now, the inhabitants have been decking their homes and gardens in preparation for the day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although I agree wholeheartedly with your commendation of Arthur J. Goldberg, I disagree just as strongly with your objection to his appointment as Secretary of Labor because, as you put it, "he is intimately identified with one of the two sides in the constant tug-of-war which he will be required to referee."

Inventories of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes, had their sharpest drop of the season in the week ended last Friday, reflecting the unusually severe weather prevalent recently throughout the nation.

Buying picked up appreciably in the city's big stores and their suburban branches yesterday. There are now three shopping days left until Christmas -- today, tomorrow and Saturday -- which is Christmas Eve.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 -- Barry MacKay and Earl Buchholz, American Davis Cup team stars, today signed three-year professional contracts at $50,000 each and took a slap at "hypocrisy" in amateur tennis.

OTTAWA, Dec. 21 -- Experts studying the complex budget speech of Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance, suggested today that Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Government had embarked on a course of discouraging the inflow of foreign capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Ambassador Avraham Harman of Israel assured the United States Government yesterday and today that Israel's new nuclear reactor being built near Beersheba would not be used to make an atomic bomb.
Plans to establish a major research center that may develop into a $40,000,000 project within ten years were announced yesterday by New York University.

An American edition of Karl Jaspers' philosophical work that won the German Peace Prize at the 1958 Frankfurt Book Fair will be published Jan. 24 by the University of Chicago Press. It will be called "The Future of Mankind."

ONE way to keep the children quiet during the hectic days before Christmas is to have them wrap presents. Even if only the materials on hand are used, this creative venture can produce imaginatively trimmed gifts at little expense.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 21 -- Finland's entry into the European Free Trade Association as an associate member has been delayed while special precautions are studied to make sure that Soviet influence is kept out.

The radio signals that locate the Preston aircraft holding pattern over the New Jersey shore were operating normally when two airliners collided here last Friday, the head of the Federal Aviation Agency declared yesterday.

The New York Rangers salvaged a tie from what seemed to be certain defeat last night at Madison Square Garden. With six forwards on the ice, Andy Hebenton whipped the disc past Glenn Hall of the Chicago Black Hawks and gained the Blues a 2-2 National Hockey League deadlock.
A sharp drop in temperatures last night iced the streets and made driving hazardous here. The Weather Bureau predicted a low of 15 degrees this morning.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For quite some time the pension system of the fire fighters of this city has been under continual attack, due to your editorial sniping.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The Army denied today that it had "retaliated" against the Johns Hopkins University for releasing without clearance data on studies critical of national security policies.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company celebrated its sixtieth year with the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report issued for publication today for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Advisers to President-elect John F. Kennedy have drafted recommendations for expansion of public-welfare and public-works programs to help meet problems of the country's economically depressed areas.
Cecil Smith of San Antonio, long one of the game's stars, and Bob Skene of San Mateo and Menlo Park, Calif., remain as high goal polo's top players at ten goals.
Traffic through the Welland Canal in the second season of the St. Lawrence Seaway increased by 6.9 per cent, according to preliminary statistics released yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- The selection of Benjamin A. Smith 2d as caretaker of the Senate seat occupied for the last eight years by President-elect John P. Kennedy has created a stir among Massachusetts Democrats.
The memory of two young persons who died in last Friday's airliner collision over New York City was honored yesterday through contributions to New York's Neediest Cases.

A report to Mayor Wagner yesterday pictured the city's Department of Marine and Aviation as a sprawling agency with deficient management tools, an archaic accounting system and a commissioner overburdened with detail.

"Extensive irregularities" in the letting and the performance of $5,500,000 worth of city contracts held by the Broadway Maintenance Corporation were charged yesterday by the State Investigation Commission.

Mayor Wagner gave further indications yesterday of his interest in the revolt against the Democratic party leadership in attending a two-hour meeting with reform district leaders at the home of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman at 820 Park Avenue.
Ralph Howe of Yale, seeded No. 2, moved through the first two rounds in straight sets as the University Club's annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament opened yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Edith Summerskill, Parliament's most persistent opponent of boxing, went down for an early count again today in the House of Commons.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Alan Rozycki, a Dartmouth halfback, tonight was named the winner of the fifteenth annual Swede Nelson Sportsmanship Award for football.

Electric power production rose to a record in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Output was 5,021,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 14,604,000,000 the week before and 14,150,000,000 in the comparable 1950 period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Organization of American States decided today to postpone until Jan. 4 a vote on the question of imposing limited economic sanctions against the Dominican Republic.

Under the system that alternates annual openings of the harness-racing Season, between Roosevelt and Yonkers raceways, Yonkers will open the 1961 season on Monday, March 20. The track will have a split season of 105 nights.
Governor Rockefeller disclaimed yesterday any thought of imposing a statewide retail sales tax in New York.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following reports and weather forecast at 10 A.M. today:
HARTFORD, Dec. 21 -- Theodore S. Ryan of Sharon was prominently mentioned today as a possible successor to Meade Alcorn as a member of the Republican National Committee from Connecticut.

The election of four new senior vice presidents in the international department has been announced by the Chase Manhattan Bank. They are William S. DuBols, Louis A. Albarracin, James A. Jacobson and John Watts.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Stock market prices remained firm here today, although trading remained at low ebb.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- Barring a last-minute hitch, an agreement on the continuation of East-West German trade was imminent tonight, according to authoritative sources.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The staff of a House investigating committee cleared Thomas G. Corcoran today of any impropriety in his approaches to the Federal Power Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- An Irish general has been named the new commander of the United Nations military force striving to keep peace in the Congo.
Outright repeal or sweeping revision of the state's Condon-Wadlin Law was urged yesterday by spokesmen for municipal employes.
THE Lenox Quartet showed in its program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, that it is one of the finest string quartets this country has yet produced.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Roger Newman of Kentucky scored 24 points tonight and led his team to an 83-78 victory over Illinois in the first round of the University of Kentucky invitation basketball tournament.

HAVANA, Dec. 21 -- The Cuban Government decreed today a purge and reorganization of its judicial system, including the Supreme Court. Premier Fidel Castro had promised that this would be accomplished with a "surgical knife."
DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- Top leaders of the automobile industry said in year-end statements that they expected new car sales in 1961 to match or exceed those of 1960.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 21 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that Israel was building a nuclear reactor for peaceful uses.
The American tanker Pine Ridge broke in two in mountainous seas 109 miles off Cape Hatteras shortly before noon yesterday.
Anyone with an eye for irony needs only to scratch the surface of the National Football League's final statistics for 1960 to find a bonanza lode of the stuff.

LIKE a million other women at this time of year, Judith Friedberg has had her fill of shopping. After circling the globe twice in one year, in pursuit of the best sources for wares and repairs in more than fifty countries, she is now content to rest on her laurels and admire her loot.

TOO scrupulous an adherence to the original plot drained much of the drama from the movie of the 1960 world series between the Pirates and the Yankees. A luncheon preview yesterday of this cinematic thriller proved highly satisfactory in every respect, pictorially and artistically. But the script produced no twist ending to heighten the impact.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An advertisement on Page 2 of The Times of Dec. 18 is frightening and puzzling to me. The notice from a prominent New York jewelry house, offers "the woman who has everything ***" an automatic coffee maker, "rendered in 14-carat gold with 250 diamonds and 150 rubies" for $50,000!

"Stock of the day, beautiful stock"to paraphrase a song in Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass" -- was American Telephone and Telegraph yesterday. Big and conservative though the company is, its shares have been among the most active and strongest this year.
Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, director of the state Civil Defense Commission, will retire from that post in January.

History goes on repeating itself in the Cuban Revolution. Yesterday's decree dismissing seventeen Supreme Court justices and laying the grounds for a reform of the judiciary is typical of what has happened in almost every modern social revolution. The French Revolution had Robespierre's famous "Law of the 22d Prairial," which gave a wide definition to political crimes.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The opposition to President de Gaulle's Algerian policy gained new recruits today. The Radical party executive committee decided to campaign against the President in the referendum scheduled for Jan. 8.
One of the city's nonprofit hospitals is losing its entire staff of resident physicians and internes because they failed last September's examination for graduates of foreign medical schools.
A court order designed to block the election of a Bronx Republican leader by the executive committee of the Bronx County Committee was obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam.
EVERYONE seemed to have problems in today's deal, which was played at rubber bridge in New York last week.

Alva Rosenberg of New York cast his memory as a dog show judge back fifty years yesterday and said that things were better now. He spoke before the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club in Luchow's Restaurant. There were fewer breeds, fewer, shows and easier requirements, for dogs gaining championship stat- ure then than now, he said.
James M. Symes, who could be excused for looking with some distaste on railroad merger projects, is full of enthusiastic plans for them.

A Navy court of inquiry heard yesterday that there had been forty-two fires this year aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation before last Monday's disastrous blaze that killed forty-nine civilian workmen.

The Soviet Union is encountering considerable production difficulties in its shipyards, but nevertheless will fulfill the program of doubling the 1958 size of its merchant fleet by 1965, an analyst of Soviet marine engineering said yesterday.

Maritime labor -- 150,000 strong -- prepared yesterday for negotiations this spring on new contracts with 300 employers who operate 90 per cent of the nation's passenger, cargo and tanker ships. The unionists were in a fighting mood.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Four hundred residents here today protested the Board of Education's banning of a creche depicting the Nativity scene on the grounds of the Hartsdale Junior High School.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A trade agreement fixing the wholesale and retail prices of British automobiles and commercial vehicles was declared void today by Britain's Restrictive Practices Court. The court held that the agreement was "contrary to the public interest."
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 -- Louisiana segregationists were set back on two fronts today.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 21 -- Documents purporting to show that Cuba had paid for pro-Castro activities in Peru have fallen into the hands of anti-Castro Cubans.
The commodity futures markets were in the pre-holiday doldrums yesterday on the New York exchanged. Trading was light and prices generally were lower or irregular.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The National Executive of the British Labor party met today for the last time this year in what a participant described as an atmosphere of personal feuding and ideological division.

The election of Robert V. Lindsay, F. Frith Pickslay Jr., John P. Glorieux, Richard W. Meyer, Ferdinand H. Brewer and Theodore H. Mengel Jr. as vice presidents has been announced by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
Richmond, Va., raised $7,580,000 in the bond market yesterday on tax-secured bonds to finance public improvements.
ALGERIA, Dec. 20 -- The problems of peace in Algeria are beginning to preoccupy the Administration here.
Activity in the bond market slackkened yesterday with the approach of the Christmas holiday week-end. Prime risk obligations of all classifications were in good demand and prices tended upward.
Salary increases for the city's 40,000 public school teachers and supervisors will be proposed today by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Royal Air Force's Fighter Command is to come under the control of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Harold Watkinson, Defense Minister, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Eisenhower advised Douglas Dillon not to accept the Treasury portfolio in the Kennedy Cabinet unless he were promised a free hand in fiscal and monetary policies.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the ruling made today by the United States District Court on school segregation issues in Louisiana:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- The Soviet Union denounced United States actions today but expressed hope that President-elect John F. Kennedy will have "a more positive policy" on issues before the United Nations than did the Eisenhower Administration.

Twenty-four policemen accused of holding outside jobs moved in Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction to postpone their departmental trials until the courts had ruled on the validity of the department's ban.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today it was ordering construction of an all-purpose satellite to serve as a "street car" for carrying a load of experiments into space.
THERE is probably no drink in America as celebrated as eggnog. It came into being during colonial days and the name apparently derives from a small drinking vessel known as a noggin.

A group of buildings and six and one-half acres of land on Lawrence Street, east of Route 1, in Rahway, N.J., have been Bold by the Mantrose Corporation of New York. They were acquired by Construction Programming, Inc., headed by George Siegler, a Jersey City builder.

The National Foreign Trade Council issued a sharp warning yesterday against moves to remedy the United States' foreign payments deficit by restrictions on long-term private American investment abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 14:
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- King Saud has taken over political control of oil-rich Saudi Arabia from Crown Prince Faisal, his brother, a broadcast by the Mecca radio announced tonight.
BEGINNING Dec. 29, New Jersey deer hunters will have three extra days of hunting to compensate for time lost in last week-end's blizzard and to reduce the large herd.
Michael Daroff has been elected president and chief executive officer of Botany Industries, Inc., succeeding A.M. Sonnabend, who will remain as chairman.

AMONG the thousands of people who made Gloria Swanson the image of a dream, a few decades ago, 400 gathered yesterday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Coney Island to hear her describe her fashion philosophy.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- North Carolina State withstood a rally and beat La Salle College, 71-68, in a basketball game tonight at the Palestra.
The 397 Realty Corporation, Paul Gardiner secretary, has purchased the five-story tenement house at 534 East Eighty-ninth Street near East End Avenue.
PALM BEACH, Pla., Dec. 21 -- Roswell L. Gilpatric, a New York lawyer, was designated today as Deputy Secretary of Defense by President-elect John F. Kennedy.

With the Security Council paralyzed by Soviet vetoes and the General Assembly adjourned in deadlock, the United Nations has been unable to take any new action on the Congo. It thus records a double failure of both of its two decisive branches, despite Secretary General Hammarskjold's warning that the Congo is still threatened with chaos and civil war.

Norm Van Brocklin of the Philadelphia Eagles was honored as the all-National Football League quarterback for the first time in his twelve-season pro career yesterday when he was named to the 1960 United Press International team.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A study issued today by the Department of Commerce said that the expected gain in the United States textile market during the next ten years might be swallowed up by foreign imports.
Book Givers Beware It is no less than a threat to the peace to give a cookbook to a lady who has been working her fingers to the bone, or at least to the second layer of epidermis, in the kitchen.
TOKYO, Dec. 18 -- A favorite joke going around Tokyo has an imaginary Japanese exclaiming, "Kurisumasu (Christmas) has become so popular in Japan that even the foreigners are celebrating it!"

Wooden planks in scaffolding, which had been blamed for contributing to the disastrous fire aboard the new aircraft carrier Constellation, were defended yesterday as indispensable and as not so flammable as critics charged.

DAYTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Dayton outscored Seton Hall, 26 -- 5, in the last ten minutes tonight and sent the Pirates to their first setback in five games, 66 -- 45. Dayton gained its sixth victory against one defeat.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 21 -- This capital, coming out of the shock of last week's revolt, is like a city of errant school children. The teacher, who was out of the room when the mischief occurred, has returned and reasserted his authority.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) off to 3 points (15 cents) up yesterday.
"Nothing imitative can equal that which is imitated. Instead of imitating effects, search for the principle that made them original and own your own effects."

Directors of the Corn Products Company voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend for the second time this year. In addition, the board proposed a two-for-one stock split, William T. Brady, chairman, announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- From the time in 1934 when President Roosevelt appointed Joseph P. Kennedy to protect private investor and public interest as a member subsequently elected Chairman of the new Securities and Exchange Commission, members of the President-elect's family have brought high administrative and personal standards to the public offices they have held.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Though outwardly the movie industry is serene, even cheerful, about the future this Christmas season, there is considerable concern about a dread word that is gaining popularity outside of Hollywood.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Ed Turville of St. Petersburg, first vice president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, today struck back at comments from Australia by Barry MacKay and Earl Buchholz that suggested "hypocrisy" in amateur tennis.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 21 -- The Government has made strenuous efforts to enforce its apartheid policy, but in practice racial separation breaks down in many ways.

THE rare and wonderful talents of Mexican comedian Cantinflas, who was nicely introduced to the general public as the valet in "Around the World in 80 Days," are pitifully spent and dissipated amid a great mass of Hollywooden dross in the oversized, over-peopled "Pepe," which opened at the Criterion last night.
Good to excellent skiing, except in isolated cases, was the word from winter resort operators yesterday in describing conditions throughout New York State, New England and eastern Canada.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 22 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy resigned as Senator from Massachusetts today.
Here Is a story for Christmas. It did not originate with a press agent. It was told by a mother.

The sugar futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday was one of the dullest in some time. Only 600 tons of world sugar changed hands, while prices moved 1 point (hundredth of a cent a pound) up to 2 points off.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell was chosen today to head a Presidential commission to seek a solution to labor-management disputes over rail-road work rules.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 22 -- (AP) -- Vince Lombardi, the Green Bay coach, smiled a little when he looked at the weight chart for the Philadelphia Eagles, the Packers' opponent in Monday's National Football League championship game at Philadelphia.

THE gift for a "difficult" person on the Christmas shopping list often is left to the last minute. Those still in a quandary as to what to buy might take a peek in Quai Voltaire's windows at 1048 Third Avenue near Sixty - second Street.
The four top-seeded players in the University Club's invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament moved into the semi-final round yesterday.

For the first time the budget request for New York City's schools has exceeded a halfbillion dollars. The expense budget for 1961-62, submitted yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald, asked for $512,938,523.

EDGARD VARESE was born on Dec. 22, 1885. Last night he was given a birthday, party at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The 75-year-old composer was present-gray-suited, sturdy, pugnacious-looking, gray hair bristling, strong chin outthrust.

A new Radio Corporation of America device smaller than a postage stamp may pave the way for virtually jam-proof military and commercial radio and other communications, R.C.A. said yesterday in announcing what it termed a greatly improved "varactor" diode.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has notified Mayors of cities with local-service airlines that they may lose their air service.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, following its Christmas-time custom, is distributing cowhide wallets and honorary membership cards to various New Yorkers.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Despite the continued quiet trading here today there was sufficient demand in the stock market to lift most industrials modestly.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers and the Baltimore Colts dominate the West team selected today to play the East in the annual pro bowl football game in Memorial Coliseum Jan. 15.
The New York Post Office was confronted yesterday with the heaviest flood of Christmas man on record.
The Yankees will make one of their earliest spring training getaways in years. They'll start flexing their muscles in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Feb. 13.
A little girl in Arkansas, discouraged because Santa Claus never learned where she lived, has written the New York Police Department to find out if Santa is still alive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A group of advisers to President-elect John F. Kennedy Is carefully straddling the ticklish issue of protectionist restrictions on foreign imports.
BULLETIN: Santa Claus is a year older than he was before the current issue of American Heritage appeared.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Dec. 17 were 4 per cent below the year-ago level. Heavy snowstorms in the East last week kept shoppers home, it was noted.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points down to 7 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Registered private-duty nurse here will raise their fee e Jan. 1 from $18 to $20 f an eight-hour day.
Net income of the Dana Corporation fell 42 per cent in the quarter ended on Nov. 30 on an 8.8 per cent drop in sales, the company reported yesterday.
There was much ado about Shakespeare yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Board of Education.
NEWARK, Dec. 22 -- The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark today announced plans for a $36,000,000 construction program to provide seven new high schools and four homes for the aged.

The National Association of Manufacturers warned yesterday that compulsory arbitration of labor-management disputes would "drain much of the vigor and urge to progress from the American enterprise system."

Bankers seldom are accused of behaving as if they believed in Santa Claus. Yet not a few look forward to Christmas with something of the anticipation of an 8-year-old. For the week before Christinas traditionally is a time when banks pass out executive promotions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Dr. Herbert F. York, Defense Department director of research and engineering, has agreed to stay on for a "limited period" after the Administration changes hands Jan. 20.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway decided yesterday to accept further tenders of common and preferred shares of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad through Feb. 2 of next year. At the same time, it proposed to "sweeten" the exchange offer for those B. O. stockholders who already had tendered their stock and others who did so between now and the Feb. 2 closing of the extension offer.

Following British protests over the Ford deal, Canada now appears to have embarked on a policy of discouraging a further inflow of foreign, principally American, capital by eliminating special tax incentives. This action adds another warning that the time has come to readjust American investments abroad not only to the American balance of payments but also to the political sensibilities and necessities of the countries concerned.

JEAN GABIN, no less, gives poor, suffering Stella Dallas some portly competition in "Rue de Paris" a Lopert Films release. In view of the almost continual parade of Gabin films from France, it's too bad the gifted film veteran isn't on view in a top entry over the holidays.
The Federal Aviation Agency indicated yesterday it planned no change in its air traffic control system around New York as a result of the collision of two airliners last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Israeli Government has now officially denied that it has other than peaceful purposes for the nuclear reactor it is building, with the assistance of France, in secrecy so deep that United States intelligence was led to believe the installation was a textile plant.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- A last-minute hitch in the East-West German trade talks today delayed a settlement, which had been expected to be reached before Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An important new clue on the effect of solar weather upon the earth has been obtained by the discovery that a severe solar storm in November disrupted the orbit of the Echo balloon satellite.
HONOLULU, Dec. 22 -- Circuit Judge Ronald B. Jamieson impounded ballots today in the recount of Hawaii's vote in the general election of Nov. 8 after a marked specimen ballot had been found.

WHEN appetites are surfeited from the Thanksgiving turkey, a goose or a couple of ducks can make a welcome and delicious change, especially for a Christmas-time dinner. Those who find the dark meat of the turkey to their taste should be especially happy to see a golden goose or duck adorning the holiday table.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 22 -- The Venezuelan Government and Reynolds Metals Company signed a contract today providing for the construction of a $30,000,000 primary aluminum plant in this country. The plant will be 50 per cent owned by Reynolds and 50 per cent by a company owned by the Government through a concern to be called ALCOSA.

A syndicate of investors represented by Jacob Schneider, Englewood lawyer, has bought Magnolia Terrace, an apartment house for sixty families at South Washington and Magnolia Avenues in Bergenfield, N.J. The building was completed in June by Masol Associates, the seller.
Conflicting testimony was given yesterday on who had accidentally knocked the plug out of a huge cylinder of Diesel fuel on the aircraft carrier Constellation last Monday.

The third -- and probably the last -- meeting between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson for the world heavyweight title is set for March 20, a Monday night, in the 18,000-seat Miami Beach Convention Hall.
ROME, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an English translation, made by the Vatican press office, of the 1960 Christmas message of Pope John XXIII:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today that sugar normally supplied by Cuba would be obtained largely from the Philippine Republic, Peru, the Dominican Republic and Mexico.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 22 -- The head of the United Nations' civilian operations here warned today that "thousands" of tribesmen were in danger of starving to death daily in southern Kasai Province if no largescale aid was organized.
The City Stores Company, which owns the Franklin Simon and Oppenheim, Collins specialty stores, operated in the red during the thirty-nine weeks ended on Oct. 29.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- The most dramatic conflict in the movie business -- the power struggle between talent agencies and movie studios for domination of the industry -- has been illustrated by one man's change of jobs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The State Department said tonight it now felt that the construction of Israel's nuclear reactor "does not represent a cause for special concern."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Dec. 17 "From the Treasury Down" deserves the most careful reading. Many of your readers will share your approbation of the appointment of Douglas Dillon as Secretary of the Treasury and also your apprehension over the appointment of Robert Kennedy a Attorney General.
FROM a child's viewpoint, the days just before Christmas may be sheer anguish and not the sugar-plum anticipation most adults would like to imagine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The North American Defense Command credited its Canadian deputy commander today with sound thinking and action in handling a false alarm from a missile-warning station. But it disputed a published report that this "averted what could have been a nuclear disaster."

There were crosscurrents, eddies and undertows in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. For largely technical reasons, most of them connected with the year-end evening-up process, stocks as a whole closed down.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures virtually ceased after a brief early flurry today and prices closed generally with only minor changes.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin, the star passer of the Philadelphia Eagles, said today that reports that he can't throw in cold weather or in snow or rain are "ridiculous."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Tom Kieffer of St. Louis sank a 15-foot, one-handed shot with four seconds left in overtime as the Billikens defeated Kentucky, 74-72, tonight. The victory gave St. Louis the eighth annual University of Kentucky invitation basketball tournament championship.
In many parts of the nation, power boats get better treatment than they do in harbors of Long Island Sound. They are pampered and protected.

For the last five weeks Kermit Bloomgarden, producer of "The Wall," has been making a major contribution to the long-advocated concept that tomorrow's audience should and could be developed from the school youth of today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- The Government today charged four major carbon dioxide manufacturers and four company officials with criminal contempt of a 1952 antitrust judgment, which barred price-fixing and other destructive activities.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Tropical Park daily double paid $2,347.20 today and only two of the twenty-one persons who held winning tickets would give their names when they cashed their tickets.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Engelhard of New York and Far Hills, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Morton Downey of New York gave a dinner dance last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the Misses Catherine Hohenlohe, Anne Alexandre and Louise R. Pierrepont, debutantes of the season.

Although he may not see It fulfilled, Willing B. Foulke, a 62-year-old chemical engineering consultant and former employe of E.I.du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has an ambitious eighty-three-year installment plan to solve a du Pont problem.

Twelve thousand persons stood at attention yesterday in the New York Naval Shipyard while taps were sounded for the forty-nine workmen killed in the fire that swept the aircraft carrier Constellation Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The United States Government said today that it felt "serious concern" about continuing Communist military aid flowing into Laos for the pro-Communist rebels there.

Buck Shaw and Norm Van Brocklin, who plan to end their pro football careers while they're on top, yesterday were named the National Football League coach and player of the year, respectively, in the annual United Press International poll.
Cabaret owners, like Broadway producers, are complaining this holiday season, that business is off.

HAVANA, Dec. 19 -- The two boys silhouetted in the seventh-floor window of the luxury National Hotel pushed, pulled and tugged at the strange slats and strings. For more than ten minutes they were agitated figures in a pantomine.
ATHENS, Dec. 22 -- The 25,000-ton Niarchos motor tanker World Hope was launched today at the Hellenic Shipyard at Skarmanga near Athens by Mrs. Konstantin Karamalis, the wife of the Greek Premier.

Bobby Fischer, the 17-year-old defending champion, played Samuel Reshevsky, the seasoned grandmaster, to a twenty-four-move draw last night in the fourth round of the United States chess championship at the Empire Hotel.

Firemen, driven to the raw edge of exhaustion in the last two weeks by a succession of disasters unmatched in Fire Department history, were called out again yesterday to fight two big blazes in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A record number of taxpayers paid record Federal income taxes this year on record earnings in 1959.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Dec. 5 you had a story on report on space law submitted through the American Bar Foundation to the National Aeronautics an Space Administration. The stoi needs three qualifications.
Samuel Baron, who has won an enviable reputation here as a flutist, appeared last night as a conductor. He led the New York Chamber Orchestra in its first concert at Town Hall.

EAT, drink and be merry for tomorrow we diet -- well, perhaps not until after the holidays. Meanwhile the shops are laden with Christmas fare, with enticing price tags on such seasonal delights as turkeys and hams.

CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- Chittagong is slowly recovering from the vast devastation left by the cyclone and tidal wave of early November that killed at least 10,000 persons and damaged or destroyed nearly 400,000 dwellings.
A wide demand for debt securities of investment grade kept the money market and bond market strong yesterday.

The importance of the health of the President of the United States is discussed in a forthcoming book by Dr. Rudolph Marx.
