ALGIERS, Dec. 26 -- Clashes between Europeans and Moslems killed one person in Oran today as the referendum campaign opened, on President de Gaulle's policy of autonomy and self-determination for Algeria.
The American Civil Liberties Union urged President-elect John F. Kennedy yesterday to take immediate action after his inauguration to stop construction of the Kinzua (Pa.) dam and reservoir.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Neil S. McCarthy's Ole Fols survived a claim of foul today to preserve a neck victory in the $23,950 Palos Verdes Handicap before a crowd of 71,017. It was the largest opening-day turnout in Santa Anita history.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Clarence Manion said on his weekly radio program last night that "socialistic poison" in proposals by President Eisenhower's Committee on National Goals would abolish constitutional government.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The emergence of the new African and Asian states and their entry into the United Nations has produced a fundamental transformation in the world organization.

Three basketball coaches whose teams have not lost a game this season solemnly explained yesterday why they would be eliminated in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden today.
With the cooperation of a student at Columbia University, it is now possible to answer one of the most frequently asked questions in advertising.
HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- A man found dead Saturday at the bottom of a cliff near Marion, N.C., was positively identified today as Dan Wexler, who was wanted here in a slaying, authorities said.

The Harlem Globetrotters, an itinerent group of court jesters, and the New York Knickerbockers, ten somber professionals dying for something to smile about, gave pleasing performances at Madison Square Garden last night.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Pilots and crews of Air France's Boeing 707 fleet, who have been on strike since Dec. 9, announced tonight that they would return to duty tomorrow.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 26 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur has accepted an invitation from Norfolk to place his war mementoes, decorations and papers in a memorial to be established by the city.

Chico Vejar, a Stamford (Conn.) middleweight making his first start in New York since January, 1958, gained a split decision over Jose Gonzalez of Puerto Rico in the feature ten-round bout last night at St. Nicholas Arena.

Ohio State, undefeated in its first six games, led the United Press International college basketball ratings yesterday for the fourth straight week. St. Louis and Duke moved up among the top ten teams.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 -- Lingering guerrilla warfare continues to gnaw at the security of the vital tribal area along India's northeastern frontier.

The nation's economy will begin 1961 slowly and cautiously but pick up steadily in the second half, according to a summary of fourteen leading economist's views issued by the National Industrial Conference Board.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics, after leading throughout, beat Philadelphia, 119-115, tonight and moved two games in front of the Warriors in the National Basketball Association Eastern Division.
About 500 eager young faces were trained on Prof. Paul A. Weiss of the Rockefeller Institute yesterday when he stepped up to his lectern to begin a series of five lectures on the "Living Form."

The Cities Service Company is consolidating all petroleum marketing organizations in the United States into a single unit. Burl S. Watson, chairman of the parent organization, said product marketing operations in the future would be conducted by the Cities Service Oil Company in the thirty-eight states from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic Seaboard.

A fresh surge of traffic deaths marred the holiday yesterday as millions hurried home in the final hours of the three-day Christmas week-end. Early hopes for a relatively low figure faded. Through Sunday night the accident rate had been lower than expected.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Government may move for a reexamination of Bernard Goldfine on the Boston industrialist's competency to stand trial on income tax evasion indictments, United States Attorney Elliott Richardson said tonight.
This has been a good year for business in New York City and the first half of 1961 is expected to be as good or better, according to the Commerce and Industry Association.
Color or race will no longer be listed on the birth certificates of persons born in New York City, starting Jan. 1.
A new $12,000,000 fourteen-story laboratory is planned for New York's research agency for helping to prevent disease and study life's biochemical secrets.

If New York State, by asking bids for a first segment, is trying to prod New York City into beginning construction of the $88,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway, it has good reason. The large benefits to accrue from this project have been recognized for more than twenty years. The cost, to be borne 90 per cent by the Federal Government and 10 per cent by the state, increases with every year's delay.

Eleven doctors on the staff of Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J., and the hospital's chaplain, the Rev. Edward Swiersbinski, recently had a problem that needed a solution. The problem was what to do with the one afternoon a week they had off during the winter months.
PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Leaders of the Right-wing Independent party and the Left-wing Radical party made radio and television appeals today against President de Gaulle's plans for Algeria.
The year 1960 is ending on a happy note for domestic ocean and waterway carriers as a result of a decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A new book by Frank Gibney, called '"The Khrushchev Pattern," is planned for Feb. 3 publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce. The author describes the tactics of the Soviet Premier over the last five years and the switch in plans that resulted in the movement toward "competitive coexistence."

MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Bill Brown of Illinois set a ball-carrying record and plunged for three touchdowns tonight, leading the North to a 41 -- 14 victory over the South in the Shrine's annual college all-star football game.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy held long conferences with key advisers today on plans to expand the United States' exploration of space and to strengthen State Department representation abroad.

Business will improve slightly by mid-year, 1981, according to a majority of credit and financial executives surveyed by the National Association of Credit Management. The 120 executives surveyed represent a cross-section of industrial, wholesaling and financial concerns, the association said.
The hour of decision is approaching for Mayor Wagner, a man notoriously slow in reaching hard decisions. The question is whether he will make war openly against Tammany Hall.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- Japan's national budget for 1961 will be based on an anticipated economic growth of 9.2 per cent in the fiscal year beginning April 1 and ending March 3, 1962, it was decided today by the members of Premier Hayato Ikeda's Cabinet who are concerned with economic affairs.

WHEN the curtain goes up on the second act of "All the Way Home" at the Belasco Theatre, Lillian Gish is discovered sitting primly on a sofa, as the deaf and daft mother of a grown family, the audience applauds before she speaks a word.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters -- Tottenham beat West Ham United today, 3-0, and completed a soccer double over its London rival. The Hotspurs lead the English First Division.
A series of thirty-minute filmed programs depicting the growth of the British Empire over a 500-year period will begin over WPIX (Channel 11) on Jan. 8 at 8:30 P.M.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- President Tito accused the West today of being the principal source of discord in the contemporary world.
The Harlem River finally got its new bridge yesterday.

Scientists, the creators of the nuclear age, are doing a poor job of making the public understand the huge potential benefits and perils of atomic energy, a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The four additional smaller cars introduced in the fall by the Big Three auto manufacturers have not yet made the impact on the market that the original Big Three compacts did a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- One of the steps taken by the Presidest-elect in his advance to the New Frontier has been in the area which, when the Eisenhower Administration set foot there, the Democrats disparagingly referred to as "Madison Avenue."

THIS is the season of the last-minute invitation to the holiday party that sends a woman peering into her closet. She turns a sober eye on her wardrobe and finds a chic top or skirt but, alas, nothing in sight to match.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The incoming Kennedy Administration was urged by an independent liberal group today to take the lead in lifting the United States out of the "fatty mediocrity" into which it said the nation had slipped.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., defeated John Newcombe of Longueville, Australia, in the semi-finals of the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships today.

The flight recorder recovered from the jet airliner in the Dec. 16 mid-air collision here is understood to indicate that the accident occurred no more than one minute after the last message from the plane.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- Beneath the grimy jersey and the bulky padding of many a hardened pro football player there beats a pure undergraduate heart. At least, this was the impression created after the National League play-off.

Victim of Our Age Albert Cadon, the understandably temperamental artist who complained that his ancestral name had been taken over by a chemical company and given to a nylon for use in tires, is just another victim of our mechanical age.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 26 -- The Socialist party demanded tonight that Premier Gaston Eyskens face the crisis of the strikes in Belgium by calling Parliament into session tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- This was the Dutchman's day. Norm Van Brocklin didn't score a point as the Philadelphia Eagles outfinessed the Green Bay Packers for the National Football League championship at Franklin Field on this surprisingly warm and pleasant afternoon. But Van was a towering figure who dominated the proceedings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Women's City Club is one of a number of civic groups which regularly follow developments on each year's capital budget and appear hearings both before the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.
Business machine manufacturers seem to be seeking ground-floor space with store fronts, according to a realty man who played a role in two recent leases of this type.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The likelihood that New York City's municipal colleges may be combined into a new university with a full-scale graduate program is an exciting prospect not only for New Yorkers but for the rest of the nation as well.

The Dravo Pioneer, a tug boat with unconventional maneuverability, will begin towing oil barges in the Philadelphia and Chesapeake Bay areas early in January. The tug has been chartered by the Interstate Oil Transport Company to tow barges with capacities of 30,000 to 40,000 barrels.

"WHERE THE AIR IS CLEAR,"* by Carlos Fuentes, is a volcanic novel of Mexico. The words, like streams of hot lava, pour through various levels of society and illuminate a wonderful country that few tourists and perhaps not all Mexicans know. Reading it is in itself an adventure.

A distinguished economist from Argentina, Rogelio Frigerio, now on a visit to Washington, came down on the side of private investments as a solution for Latin-American ills. If the United States would give more incentives to private investors through tax concessions and insurance against confiscation, we could "prevent more Cubas," Dr. Frigerio believes.
This nation's merchant fleet gained four vessels totaling 104,000 deadweight tons in November, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 26 -- An acting provincial governor and 102 Socialist mayors refused today to carry out new Government measures aimed at smashing the six-day-old strike against Belgium's proposed austerity program.
Friends of New York's Neediest Cases are everywhere. Contributions to the annual appeal on their behalf bear postmarks from near and far.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- The National Football League championship, as well as baseball's supreme crown, now reposes in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 20 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim is having serious difficulty with Iraq's largest minority, the 1,000,000 or so Kurdish tribesmen of the North.

THE shocking toll of automobile accidents that is the grim accompaniment to every holiday week-end was studied exhaustively last night in "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. If chilling visual evidence, undisputed statistics and the advice of police officers have any persuasive force, the program may well help to curtail the carnage by the end of the New Year's holiday.
The realty affiliate of a discount store chain based here has acquired six sites in the Washington, D.C., area to build discount department stores.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants totaling $6,670,000 for research in the humanities and to support scholarly publication in the humanities and social sciences.
The director of a citizen's crime commission said yesterday that many such organizations were worse than useless.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

The first major step toward securing President-elect Kennedy's priority program of domestic legislation will be taken if there is effective action at the opening of the new Congress to "liberalize" the Rules Committee of the House. It now appears that at long last Speaker Rayburn is ready to move in this direction, which is almost the same thing as saying that the effective step will be taken.
HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- Cuba's first group of Soviet tourists arrived in Havana today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The story of how an Air Force captain thought up a gold-saving barter deal came to light today. The deal is part of $5,000,000 underwater cable-laying project for the Atlantic missile range.
Burt Lancaster and Elizabeth Taylor were cited as the best movie performers of 1960 in the annual poll conducted by the trade journal, The Film Daily.
CONTRACT bridge has its odd statistics, like any other competitive game. And it has students of such statistics, who on request and often unprompted will cite the odd statistics.
THIS is the season when traditional family recipes are brought out of safekeeping places and the novice in the kitchen has visions of producing something "as good as mother used to make."

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Dec. 26 -- The pastor of a Roman Catholic church here has told his parishioners that henceforth they must contribute one-tenth of their income before taxes to the support of their church and to charity.

FROM 8 o'clock to about 9:35 last night, nothing much happened at the Metropolitan Opera. Then Richard Tucker, singing "Cielo e mar," brought down the house. Shortly after that, Eileen Farrell and Nell Rankin made stentorian noises in their duet.
MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Greentree Stable's Eurasia, paying $37.60 for $2, won the $11,900 Christmas Handicap today before a crowd of 16,872 at Tropical Park.

Tennessee Williams' next play, "The Night of the Iguana," will be introduced here by Charles Bowden and Ridgely Bullock, according to present plans. Assisting them in the venture will be Violla Rubber, who tested the script last summer at the Coconut Grove Playhouse in Miami, Fla.
Profits from color television sales by the Radio Corporation of America this year will be at least $1,000,000, David Sarnoff, chairman, has desclosed.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 26 -- King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva assumed the chairmanship today of a new Council of Ministers appointed by him to succeed the Nepalese Cabinet he deposed eleven days ago.
A fireman burned in a shipboard explosion in the Canal Zone is trying to have his $102,500 damage suit reviewed by the United States Supreme Court, according to his attorneys.
THERE is gold in "Do Re Mi" -- and some gold bricks, too. But in a tough season for new musicals let us be grateful for one that has not entirely abandoned the amusement standard.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Dec. 26 -- Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Premier, was reported today to be getting favored treatment in prison.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 26 -- The man who killed his two teen-age daughters and committed suicide here yesterday had a record of a previous killing, the police disclosed today.

NOW THE problem is to get a young setter named Pat down to McMinnville, Tenn., by public conveyance, and it looks like the thing has been worked out. But it takes some doing, including rides in an automobile, an airplane, a train and/or truck, and another automobile.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 26 -- The man who killed his two teen-age daughters and committed suicide here yesterday had a record of a previous killing, the police disclosed today.

NOW THE problem is to get a young setter named Pat down to McMinnville, Tenn., by public conveyance, and it looks like the thing has been worked out. But it takes some doing, including rides in an automobile, an airplane, a train and/or truck, and another automobile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- This year's boom in exports to Western Europe and Japan is "closely linked" to continued boom conditions in those countries, the Department of Commerce said today. In other words, the United States' healthy surplus of exports over imports is not yet a permanent fixture.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 24 -- South Africans have recently taken two noteworthy steps toward facing their racial problems.

The producers of Brendan Behan's "The Hostage" petitioned Actors Equity yesterday for "special dispensation" of union rules to continue the play's run off Broadway. A union spokesman said last night that Equity's Council would act on the request at its next meeting Tuesday.

Following are excerpts from an address, "The Moral Un-Neutrality of Science," by Sir Charles P. Snow, prepared for delivery before the American Association for the Advancement of Science in New York yesterday:

MORE caviar is consumed throughout the world in the week before the New Year than at any other time. In the United States, the residents of New York and Los Angeles eat more fresh caviar than those of any other city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Average wholesale prices for the week ended Dec. 20 rose 0.1 per cent, to 119.5 per cent, of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- In a new move to combat the gold drain, Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller urged American business today to make greater use of United States air and sea carriers.

TRIESTE, Italy, Dec. 13 -- The cold north wind hummed around the corners of the hotel, tugged at the hats and coats of pedestrians and whipped the waters of Trieste's harbor into whitecaps that burst against quaysides in a fine spray.

SIR CHARLES PERCY SNOW is a large, bald Englishman whose flinty viewpoints have struck many sparks in his London clubs, the Athenaeum and the Savile. They struck some sparks yesterday, too, when he told American scientists that within a decade some atomic bombs would have been exploded through "accident, or folly or madness."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Bob Gaiters, a New Mexico State University halfback who led the nation's college football players in scoring and rushing this year, was the first draft choice of the New York Giants today.

There was no abatement of the price firmness of basic fixed-income investments yesterday, but activity in the secondary market for United States Government obligations and other prime debt securities slackened to a minimum.
LONDON, Dec, 27 (AP) -- The world's big airline companies are closely watching an argument by two British officials about a jet fuel that one of them calls dangerously explosive.
The number of persons injured in city traffic accidents last week was 945, a decrease of 169 compared with the same period a year ago.

Stocks gave an unimpressive performance on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing about where they opened after bending downward in the early afternoon. The result was a small loss or a small gain, depending on the measure used.
A prominent freight traffic executive will join Hellenic Lines, Ltd., next Tuesday as a director. He is Frank G. Slater, until recently vice president for freight traffic for American Export Lines.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 27 -- Strikers demonstrated in Brussels and other industrial centers today against the Government's austerity program, but public services were partly restored to many parts of Belgium.
The New York Central Railroad cleared $212,007, or 3 cents a share, on its 6,514,024 shares of capital stock last month, but for the first eleven months this year it had a net loss of $2,089,218.

THE Roth-Stone bidding system differs in several respects from the "standard American" system used by most players. Its most dramatic feature, however, is the double of an opponent's overcall, which is not a penalty double as in most systems but is for a takeout.
The existence of a shell of dust about the earth some 600 to 1,000 miles in space was suggested here yesterday at a symposium sponsored by the American Astronautical Society.

The Federation Internationale de I'Automobile has, in the interest of further international competition, created a new formula, the Intercontinental (Formula IC). It has approved six dates and places for such racing in 1961, two in the United States, two in England and two in Italy.

IF you are fond of the songs of Stephen Foster -- and who isn't ? -- "Beautiful Dreamer" assembles a sentimental anthology. Some, like "My Old Kentucky Home" and "Jeannie With the Light Brown Hair," are as familiar as one's childhood prayers.

THE game had ended but the conversation kept flowing without even a timeout to rest a weary tonsil. This was immediately after the Philadelphia Eagles had squeaked past the Green Bay Packers, 17 -- 13, to win the pro football championship, and the hotel headquarters in Philadelphia was jammed with the deeper thinkers of the National Football League.

A plea for the surrounding of engineering with glamour so that it can compete for students on an equal basis with science was made yesterday by Dr. Richard T. Fallen of Michigan State University's School of Engineering.
Warfare among youth gangs in New York will die out in about five years, the head of the city's street club project predicted yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 27 -- Iona of New Rochelle, N.Y., and LeMoyne of Syracuse joined Fairleigh Dickinson University and Long Island University in the semi-final round of the Middle Eastern College Athletic Conference basketball tournament tonight.

From the West Coast comes news that Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, their musical "Camelot" firmly ensconced at the Majestic, will do a musical based on the lite of Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, the famous French couturiere.
Franklin Satterthwaite of Exeter Academy, the titleholder, led the way into the third round of the eleventh annual Metropolitan junior squash racquets championship yesterday.

SOME 6,000 women are in the process of deciding what to wear on the evening of Jan. 20. Invitations to the Inaugural Ball are being mailed today. Each invitation is extended to one person and a guest to attend the ball, which is being held in three places in Washington, the National Guard Armory, the Sheraton-Park Hotel and the Mayflower Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Staff employes of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union have formed their own union-within-the-union to gain better wages and working conditions.
TOKYO, Dec. 24 -- The Japanese Defense Agency is reviewing its second five-year defense plan because of the new United States dollar economy measures.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 27 -- Amid the torrent of statements pouring out about the Belgian strike situation, one Socialist declaration describes the walkout as based on "general dissatisfaction."
The Misses Margot Beatrice Campbell, Ora Otis Hubball and Anne Washington Kinsolving were honored last evening at a dance given on the St. Regis Roof by their parents.
WARSAW, Dec. 27 -- Poland joined today the demand of the Soviet Union for a parley of great powers to consider the "threat to peace in Laos."
YASSIADA, Turkey, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- A court trying members of the former regime of Premier Adnan Menderes began hearing a new case today.

Two states, Oregon and Maryland, have announced proposed capital offerings totaling more than $50,000,000. Oregon said it would seek competitive bids for $30,000,000 of bonds on Jan. 17.. The veterans farm and home obligations will mature from 1976 to 1978.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- The average New Yorker paid $146 in local taxes last year, in addition to his state and Federal payments.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 27 -- A conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will take place in Caracas on Jan. 15, it was announced here today. The participants will be Venezuela, Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait -- signatories of the "Pact of Baghdad" which pledged members to raise prices of oil.
New York's newest radio station, operating next to a battery of bells that makes network chimes sound sickly, goes on the air New Year's morning.
A Brooklyn municipal court justice refused yesterday to evict a family from a cooperative apartment house because its 6-year-old son would not give up his pet Mexican Chihuahua.

The membership of the threeman voting trust that will vote the 78 per cent of Trans World Airlines' stock owned by Howard Hughes' Hughes Tool Company was fixed yesterday with the appointment of Ernest R. Breech, 63, and Irving S. Olds, 73, as trustees.
Robert Byrne, the United States open champion, registered his first points in the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship yesterday at the Empire Hotel.
The long-cherished hope of Queens residents that they might be sheltered from inclement weather while awaiting buses moved a step closer to fulfillment yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Davis Cup, symbol of world amateur tennis supremacy, has been packed away for another year in Australia. There is little prospect of its changing residence for the next several years.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller was urged today to support a change in the gross receipts tax levied on businesses by New York City "to gear the tax more closely to ability to pay."

The most popular economic cocktail offered these days consists of a brew of optimism flavored with a dash of pessimistic bitters. Yesterday the credit policy committee of the American Bankers Association came out with such a mixture, estimating in its semi-annual survey that business would be "good but not booming."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 -- The major television and radio networks agreed today to broadcast live some of the Kennedy news conferences during the next administration. These will include probably, the first from the White House.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain got 39 points and Paul Arizin 34 as the Philadelphia Warriors defeated Boston, 116 -- 101, tonight. The decision snapped the Celtics' six-game winning streak in the National Basketball Association.

AN alarm clock rings in the head of almost all fresh-water fishermen in this part of the world on the morning after Christmas and they begin babbling automatically and in unison about Southern bass fishing.
Cotton futures moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) off to 4 points (20 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

After six years of winter temperatures that they said ranged from 28 to 42 degrees in their apartments the tenants of a six-story tenement building took their protest yesterday to the Upper Manhattan Arrest Court.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The appointment Adlai E. Stevenson to represent the United States is widely considered here to be one of the most encouraging things that have happened to the United Nations.

Governor Rockefeller is correct in his appeal for a six-month extension of Saturday's deadline on employment of foreign medical graduates who failed to pass the recent examination given them. The basic reason the Governor is correct is the desperate situation confronting many hospitals here which face the prospect of no house staffs, or inadequate house staffs, if they must end the use of such doctors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States and four of its North Atlantic Treaty allies have signed a $1,500,000,000 agreement for the production in Europe of F-104G Starfighter jets. The planes will be under the command of the Atlantic Alliance.

New orders for machine tools from domestic and foreign buyers dropped 11.7 per cent in November from the figure for the month before, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday in Washington.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Ted Williams, the former Boston Red Sox slugger, signed a contract today to help develop, test and promote sports and outdoor equipment for Sears, Roebuck and Company.
A college psychologist charged President Eisenhower yesterday with failing to differentiate between desegregation and integration and thus hindering a solution of the racial problem.
The Christmas rush started all over again in the stores yesterday.
BAKWANGA, the Congo, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- As the rain heat on the metal roof of the barrackslike building, hundreds of ragged Africans inside, mostly children, huddled three and four to a cot.
The city's residents will soon be able to pick up the telephone and obtain the latest facts in emergencies, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- Yugoslavia announced today a monetary reform plan that entailed linking her economy more closely to the capitalist West.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- New York University found its scoring punch in the second half tonight and beat Tulsa, 70 -- 61, in the opening game of the twenty-fifth annual All-College basketball tournament.

Ohio State and Utah joined St. John's and St. Bonaventure in tomorrow night's semi-finals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's ninth annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament by scoring runaway victories at Madison Square Garden last night.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. criticized the Navy yesterday for "slcppy and messy" housekeeping and fireprevention practices aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Prof. Archibald Cox of the Harvard Law School will serve as Solicitor General in the Kennedy Administration.
A league of mayors, depositors in piggy banks, members of an entire family and a number who signed themselves "Anonymous" were among contributors yesterday to the fund for New York's Neediest Case.

Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday in dull trading on the New York exchanges. Most were at or near the preceding session's closing levels.

Despite field-goal famines of four minutes and six and a half minutes, the St. John's basketball team routed Providence College, 76 -- 54, yesterday in the opening round of the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden.
All three major construction categories showed sharp gains in November, setting a new record for the month in total construction contracts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Budget Bureau for the first time has taken a long look into the future to see where the budget is headed.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In his campaign President-elect Kennedy declared traffic accidents to be "perhaps the greatest of the nation's public health problems.' The American Brake Shoe Company, in a further diversification stop, entered the instrumentation field yesterday through the purchase of Dynisco, Inc., of Cambridge, Mass. The consideration was an undisclosed amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The prospects of a drastic Pentagon reorganization were described today by qualified sources in the incoming Kennedy Administration as relatively slim for some time to come.

Wages will have to go up faster if the country is to achieve full employment, the labor federation has told its affiliated unions.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 27 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, said tonight that the United States might upset the relative stability now prevailing in the Middle East.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 -- Mr. Whitton, newly appointed Federal Highway Administrator, is a career engineer whose only employer since he graduated from the University of Missouri in 1920 has been the Missouri State Highway Department.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- William Lenoir of Tucson, Ariz., posted a five-set victory over Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., and won the boys' 18-year-old-and-under title of the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships today.

A neighborhood teen-aged tough, who tried to steal the 50-cent tip that 14-year-old Robert Giuttari had received to deliver a Christmas tree Friday night, admitted yesterday he killed the boy, the police announced.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The White House Police pistol team showed off its big collection of trophies today to an appreciative oneman viewer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic Church in the United States reported today that it had "a prosperous if stormy," 1960. It also thanked Protestant and Jewish leaders who defended it during the Presidential campaign.

HAVANA, Dec. 27 -- A bomb exploded today in a midtown cafeteria, injuring fourteen, most of them women and children.
THE latest American buyer to succumb to modern Danish designs is the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The strikes in Belgium are serious for the already stricken economy of the country and they may well cause a political crisis and new elections. Therefore one should not minimize their importance. At the same time, there seems to be no reason to be unduly alarmed about the possible economic and political consequences.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Government will not seek a Supreme Court review of the decision that upset its conspiracy case against twenty visitors to the underworld meeting in Apalachin, N.Y.
Mayor Wagner gave his unqualified support yesterday to Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan in the handling of witnesses for city inquiries.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Rockland County asked the state today for a law permitting it to hold a referendum on the purchase of property for county parkland.

The 3,500 men who clean the holds of freighters in the Port of New York will start the new year with a package wage increase of 37 cents an hour.

The nation's leading makers of seven large household appliances predicted yesterday that their over-all 1961 factory sales would exceed those of this year by 3.5 per cent.

The problem of where to place let airports, prisons and other essential regional installations that are unwelcome in most local communities was put yesterday before 400 land-use experts. None had a ready answer.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- A major exhibition marking the fiftieth anniversary last month of the death of Leo Tolstoy is being presented in the Mansart Gallery of the French National Library.

A Roman Catholic priest who had told his New Jersey parishioners they must tithe to support their church said yesterday that while the plan was "not optional" it was not compulsory, either.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27 -- The two top-ranked teams won their first-round matches today in the national collegiate chess championships.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a pity that time has corrupted the spelling of Stirling Forest and even, as your news story of Dec. 22 shows, of Lord Stirling's name. He claimed, rather arrogantly, to be the true Earl of Stirling, and his contemporaries indulged him in it, for this was the only soft spot in a very shrewd and courageous head.

WHEN New York women were reported earlier this year to favor the costume -- a dress with matching jacket -- Nelly Don must have been listening. That concern's colorful spring collection, shown yesterday at Stern's, gave first place to this popular style.
A proxy statement of Swift Co. mailed yesterday revealed that the Chicago meat packer was considering issuing up to $35,000,000 of convertible debentures.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was threatened with jail yesterday. A court said he had disobeyed an order that forbade him to assign policemen to higher duties without promoting them.

The United States Rubber Company will spend more than $53,000,000 next year to intensify its research and development and to modernize and expand its manufacturing and distribution facilities here and abroad, George R. Vila, president, disclosed yesterday.

Former President Harry S. Truman told the nation's archivists yesterday that the state papers of all former Presidents should be microfilmed and made available to students all over the country.
New York's suburbs will orchestrate New Year's Eve with a flamboyant and fashionable night life that has emerged to compete with the Big Town.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 28 -- The executive council of the Venezuelan Government oil company -- Venezuelan Petroleum Company -- was named last night. There are only two books published today. One is "Boarsted: A Biography of Marcus Samuel, First Viscount Bearsted and Founder of 'Shell' Transport and Trading Company," by Robert Henriques. It is issued by Viking at $7.50.

The Canadian dollar fell to $1.00 3/16 in New York foreign exchange trading yesterday, the closest it has come to par since April 2, 1956. The opening price was the low for the day and encouraged short-covering by persons who had anticipated the decline and had settled exchange forward.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 28 -- LeMoyne and Long Island University gained the final round of the Middle Eastern College Athletic Assocation tournament at the Jersey City Armory tonight.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The inventories of automobile dealers shot up over the 1,000,000 mark in the Dec. 11-20 period, a record for that time of year, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
The Transit Authority, which says it operates the largest and safest rapid transit system in the world, has determined to make it the cleanest, too.
As much as 90 per cent of the universe within visible range appears to be "missing."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The chairman of the House Subcommittee on African Affairs called today for "complete divorcement" of the United States from colonialism.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The Board of Regents endorsed today proposals to establish a University of the City of New York, charge tuition at the free public colleges, and -- with reservations -- give state aid to private colleges.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The following conditions were reported today to the State Commerce Department:

The critical nature of the Congo problem is underscored by Secretary General Hammarskjold's impending trip there to assess the situation once again on the spot in an attempt to consolidate effective Government and to head off civil war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Differences among the Western allies have prevented a unified stand among them on the deepening crisis in Laos. Diplomatic sources said today these differences persisted despite the clear evidence of open Communist involvement in favor of the anti-Government rebels in Laos.
THE winning device in this deal was a play called the backward finesse.

CHRISTMAS skates can mean wintertime joy, providing certain precautions are observed. This warning comes from Edward J. Slezak, associate supervisor of physical education for men at the University of Michigan. Mr. Slezak offers ten safety rules to avoid tragedy:
The Hartford County, Conn., Metropolitan District sold $4,000,000 of water and sewer district bonds, due from 1961 to 2000, at competitive bidding yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- Parliament wound up a spectacular three-day session today by approving both the Federal budget and the nation's economic plan for the coming year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Kenney Wharram scored at the 18-second mark of the third period tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 -- Two of Mexico's three international airlines, Mexicana de Aviacion and Guest Aerovias de Mexico, have entered a jet-plane sharing agreement.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Industrial shares prices developed no decided trend in the stock market here today. The volume of trading was small after the four-day holiday.
MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The friction between Navy and Missouri, who will be Orange Bowl football rivals next Monday, faded today.
NEW JERSEY shotgunners will begin this morning three extra days of deer hunting, declared as an emergency measure because miserable weather during the regular season kept the deer harvest too low.

SINCE man first discovered that dining is a pleasure, cooking has been considered the eighth lively art. It comes as no surprise then that James J. Rorimer, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an enthusiastic chef with no mean talent.

A crowd of 18,000 persons is expected to attend tonight's Holiday Festival basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. Ohio State and St. John's, two undefeated teams, will meet in one of the tournament's semi-final games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- There are major differences of detail between the 1937 proposals to improve the product of the United States Government agencies and those submitted to President-elect Kennedy this week by James M. Landis. But latent in the 1960 version is the same end-product -- Presidential domination of so-called independent agencies that Congress refused to give President F.D. Roosevelt.
The stockholders of the Federal Chemical Company approved a proposed merger with the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation at a meeting in Louisville, Ky., yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dana Schmidt's account in The Times of Dec. 22 of Israeli development of a nuclear reactor ascribed to unnamed "United States officials a gratuitous and demeaning reference to what Mr. Schmidt terms the Israeli "habit of secrecy" deriving from "the ghettos of Eastern Europe" and the "underground Zionis movement."
Although market movements were described by one broker as "the whirlpool at the bottom of Niagara Falls," stocks showed a general upward tendency on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The relaxed state of the money market at the approach of the year-end made for continued firmness in the prices of high-grade debt securities yesterday.

Three of the four persons whose opinions were sought on recent decisions by the Long Island Kennel Club and the Westbury Kennel Association to eliminate variety group and best-in-show judging from their large 1961 outdoor dog shows favored the measure.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Cornell University today selected 33-year-old Tom Harp, the backfield coach at Army for the last five years, to succeed George K. (Lefty) James as its head football coach. Harp will be the youngest head coach in the Ivy League.

BAYONNE, N.J., Thursday, Dec. 29 -- A series of explosions in a propane gas depot here rocked the harbor area shortly before last midnight. Scores of metal bottles of the highly flammable gas blew up like bombshells, sending flames as high as 500 feet in billowing flares than were visible in Brooklyn, across Upper New York Bay.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -- New York's economic problems cannot be solved by penalizing successful areas of the state to aid the unsuccesful, a General Electric Company official said tonight.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- The West German Government announced today that it expected to sign a new trade agreement with the Soviet Union before the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Beginning Jan. 20 there will be a flow of legal and executive talent of the Eisenhower Administration from public into private life.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 29 -- King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola interrupted their wedding trip to return to Brussels today as the Socialist-led strike against a Government austerity program went into its eleventh, day of mounting violence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming ordered today that a new internal inspection system be set up in the Food and Drug Administration. He specified that the man to head it be named by Jan. 16.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Federal indictment charging vote-buying in the Nov. 8 election has been returned against two Democratic district workers in Chicago.
The New York Central Railroad petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday for a 10 per cent increase in all commutation and coach fares in the New York suburban area, effective Jan. 29.

WHEN Daniel Defoe was born in London no one was shrewd enough to realize that he would write two or three classics. His vital statistics are so inconclusive that we do not know whether he Was born in 1659, 1660 or 1661.

A DRY, almost clinical economist who enjoys arising at 5 o'clock in the morning to contemplate statistics, Gaston Eyskens, Premier of Belgium, has nonetheless managed to include in his public career much political excitement.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- East and West Germany reached agreement tonight to continue trade between the two countries in the new year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today the appointment of new chairmen for four of the twelve Federal Reserve banks, and of two new officials at the New York bank.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 4 to 10 points (20 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today the plans of Trans World Airlines to finance a fleet of jet aircraft. It also approved Ernest R. Breech, Irving S. Olds and Raymond M. Holliday as trustees of the Hughes Tool Company's 78 per cent stockholdings of T.W.A. outstanding common shares.

John J. McCloy, who will retire as chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank tomorrow, announced yesterday that he would rejoin the law concern here of Milbank, Tweed, Hope and Hadley as counsel next week.

FOOD prices generally remain at their Christmas levels. In fact, stores that were tantalizing customers with special prices on turkeys and hams are singing the same song for the New Year. Legs of lamb and pork loin roasts have joined the list of featured meats.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- A former Premier and a former Governor General of Algeria put President de Gaulle's Algerian policy under a cross fire of criticism from Left and Right today.

THERE is something inherently distasteful about the shabby way two Americans abandoned amateur tennis a week ago and openly embraced professional careers as members of Jack Kramer's troupe. Earl (Butch) Buchholz and Barry MacKay sang a sorry exit chorus, not as gentlemen but in the fashion of those who kiss and tell.
BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The heroism of two men was credited today with having prevented a major disaster after an explosion of propane gas at a depot here late last night.

Frances Perkins, who made history as the nation's first woman Cabinet member, yesterday solved a mystery concerning her long-time friend, Alfred E. Smith. In doing so, she had the help of three history professors.
"VICTORY AT SEA," a series that has become a television classic since it first appeared in 1952, was condensed and shown as a ninety-minute program, last night on Channel 4.
David Rockefeller said yesterday that $250,000 in Federal funds had been requested for a preliminary study of realty blight in the Morningside Heights area.
Hans Kmoch, the referee, forfeited Hans Berliner when he overstepped the time limit in the Leasing J. Rosenwald tournament for the chess championship of the United States, today at the Hotel Empire.
COLUMBIA. S.C., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A 38-year-old former Defense Department statistician was arrested today on a charge of stealing 200 secret documents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The value of mineral output this year in the United States reached an estimated $17,800,000,000, Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, reported today.

Helen Menken is returning to the stage. She will take a leave as president of the American Theatre Wing to act the role of the fortune teller in "The Skin of Our Teeth," Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer-Prize drama.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $73,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Studies by the Moore state commission have criticized the city's borough president set-up as a source of overlapping, duplication, diffusion of powers and decisions based on sectional or political interest.
Three five-story commercial buildings at 90 Worth Street and 325-27-31 Broadway in the textile district have been sold" by the Consolidated Realty Corporation, Abraham Marinoff, president.
MADRID, Dec. 29 -- An actor and a newspaper man left today on a trip that is to terminate New Year's Eve in a parachute jump from a helicopter into a remote area of Central Africa.

LEBANON, a little country wedged between Israel, Syria and the sea, has become a popular tourist attraction in recent years. Cruise ships send their passengers by automobiles to visit the ruined splendors of Baalbek and air travelers circling the globe or returning from India often stop off at Beirut.
The traditional moves by Wall Street firms to admit new partners at year-end showed some signs of abating yesterday. Only two investment houses announced additions to their executive staffs.
The ill wind that turned the metropolitan area's forenoon snow into an afternoon rain boded no evil for Eastern winter resort operators yesterday.
TONDELEYO, the halfcaste, a jungle temptress who emerged from the fevered imagination of Leon Gordon in 1923, is back in business at the Players Theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Clarence N. Sayen, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to postpone the hearing on the mid-air collision over New York on Dec. 16. The hearing is scheduled for next Wednesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Morale at the United Nations is probably lower than at any time since the early months of 1950, when a general walkout by the Soviet Union seemed to threaten the very existence of the organization.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is generally reported that the American participants at the recent conference of scientists in Moscow returned convinced that the Soviet Government is strongly motivated toward disarmament and prepared to make important concessions.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Thompson Ramo Wooldridge, Inc., has obtaine an option to acquire more than 90 per cent of the common stock of the Radio Condenser Company of Camden, N.J., Dean B. Wooldridge, president of the Cleveland company, said today.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz accused nine chemical companies yesterday of price-fixing in the sale of liquid chlorine to New York State and to municipalities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Seasonal factors combined with the Christmas holiday last week to produce increased truck loadings, the American Trucking Associations reported today.
One of the nation's leading conservationists yesterday called on citizens everywhere to become "activists" against road builders and politicians who encroach on parklands and open recreation spaces.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Delaware's Board of Education, complying with a Federal court order, submitted today a plan calling for desegregation of all the state's school districts by September, 1970.
HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- Communist China declared tonight that more than half of its cultivated, land had heen subjected in the last year to the worst series of "natural calamities" in a hundred years.

A pair of deadlocks, for best English-language picture and best director of the year, marked the twenty-sixth annual poll of the New York Film Critics. "The Apartment" and "Sons and Lovers" and the respective directors of these features, Billy Wilder and Jack Cardiff, tied for top honors in these categories.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped by $25,006,000 to $49,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $39,000,000 to $708,000,00.

When Secretary General Hammarskjold flies to the Congo next week he will visit a formerly rich and potentially still prosperous land to which premature independence has brought only political chaos, civil and tribal war -- and mass starvation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Those career diplomats who long have watched the very different career o Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, with fascination resembling that of the dove for the serpent, will not expect too much of his promises to President-elect Kennedy this week at Palm Beach.
Buying orders pouring into the market with the waning of the 1960 calendar carried many United States Government obligations and other prime debt securities to new high prices yesterday.

UNLESS the signs are wrong, Westchester County will entertain about twice as many deer hunters in its special January shotgun season as showed up in the first special season last year. And if they (and Westchester County) are lucky, they will kill about twice as many bucks and does.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- As the Eisenhower Administration entered its last weeks, Civil Service Commission officials reported today that last-minute Federal appointments, promotions and protective job shifts had been "fewer than expected."
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 29 -- Hofstra defeated Queens College, 95 -- 66, tonight to move into the final round of the Long Island tournament and notch its twenty-first victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The five-year-old Washington Opera Society added an enchanting, multicolored feather to its cap last night with the unveiling of a beautiful new production of Igor Stravinsky's "Le Rossignol."
Twice in recent weeks the earth's atmosphere has reached up and clutched at Echo I, the balloon-like satellite, causing two abrupt losses of its orbital momentum.

The bi-state Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has not only documented convincingly the necessity for its continuation. It has established beyond contradiction the desirability of enlargement of its powers. Without asking, it has raised the large question of what if anything the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is doing to clean up the International Longshoremen's Association, which since late 1959 has been back in the house of labor despite a scandal-ridden past.

"QUEEN FABIOLA'S gown is not expected to influence bridal dress design for spring and summer weddings," says Teresa S. Cox, bridal buyer and consultant at Stern's. This is probably because the Belgian Queen's wedding dress, was trimmed with fur.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The British Government is convinced that Laos can remain neutral between East and West with a broadly based government that represents the various Laotian political elements.
MONTREAL, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Pete Geogan scored an early third-period goal and the Detroit Red Wings tied the leagueleading Montreal Canadiens, 1-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Ron Glaser set the pace with 29 points as Marquette defeated Wake Forest, 91 -- 83, in the first round of the Dixie Classic before a crowd of 12,400 tonight.
A system for producing collapsible aluminum tubes directly from primary ingot went into full operation yesterday at the Hawthorne (N.J.) plant of the White Metal Manufacturing Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission will leave this week-end for Leopoldville to try to reconcile the differences of the rival political factions in the Congo.

When Thomas Dunn, conductor of the Cantata Singers, started to plan last night's Bach concert at Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he turned first to a Christmas cantata rarely, if ever, performed here.

There are few problems in the field of United States foreign affairs arousing more heated controversy nowadays than the American attitude toward colonialism. By colonialism in this context one means the status whereby a nation has possession of a foreign country which it controls in its politics, economics, defense and foreign affairs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was glad to see Grant E. Sita's letter in your issue of Dec. 24 expressing surprise that the book "1984" had been omitted from the Paperback Bookshelf compiled by the Foundation for Religious Action in the Social and Civil Order in cooperation with the Office of Armed Forces Information and Education and recently released to the press by the foundation.
Winter's effect on the Hudson and Connecticut Rivers can now be ascertained quickly by dialing HAnover 2-5700 and asking for extension 624.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 -- Le Moyne of Syracuse registered its eighth straight victory in the final of the Middle Eastern College, Athletic Association basketball tournament tonight, turning back Long Island University, 66 -- 57, at the Jersey City Armory.

A professor of economics Amherst College has written paper advocating legislation that advertisers be made gaily responsible to insure that their advertisements represent a full disclosure of information about their product.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Eighty-two per cent of 200 registered voters polled recently by the League of Women Voters did not know what form of municipal government Norwalk has.
