The Bendix Corporation increased net sales 15 per cent in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 to a record of $787,025,279 from the $683,800,000 volume of the preceding year. Total income, including royalties and other operating income as well is returns from investments and other sources, also increased, to $794,499,000 from $691,511,604.
Baltimore, Md., is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $47,550,000 on Feb. 15. Proceeds from the borrowing will be used for municipal improvements.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Susquehanna and Upsala moved into the final round of the Upsala invitation tournament tonight. Susquehanna defeated Alfred, 62 -- 44, and Upsala beat Rensselaer Polytechnical Institute, 70 -- 62.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The manufacturing picture darkened further in November with new declines in sales, new orders, backlogs and inventories.
A number of price changes, mostly downward, were announced yesterday. Some were roundabout reductions, achieved by the elimination of extra payments.

The grand ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn echoed laughingly yesterday afternoon with remembrances of the $7,000,000,000 that state and local governments raised in the public market on bond issues this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- United Air Lines has extended an offer to exchange its common stock for the 4 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Capital Airlines as part of a proposal to merge the carriers, United announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The State Department confirmed today that there were differences between the United States, Britain and France on dealing with the crisis in Laos.

The following reports wore provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses. If no time is indicated the report was provided by the wire services.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 - -Fifty of the leading educators, writers and philosophers of Israel urged the country's politicians today to cease fighting for personal power lest they endanger, the future of the state.
The Board of Education cleared the way yesterday for the presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" in the city's high schools.
For years, American-made outboard motors have been going to the far corners of the world in notably larger and larger exports each year.

The State investigation Commission was upheld by the State Supreme Court yesterday in its inquiry into the operations of an electrical service company that has annual city contracts totaling $5,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: Most feature and editorial writers, in discussing the recent tragic air accident, point to the need of better control of planes flying with in a congested air space. Your Dec. 18 editorial reassures us that "a massive program for the modernization of traffic control has been undertaken." This is a necessity.
Hospitals in New York State received a reprieve last night from a medical ruling that would have cost them the services of more than 500 foreign-trained physicians.

A.M. Sonnabend who, on Wednesday lost his bid to take control of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, disclosed yesterday that he no longer was even a stockholder in the company. In a telephone interview, Mr. Sonnabend revealed that he had disposed of the last of his holdings in the automobile manufacturing company yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers disclosed today they hoped to "persuade" Leo Durocher, once the most controversial manager in baseball, to take a coaching job for the 1961 season.
Steels, oils, utilities and an excited little group of low-price stocks led an advance yesterday that added about one-half of 1 per cent to aggregate values on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Senate investigators made public today testimony alleging and denying that 120,531 of the funds of a labor union were missing.
SPARKILL, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- George W. Gray of this village, science writer and former staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation, died today of a heart attack in Palisades. He was 75 years old.

Seton Hall, relying on possession basketball and the gifted right hand of Art Hicks, upset Providence, 92 -- 83, in the consolation round of the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Armstrong Corporation, a new company of underwriters and security dealers, has leased space in the office building at 15 William Street. Ira M. Koerner and Charles L. Goldenberg of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers.

MANY years ago the principal bridge authorities considered a singleton a very poor opening lead. They were dogmatically wedded to what they then called the "longsuit game" the defenders should always try to establish their longest suit and plug away at it until the declarer is out of trumps.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 29 -- The reorganization of Nassau County's governmental structure after a comprehensive study by a charter revision commission is urged in a City College report that will be published tomorrow.
The long-expected battle between Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. De Sapio for supremacy in the New York County Democratic organization was joined yesterday.

Yesterday's fresh snow, which piled up on other snow that fell more than two weeks ago proved decisive for Leland Hayward. The producer promptly decided to send a television troupe to sunny, snow-free Key West, Pla., to retape a "Porgy and Bess" sequence for "The Gershwin Years."
T.S. Eliot, the Nobel Prize-winning poet, whose works are widely taught in schools over the world, believes that contemporary poetry, including his own, should not be studied formally in school.
ANSONIA, Conn., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A settlement was announced today in the lengthy court battles over the multi-million-dollar estate of George E. and Annie W. Matthies of Seymour.

An arbitrator has rejected a pay claim by members of the New York Newspaper Guild who were temporarily out of work when seven metropolitan dailies suspended publication during a deliverers' strike two years ago.

NOTHING since the invention of the Gregorian calendar has been more suited to launching a New Year than food and drink. Whether it is a midnight supper for two or a gathering for a score or more, victuals and spirits are in keeping with the occasion.

The Southern. Pacific Company, giant West Coast transportation system, reported yesterday a 33 per cent rise in profits for November. Net income climbed to $4,193,439 from $3,150,480 in November, 1959. Net operating income spurted to $3,077,517 from $1,950,271.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor's 28 points made the difference tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 111-95, in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall.

Charles (Chuck) McKinley, the fourth-ranked player in the nation, was suspended yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association for his "regrettable" conduct during the Davis Cup interzone final.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- A $100,000,000 effort to attract new industry to New York State and combat unemployment will be proposed next week by Governor Rockefeller.

"BUYING by ear instead of by eye is the biggest mistake made by young collectors of art," according to Eleanor Ward, owner of the Stable Art Gallery, which is a showroom for contemporary American paintings and sculptures.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit will rule tomorrow on whether a temporary injunction should be issued to prevent the eviction of 700 Negro sharecroppers from their homes in Haywood and Fayette counties in Tennessee.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city was "shooting for a target date of March o April" for starting its long-heralded $169,700,000 attack or blight on the uppper West Side of Manhattan.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Although there was confusion, there was no panic on the deck of the Pine Ridge after the tanker broke in two last week, a survivor testified today.
TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- A major primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor appeared certain tonight, barring a withdrawal of Hoboken's Mayor John J. Grogan.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Baylor Bears, the surprise team of the All-College basketball tournament, shot their way into the final round with a 58-50 troumph over New York University tonight.

THE advantage of a gift certificate is that it can buy anything for the price. As opposed to the luxury of a blouse or scarf that is not really needed, the certificate can be put to a practical use that few relatives or friends might think of.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- McGeorge Bundy was chosen today to serve as President-elect John P. Kennedy's special assistant for national security affairs.

The world stands at the threshold of a decade dominated by science as no era has been since the days of Isaac Newton, Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, said here yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The University of Miami Hurircanes took a 77-to-71 decision from Holy Cross tonight for the Hurricane a Bsketball Classic championship.

A bank clerk was critically wounded yesterday when a two-inch stud bolt pierced the eleventh-floor window of a downtown office building and struck him as he was seated at his desk. Passing through an arm, the bolt plunged into his chest and lodged just below the heart.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- New wage and contract proposals endorsed by leaders of the Football League aroused hope today that the strike of professional soccev players due Jan. 21 would be averted.

The abnormally cold weather throughout most of the nation last week resulted in another sharp drop in stocks of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes. According to the American Petroleum Institute, there was a decline in inventories of 8,437,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday.

PUCCINI'S "Manon Lescaut" received its sixth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It had a cast of exceptional strength, with Renata Tebaldi in the title role and Richard Tucker as the lover to whom Manon brought ruin.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Allen Hughes, who plays both football and basketball for Navy, came off the injury list tonight and scored 19 points as the middies gained a 69-62 overtime victory over Florida in a semi-final of the Gator Bowl basketball tournamont.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union's oft-criticized Minister of Agriculture, Vladimir V. Matskevich, was removed from his post today. He was relegated to the chairmanship of a newly formed district in the "virgin lands" area of the Central Asian Republic of Kazakhstan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The effects of the Presidential election are still being counted, but the president-elect of the half-million-member National Federation of Republican Women already has her eye on winning the next one for the Republicans in 1964.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Demand was small and selective on the stock market here today and price movements were mixed. Most changes were in pennies.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Second-ranked Columbia played first-seeded Toronto to a tie today to move into first place in the national intercollegiate team chess championship tournament after four rounds of matches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Leaders of Americans for Democratic Action criticized Speaker Sam Rayburn and two influential Senate leaders today for "sniping" at President-elect John F. Kennedy's position on teachers' pay, medical care and civil rights.

With an irresistible late drive, Ohio State's national champion basketball team stormed from 13 points behind with eighteen minutes to play last night a defeated St. John's, 70-65, before a spill-over crowd of 18,499 at Madison Square Garden.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Ingemar Johansson lost six pounds under mysterious circumstances the night before he was knocked out by Floyd Patterson last, June, the former heavyweight champion said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Senate Investigations subcommittee said today it was exploring the alleged bribing of some civilian employes of the Military Sea Transportation Service in New York.

Irving B. Kahn, the president of TelePrompTer, Inc., said last night that his organization had been awarded the exclusive contract for closed-circuit television and other subsidiary rights for the March 13 heavyweight title fight in Miami Beach between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The most active trading of the year hit soybean futures today on a strong general demand and prices again moved up sharply to new highs for the season for all old crop contracts.
More and more the dramatic fight for control of the Balti more and Ohio Railroad be comes a battle of management giants, and the small stock holder moves to the back o the stage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Dr. Earle J. Reynolds on charges of sailing into a restricted area during the 1958 Eniwetok nuclear tests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Eisenhower Administration has adopted a policy favoring private development and utilization of communications satellites as one of its final actions in the space field.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 29 -- The forces supporting Patrice Lumumba, imprisoned former Premier, were reported today to be gaining ground in the east and southeast of the Congo.
The election of Frank R. Denton and George D. Woods was announced yesterday by E.' T. Asplundh, chairman.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- TWO last-period goals enabled the Harvard hockey team to tie New Brunswick of Canada, 4 -- 4, in the Rensselaer invitation tournament tonight.

The American Jewish Committee accused Premier David Ben-Gurion yesterday of having violated an understanding made ten years ago regarding the relationship between Israel and Jews outside that country.

Louis Fischer has written a new book, called "Russia, America and the World," in which he explains the foreign policy practiced by the United States in its relations with other nations and the policies of other nations in regard to the United States.

The business building containing 82,000 square feet of space at 50 Avenue L, Newark, has been sold by the Federal Pacific Corporation. The buyer, an investing client of George Lessall, lawyer, leased the property back to Federal Pacific.
A copy of an ancient letter in Greek that ascribes a secret gospel to Mark and that narrates a miracle absent from the present Gospel of Mark was made public last night.

For the first time since July, an appreciable amount of platinum was traded yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In all, 142 lots changed hands. January contracts brought $81.45 an ounce while those for April were priced at $82.95 an ounce.
The apparent theft of two cartons of personal letters written by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was revealed in a reward notice published today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Every major movie producing company in Hollywood has been named by a group of writers and actors in a suit to do away with a political blacklist allegedly maintained in the industry since 1947.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission authorized General Telephone and Electronics Corporation of New York City today to acquire 51 per cent control of the Orange County Telephone Company, at a cost of $1,149,300.
The mother of nine young children, expecting a tenth asked her husband to send a donation to New York's Neediest Cases rather than give her a Christmas present this year.
Deputy Fire Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta accused a Navy court of inquiry yesterday of deliberately seeking to discredit the city Fire Department.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said tonight he had discussed Arkansas unemployment, particularly lay-offs at the Reynolds Metal plants, with President-elect John F. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The new appointments to the Federal Government tell us some interesting things about Senator Kennedy.
The New York Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union yesterday authorized a strike next Wednesday by 12,000 workers in the New York market.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Dec. 24 were 30 per cent above the year-earlier level.
Two inches of snow fell in the city and near-by areas yesterday morning and delayed travelers and, commuters on their way to work.

Ancient barriers to communication among adherents of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox faiths were whittled down significantly during 1960, according to a prominent church official here.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Peru severed diplomatic relations with Cuba tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Queen Elizabeth's New Year Honors List was published today and among the 2,200 names were those of Tyrone Guthrie, Margaret Rutherford, the Prime Minister of Malaya and Dr. A. C.B. Lovell.

The Navy superintendent of building and repair at the New York Naval Shipyard was questioned yesterday about who was responsible for fighting blazes such as the one that swept the aircraft carrier Constellation on Dec. 19.

A controversial letter presented to Biblical scholars here on Thursday night as an ancient screed by Clement of Alexandria is "genuine," according to the Rev. Dr. Pierson Parker of General Theological Seminary. The letter was presented in an eighteenth-century copy.

A geologist warned yesterday that the activities of surfcasters, real estate developers and just ordinary people must be restricted to prevent the severe erosion and eventual disappearance of Fire Island.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30 -- President-elect John P. Kennedy announced today that he would meet next week with farm leaders to draft a program "to relieve the farm crisis."

Jack Gardner, Utah's realistic coach, said yesterday the best way for St. Bonaventure to beat Ohio State in the Holiday Festival tournament final at Madison Square Garden tonight was to let all the air out of the basketball.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 30 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Algerian Provisional Government, will take part in the African "summit" conference in Casablanca next week, the Moroccan Government announced tonight.

Bayonne Lanes, a new bowling center at Avenue E and East Fifty-second Street in Bayonne, N.J., has been sold by Jiefsmar, Inc., the builder, to a New York investor. The building contains twenty-four alleys, a restaurant and a bar and lounge.

Having cleared the final hurdle that was blocking funds for the presentation of Shakespeare in the city's high schools, Joseph Papp, director of the venture, plunged yesterday into the serious business of getting on with the show.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec, 30 -- Suffolk County's ten-man Board of Supervisors will start the new year with a roll-call of five Republicans and five Democrats.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec 30 (AP) -- It's anybody's guess who will win when Baylor's airminded Bears and Florida's power-running Gators meet in the sixteenth annual Gator Bowl football game tomorrow.

The tug of war over a new Borough President of Manhattan to replace Hulan E. Jack seems, for the moment at least, to have brought a test of strength between Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall. The Mayor has previously been careful to preserve an aloof position above the battle between "reform" elements and Mr. De Sapio as a symbol of "bossism."

The churches of New York will hail the New Year tonight with solemn and reverent services of prayer, meditation and song. There will be special holy hours, musical presentations and the traditional Watch Night as the old year wanes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to a news article in The Times of Dec. 16, the Rev. Dr. Henry E. Kagan, rabbi-psychologist, claims to have found "statistical confirmation" that Catholics are aggressive. He cites a "finding" which is supposed to show "the incidence of acts of violence to be highest among Catholics."
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The stock market ended the year with a surge of strength. Industrial shares scored gains of as much as 2 shillings (28 cents) and British Government securities were higher.
Belmont Abbey College scored an 86-70 victory over the New York Athletic Club to win the Winged Foot Christmas basketball tournament last night at the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Eisenhower proclaimed today a new space policy under which the Government would "aggressivly encourage" private industry to establish a global communications network with satellites.
Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, fell in his apartment at 1067 Fifth Avenue on Thursday while playing with his young children, and broke his right hip
Quiet trading was the rule on most New York commodities markets yesterday. Price moves were irregular or down in most cases.
Bobby Mack, a Yale sophomore, won the 3-mile run last night in the third and final indoor handicap track meet of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union at the 102d Engineers Armory.

The council of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, at its final meeting here yesterday, made new plans to reach out to the American public with some of the lessons that science has learned.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The Columbia chess team remained undefeated, taking its fifth and sixth round matches today to win the national intercollegiate team championship.
Activity in the market for new capital promises to rise rather sharply next week from the light sessions of the last fortnight. Even so, it will be a relatively light week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The President's Committee on Government Employment Policy today termed "completely untrue and unfair" charges that it had been "reluctant to carry out its mission of opening all facets of the Federal Government to qualified Negro applicants."
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- President de Gaulle served notice today that not even a Marshal of France, the most illustrious of French military ranks, can oppose the President on Algeria and escape discipline.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Soybean futures recovered twice today from fairly heavy bursts of profit taking but finally yielded ground in the final few minutes of trading and closed with small declines.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Utah State found the scoring range in the second half and overcame an early deficit to defeat New York University, 57 -- 45, for third place in the twenty-fifth All-College basketball tournament tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Dec. 28 "More Doctors Needed" is a misguided though well meant appeal to remedy a grave illness with palliative measures. It is a question rather of a more competent use of medical graduates, foreign and native, than their lack.
Steel industry watchers had a trend, possibly hopeful, to ponder as the old year ended and the new began.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Captain Fair, a supplementary nominee, today staged a front-running victory in the $26,750 California Breeders Trial Stakes for 2-year-olds at Santa Anita.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following report on ski conditions today:
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange fell sharply, in 1960. Optimistic forecasts made in 1959 for 1960 did not materialize. Sales fell about 6.5% below the 1959 volume.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 30 -- King Baudouin conferred today with the chiefs of Belgium's three largest political parties while violence in the nationwide strikes reached a new peak.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The pensions of 65,000 retired soft-coal miners will be reduced from $100 a month to $75 as the recession's pinch on union welfare benefits grows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- An organization of House liberals moved today to press Speaker Sam Ray burn for a commitment on proposals to curb the power of a conservative coalition that dominates the House Rules Committee.

TONIGHT, at midnight, a young couple may toast the home they hope to buy in 1961 -- the one they could not afford in 1960. Another family with growing children may consider whether this will be the year to move out of suburbia and back to the city because of increasing taxes and commuting problems.
Probably the biggest and cer tainly one of the most attractive post-season football schedules in history goes into full swing,today with seven games.

The New York County Medical Society announced yesterday its support of Governor Rockefeller's proposal to help foreign-trained physicians pass examinations that would enable them to work in hospitals in New York State.
WHATEVER New York duck hunters may have been thinking while they shivered in the blinds, there have been more ducks this year -- 80 per cent more in the state than the average of recent years.

Because the New York Knickerbockers already have established nowhere as their destination for this season, the news at Madison Square Garden last night was not that they lost another game, but rather that at times they looked like an up-and-coming basketball team.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 30 -- Hofstra's Flying Dutchmen won the Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges Christmas basketball tournament tonight by defeating Adelphi's Panthers, 68 -- 54.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- Gov. Foster Furcolo tonight described as "completely incredible" President-elect John F. Kennedy's choice of McGeorge Bundy as his special assistant for national security affairs.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points down to 9 up yesterday, except distant July, which rose 30 points.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- York Larese and Doug Moe led North Carolina to an 87-67 rout of Villanova this afternoon and unbeaten Duke defeated Marquette, 86-73, to-? night to gain the final of the Dixie Classic basketball tournament.

THE Greeks may have made man the center of all things, and certainly the human figure is the canon of Greek art. Nonetheless, as an anthropomorphic art, it is surpassed in intensity by pre-Columbian art, no slightest artifact of which does not portray or suggest human beings.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute won its invitation hockey tournament tonight by defeating the University of New Brunswick of Canada, 4 -- 1, before 4,500 fans.
Commuters on the Harlem division of the New York Central Railroad are finding that during the cold weather it is about as comfortable outside some stations as inside. And often more pleasant.
Adjourned games were settled in yesterday's play in the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship.
ALONG with the current servant-less homes is a growing trend to include housekeeping skills in academic curriculums for the young.
GENEVA, Dec. 30 -- The Swiss police pushed an international search today for a former French Army officer accused of a poison murder that has had important political repercussions on two continents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, announced today that he would seek re-election in 1962.

HAVANA, Dec. 30 -- The Cuban Army's intelligence service announced today the arrest of seventeen persons as terrorists and the seizure of three "bomb factories" that it said had received explosives from the United States.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Susquehanna defeated Upsala 74 -- 59, in the final of the second annual Upsala invitation basketball tournament. Alfred University beat Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 59 -- 58, for consolation honors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The United Nations seems at the moment to be the focal point of attack. The purveyors of confusion and chaos, never eager to see the structures of peace standing too straight, gaily gnaw away at the organization's vital supports.

THE great Zodiacal wheel of the brasstop conferences -- Casablanca, Yalta, Potsdam and so on -- rolls through "The Stars and Stripes Story of World War II,"* edited by Robert L. Meyer Jr., But it is the individual fortunes of Americans in brawn suits they had seldom expected to wear that give this brimming scrapbbok of the soldiers newspaper its deepest interest and vitality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A highly decorated Marine aviator was awarded a patent this week for a magnetic fish lure. In the patent drawings is looks something like a miniature battleship. The patentee is a jet pilot and fishing enthusiast, Lieut. Col. Frederick E. Hughes.
As a welcome New Year's boon, the Soviets and their East German puppets have postponed a new Berlin crisis by concluding trade agreements with West Germany that leave Berlin in statu quo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee urged the Defense Department today to review its decision diverting overseas frozen-food shipments from New York Harbor to Cheatham Annex, Va.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, expressed concern today that a settlement of differences between the Soviet Union and the new Administration in the United States might work to Israel's disadvantage.

The State Board of Regents is investigating charges that insurance companies have been defrauded by physicians in New York City and Long Island. The board plans to extend the inquiry to the rest of the state.
A 14-year-old reform school inmate home on special leave for the holidays was seized by the police yesterday after he had admitted shooting and fatally wounding his cousin in an East Harlem tenement.
New securities offered her to the public in December de clined from those of a yea earlier.

SOMERVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Displaced Negroes living in a tent village near here were jubilant today when they learned of a Federal court order to stop sharecropper evictions in neighboring Haywood Country.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The presence of two fine passers in the line-up made the South a 6-point favorite today to defeat the North in the twenty-third annual Blue-Gray football game tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today safety aspects of the N.S. Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered merchant ship, would be considered at a public hearing before any approval was given to start its nuclear power plant.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The atomic-powered submarine Patrick Henry left this seaport for duty somewhere in the Atlantic today, her tubes fully loaded with Polaris missiles.

The report of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, entitled "Democracy and Public Review," is a useful appraisal of a most interesting development in the labor union field -- the Public Review Board established by the United Automobile Workers in 1957. This represents by far the broadest grant of authority over the internal affairs of a union to be voluntarily given to outsiders.
Carmine G. De Sapio yesterday openly challenged Mayor Wagner's contention that he had the backing of enough Manhattan Councilmen to select the next Borough President.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Treasury bill rate ended the year on an advance. It was a long way down from last New Year's Eve, but solidly within the range it has held to for the last seven months.
Stock prices ended 1960 yesterday in a virtually meaningless jumble of small gains and losses, for transactions made with one eye on income-tax ruled the day.

The 1960 bond market went into history bullishty yesterday. Prime-risk United States Government and corporate obligations of many issues closed the yean in firm demand. In many cases new highs were scored.

The draft of a speech President Eisenhower never had an opportunity to deliver to the people of Leningrad last summer will be published Jan. 16 by Columbia University Press.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 -- Prices on all brands of automobiles sold in Mexico will be frozen throughout 1961, it has been reported here. The morning newspaper Novedades in an exclusive article said unqualifiedly today that the Ministry of Commerce and Industry would announce next Week that the ministry had "turned down all requests for increases in prices of new automobile units."
MAIMI, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Del Daily won the annual Orange Bowl Regatta's nine-hour endurance boat race today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The rail industry reported today small year-to-year declines in freight loadings.

EVERY bridge player can profit from knowing the proper way to play each variety of card combination he may encounter. This will produce the best result for him nine times out of ten. But he can profit also by remembering -- the tenth time -- that a declarer's primary object always is to make his contract, while the defenders' primary object always is to defeat it.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 30 -- The United States Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals issued today an injunction to prevent the eviction of about 300 Negro sharecroppers from land in Haywood County, Tenn.

The Civil War west of the Rockies is the subject of a new book by Oscar Lewis that Doubleday will issue Jan. 13, Called "The War in the Far West," it tells of the operations of the contending forces and the significant part California played in the strife.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 -- One of the words most commonly heard in Tokyo this winter is "gametsui." This is a new word to the Eddoko, as Tokyo residents call themselves (for "children of Eddo," the ancient name of the capital).
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- A 50-year-old Sikh on a rope bed was the center of attention today in a political struggle in which more than 40,000 Indians have been arrested since last spring.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The following conditions were reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A hearing examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that the C.A.B. approve the proposed merger of Capital Airlines into United Air Lines, creating the largest airtransport system in the nation. American Airlines now is No. 1.

TRIESTE, Italy, Dec. 13 -- The highway west from the Yugoslav border to Trieste cuts straight across the stony highlands through the village of Opicina, runs through a cut in the last ridge and turns sharply to begin a slow, winding descent to the sea.

A NEW conductor made his appearance with the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. He was Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, the recently appointed musical director of the Minneapolis Symphony.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Laos asked the United Nations today for support against a reported invasion by troops from Communist North Vietnam and possibly Communist China.
Three young children burned to death late last night in a Bronx tenement fire.

The Albemarle Paper Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that profits in the thirty-six week period ended on Dec. 11 were higher than in the 1959 period. Many paper companies have been reporting reclines in earnings this year.

NINETEEN SIXTY-ONE is likely to see supermarkets becoming wider in scope while their customers (at least, theoretically) become narrower in physical proportions. During the past year the 900-calorie diet made a bigger hit than anything on Broadway and, even if this proves to be a nine-day wonder, the public preoccupation with dietary problems seems here to stay.

Swelled by larger industrial, foreign and railroad refundings, the total of bonds called for redemption in December before maturity jumped to $48,473,000 from $11,092,000 in November and from $32,388,000 in December, 1959.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 26 -- Men and machines are burrowing into the polar ice cap 800 miles southeast of here Where the first all-undersnow scientific station on the Antarctic Continent will be built.
A Brooklyn public school teacher, with the aid of several educators and former pupils, has organized a nonprofit group to stimulate activity in the performing arts in the city's high schools.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The Citadel Bulldogs produced a pinpoint passing attack and a bulldozing ground game tonight to beat Tennessee Tech, 27 -- 0, in the fifteenth annual Tangerine Bowl football game.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Two young scientists are ready to go ahead with a spectacular experiment involving a nuclear explosion that could be seen from half the earth's surface.

Old Year's Day Tomorrow we celebrate the New Year and call the occasion New Year's Day. If we did any celebrating today (that is, prior to this evening), we ought to call it Old Year's Day.

CORRESPONDENTS of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System completed last night their annual seminars on the state of the world. Once again recent television history repeated itself: N.B.C. had much the best of it.

Deposits in the twelve member banks of the New York Clearing House Association, which includes eight of the nation's fifteen biggest banks, declined $304,000,000, or 1.13 per cent on a daily average basis, to $26,513,000,000 in 1960.
The Transit Authority announced schedule changes yesterday for the BMT Brighton, Fourth Avenue and West End lines.
Charles (Chuck) McKinley said yesterday he had no intention of turning professional at this time unless his suspension by the United States Lawn Tennis Association forced him out of the amateur game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy has selected Dr. Robert C. Weaver, vice chairman of New York City's Housing and Redevelopment Board, to be the new Housing and Home Finance Administrator.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- On New Year's Day the European Economic Community will take the first steps toward establishing a common tariff and ultimate separation of Britain from the political and economic grouping of Europe's most populous and prosperous nations.
PORT READING, N.J., Dec. 30 -- A construction foreman was killed and nine other workmen injured when a 200,000gallon water tank burst here this morning while being tested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Gordon M. Tiffany, outgoing staff director of the Federal Civil Rights Commission, recommended today strict adherence to the Constitutional provision that states that bar Negroes from voting be subject to loss of seats in the House of Representatives.

A 365-acre airport in Baltimore has been converted to a marine terminal. The area, bordering on Colgate Creek in the Maryland port, was bought by the Maryland Port Authority from the City Department of Aviation for $4,047,310.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 30 -- Col. Joseph D. Mobutu announced today that "important events" would take place in Kivu Province during the next few days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad won a new lease on solvency today with Federal backing for a $3,500,000 loan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Government rejected today the plea of independent tanker operators for a ruling that half of the country's oil imports be carried in American-flag ships.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Eastern power rated a one-touchdown edge over Western speed on the eve of the thirty-sixth annual Shrine EastWest football game before a capacity crowd of 60,000 at Kezar Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices ended the year about 5 per cent higher than at the start, and up nearly one-half of 1 per cent from a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Temple beat American University tonight in the final of the first Capital basketball tournament, 61-51. Lafayette took consolation honors by downing Lehigh for the thirty-sixth straight time, 62 -- 49.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A New York architectural firm's concept of a cluster of perpendicular tablets carrying famous words of Franklin D. Roosevelt won today a $50,000 award for the best design for a memorial to the New Deal President.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The largest construction program for highways and public buildings ever undertaken by the state will be recommended by Governor Rockefeller when he addresses a joint session of the 1961 Legislature on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Burlington Truck Lines, Inc., a subsidiary of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, announced today it has acquired under lease the operation of H.B. Green Transportation Line, Inc., Burlington, Iowa.

HAL HOLBROOK, who rose from television soap opera to international stage stardom in "Mark Twain Tonight," may impersonate Lincoln on a one-man television show. Designed to bring out the humorous, soft-spoken Lincoln, the program would present a reading from his letters, speeches and other material.
The United States and Canadian dollars stood almost equal in value last week for the first time in some four years.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- L.A. Chesler's Kings Song rallied in the last seventy yards to win the $11,900 City of Miami Beach Stakes for 2-year-olds by a nose at Tropical Park today.

In preparing for the thirty-fifth anniversary celebration of the client-agency relationship between the American Tobacco Company and the Lawrence C. Gumbinner Advertising Agency, Inc., it was decided that it might be appropriate to have a collection of the 1925 issues of The Saturday Evening Post in which Gumbinner's first advertisements on behalf of their new client appeared.
A legislative respite in the school desegregation conflict is predicted by the Southern Education Reporting Service after a survey of fourteen Southern and border states.

FOR THIS WEEK: Be sure that the living Christmas tree is planted outdoors and mulch it well to insure good root growth. . . . Use a cut tree as a feeding station for the birds. . . . Whenever snow falls, brush it off evergreen or deciduous shrubbery to avoid branch breaking. . . . Spread sand on icy walks; rock salt melts into the ground and damages near-by plants.

As 1961 opens -- a year of fateful decision and great uncertainty -- these are the four insistent questions:
SOMERVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31 -- Residents of Fayette and Haywood Counties awaited today the next development in the Federal Government's attempt at enforcing voting rights for Negroes here.

THE 1961 winners of the All-America Gladiolus Selections award are Gypsy Dancer, Rusty, and China Blue. Labeled packages of these patented varieties are available and should be ordered now, even though the planting of gladiolus corms does not begin until the soil warms up in spring.

JANUARY is a good month to browse perennial catalogues. Succession bloom is an achievement, and if there were gaps in last summer's floral display, plans can be made for fill-in plantings next spring.
PHARR, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Gerald Grayson scored four touchdowns today and led his McKeesport (Pa.) Little Tigers to a 56-0 rout of the Houston Variety Boys Club in the twelfth annual Milk Bowl.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 31 -- Western military experts gave careful study today to the Laotian Government statement telling of an invasion by troops of Communist North Vietnam. They wondered whether the invasion could be one of many sallies across the ill-defined border.
PHOTOGRAPHY as a science is the latest addition to the hobby field for young people. It is offered as a package, "The Science of Photography Lab," by Science Materials Center, 59 Fourth Avenue.
THE current revival of Victoriana means, for many Americans, a passport back to childhood.

FOR students of American liberalism, Oswald Garrison Villard (1872-1949) is a fascinating figure. He was one of the few liberal publicists of post-World War I years who interpreted events from the perspective of a reform tradition that antedated the Civil War.

AMONG the most delightful places this reviewer has known in America was a Connecticut farmhouse on whose walls paintings bloomed as naturally as flowers in the surrounding fields. Originally belonging to the subject of this volume, J. Alden Weir (1852-1919), third in a family line of painters, the house was at that time the home of his daughter Dorothy, herself a painter and married to the powerful sculptor, Mahonri Young.

THERE'S a hard year coming for music editors and festival managers. Few musicians of real importance managed to get themselves born or leave this world in the year 1861. A single illustrious name lights up the register for 1811, and 1761 was a black year for musical vital statistics, unable to offer us a single bicentennial celebration.

You and your fellow heroes of causes public and private demonstrate a stupidity frightening in the lengths it will go to feed its own meglomaniacical [sic] vanity . . . . Your lack of touch with actuality and the irresponsibility with which you conjecture leaves little common ground on which an attempt to improve your judgment can be made.

The calendar gave holiday business a break in the pre-Christmas week but it worked to the disadvantage of the year's closing week. Sales in the week ended Dec. 31 had five shopping days, against six a year ago.
Your headline of Dec. 27 "Eisenhower Plans a Foreign Aid Cut" is very disturbing news. A simple analysis shows that it is disturbing for two significant reasons.
TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- In the face of recent bus tragedies in this country and Canada, the State Division of Motor Vehicles has initiated a rigid examination for prospective drivers of school buses.
A truck with a built in conveyor belt to expedite the loading and unloading of freight, mail and passenger baggage from jet aircraft has been put to use at New York International Airport.

THE process of obtaining tickets for New York productions seems to be a major project, comparable to orbiting the more complicated missiles. I have sent approximately seventeen letters (involving return envelopes in each case) and, at the moment, I have one ticket, with four in doubt.

Oscar Robertson of the Cincinnati Royals was the only rookie named yesterday to start in the National Basketball Association East-West all-star game at Syracuse on Jan. 17. "Big O" will play for the West.

Much as I dislike having to disagree with the gracious senior Senator from the State of Maine, I must register my objection to the recent plan put forth by Margaret Chase Smith for abolishing the Electoral College. Under her proposed constitutional amendment we would elect our Presidents by direct majority vote.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Although Chicago's vast new exhibition hall, McCormick Place, is already heavily booked for the next five years, its management is hopefully reserving likely dates in 1964 for one or both of the major political conventions.
The Echo I satellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, seven times this week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced.
The New York Knickerbockers will make only one home appearance this week, Tuesday night, against Syracuse in Madison Square Garden.
A picture of unrelieved gloom was drawn for the country's shipyards last week in a year-end statement by L.R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science, the world's largest federation of scientific societies, held its annual meeting in New York City last week. It dealt with a vast potpourri of subjects in both the physical and social sciences.
" This city is like an ocean -- it swallows things up," a young man in Sterling Place, Brooklyn, was saying yesterday.
American singers took the five major roles in "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon when the Verdi work was restored to the company's repertory after a season's absence.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- The Italian Government has taken effective measures to limit the outflow of dollars from the United States to Italy. In this way it has given its unsolicited cooperation to the efforts being made by the Eisenhower Administration to prevent a further depletion of the American gold reserves.

BUFFALO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Canisius defeated Princeton tonight, 79 -- 73, and gained the final of the seventh annual Queen City invitational basketball tournament against Drake. The final will be played on Monday. Drake turned back Connecticut, 90 -- 81, as Gus Guydon starred.

NOW that we can look back over fifteen years of recorded versions of musical shows, it becomes increasingly apparent that there is more to this still-young art than placing the members of a cast before microphones and having them sing a show's song.
HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- The Government ended today visa-free entry by Americans into Cuba.
It is human to expect each one of our twelve-month slices of time to be an improvement over the one immediately preceding it, but we do not know. The questions are not answered in advance.

THE difficulties of writing about a country not one's own are hideously frustrating. I should love to write about America. Here is this stimulating scene, bright, new, different, but not so different that the visitor can't grasp its essence; yet I dare not, for the moment, anyway, touch it. It is maddening.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Bill Mazeroski, world series hero of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was named major league baseball's player of the year by The Sporting News today.

THE Pennsylvania Turnpike, the nation's first multi-lane toll superhighway, is quietly marking this winter twenty years of operation. Meantime, its commissioners are working hard to move traffic in better order and more safely and are still holding firm, on the pike's main line, to the original toll rate of about 1 cent a mile for passenger cars.

HONGKONG, Dec. 31 -- Communist intervention in strategic Laos has risen in recent weeks and there are no signs of an imminent tapering off. Indeed, if the volume of Communist propaganda against the new pro-Western Government of Prince Boun Oum and the efforts the Communist bloc is making to marshal international opinion against the regime and nations friendly to it represent any test, the Communist drive against Laos is entering a new and dangerous phase.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 31 -- When Dag Hammarskjold arrives in the Congo early next week he will be confronted with a state of division, dissension and disintegration that verges on civil war.
The Department of Buildings has used every available weapon in the last two years to stamp out graft and corruption, Commissioner Peter J. Reidy declared yesterday.

IN novels about Americans abroad, there is a new and uncongenial stereotype: the feeble American. Henry James' sojourning Americans had a certain purity and native vigor; they were protected by their innocence against the violations of spirit perpetrated by weary, cynical Europeans.
HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- The Cabinet established diplomatic relations today with North Vietnam, Albania, Outer Mongolia and Hungary. All members of the Communist bloc.
Many debutantes of the season attended last night's Mayfair Assembly, a dinner dance held in the Pierre Roof.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31 -- Development of the resources of the Tennessee Valley region this year continued to yield increasing returns, the Tennessee Valley Authority reported today in its annual report to the President and Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- Jimmy Herbstreit of Ohio State, the smallest man on the field, turned in the biggest play, a 55-yard runback of an intercepted pass, as the East beat the West, 7 -- 0, before 59,000 in Kezar Stadium today.

SIDNEY LUMET, whose work in films ("12 Angry Men"), television ("The Iceman Cometh") and the theatre ("Caligula,") leaves no doubt as to his directorial versatility, is preparing, to return to the movie field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Dear Senator Kennedy: In making your plans for the new year, I hope you will take into account the longings of the American people.
FIVE plays have recently been running in the West End of London that could not have been staged legally only a few years ago.

A CHARACTER named Rittenhouse, who never appears on stage, is one of the butts of the jesting in "Critic's Choice." He is the second-string drama critic, and according to the noble, gifted first-stringer, who is visible all the time in the glamorous person of Henry Fonda, he is complacent and fatuous.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- The Laotian representative to the United Nation called on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold this evening for the second time in twenty-four hours following reports that Communist troops from North Vietnam had invaded Laotian territory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy is seriously considering appointing John J. McCloy of New York to head the nation's disarmament efforts.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- A new West German-Soviet trade agreement providing for a 20 per cent increase in the exchange of goods was signed here today.

WRITERS with established reputations dominate Martha Foley's and David Burnett's current annual offering of "best" American short stories. Only two of the nineteen authors can really be called newcomers, and only four have not already published books of their own.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 -- An indication that Vice President Nixon plans to keep a tight rein on his home Republican cadre appeared this week.
New York entered the New Year today facing the possibility of a heavy snow.

THE New Year bodes well for motorists whose itineraries call for them to pass through New York City and its environs. For being realized now are the first benefits of a long-awaited system of bridges, tunnels and expressways that is designed to speed the motorist on his way and, it is hoped, prevent further clogging of many of the city's principal north-south and east-west arteries.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- A Boston literary landmark has been saved from demolition.

After a period of inactivity because of the holidays, dog show competition will be resumed next week-end. The event is the forty-fourth national specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt on Saturday and Sunday.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- A biography of the incoming President of the United States will appear here; in French on Jan. 20, Inauguration Day, as the first translation made possible by a new use of American Government funds.

When Mrs. Gertrude L. Earl shepherded the second and last of the season's Junior Assemblies to a close on Dec. 23, she also wrote finis to a long career as secretary and treasurer of the dances, New York's most exclusive debutante parties.

The 1960 curtain came down on the stock market last week on an appropriately uncertain note. Prices edged down a bit on average in narrow and irregular trading. Last-minute switching -- for tax-selling purposes -- was a major reason for cross-currents in the four-day trading period.

SHORTLY after noon tomorrow, millions of Americans will start taking part -- vicariously -- in the gladiatorial rituals that annually climax the college football season: the bowl games. For eight hours they will be able to sample the festivities and brutalities of the Orange, Sugar, Cotton and Rose Bowls, all bound up in one glorious afternoon of ceremonial violence.
The year 1960 was characterized by a steady growth in the quality and scope of rehabilitation services both in the United States and abroad.

Of the many boards, commissions and agencies in the Federal Government, four attract the most attention and controversy. NO doubt it is a coincidence that the three most impressive films to come along at the year's end have to do with soldiering. "Exodus," "Tunes of Glory" and "Ballad of a Soldier" are all concerned with various professional or personal problems of assorted military men.

TUNIS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The Algerian rebel regime will conduct a campaign calling for a boycott of the referendum in France and Algeria next month, a spokesman for the rebels' Provisional Government said here today.

TORONTO, Dec. 31 (UPI) --Dava Koon, a rookie, scored twice tonight and led the Toronto-Maple Leafs to a 2-1 victory over the' New York Rangers in a Nati0na! Hockey League game.

A GROUP of college seniors was asked recently to expand the unfinished sentence, "Out of my childhood I love to remember -----." Again and again the completed sentences dwelt nostalgically on memories of humor and gaiety in family life.
The fifth annual Polonaise Ball will take place at the Sheraton-East on Jan. 14. Proceeds will go to Polish Mutual Assistance for the relief here of aged, sick and unemployed refugees from Poland.
MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- One of Britain's top space scientists said today he expected the Russians to be the first in the field of manned space flights.

A five-year project to raise the academic level of both teachers and pupils in Negro secondary schools in the South is described in a 250-page report published recently by the Phelps-Stokes Fund. Plans for a single-chamber legislature for the city -- with guaranteed minority representation -- were reported likely yesterday to be part of the Moore state commission's charter revision proposal, which is due soon.

TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Two first-quarter fumble recoveries by Les Senft of Rutgers and one by Dick Mills of Pittsburgh sparked the National All-Stars to a 27-8 victory over the South-West today in the Copper Bowl football game.

Steel production in the Chicago area in 1960 has been estimated at 19,165,000 net tons. The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry said that the figure was the fifth highest steel tonnage recorded by the area. Output in 1960 was 2,250,000 tons below the record set in 1955, but it compared with 16,809,000 tons pro duced in 1959 and 16,800,000 tons in 1958.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- The Hadassah delegation to the World Zionist Congress here sprang tonight to defense of Premier David Ben-Gurion, who angered Jews abroad with his statement that "whoever dwells outside the land of Israel is considered to have no God."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Dick Groat, the Pittsburgh Pirate shortstop, today was named winner of the Lou Gehrig Memorial Award, presented annually to the major league player best typifying the spirit of the former New York Yankee star.

WHEN a flashlight fails to operate properly suspicion usually falls the batteries or the bulb. If these have been checked and found satisfactory, yet the flashlight still does not work, then check the various contact points inside the case to make certain they are clean.

THE section of the James M. Landis report dealing with the Federal Communications Commission hit the nail on the head. The last week of the old year drew to a close on a somewhat bleak note for retailers in this area. Department store executives estimated that sales fell as much as 5 per cent below the 1959 level. Merchants said the reason for the decline was an unfavorable shift in the calendar combined with poor weather on Thursday, an important selling day.

The exceptionally severe snowstorm which came at the middle of the month was in part responsible for the less-than-expected Christmas business.
The country's merchants are confident there will be new gains in sales this year, but they do not expect a steady climb to begin for some months.

MADRID, Dec. 31 -- Enrique Cardinal Play Deniel, Roman Catholic primate of Spain, has warned Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime that a "conflict" is looming here between the church and the state.

" LUDUS DE NATO INFANTE MIRIFICUS" is the euphonious title of Carl Orff's latest work, which was given its world premiere by the Wuerttemberg State Opera in Stuttgart shortly before Christmas.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- C.V. Whitney's Tompion made a strong stretch run to win the $27,650 Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita today in a race that lost most of its excitement when Kelso, the "horse of the year," was declared out of action.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 30 -- Joseph Abraham, a local boy who went out into the world and made good, walked into the Association of Americans and Canadians here today and asked for help. He is now 103 years old.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 31 -- Bernie Allen of Purdue and Ray Purdin of Northwestern combined their talents today and led the North All-Stars to a 35-7 victory over the South in a rainy Blue-Gray game.

In 1960, the theme for American education was curriculum reform. For the first time in more than a generation American educators, especially in elementary and secondary schools, were introducing drastic changes.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Iowa, boasting a big front line and two fast guards, stopped the high-scoring University of California at Los Angeles last night and won the Los Angeles Basketball Classic.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet press agency Tass said Mr. Khrushchev had brought up the U-2 incident when he "recalled a statement made by Mr. Kennedy during the United States election campaign that, if he were President, he would express his regret to the Soviet Government over the U-2 plane flight."

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- A twenty-word statement made in 1958 is believed to have produced Gov. Foster Furcolo's attack last night on Dean McGeorge Bundy of Harvard College, named today by President-elect John. F. Kennedy as special assistant for security affairs.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 31 -- A number of observers rate Joe Bellino the finest college football player since the Roaring Twenties, when Red Grange ran wild for Illinois. And Bellino, who on Monday will lead Navy against Missouri in the Orange Bowl, has the credentials to support the claims.
Bailey Brown, a 17-year-old Senior from Bronxville High School, won the junior title as the annual Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships ended yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy said tonight there would be no comment on the suggestion by Premier Khrushchev to bury the U-2 incident.

THE spell cast by Rome on European and American artists from the Renaissance to the late eighteenth century is the subject of a fascinating exhibition, "Ruins of Rome," now being held at the University of Pennsylvania's museum in Philadelphia.
THE year 1960 in contract bridge followed the pattern of the last several years. Wherever statistics are available, they show increases ranging from 5 to 10 per cent over the previous year.

Our schools and colleges are teaching less and less of the dead languages and more and more of science, mathematics and Russian, but you can't keep track of the newest missiles, rockets and satellites unless you have a nodding acquaintance with the gods of Greece and Rome.
TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- Heart diseases accounted for 27,637 deaths, or nearly half of all those recorded, in New Jersey this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Cuba asked tonight for an immediate meeting of the Security Council, to consider charges that the United States had "aggressive" intentions against the island republic.

ONE of the pleasant gifts for an art museum during 1960 was $150,000 from the CBS Foundation (through which the Columbia Broadcasting System makes its gifts) to the Museum of Modern Art -- $30,000 a year for five years.

Valuation of building permits in 107 reporting cities of the district rose 16 per cent in November, to $39,492,082, from the 1959 level, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Cumulative valuations for the eleven months of 1960 still trailed last year's total of $457,268,282 by more than $21,000,000, or 4.7 per cent.
