BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 31 -- The Belgian sitting at home tonight is likely to say, "Happy New Year, bah!" and then, looking around his family circle, take a drink and add, "Oh well, Happy New Year!"

The almost unbounded optimism that permeated steel industry forecasts a year ago is totally missing from the year-end statements now being issued by industry leaders. Not only are steel industry executives wary and only mildly optimistic about an upturn in operations soon, but also they are refraining from predicting 1961 production of the basic metal.

The Cuban insurrection ended in triumph two years ago today and the revolution began. It is a devastating thought, but students of such upheavals from the French Revolution onward know that this type of revolution normally lasts many years, or at least takes many years to work itself out.

SINCE World War II there has a major revival of interest in Tennyson. The publication in 1949 of Sir Charles Tennyson's "Alfred Tennyson" provided a sound biographical basis for work on the poet, and subsequent removal of Tennyson's extensive papers to Harvard University has made possible their close scrutiny by a number of scholars with impressive results in the learned journals.

I ADVERTISED in my last lecture to the prevailing laxity in the use of terms: this is the principal complaint to which the moderns are exposed, but it is a grievous one inasmuch as it inevitably tends to the misapplication of words and to the corruption of language.
A 22-year-old Brooklyn mother shot and killed her policeman husband with his service revolver yesterday in a dispute over her care of their three young children.

The year 1960 bowed out with a spate of predictions for the new year. Scanning them, one is reminded of George Eliot, who said, "Among all forms of mistake, prophecy is the most gratuitous," or a paraphrasing of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, when he said, substantially: when he said, in substance: prophets to the left and bewilderment in the middle.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 31 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., the only competitor who had been in the first regatta back in the early Nineteen Thirties, proved today that the newer generation had a thing or two to learn about dinghy sailing.

Factory sales of all kinds of electrical products last year reached a record of $22,622,300,000, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported last week. This was an increase of 5 per cent above the $21,522,900,000 in 1959.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 31 -- Chief Rabbi Itzhak Nissim gave a qualified endorsement tonight to Premier Ben-Gurion's statements, but noted some exaggerations and some understatements.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 31 -- Parishioners of St. Luke's Roman Catholic parish here have been supporting their church for three years by a "tithing" plan somewhat similar to one announced on Christmas Day by a New Jersey Catholic pastor.

FIREFIGHTING is the most dangerous of peacetime professions -- and often the most dramatic, as the pictures on these pages show. One man has been killed every five weeks in the New York City Fire Department since it was established in 1865. The 1959 toll was thirteen slightly higher than average.

AN all-out thermonuclear war is generally described as "unthinkable." The description has psychological validity. Most of us conclude that it would mean the end of everything and refuse to think further about it.

IN the movie industry, where a film made ten years ago can be referred to as "a classic," and stars who worked within the lifetime of most living Americans are treated with the mysterious awe of pagan gods, legend finds fertile soil.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- The big news here for tourists and residents alike has been the traffic relief afforded by the opening of the vehicular tunnel under the New River on U.S. 1.

President-elect Kennedy's designation of Dr. Robert C. Weaver to be his Housing and Home Finance Administrator is primarily important because Dr. Weaver is a gifted and experienced man in this field. His book, "The Negro Ghetto," published twelve years ago, showed that he was already thinking wisely and calmly about one of the outstanding problems of housing.
Press censorship, often disguised, grew tighter in many areas of the world in 1960.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 31 -- Dean William B. Lockhart of the University of Minnesota Law School is recruiting bright students.

ON the morning of Nov. 8, 1956, excitement ran high in the South Pacific port of Papeete, Tahiti. A locally built bamboo raft was about to attempt a west-to-east passage to the coast of Chile. The raft, christened Tahiti Nui (Great Tahiti) was captained by a 66-year-old Frenchman, Eric de Bisschop.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- Unseeded Ham Richardson of Fanwood, N.J., won the twenty-fourth annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today by defeating Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

THE American minority in the triumvirate that formed Britain's youngest and most daring film company, Woodfall Productions, has been eliminated. Harry Saltzman, the partner of John Osborne and Tony Richardson in the making of "Look Back in Anger," "The Entertainer" and "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning," has resigned.
Nestor Joseph -- "please just call me Mac" -- MacDonald, president of Thomas Betts Company, Inc., is a good salesman and an honest man.
The sale of Goose, a Six-Meter yacht, by Herman F. Whiton of New York last week to Wilmot V. Castle of Rochester, N.Y., probably will result in the end of Six-Meter competition on Long Island Sound.

The cold facts of rising expenses and a reduced rate of traffic growth iced the wings of the domestic trunk airlines in 1960, bringing them down to the lowest profit levels since 1949 -- the year the industry turned its first post-war profit.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The University of Cincinnati's basketball team defeated George Washington University tonight 84 -- 61. Cincinnati led at halftime, 35 -- 31. In less than six minutes of the second half, Cincinnati went ahead, 49 -- 33, when the starting five and one substitute joined in a 14-point scoring spree.

The decline of the American theatre is lamented by almost everyone who writes on the subject. High box-office prices are said to be the primary cause, and government-subsidized repertory is offered as the solution.
THE tenth annual Capezio Dance Award has fallen to Ruth St. Denis, and the presentation of the scroll, and the $1,000 check that goes with it, will be made to her at a luncheon later this month.

Rafer Johnson was named yesterday as the winner of the 1960 Sullivan Trophy. The prize, in memory of James E. Sullivan, is awarded by the Amateur Athletic Union to the year's outstanding amateur athlete.

ON this the first day of the New Year, all resolutions made and eyes resolutely ahead, the time has come to discuss a most important topic: how to establish yourself as a connoisseur of music. Now, goodness knows, there are all kinds of books on music appreciation; books in which quaint subjects like fauxbourdon, harmonic and melodic minor, the contributions of the madrigalists and the number of rests in Beethoven's last quartets are discussed.
The strains of "California Here I Come" pervade the board rooms of some of the nation's major oil companies.
Maritime labor has assailed the Eisenhower Administration for pursuing a course of inaction while the merchant marine fleet carries increasingly smaller quantities of cargo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- House investigators announced today they had referred complaints involving elections in the Eleventh District of Missouri and Fifteenth District of Illinois to the House Administration Committee without recommendation.

Dollar transactions flowing through Philadelphia banks have jumped nearly five-fold since 1940, according to Leonard A. Drake, staff economist of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia. In 1940 the monthly average of total bank debits, excluding time accounts, was $1,386,000,000.

TELEVISION antennas sprouting weedlike from wretched hovels in Rio de Janeiro or tilting drunkenly above packing crates that serve as homes in Naples are testimonials that, for better or worse, the mass medium is becoming a true medium for the masses of the world.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- A psychiatrist has urged that the nation's general hospitals set up "walk-in" psychiatric clinics.
Levity is a rare commodity in the international airline industry, particularly where passengers are concerned.

FOR the first-time visitor to Israel, the country itself, its ambitions and its amazing progress on many fronts during the twelve years of its independence, provide drama to which the theatre, music and other entertainment arts would seem to take a secondary place.
DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 31 -- Residents of a community in India recently entertained twelve American families stationed in that country as a reciprocal gesture toward residents of Darien.
Mr. Schonberg is correct in stating that our present day singers, by and large, are better musicians; but very few have the vocal techniques of their predecessors. Why? There are several reason.

Once upon a time the "putt-putts" were cantankerous, ornery, rebellious little machines that caused boatmen to swear like troopers and generally lose their tempers. Happily most of that has changed for the better.
FIRST came the British, then the Americans -- tomorrow, the world, part of it, anyway.

From singing instruction for bluebirds to the number of tons of seafood the human race consumes each year -- these points were among an imposing deluge of facts and ideas loosed on New York during the last six days.

NAILS which can be driven in with a hammer -- yet which hold like a wood screw -- are becoming more and more popular for use in all types of carpentry work where greatly increased holding power is desired.
DALLAS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Southeastern Conference, with three representatives, paced the ninth annual all-America academic football team announced today.

Nineteen Sixty has been a bad year for peace. * * * Can 1961 do better? It can; but only if both sides profit from the lessons of the past year. The main obstacle to disarmament is lack of trust. * * * Both sides should try to build on the ground they have in common instead of concentrating on the differences between them.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- The ideological battle for Mexico is expected to become more intense and widespread next year.

Re "Blueprint for an Ideal College," by McGeorge Bundy (Dec. 11). I couldn't help but admire the lucid, detached analysis made by Dean Bundy in advocating status-free, football-free, academically minded students at his ideal college. But it appears that his criteria change radically when he discusses staffing this same college.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Florida won the Gator Bowl football game, 13 -- 12, today when Baylor missed a go-for-broke 2-point conversion attempt in the closing seconds. Baylor, led by its quarterbacks, Bobby Ply and Ronnie Stanley, almost pulled out a victory after Florida had built a 13-0 lead.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 31 (A.P.) -- Twelve oil companies were convicted in Federal Court here late last night of fixing gasoline prices in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
The Main Reading Room in the Fifth Avenue building of the New York Public Library will be open today and tomorrow from 1 to 10 P.M.

OBVIOUSLY, every critical approach to poetry, the appreciative no less than the historical or "new" or moral, has its perils. It can lead, as it all but inevitably seems to do, to displays of bad temper or wounded vanity, the cultivation of prejudice or self-indulgence, the blurring of distinctions between a poet and his work that are best kept clear.

Plans are under way for the re-enactment this year of some of the major events of the Civil War. These will range from the first shots fired in the Charleston, S.C., harbor on Jan. 9, 1861, to the surrender of General Robert E. Lee at Appomatox on April 9, 1865.
A scientist said yesterday that all colleges should have required courses on current affairs, with regular class discussions based on required daily newspaper reading.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Each member of the Kid Line of Ralph Backstrom, Billy Hicke and Gilles Tremblay scored tonight as the Montreal Canadiens gained a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins.
HOUSTON, Dec. 31 -- The Los Angeles Chargers, riding a four-game winning streak, will meet the Houston Oilers tomorrow in the first championship game of the new American Football League.
With a successful Christmas season behind them, resident buying offices in this city last week began shifting their activities to meet the early requirements of the spring season.

AS the New Year opens, one issue, made clear by last year's storms and dissension, is paramount. Nations are obsessed as never before with "prestige." They are not only concerned about what they do; they are immensely preoccupied with the impact on other states of what they do.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Assistant Attorney General Robert A. Bicks reported today that the Government had started more than ninety antitrust suits in 1960, a post-war high figure.

The teaching profession is losing intellectually superior men who like teaching, but who do not like the pay or the working conditions, according to a study made of Air Force veterans who entered teaching after World War II.
A new nautical light has been added to navigation charts for Long Island Sound.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31 -- North Carolina's Tar Heels took the lead in the final ten minutes and toppled previously unbeaten Duke, 76 -- 71, tonight in the final of the Dixie Classic basketball tournament.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur's mother was born in Norfolk of an old Virginia family. It is natural that he should accept that city's invitation to create out of an old neo-classical Greek courthouse a MacArthur Memorial. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Western Hemisphere command headquarters are in Norfolk and the city is a military citadel of the West.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York yesterday called on its 1,700 member churches to help make this city a better place in which to live during 1961.

WASHINGTON. WASHINGTON prophets disagree on what will happen when the new Congress, now assembling on the local scene, is married to President-elect Kennedy at noon, Jan. 20. Some predict a row soon after the wedding guests leave and the two face the realities they find in each other.

A leading New York rabbi took issue yesterday with Premier David Ben-Gurion's remark last Wednesday that Jews who lived outside Israel were "godless" and were violating the precepts of Judaism every day they remained away from the country.
The beginning of a new year finds the big New York City banks in a familiar stance -- inside the city looking out.

SINCE every self-respecting, red-blooded, right-thinking American hunter and fisherman is bound to make resolutions on New Year's Day, the thing might as well be done and cleared away now, and forgotten.

THE citizens of Tampa, Fla., already are making preparations to surrender themselves, their guests and the city to a band of fun-thirsty pirates. The Jolly Roger will fly over Tampa's City Hall on Monday, Feb. 13, and at noon on that day a fully-rigged pirate ship, the Jose Gasparilla, will sail into Tampa Bay.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The giants of English League soccer went on a scoring spree today.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, the State Health Commissioner, today renewed his warning that air pollution was an increasingly serious health hazard.
MY recent checklist of 1960 favorites was restricted to novels. Now, in the lull between seasons, seems a good time to look at the other crime books of the past year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The several special interest groups whose programs were substantially incorporated in the Democratic national platform of 1960 as pledges for redemption by the convention nominees, if elected, have begun to organize pressures on President-elect Kennedy for prompt fulfillment. Foremost among these groups, as the first year of the new administration opens, are the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the Americans for Democratic Action and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

Michael H. Drendergast, the Democratic state chairman, yesterday urged Republican members of the Legislature to rebel against Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a straight 10 per cent rebate on 1960 income taxes.
A mammoth program is under way to publish for the first time all available original records of great figures in American history.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Jan. 1 -- Premier Khrushchev said early today that he would drop the Soviet complaint against the United States concerning the U-2 spy plane incident in the hope of improving relations between the two countries after the Kennedy Administration was installed.

INCREASINGLY, I am disturbed by our current fuzziness in the use of words. The number that float in a sea of vagueness constantly increases. First, perhaps, we became aware of what was happening to certain words with a political content of connotation -- words like "democracy," "liberal" and "conservative."
Teams representing Moscow and Leningrad engaged in a double-round match on forty boards in Moscow recently. Leningrad won, 40 1/2 -- 39 1/2.

KEP, Cambodia, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, ousted premier of strife-torn Laos, bitterly denounced the United States today for helping his enemies. He called for a meeting of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France to prevent Laos from becoming "another Korea."
HOUSTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Prairie View A. and M. scored a 19-8 triumph over Arkansas A. and M. in the thirty-third Prairie View Bowl tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States Government warned the Communists today that it would take "the most serious view" of any intervention in Laos by the Chinese Reds, North Vietnamese or others in support of the Communist rebels there.

HARTFORD, Dec. 31 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff will give his address of farewell to Connecticut politics and government Wednesday before a joint session of the State Senate and House of Representatives on the opening day of the biennial session of the General Assembly.

THE assassination of President James A. Garfield in 1881, overshadowed, in the public mind, the prospects of an Arctic expedition which had sailed north earlier in the summer. This was the expedition under the command of Lieut. Adolphus W. Greeley of the United States Army, to northeastern Ellesmere Island for the purpose of establishing and maintaining a station for observation of polar phenomena.
IN 1951, a 17-year-old choir singer from a hamlet called Dale, Ind., checked into New York in search of a career in show business.

AND a Happy New Year to you, too! There is no known cure for a hangover, the only fact in this column that is guaranteed to be correct. The remaining contents are accepted at your own risk. This sale is final. No returns. No refunds. If the customers will form an orderly line, we'll see what the coming twelve months have to offer.
A post office clerk and his family of six will be the first tenants to move into James Monroe Houses, a newly completed low-income public housing project in the Bronx.
The Day Treatment Center and School of the Godmother's League will benefit from a motion-picture party to be held at Wednesday evening's showing of "Exodus" at the Warner Theatre.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Denmark, a small country with a great seafaring tradition, has greatly extended its shipbuilding capacity in a bid to capture a sizable share of the world's new market for supertankers.

Premier Khrushchev increased still more the production goals for some industrial commodities last week and dismissed his Minister of Agriculture. The two developments summed up the differing fortunes of the two key areas of the Soviet economy in 1960.

Dr. Rudolf L. Mossbauer, 31-year-old German physicist now a research fellow at the California Institute of Technology, will receive the 1960 Research Corporation Award of $5,000, it was announced last week by Caltech and the Research Corporation.

A COUPLE of weeks ago a thought was offered here that if first novels had a season all their own -- December, say, and/or midsummer -- they would receive mine attention than when published amid the turmoil of the rest of the year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- The benefits of having the mother accompany an ailing child during a hospital stay should not be overlooked, a study published by the World Health Organization said today.

An Administration in its last weeks of power has little real chance to set long-range national policy. Since President Eisenhower knows this full well, the chief purpose of his statement declaring "the Government should aggressively encourage private enterprise" in setting up communications satellites must be to put his views on record and encourage public discussion.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 30 -- The dream of African unity or solidarity appears to be receding as more and more African countries achieve independence.

With "Happy New Year" still ringing in the air, women have a frivolous way of turning their heads to spring. Some of the things they will see are indicated by the custom millinery shown here. Brims, ranging in size from minute to immense, are a major theme in the spring hat story. The brimmers will appear in silks and straws and may be worn at many angles.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy today disregarded protests by Gov. Foster Furcolo of Massachusetts and appointed McGeorge Bundy as a special assistant for national security affairs.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 31 -- For two weeks the town squares of Belgium that usually present a cheerful scene of flower markets bordered by medieval buildings have been disfigured by angry mass meetings, by breaking of windows and by scuffles between the roughest members of the crowds and the police.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Britain will begin a busy year of African diplomacy and negotiation this week with discussions of economic and financial cooperation between her East African colonies and protectorates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Approved dress for the various official functions connected with the Presidential inauguration of John F. Kennedy was announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The Security Council will meet at 10:30 A.M. Wednesday to consider charges by Cuba that the United States is planning aggression against her.
The New York Stock Exchange normally doesn't operate with a crystal ball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Arthur J. Goldberg announced today that he had severed connections with all labor organizations and had divested himself of any property interests that might conflict with his new job as Secretary of Labor.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Baily Howell paced the Detroit Pistons tonight to their fourth straight victory, a 116-105 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association game.

GENEVA, Jan. 1, -- Narrow gains were in the majority last week as the Swiss stock markets ended the year on a calm and steady note. Volume failed to expand noticeably from the relatively low levels of recent weeks despite a last-minute flurry among the Swiss chemicals.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 -- George Byers Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, won the Orange Bowl Regatta Grand Prix today. He drove his seven-litre hydroplane, Miss Desoto VI, at speeds of more than 100 miles an hour. Dixon Vose of Turner, Ore., was second.
HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- Communist China warned today that world wars could result from local wars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- The Army made public today details of the Davy Crockett rocket, designed to provide the foot soldier with a highly mobile weapon equal in fire-power to massed heavy artillery.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 -- Three foreign investments totaling $90,000,000 for Argentina's expanding chemical industry have been approved, according to the Ministry of the Economy.
KEEPING a girl down on the farm after she's seen Paris is tricky business. No one understands it better than those two rivals for her affections, Sears, Roebuck and Montgomery Ward.

The city's Department of Commerce and Public Events has performed a useful service in issuing the fourth annual edition of its "Statistical Guide for New York City," this one for 1960. The book seeks to provide answers for the cascade of questions that constantly pour in regarding the city's economy, people, facilities and activities.

CARL JUNCTION, Mo., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Twenty-eight cars of a 115-car Kansas City Southern freight train were derailed near this southwest Missouri community last night and caught fire. Two cars loaded with propane, a liquid gas, exploded during the predawn darkness sending a wall of flame over the rest of the wreckage.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The United States today won the Orange Cup junior tennis team championship for the first time in the three-year history of the event, defeating Australia, 3 -- 0.
A 17 per cent decline in automobile fatalities in this city last year was reported yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Minnesota's outsized Gophers, the nation's top-ranking collegiate football squad, will match their muscle against the Washington Huskies' speed tomorrow in the forty-seventh annual Rose Bowl game.

The career of Ivan Lyon, "one of the least orthodox, most mysterious warriors of World War II," is the subject of a new book by Brian Connell called "Return of the Tiger." Captain Lyon was a member of the Gordon Highlanders stationed in Singapore before its capture by the Japanese.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The United States Government has called for the earliest possible meeting of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization Council to consider the crisis in Laos.
Up needles, up scissors, counter-attack! That was the battle-cry sounded yesterday by the leader of New York s 89,000 union dressmakers in a war against imports from Paris and Rome.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday it would give top priority to election reforms in the 1961 legislative session, which opens in Albany Wednesday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Hamilton Richardson completed a sweep of honors at the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today when he teamed with Ron Holmberg and whipped Gardnar Mulloy and Crawford Henry in the doubles final, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Seventeen projects in fourteen New York State communities will receive urban renewal loans totaling $12,000,000 this year, State Housing commissioner James W. Gaynor announced yesterday. More than half has been allocated to four New York City projects.

PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The tugboat Phillip Arthur sank in the Intercoastal Canal shortly before midnight last night after being rammed by a line of three empty oil barges she had been towing. The crew of six went down with the tug.
VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- The current success of Mary Chase's "Harvey" at the Akademie-theater has focused attention on the increasingly important role of American authors in theatre life here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The usual year-end calm settled over grain futures dealings last week on the Board of Trade but there was no sign of it in the soybean pit where activity was the heaviest of the year.

ROME, Monday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The correspondent for the Italian news agency Ansa in Mogadishu, Somalia, said the clashes between Ethiopian troops and Somali tribesmen occurred in the Damot region. He reported about 140 dead -- 120 Somalis and possibly twenty Ethiopians.
A florist grappled with a hold-up man and then called on the wrong bystander for help yesterday morning. The bystander turned out to be the hold-up man's accomplice.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 27 -- A rich deposit of hard coal has been discovered in the mountains ninety miles from here.
One of the most influential arms of New York State government came of age yesterday. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the Department of Taxation and Finance became the Department of Motor Vehicles.

The New York Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union has deferred until 2 P.M. Thursday a strike of its 12,000 members in the metropolitan area that was originally scheduled to start Wednesday. The postponement was announced yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the union, after a bargaining session with representatives of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association in the Astor Hotel.

City Councilman Earl Brown appeared likely yesterday to emerge as the choice of both Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. De Sapio for Borough President of Manhattan. Such a development would delay an open showdown between the Mayor and Mr. De Sapio, the leader of Tammany Hall, as to which is the top Democrat in Manhattan.
ANYTHING can happen on New Year's Eve. The New York Philharmonic, for example, was playing Irving Berlin's "Heat Wave" in Carnegie Hall.

VACATIONING children and their parents braved crowds, freezing temperatures, snow and rain in their annual search for entertainment over the holidays. It was sometimes hard to tell where endurance ended and fun began.
The city's long-term debt was reduced by $81,000,000 during 1960, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A statistic died last night. The steel industry discontinued publication of its annual estimate of production capacity -- the tonnage figure on which weekly percentage estimates are based.
Foreign exchange market finished out the year generally on the soft side. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar continued lower on active dealings.

Anton Baumann of Yorkville, on the upper East Side, is a happy man at 76. He has a new pair of binoculars to enjoy on his week-end walks in the country. His wife, Maria, is happy, too, because they have income in addition to Mr. Baumann's Social Security and pension from the brewery where he worked.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 1 -- Latin-American diplomats, looking forward to what they hope will be a new era in relations with the United States, are attaching considerable importance to the new top diplomatic personnel Washington will assign to this region.

A film symposium, starting Wednesday and continuing through Jan. 19, will be held at Smith College. Three of the films to be screened are "The Great Train Robbery" of 1903 and Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times" and "The Cure," all of which will be shown on Wednesday.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- President-elect John F. Kennedy joined in a prayer this New Year's Day for divine guidance of the nation in these times of international tension.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- The University of Chicago Library has announced the acquisition of a collection of letters that, in the words of the announcement, provides "a rare view of the political machinations behind the career of an American President."
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Somalia charged today that Ethiopian planes and troops killed more than 100 Somali nomads in recent incidents on the ill-defined border.
The Soviet Government has finally permitted publication of data showing how close the Soviet Union came to economic collapse during World War II.

One hundred inspectors from the Department of Markets will begin a thorough check of retail meat markets tomorrow. The action is being taken to protect the public against shortweighting or overpricing as a result of a strike against wholesale meat dealers in the New York area.
Members of the United Nations Conciliation Commission for the Congo started last night for Leopoldville to try to mediate issues in the new African nation.
The second annual Boy Scouts Gala has been arranged for March 16 at the Commodore to raise funds for the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.

Frank Mahovlich has been poison to the New York Rangers all season. Last night at Madison Square Garden, Mahovlich's potion consisted of two third-period goals as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Blues, 4 -- 1.
BEZIERS, France, Dec. 20 -- Thirty years of digging have transformed a vine-covered hill into one of France's richest and most exciting archaeological sites.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 --An unusual experiment, which brought together a television station and an actors workshop, was tested here this evening.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Glenn Hall scored his sixth shutout of the National Hockey League season tonight and his third straight over the Detroit Red Wings in a 3-0 victory for the Chicago Black Hawks.

An unusual program has been scheduled by Lucille Lortel, artistic director of the single matinee offerings presented by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy. The fourth in this season's series, it will bring together Richard Burton, Cathleen Nesbitt and Walter Abel in a poetry reading.
Cardinal Spellman, returning from his Christmas tour of Arctic military bases, presided yesterday at the 10 A.M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 -- The Indian Government is negotiating an oil deal with an Italian concern that has offered to participate extensively in a petroleum development program.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Business men all over Europe will have to start dealing tomorrow with the realities -- not just the theory -- of the division of the Continent into two trading blocks.
AN appetizing hint of the treats to be expected from the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts was offered yesterday by "Omnibus" over Channel 4.
One hundred persons, winners in a puzzle contest the State Attorney General has termed "fraudulent," soon will receive $56,000 from funds the state ordered placed in escrow.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The stock market ended 1960 on a note of firmness. But there was uncertainty about the prospects for the new year.
HAVANA, Jan. 1 -- Premier Fidel Castro accused the United States early today of planning to attack Cuba before President elect John F. Kennedy takes office Jan. 20.
Governor Rockefeller plans to ask for the establishment of a Bureau of Heart Disease in the State Health Department to fight the greatest single cause of death in the state.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,908,075,523. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Denis W. Healey, the Labor party's spokesman on foreign affairs in the House of Commons, said today "the American Republicans" were mostly to blame for the conflict in Laos.
Over-the-counter securities ended 1960 on a strong upward note.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Laos has accused the Soviet Union before the United Nations of flagrant violation of Laotian sovereignty and interference in her internal affairs.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- With Bob Cousy scoring 11 of his 14 points in the first period, the Boston Celtics took an early lead and coasted to a 113-96 victory over the Syracuse Nationals in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The University of Mississippi is favored by 10 points to win the Sugar Bowl football game for the second straight year tomorrow. But most of the anticipated crowd of 80,000 fans are expecting Rice to make the game close.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. Jan. 1 -- Rum Dum, sailed by Jack Sutphen of Larchmont, was first in the Interclub Class at the Manhasset Bay Yacht club today. The rest of the second-day program of the thirtieth annual frostbite regatta was called off because of strong northeast winds.
The New Year got off to a good start yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

The New School will benefit from theatre parties at the Phoenix Theatre on Jan. 25 and May 2. The first will be at a preview of the revival of Dion Boucicault's "The Octoroon," and the second at a preview of a play to be announced.
THE story has been repeated with such avidity in football circles, that it has lost a bit of its sheen. But it is so devastatingly illustrative that it's impossible to resist one more repetition.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- A resolve to begin the new year with new order in pedestrian safety remained just that tonight -- a resolve.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 1 -- The Nassau County Democratic chairman said today that an amendment would be introduced in the forthcoming session of the State Legislature to change the present method of apportionment.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 1 -- Label A. Katz, international president of B'nai B'rith, told the World Zionist Congress here tonight that God could not be confined to any particular place.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera for the first time this season on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 14. Erich Leinsdorf will conduct the broadcast performance. The cast will be headed by Cesare Siepi, Eleanor Steber, Lisa Della Casa and Fernando Corena.
MIAMI, Jan. 1 -- The feeling around these parts is that the most attractive of all the post-season football games will be staged here tomorrow in the Orange Bowl.
THE conduct of American prisoners of war during the Korean conflict was the subject of an engrossing telecast last night on "The Twentieth Century" over Channel 2.
HOUSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Both coaches agreed after the American Football League's championship game today that Houston's 24-16 victory over the Los Angeles Chargers was deserved.

Arthur Krock's Dec. 23 column says that the history of the "secret" nuclear reactor in Israel "begins substantially" in September, 1957, and he ties in this assertion with a quotation from a report published at that time by the Israel bond organization and prepared by my wife and me.

VANGEL GRIFFIN, a vague, meek and melancholy young man, made a suicide pact with himself when he was 29. Since he had never done anything impulsive in his life, he did not hurry. "I'll give myself one year," he decided. "Unless I find some reason for living longer, I think I'll kill myself this coming June."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Robert S. McNamara, the next Secretary of Defense, regards his position as that of a maker of strategic policy rather than merely a production expert. He has made his views clear to President-elect John F. Kennedy and others in the new Administration.
WHENEVER William Sanford Hults enters his official or personal automobile, his hands grasp automatically for the seat belt and he buckles it as naturally as if he were buttoning his coat.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 1 -- The pro-Western Government of Prince Boun Oum said tonight Communist forces had captured Laos' strategic central plain, the plain's airstrip and the northern provincial capital of Phongsaly.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 1 -- Belgium's two-week strikes, at least temporarily calm for the holiday, were viewed in certain quarters today as an attempt by Socialist union leaders to win a tactical victory in their campaign for state socialism.
Holy Name Sunday was celebrated at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday with morning prayer, holy communion, and a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Edward N. West, Canon Sacrist.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The Soviet Union has obtained a "good delivery" registration on the London Metal Exchange for lead produced by the Usk-Kamenogorsk Zinc-Lead Combine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- For the preservation of America's key deer herd at the national refuge in Monroe County, Fla., additional land and money have been donated, Ross Leffler, assistant secretary of the interior, announced today.
MOSCOW, Jan1. (UP) Soviet scientists plan to orbit several more experimental spaceships before launching men into space, the Communist party newspaper Pravda said today.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- NATO's Eisenhower decade ends this month with the President's retirement. One important consequence will be eventual replacement of the alliance's Supreme Commander, Gen. Lauris Norstad. Norstad is the last of the "Eisenhower Dynasty."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 1 (AP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today he had been misunderstood by American Jewish leaders who said he believed that Jews outside Israel had no God.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Carl Hanford, the trainer of Kelso, "horse of the year" in 1960, said today he hoped the colt would recover in "a few days" from an injury suffered yesterday.
The Port of New York will start the new year with a flourish.
Three new films will arrive in local theatres this week. Programs of the new year's initial movies follow.

Jerry Lucas, whose aplomb is as startling as his unerring genius with a basketball, is a/ unsmiling giant who shrivels in the limelight.

THE American Contract Bridge League has made it official that Robert Jordan of Philadelphia was the leading tournament player of 1960 in this country. HONOLULU, Jan. 1 -- Henry J. Kaiser is getting out of the hotel business in Honolulu to concentrate all of his efforts in his $350,000 Hawaii Kai Community.
The appointment of twenty- nine editors as Pulitzer Prize jurors of journalism for 1961 was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters predicted today an early end to the Board of Monitors set-up to oversee the union's affairs They also predicted that James R. Hoffa would be re-elected as the union's president.
IF anyone suggested to the average New Yorker that cereals should be used more frequently as a main course, the response would likely be a grimace.

A 41-year-old man in the Bronx was killed yesterday in a fight with his two sons when they intervened during a quarrel between the parents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator Mike Mansfield proposed today that the United States offer to withdraw part of its troops from Europe if the Soviet Union reduced its forces in satellite countries.
