LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British Government urged United States support today for the reestablishment of the International Control Commission in Laos as the first step toward peace in the Southeast Asian kingdom.
TORONTO, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Earnings of British American Oil Company, Ltd., for 1960 are expected to be between $29,000,000 and $30,000,000, according to E.D. Loughney, president.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Soviet citizens started turning in their rubles for the new currency issued today, at the rate of ten old ones for one new one. At the same time, price tags on all goods were changed throughout the nation.
MASTIC, L.I., Dec. 28 -- The Mastic Airstrip is to be turned over to the Town of Brookhaven by New York State for development as a municipal airport.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 2 -- President Joseph Kasavubu announced today that a Congo round-table conference for constitutional reforms would begin Jan. 25.
The Army's Transportation Terminal Command has started a system to transmit shipping manifests of military ships to an overseas port electronically.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A leading London bullion concern predicted today that the continued demand for silver would lead to a shortage. It suggested that the United States Treasury, whose stocks it said had fallen to a three-year supply, might stop selling silver to American industry.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The French Foreign Ministry said today it had received "no confirmation of an invasion of Laotian territory'' by military forces of Communist North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Demands for the abolition of the House Committee on Un-American Activities were pushed today in White House picketing, calls on members of Congress and at a rally here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana said today that as the Senate Democratic leader in the new Congress he would regard himself as President-elect John F. Kennedy's "representative."
The city has delayed making public a report that could speed construction of the $88,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway.
Jack Molinas will try to wipe out his past with the aid of the antitrust laws in a trial expected to start this week before Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- The University of Chicago has become the ninth member of the Institute for Defense Analyses, Dr. Warren C. Johnson, the university's Vice President for Scientific Affairs, announced today.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Gov.-elect Terry Sanford today named Hargrove Bowles Jr., Greensboro real estate developer and insurance executive, to be director of the state Conservation and Development Department.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Angry crowds demonstrated against the United States and neighboring Ethiopia today after clashes with Ethiopians caused many casualties. The crowds criticized the United States for giving military aid to Ethiopia.

Moscow, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev said tonight he was alarmed by reports from Cuba that the United States was preparing to attack the island. "The Eisenhower Administration, living through its final days, is pursuing an extremely dangerous policy," he said.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The all-America quarterback, Jake Gibbs, scored both touchdowns for Mississippi today as the unbeaten Rebels defeated Rice, 14 -- 6, before 82,851 fans in the Sugar Bowl football game at Tulane Stadium.
On New Year's Eve an anonymous contributor to the Neediest Cases Fund posted a letter with a $5 gift and this all-inclusive wish: "For a happy, healthy peaceful 1961 for all peoples of the world."

"SHADOWS ON THE GRASS,"* by Isak Dinesen, is a quartet of serene elegies to her Africa of far away and long ago. Here she pays tribute to those who endured with gallantry the hazards of the commonplace and shared her sense of astonishment at the pretensions of the world.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Gov. J.J. Hickey resigned officially today.

One of London's busiest producers is Toby Rowland, who was born in Libby, Mont., and has applied for British citizenship. After a visit here, he is flying back to London today to accelerate production activity on four attractions.
One of labor's most respected theoreticians has recommended a basic overhaul of union structure to overcome the reluctance of white-collar and professional workers to unionize.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- The twelve-day-old Dutch Cabinet crisis ended tonight as Premier Jan E. de Quay withdrew his resignation.
Carl Braun, who can play basketball better than many performers in the National Basketball Association, now feels old enough to sit on the coaching bench and remain there.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Car production fell sharply during the last week of 1960, bringing the total year's production just short of 6,700,000 units.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Eisenhower will send to Congress this month a budget in which expenditures of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will be set at a record $4,000,000,000. This will cover the fiscal year starting next July 1. It will be the last Eisenhower budget.

A new book by Henry A. Kissinger, author of "Nuclear Weapons and Foreign Policy," will be published Jan. 16 by Harper. To be called "The Necessity of Choice," the book enlarges upon some of the problems Mr. Kissinger dealt with in his earlier volume and sets forth his thoughts on current foreign policy matters and defense issues.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Carole Washburn, 18-year-old Queen of the Tournament of Roses, arose from a sick bed today to lead the seventy-second annual procession.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Sir Winston Churchill urged Britain, Western Europe and the United States today to draw closer together to face the problems of 1961.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Representative Alfred E. Santangelo said today he would introduce legislation this week to liberalize immigration laws.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain scored 56 points tonight, his top total this season, in leading the Philadelphia Warriors to a 131-115 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Australian bowlers ripped through the West Indian batting order today as the home team drew close to victory in the second cricket test between the countries. A crowd of 65,372 attended.
More than halt of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's total sales of $1,300,000,000 in 1960 resulted from programs developed in the last five years, Robert E. Gross, chairman, reported yesterday.
Bobby Fischer, the 17-year-old international grandmaster, last night won his fourth straight United States chess championship at the Hotel Empire.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The new legislative session opening here on Wednesday will be planting time for both major political parties. The seeds they sow now will yield the crops with which they hope to tempt voters in next fall's city elections and in the state elections of 1962.
Rodolfo Diaz of Argentina stopped Clarence (Tiger) Floyd of New York in the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Geechee Lou, a 5-year-old bay mare, set an American record for one mile and a furlong on the grass today. She won the $29,300 San Gabriel Handicap before 43,559 racegoers at Santa Anita Park in 1:46 3-5.

One of England's less ancient traditions is on its way out, according to Royal Mint officials. Along with other signs of progress -- of new homes centrally heated, of tea shops with juke boxes, of wide highways and no hedges, of presliced bread -- is the news that very few threepenny bits were to be found in the traditional Christmas pudding.
WHEN American forces driving through Bavaria in 1945 ran up against stubborn defenders inside the walls of Rothenburg, Lieut. Gen. Courtney Hodges decided to shell the town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Radical surgery or a change of climate? This is the question that divides students of the Federal regulatory agencies as they ponder a prescription for the agencies ills.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet All-Stars, shooting short passes with accuracy, trounced the University of Minnesota, 10 -- 2, in an exhibition hockey game tonight.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 2 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China received a colorful welcome and was hailed as a "well-wisher of Burma" on his arrival here today for a week's goodwill visit.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 2 -- It appears that Antarctica has two active volcanoes, not just one, according to a short-wave radio report received here today.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A new translation of the New Testament in "frankly contemporary" English -- designed to supplement the King James Bible of 1611 -- will be published March 14 by the Oxford and Cambridge University Presses.
Some oddities went on display at the Aquarium in Coney Island yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The Laotian representative in the United Nations said tonight that his Government would appeal to the Security Council if the military situation in Laos got worse.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- The Mummers wagged an impish finger at a troubled world here today.
They call him Fat Toy, and in the world of Broadway -- a world that liberally dispenses honorary titles -- he is known as the king of Chinese laundry advertising.
Television set makers, with the outstanding exceptions of the Zenith Radio Corporation and a few others, ended last year with lower sales than they had in 1959.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Jerome Derenzo's heavily favored April Skies, with Willie Hartack riding, ran down Tudorich in the final seventy yards today to win the $11,150 New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Mississippi Southern extended its winning streak to twenty-five games by defeating Fairleigh Dickinson, 89 -- 82, in a double-overtime basketball contest tonight. The triumph was the Golden Giants' tenth this season.

Except for the dampening effects of a black, rainy New Year's Day, the attendance picture was a bright one at most of the first-run motion picture theatres over the four-day holiday week-end, according to preliminary estimates made by management spokesmen yesterday.
BAKWANGA, the Congo, Jan. 2 (AP) -- President Joseph Kasavubu opened an official weekend visit to South Kasai by refusing to leave the airliner that brought him here.

With the defense of Quemoy and Matsu emerging as one of the major issues of the recent campaign and the subsequent nominations by President-elect Kennedy of Dean Rusk and Chester Bowles for the top two posts in the State Department it is likely that basic changes in our commitments to the Republic of China will become a paramount problem for the next Administration.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- More services and facilities will be required to meet population pressures in Bergen County, according to a report made today by Anthony Pepe, director of the Board of Chosen Freeholders.
Twenty-two business men and public officials have been elected to the expanded board of the Greater New York Safety Council.
When the North Wind doth blow, Greenwich Villagers call the Committee of Neighbors to Get the Clock on Jefferson Market Courthouse Started.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -House Speaker Sam Rayburn moved today, on the eve of the opening of the Eighty-seventh Congress, to break a conservative coalition's power to obstruct President-elect John F. Kennedy's legislative program.

Coaches, who have always marked their own report cards may find the grading less leient and more objective in the 1961-62 school year. The Public Schools Athletic League has requested a budgetary allocation of $8,700 for a supervisory staff to evaluate the coaching, the officiating and the administration of interscholastic competition next season, it was recently learned.

The Moore state commission is considering a proposal that would increase real estate taxes to pay in cash for more of the city's capital projects -- schools, transit and the like. This would cut the share paid for by borrowing.
New Yorkers were asked yesterday to donate blood to the New York Regional Blood Program to replenish the "uncomfortably" low level of blood available for emergencies.

IN addition to the annual competition for the McKenney Trophy given by the American Contract Bridge League to the player with the best tournament record of the year there is competition for the award by the Greater New York Bridge Association to the player of the year in this district.

THE mention of India often brings to mind exotic colors, textures and exquisite hand embroidery. About two years ago, some Americans took a gamble on bringing all these things to this country in the form of ready-to-wear dresses.

Webb Knapp, Inc., has sold its 50 per cent interest in Canada House, the twenty-six-story office building at 680 Fifth Avenue, to the building's original group of Canadian sponsors. The structure, completed in 1958, cost $11,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- All office workers and Government employes in Yugoslavia received a 10 per cent pay increase yesterday. It was the first step in the Government's attempt to maintain the standard of living this year against heavy inflationary pressures.
Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has purchased the parking lot at 600-10 Third Avenue and 159-63 East Thirty-ninth Street, the northwest corner, from Fisher Brothers, builders.

NEWARK, Jan. 2 -- The Essex County Supervisor proposed today that New Jersey's most populous counties jointly appoint a legislative watchdog to discourage the shifting of legislative burdens by the state to local and county governments.

The Edison Medal of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers has been won by Dr. Harold S. Osborne of Upper Montclair, N.J., it was announced yesterday. He was the chief, engineer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from 1953 until his retirement in 1952.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 2 -- One hundred and forty jurists from twenty African countries and ten countries outside Africa will take part in a five-day conference on "Government Security and Human Rights" that opens here tomorrow.

The fine art of conserving capital -- and increasing it -- received its usual lift last year from art itself. At the same time, investors in securities struggled against a fateful decline in the stock market averages.
ALGIERS, Jan. 2 -- Pierre Messmer, French Defense Minister, arrived today to exhort the army to get out the Moslem vote and work for a massive "yes" for President de Gaulle's reform policy.
The Grand Union Company, large grocery chain, reported a 2.1 per cent dip in sales and a 10 per cent drop in profits for the nine months ended on Nov. 26.

DALLAS, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Duke's Blue Devils surged 73 yards, mostly on passes from Don Altman to Tee Moorman, as they rallied to upset Arkansas, 7 -- 6, in the twenty-fifth annual Cotton Bowl game before 74,000 fans today.

PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two brothers were shot to death at their home tonight. A few hours later their brother-in-law, described by the police as a mental case, surrendered in another Michigan city after having been sought in the first shooting.

The Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday announced that its new twelve-story national headquarters would be at 803-815 Second Avenue, near Forty-third Street, and that construction would start this spring.
New Yorkers suffered no apparent hardship yesterday because of the strike of 3,000 wholesale meat handlers.

The score of the tenth-round match in which Bobby Fischer clinched the United States chess championship at the Hotel Empire on Monday night was released yesterday. The 17-year-old Brooklyn grandmaster offered a draw to Pal Benko, which Benko accepted, thereby giving the title to Fischer for the fourth straight time.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Australia trounced the West Indies by seven wickets today and took a 1-0 lead in their five-match test cricket series.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eisenhower Administration took full responsibility tonight for the diplomatic break with Cuba.
The breach of diplomatic ties between the United States and Cuba, announced last night, severed a close but frequently stormy relationship of sixty-two years.
The tail-end New York Knickerbockers' current losing streak reached five games last night as they dropped a 129-104 decision to the next-to-last-place Syracuse Nationals at Madison Square Garden.
Bhikssu Chaman Lal finds no contradiction in the pursuit of his vocation as a Buddhist monk and his avocation as a recognized anthropologist. In fact, he believes they complement each other.

The track and field set -- varsity, pre-varsity and post-graduate -- has received happy New Year tidings. Charles H. Starke, the director of recreation for the New York City Department of Parks, announced that all-weather runways for the broad jump, high jump and pole vault would be installed at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island in the spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles are leaning toward their line coach, Nick Skorich, as the Successor to Chet Shaw, the recently retired' head coach, and will offer Norm Van Brocklin a record National Football League salary to play at least one more year, it was learned today.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Senators and Assemblymen descended on the capital tonight to prepare for the opening of the 1961 legislative session here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Following is the text of a State Department statement today on Soviet and North Vietnamese activities in Laos:
The Carroll Club, which had offered religious guidance and recreation for Roman Catholic business women here since 1919, has suspended operations.
The Cuban Government did not put up the money yesterday to meet $2,366,529 of interest and sinking fund payments on a long-outstanding issue of 4 1/2 per cent bonds payable in United States dollars.

FRANK LANE is as restful as a hurricane. He comes swirling in, accompanied by sound and fury. When he departs, things are never quite the same. Often they are totally unrecognizable. Frantic Frankie is a general manager who is dynamic, mercurial, shrewd, tireless, clever, intelligent, imaginative and perhaps even a trifle bombastic.
A group of men began yesterday the formidable task of counting had verifying $10,000,000,000 of bonds and stocks. The job is expected to take about eighteen months.

The duel between the United States and Cuba over Premier Fidel Castro's determination to export to the rest of Latin America his revolutionary doctrine of "Fidelismo" was one of the major causes that brought on the breaking of diplomatic relations.
Carmen Basilio of Chittenango, N.Y., is due in New York this morning to complete training for his Saturday night ten-rounder against Gaspar Ortega of Mexico City in Madison Square Garden.
Alternate-side parking regulations, which have not been in effect since Dec. 12, will be suspended again today, Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday.
The United States rupture of diplomatic relations with Premier Fidel Castro's regime brought new hope last night to Cuban exiles here, who are seeking the overthrow of his Government.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Willie Mays, outfielder for the San Francisco Giants, and his wife Marghuerite were reported today to have had a disagreement that had reached a climax on New Year's Eve with the ball player moving his personal possessions from their home at 90 Croft Terrace here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight ended its short life today with a noisy political squabble.

In an effort to provide a workable training ground for new actors, directors and playwrights with motion picture potentialities, Columbia Pictures is establishing a "talent farm" at the Gateway Playhouse, a summer theatre in Bellport, L.I.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The white boycott of New Orleans intergrated schools weakened only a little today after the ten-day holiday vacation.
A busy week of holiday tournament play shook up the United Press International college basketball top ten today but kept Ohio State atop the coaches' ratings.
Some of the big banks in New York reported yesterday that their earnings for last year were above those for 1959.

In little more than an hour yesterday a woman's pocketbook containing $3,655 in cash, four bankbooks with $15,120 in deposits and six rings was lost and found in the subway system and returned to the owner.
UNDULY concerned by something he read not so long ago about bass lures of spectacular size and coloring, Dave Eisendrath called up to blow the whistle on himself and Dave Roberts.
The wisdom of the Federal Government's ship-scrapping program is being sharply questioned in some shipping circles.

"ASTRONOMY IN THE NEWS" is the name of the new sky show at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street. The show is a review of the headlines that astronomy has made in recent years, including its use in the development of satellites and rocket launchings.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 3 (AP) -- John A. Notte Jr. became Rhode Island's Governor today. He immediately pledged his administration to try to improve business conditions in the face of rising unemployment.
Jack L.S. Snead Jr., who quit last July as president of Consolidated Freightways, Inc., the nation's largest trucking company, is back at work as a trucker.

VIENNA, Jan. 3 -- Conditional approval of the Communist Chinese thesis favoring civil war as a means of overthrowing bourgeois governments was published Dec. 30 in the official newspaper of the Bulgarian Communist party.
The three-day New Year's holiday was described yesterday by the National Safety Council as "the safest on record" for the nation's drivers and pedestrians.

OTTAWA, Jan. 3 -- Canada's mineral production reached a new high in 1960, the Bureau of Statistics said today. Mineral production rose by 2.6 per cent to a record $2,471,742,000 last year from $2,409,021,000 the year before.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Mr. Smith came to Washington last night.

Stockholders of the Jim Walter Corporation at a meeting yesterday in Tampa, Fla., voted to simplify the capitalization of the company. They approved the board's recommendation to call in all A warrants. A warrant options, B warrants and FR B warrants now outstanding.
The harbor lived up to its reputation as the busiest port in the world yesterday.

The new No. 8 world sugar futures contract, made available yesterday for the first time on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, was widely accepted. At the end of the day, 10,050 tons changed hands with prices ranging from $2.89 to $2.91 a hundred pounds.

Mayor Wagner begins the final year of his second term in office with considerable accomplishment to his credit, and also a big inventory of unfinished business. His political plans are undisclosed, and perhaps unformed, but whether he goes or stays he will want to make this eighth year at City Hall a year of achievement, completing a record to run on or be remembered by.

Defense officials in Washington indicated last night that there was no immediate likelihood of a change in the status of the United States' naval base at Guantanamo Bay, despite the severing of relations with Cuba.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Reverie Knoll Farm's Quillita, closing strongly on the outside, finished a nose in front of Art Market today in the feature at Tropical Park. Garchew was third in the mile-and-a-sixteenth allowance race.
A total of 124,449 pints of blood were donated in 1960 to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. This was a decline from the 131,585 in 1959.
TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones appeared tonight to have taken an impressive lead in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Two men and two women admitted yesterday that they had participated in a $30,000 payroll padding scheme in the Board of Education.

ALGIERS, Jan. 3 -- Leaders of the opposition to President de Gaulle in Algiers asked today whether the French Army had been ordered to campaign for a "Yes" vote in the national referendum on Algerian policy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The Chicago Daily News printed its first edition of 1961 today in a new home, The Chicago Sun-Times building.
Nineteen men and a woman, some described as kingpins in the gambling rackets, were arrested yesterday in a series of raids on known and suspected bookmakers.

TWO American painters of major reputation are exhibiting again this week after recesses of five years, and both are symbolists, although of contrasting kinds. At the Rehn Gallery, 36 East Sixty-first Street, Charles Burchfield has a show of nine pictures, the first since his retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art in January, 1956.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 -- A behind the scenes battle was being fought tonight within the incoming Administration over the suggested appointment of Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver of Georgia as Secretary of the Army.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- More than 500 pickets from eight groups marched near the White House yesterday, some opposing and others supporting the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The State Department estimated today that 3,000 to 3,500 United States civilians still resided in Cuba.
Francis Littlejohn, for seven years director of news and public affairs for the American Broadcasting Company, resigned yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller will urge the 1961 Legislature tomorrow to upgrade the salaries paid the state's top professional and technical civil servants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of E.R. Quesada as administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency. He wished Mr. Quesada well in "future endeavors, athletic and otherwise."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- Baltimore Gas Electric Company today reported a net profit of $19,983,000, or $1.34 a common share, for the 11 months ended on Nov. 30, against $19,342,000, or $1.30, in 1959.
The board of the General Motors Corporation elected yesterday Elis S. Hoglund as a director and Earl C. Daum as a vice president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Numerical control of New York's House delegation passed to the Democratic party today for the first time in eight years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower named five Government officials today to receive the President's Gold Medal Award for distinguished Federal civilian service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- There is a rumor making the rounds here that Senator Kennedy is "in touch" with the Russians, and since this has neither been confirmed nor denied in Palm Beach, the comparatively innocent facts had better be reported.

With the club back at full strength, the New York Rangers yesterday returned Danny Belisle and Bob Kabel, forwards, to the minor leagues. It had been anticipated that Belisle and Kabel would be sent down, since Dean Prentice and Camille Henry, left wings, are again available for full-time duty.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries announced yesterday a gain of 8.6 per cent in electric operating revenues and an increase of 10.6 per cent in net income for twelve months ended on Nov. 30. Electric operating revenues for the first eleven months of 1960 rose 8.7 per cent and net income by 11.1 per cent.

A grand jury crackdown on "paper unions" that victimize low-paid workers appeared in prospect last night as a result of teamwork between District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the state Labor Relations Board.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Laos has complained to the United Nations that Communist North Vietnamese troops have committed "unprovoked aggression" against Laotian territory.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- When the 1961 legislative session convenes at noon tomorrow, the lawmakers will have ready for their consideration a backlog of 2,142 bills sponsored under the prefiling system.

NEWARK, Jan. 3 -- Mayor Leo P. Carlin announced today the formation of an eleven-man committee for Small Business Relocation Needs. It will offer guidance and assistance to small businesses in areas slated for urban renewal projects.
PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The conference on the future of continental Europe that was postponed in December because of the ill-health of Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany will take place early in February.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 3 -- Leaders of India's ruling party agreed tonight that the responsibility for rural economic development should be transferred to village councils in "as large a measure as possible."

When President-elect John F. Kennedy arrives in New York today to set up pre-inaugural headquarters at the Carlyle Hotel, he will find his tower suite glowing with an elegant new look quite different from the last time he stayed there in December.

Actors Equity unanimously turned down a request yesterday to move Brendan Behan's "The Hostage" off Broadway. The play will end its run Saturday at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre after its 127th performance.
A strike by 12,000 New York millinery workers was averted last night.

The building occupied by the Father and Son Shoe Company at 6 and 8 Main Street, Hempstead, L.I., has been purchased for investment by a client of Charles Port, lawyer. It was sold for cash over the existing first mortgage in a deal negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Ruffino Realty Company, Kew Gardens, broker.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The British Government has received no information that would change its mind about increasing landing charges at London Airport as of April 1, a spokesman for the Ministry of Aviation said today.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Vermont Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court decree that had declared that payment of public tax funds as tuition to Roman Catholic parochial schools violated the Vermont Constitution and the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.

PARAMUS, N.J., Jan. 3 -- A Long Island man was killed here this morning when a fuel oil truck overturned and crushed his car on Route 4. The victim was Martin Levine, 44 years old, of 591 Church Avenue, Woodmere.
New York City branch-system commercial banks are making a major effort to attract and keep new savings deposits.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 851 persons were injured in traffic misaps here last week. This was a decrease of 191 over the comparable period the year before.

The average rate of interest on short-term loans to business by New York City banks rose slightly in the first half of December over the first half of September, according to the regular quarterly survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Contract negotiations begin today between the Marine Towing Transportation Employers Association and Local 333 of the United Marine Division, affiliate of the National Maritime Union.
Experiments that might lead to a "low-cost nuclear fusion process" were announced here yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 3 -- All twenty-two passengers and the crew of three of a Finnair DC-3 airliner were killed today when it crashed in flames into woods near the western Finnish town of Vaasa.
Wall Street brokerage houses continued yesterday to report changes in their partnership arrangements and the election of new vice presidents at those companies which operate as corporations.
BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following report on ski conditions and weather forecast today:
The city sent 6,700 letters to electrical contractors and concerns yesterday warning them against "corrupting" employes of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The United States Government charged today that the Soviet Union and North Vietnam were guilty of "extensive participation" in military operations against the Government of Laos.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to equalize railroad freight rates on export-import traffic between the Midwest and all North Atlantic ports.

Preliminary reports on the annual Christmas bird count in the metropolitan area have indicated that house thrushes and brilliant red cardinals are increasing, but that the bluebird continues in trouble.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The United States formally terminated diplomatic and consular relations with Cuba tonight.

The exchange of new "heavy" Soviet rubles at the rate of ten old for one new has begun in Moscow. For most Soviet citizens who are dutifully lining up to turn in their old currency for new, the inconvenience may hardly seem worth the trouble. They know that both prices and wages have been reduced in the same ratio so that nothing real has happened to their purchasing power.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Soybean futures, with their broadest gains in several months, led a generally higher grain futures market today on the Board of Trade.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Power-boat drivers from all over the nation wound up the five-day Orange Bowl regatta today by setting five national speed records in the flying kilometer time trials on a glass-smooth canal west of Fort Lauderdale.

IT is almost thirteen years since the Experimental Theatre presented a fusion of dance and song known as "Ballet Ballads." Although the program made a devoted group of friends who fought hard to keep it in business, it languished at the box office.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- At the invitation of the Soviet Union's Ministry of Culture, and under the sponsorship of the British Arts Council, the Old Vic Company left London this week to pay its first visit to Russia, and later to Poland.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points up to 20 points off yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

One more disturbing indication of the city's unwillingness to come to grips with its ever-worsening traffic problem has been pin-pointed by the Automobile Club of New York in calling on Mayor Wagner to rescue the $100,000,000 parking program from oblivion. It is unfortunate that the motorists' organization must plead for action on a plan to which, when it was announced a year ago, that Mayor promised his whole-hearted-support.

CONCURRENTLY with its annual competition for the player-of-the-year award in, this district, which is invariably won by one of the highest-ranking players, the Greater New York Bridge Association makes an award to the nonmaster with the best record for the year.
The former United States Immigration Building on the site of Lincoln Center is proving to be one of the sturdiest structures ever brought down in the city, according to the demolition engineers.

The Civil Aeronautics Board public hearings today into history worst air disaster -- Dec, 16 collision of two air-rs here that cost 134 lives. Among the first of seventy-persons slated to testify are in listed as "witnesses to the accident."

A six-story apartment building at 1230 Sheridan Avenue, between 167th and 168th Streets, the Bronx, has been sold by Salo Koeppel. It was bought by an investing client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker in the deal.

Construction and permanent mortgage financing amounting to $3,585,600 has been obtained by Surray Equities, Inc., Builders, on two six-story apartment houses they are constructing on the south side of Tilden Street, between Barnes and Bronxwood Avenues, the Bronx.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Small gains predominated in most of the industrial sections of the stock market here today. Rises on balance were less than a shilling (14 cents).

CARACAS, Jan. 3 -- A meeting of Latin-American oil producers will be held soon in Caracas, according to the Ministry of Mines. It will follow a conference of the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries, which will take place here on Jan. 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Military involvement in Laos would confront the United States and its allies with battle and operations problems far more formidable than those experienced in Korea.

Although their operating rates were way down, the ten major United States steel companies kept their 1960 cash dividends up to the level of the preceding year, with one-exception. Now that the new year is under way the question arises as to just what the steel producers will do about dividends at their meetings this month and next.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower is considering a farewell radio-TV address to the nation and the world before leaving office on Jan. 20, the White House disclosed today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 3 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission for the Congo assembled here today. The eleven-nation body will offer its good offices to the Congolese factions to try to end the four-month-old political impasse.

The aggregate market value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell almost 1 per cent yesterday in a session marked more by a lack of bids than by genuine selling pressure. Turnover was about half that on Friday.

The assurance that the market for United States Government securities has been manifesting recently turned to nervousness yesterday in the face of the war crisis in Laos. Prices fell sharply on light trading. High-grade corporate obligations declined slightly in price, too.

The Times is to be congratulated for its Dec. 25 editorial on "Atlantic Convention." As the editorial quite accurately observed, Congressional approval for United States participation in a convention of NATO states, which will deliberate on methods of strengthening the political and economic fabric of the Atlantic Community, was "an action that deserved far more notice than it received."
The Long Island Rail Road appealed yesterday for financial help to avert what it said was an impending crisis.

Paul E. Richards, who until last spring was general sales manager of the Conn Corporation, band instrument maker, heads a group that has formed the Richards Music Corporation of Elkhart, Ind., and the latter concern has acquired four companies that make musical instruments.

The Fire Department and the New York Naval Shipyard buried the hatchet yesterday after a week of reciprocal criticism in testimony at a Navy court of inquiry into the disastrous Dec. 19 fire aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation.
Sales and earnings of R.H. Macy Co., Inc, for the fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 29 exceeded those of the preceding period, according to the un-audited consolidated statement issued to stockholders.

THE song has it that May is nut-gathering time. However, it is more likely to be on a cold and frosty fall morning that the major harvesting is done. And it is definitely around the end-of-year holiday season that the nut really comes out of its shell.
The former general director of the New York City Opera, Joseph Rosenstock, will conduct Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde" and Strauss' "Elektra" at the Metropolitan Opera.
Automobile production in the nation last year was the second best on record. However, it declined last month from the November level while remaining above that of December, 1959.

Most corporate annual reports will not be in the mails on the way to stockholders for another six weeks or so. HAVANA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The break in diplomatic relations brought this terse comment tonight from Premier Fidel Castro: "Cuba is Alert."
Believing that the country's compulsory retirement policies need reform, a University of California law college dean set about reforming his own professional school.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Vice President-elect, left the Senate today with a characteristic flourish. He offered his resignation before any one quite realized what he was doing, just three minutes having been sworn in for a tird term.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., -- Cecil Farris Bryant, a 46-year-old Ocala lawyer, took the oath as Governor of Florida today with a pledge to end sectional differences in the state.
The Monsanto Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would build a big ethylene plant in Chocolate Bayou, Tex., with a capacity in excess of 500,000,000 pounds a year.

Yonkers Raceway yesterday scheduled seven events, including the $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Trot, to complete its 1961 list of major races. The newly listed contests are set for the summer or second meeting at the track. They bring to $1,180,000 the total in purses for stakes and features this year at Yonkers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left for the Congo today in an attempt to end the civil disorders threatening the work of the United Nations force there.

The Liberal party declared yesterday that New York State must reassert its leadership among the states if it was to ride a tide in the nation running "strongly in the direction of liberalism."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eighty-seventh Congress convened today amid clashes in both houses over rules of procedure.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The Laotian-Government has raised a number of conditions and qualifications to Britain's proposal that the International Control Commission be reconsitituted to help solve Laos' problems.
Major department stores in the New York metropolitan area failed last month to match the Christmas business of 1959, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 3 (UPI) Frank Lane, baseball's traveling tradesman, was named general manager and executive vice president of the Kansas City Athletics today. It was the first move by the club's new owner to build the American League doormat into a pennant contender.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 3 (AP) -- King Savang Vathana opened an extraordinary session of Parliament today to give Premier Boun Oum's pro-Western Government a vote of confidence and new political strength in the war against pro-Communist forces.

A political rarity -- a campaign fund with a surplus after Election Day -- has emerged here. It will pay for Inauguration Day festivities in Washington for about 400 New Yorkers who had opened their purses to help elect John F. Kennedy to the Presidency.

The American Machine and Foundry Company plans to split its common stock on a two-for-one basis, subject to approval of shareholders at the annual meeting on April 18.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The Bishop of Pavia, the Most Rev. Carlo Allorio, has taken a measure that Roman Catholic observers have termed "revolutionary."

The inauguration of Gov. Luis Munoz Marin to a fourth term on Monday was a happy occasion for Puerto Rico and the United States. Since Puerto Ricans are American citizens, this is a satisfaction that we have a right to share.

HAVANA, Wednesday, Jan. 4 -- The United States Embassy last night urged all Americans in Cuba to leave the island. A statement issued by the press attache said that "all American citizens are urged to depart from Cuba immediately unless compelling, reasons oblige them to remain."

Walter B. Devereux of Rye, N.Y., was elected president of the National Horse Show Association at the organization's annual meeting at 90 Broad Street yesterday. He succeeded William Joshua Barney Jr. of Southport, Conn., who became chairman of the executive comimittee.

An official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged yesterday that in its five years of existence the merged labor movement had failed to eliminate racial discrimination and segregation in many affiliated unions.

Trial of a $3,000,000 antitrust brought by Jack Molinas, a former basketball star against the National Basketball Association will begin at 10:30 this morning in United States District Court.

Some unfinished business from baseball's whirlwind expansion activities of last month will be taken up today at a meeting in Commissioner Ford C. Frick's office.

An American edition of a study of Kwame Nkrumah, President of Ghana, will be published tomorrow by Praeger. KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority today said it was paying 20,716,198 of power revenues the U.S. Treasury. This the first payment under a revised schedule provided under 1959 Power Bond Legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower will ask Congress to vote less funds for the coming fiscal year than for the current year.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver asked President-elect John F. Kennedy today to withdraw his name from consideration for appointment as Secretary of the Army.
Live-virus vaccine proved during the past summer that it can erradicate poliomyelitis from a community, Dr. Albert B. Sabin said here last night.
The leadership of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers has decided to ask union tailors to stop cutting Japanese fabrics received by manufacturers after May 1.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City dropped by $74,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $225,000,000 in the comparable week a year ago.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 5 -- The Norwalk Flood and Erosion Control Commission said today plans for two major municipal flood-control projects would be ready for consideration in two weeks.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- King Saud, who took over full power in Saudi Arabia fifteen days ago, named himself today the head of a new Supreme Planning Council, the Mecca radio reported.
A mediation session continued into the early hours of this morning in search of a formula to settle the three-day strike of 3,000 wholesale butchers.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who will be 48 years old next Monday, will have the delicate task today of opening the ballots sent in by the members of the Electoral College from the various states. Looking on will be the members of both chambers, including Speaker Sam Rayburn of the House, whose seventy-ninth birthday this is.

THE camera and the cult for "personal" interpretation have pretty well done away with the kind of work of art, once so prized, that sought primarily to convey visual information. But, for good reasons, Piranesi, whose prints are the subject of an exhibition at the Old Print Center, 161 East Fifty-second Street, still holds his own.
The destiny of France, of Algeria and of President de Gaulle is now in the hands of some 35,000,000 French voters summoned to a national referendum that begins in Algeria today.

A sharp increase in New York City bank clearings lifted the total for the nation's twenty-six leading cities in the holiday week ended Wednesday from the level of the preceding holiday week and the like week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
This is the time of year when baseball suddenly drops everything else and goes on its annual meaningless spree known us contract signing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Diplomatic sources said here today that the Soviet Union had rejected proposals to revive the International Control Commission on Laos.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The Rockefeller administration's bill for a 10 per cent rebate on 1960 personal income taxes was introduced in the Legislature today. It contemplates a total refund of $90,000,000 on returns due April 15.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- A team has been sent to begin an intensive investigation into the explosion at the National Reactor Testing Station Tuesday that claimed three lives.

EGGS have dropped -- not literally, but in price. Large Grade A whites were reduced this week a big and welcome 6 cents a dozen to a general price of 69 cents a dozen. Milk also took a seasonal 1 cent drop and now sells for 27 cents a quart in most stores.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $127,000,000 t $176,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements increased $208,000,000 to $909,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The nip-and-tuck Senate battle over the filibuster rule continued on and off the Senate floor today, with both sides maneuvering for the few votes that will decide the outcome.
A $17,500,000 all-cash real estate purchase was completed yesterday, clearing the way for the development of a huge community at Breezy Point on the Rockaway Peninsula.

Stocks began yesterday's session with a burst of enthusiasm, a late tape on the up side and gains that entered every section of the New York Stock Exchange list. They ended with considerably less enthusiasm, a late tape on the down side and almost half of the maximum gains erased.

The state's district attorneys asked the Legislature yesterday to allow juries to make a binding recommendation of life imprisonment in all murder trials. The plan also would prohibit the parole of slayers serving life terms.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The flew of Cuban refugees to the United States will be greatly reduced for some time as a result of the break in diplomatic relations, Government officials conceded today.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Encouraged by strength in Wall Street, trading increased in the stock market here today and industrial share prices advanced strongly.

The first "really dramatic novel in English" and three others by its long-forgotten Elizabethan author will be published on Jan. 18 in an omnibus volume called "The Novels of Thomas Deloney." It has been edited by Merritt E. Lawlis.
MIAMI, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A New York group is negotiating to buy the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League and comment from the two sides indicated tonight that a deal is imminent.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Stan Mikita's eighth goal in six games gave the Chicago Black Hawks their sixth consecutive National Hockey League victory tonight, a 4-3 decision over the last-place Boston Bruins.

Net operating earnings after taxes of the Chase Manhattan Bank were $74,276,783 or $5.53 a share in 1960, it was reported yesterday. This was 14.9 per cent above the $64,634,545, or $4.81 a share, cleared in 1959. Share earnings were based on the 13,430,340 shares now outstanding.
A strong effort was made yesterday to place at least part of the blame for the Dec. 16 airliner collision here on lapses and inadequacies in traffic-control procedures.

Basketball grabs most of the headlines during the varsity winter season, but it would be grievous to suppose that campus sports interest begins and ends at the boundaries of the 4,700 square feet of hardwood that make up a regulation court.

Followers of the Fordham basketball team clenched their teeth and dutifully trudged into the Rose Hill gymnasium last night, half expecting to see their idols fall again. Their worst fears proved groundless.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A proxy fight for control of the Detroit Lions of the National Football League is under way between supporters and foes of the club president, Edwin J. Anderson.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Thomas M. Cooley 2d, dean of the University of Pittsburgh Law School, is the likely choice for Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization in the new Administration.
An immigrant who believes he owes the people of this country "a great deal" sent a $5 gift to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday in part payment of what he called his "debt."
Negotiations were reported to be progressing yesterday for Marilyn Monroe to make her television drama debut in "Rain," the play based upon W. Somerset Maugham's short story, "Miss Thompson."

Harry Danziger, who says he owns personally or through his concern, Danziger Kirmse, more than 3,700 shares of stock in the Valley National Bank, Valley Stream, L.I., is soliciting proxies for the annual meeting next Tuesday.
The Soviet all-star hockey team will arrive in New York tonight as a heavy favorite to defeat the United States National team in their game at Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will visit President de Gaulle late this month and resume his personal campaign for two British policy objectives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Census Bureau said today that family incomes had increased more than twice as fast as living costs between 1947 and 1959. It said that after taking inflation into account, the median income had risen from $4,000 to $5,400 during the twelve years.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Thirteen-year-old Carol Noir of East Orange, N.J., took the lead today for the senior women's title in the Eastern figure-skating championships.
LIMA, Peru, Jan. 5 -- The Peruvian Senate approved today an addition to the penal code outlawing the Communist party and similar organizations thought to be subversive.

It is good news indeed that an end has been called to the hassle between the city Fire Department and the Navy about how the Constellation fire was fought. The dispute had been getting badly in the way of what both sides ought to do about the fire -- to make as sure as humanly possible that nothing like it could ever happen again.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle commuted today the death sentence of Mrs. Edythe Klumpp on the eve of her scheduled execution in the electric chair. He indicated that he would grant her a pardon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Forty-four Senators joined today in sponsoring a bill to carry out President-elect John F. Kennedy's pledge of Federal aid for economically depressed areas.
WANTAGH, L.I., Jan. 5 -- Five Long Island Railroad trains were delayed up to forty minutes during the rush hour after a passenger suffered a heart attack and died on a train here this morning.

Events today: "Simon Bocanegra," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, conductor; Rohan de Saram, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Mildred Dilling, harpist, lecture-recital, Town Hall, 5:45; Beveridge Webster, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30, and Chavannes Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Spain has canceled a $71,000,000 line of credit it obtained seventeen months ago from thirteen United States commercial banks, crediting improvement in its gold and foreign exchange position. It never drew as any part of the credit.

Paperboard production in the Christmas holiday week ended last Saturday dropped to 163,709 tons from 285,977 tons the week before, rite National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the comparable year-ago period, which also included a holiday, output was 251,626 tons.

The Waterfront Commission has postponed a hearing on the possible suspension or revocation of the license of a hiring agent and of the registration of three International Longshoremen's Association shop stewards, the commission announced yesterday.

TRENTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The state racing commission today allocated fifty-day seasons for 1961 to each of New Jersey's four tracks, giving Monmouth Park at Oceanport the profitable first week of August.

IT is unfortunate that Fidel Castro was not a better pitcher in his younger days. Then he would have made the big leagues and Cuba would not be in the mess it is in right now. But the bearded dictator still has it in his power to scramble the coming pennant races by spitefully refusing to permit Cuban nationals to return to the States for continued employment in the majors.
Mixed price trends appeared in the market for prime-risk debt securities yesterday.
Senator A.S. Mike Monroney appealed to military and civilian air transport leaders last night to "agree on a common, workhorse type of cargo carrier."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Defense Department committee proposed today that officer promotions be based more on ability and less on length of service.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 5 -- Illinois faced a constitutional crisis today as her Republican Secretary of State asked a court order to oust a Democrat who was elected Speaker of the House in a rump session yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- India's political leaders urged today that Laos be permitted to "remain as an uncommitted area" without outside interference.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals says a building company can renew its efforts to collect $750,000 in damages from a suburban community that blocked the company's integrated housing project.

Along about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a casual visitor to the Mosholu Parkway Junior High School in the Bronx might have thought the din he heard in one wing was inspired by perhaps a lively basketball game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower accepted the resignation today that Democratic and Republican critics had long sought when Ezra Taft Benson stepped out as his Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The order by President Eisenhower to sever United States diplomatic relations with Cuba, especially the date of its issuance, demonstrates a fact of our Government system that many lose sight of with the election of a new Chief Executive.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Par wasn't threatened today as thirty-six professional stars completed the first 18-hole round of the football players golf championship.

ONLY one Bean is necessary to make a Twelfth Night reveler become king for a night. A bean, a pea or even a coin (an old-fashioned silver three-penny bit is generally employed by the British) is traditionally buried in each Twelfth Night cake and the recipient is "crowned" king.
" THE real war will never get into the books," Walt Whitman remarked about the Civil War when he was still brooding over it a decade after General Lee's surrender.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Jan. 5 -- Five neutralist African nations moved closer today to withdrawal of their troops from the Congo, where they have been serving with the United Nations force.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Clarkson's hockey team overcame a 2-0 deficit and defeated Princeton, 5 -- 4, at Baker Rink tonight. It was the fourth straight loss for Princeton.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Army made public today a new four-and-a-half pound anti-tank rocket grenade weapon with a powder explosive.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin severed relations with the Philadelphia Eagles today after a cryptic conversation with Frank McNamee, president of the National Football League champions.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The United States freighter Portland Trader was abandoned in Philippine waters some 400 miles south of Manila today but the thirty-eight-man crew was rescued, officials of the West Coast Steamship Company reported here.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics snapped a Cincinnati winning streak at four games tonight, crashing the Royals, 125-107, before 9,461 National Basketball Association fans at Cincinnati Gardens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Representative Victor Anfuso, Democrat of New York, said today he had information from anti-Castro sources that Premier Fidel Castro planned to let the Soviet Union install missiles on secret launching pads in Cuba.
Sales and earnings of Oscar Mayer Co. for the fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 29 dipped below those of the fifty-three weeks of the preceding fiscal period.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- The Security Council adjourned tonight after having in effect rejected charges to Cuba that the United States planned a military invasion of the island.
A silver lining in the dark cloud of higher interest charges on the Federal debt appeared yesterday.

Two sons of former Magistrate J. Roland Sala were arrested last night. The police said one had stolen a car and led them on a chase in Brooklyn and the other had grappled with them to free his brother.

Governor Rockefeller has agreed to add Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer to the Appellate Division in the First Department next week. This addition has been requested by the Appellate Division and the Judicial Conference because of a backlog of appeals.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Aaron Wagman of New York was sentenced to five years in prison today and fined $10,000 for trying to bribe a University of Florida football player.
The invasion jitters eased somewhat in Laos yesterday, although Soviet aid to the pro-Communist forces continued.

The once-beaten teams of St. John's University and Temple are paired in the first game of a college basketball tripleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. Manhattan will meet St. Peter's and New York University will face St. Joseph's in the other contests.
Sponsors for fifteen new housing projects in an eight-block area of the city's Urban Renewal development on the upper West Side were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 -- John A. Volpe of Winchester became the fifty-seventh Governor of Massachusetts today. He immediately called for reform in state government at all levels.

The election of Dr. G.M Monroe as president and chief executive officer of the National Data Processing Corporation was announced yesterday. Herman L. Philipson Jr. was elected chairman of the Dallas (Tex.) company, manufacturer of bank automation and optical-scanning equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Eventual elimination of large custodial mental hospitals was recommended today by a special Public Health Service Committee.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The home furnishings that consumers will find in stores this spring are predominantly American in design and drawn from the past as well as the present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad today notified the Interstate Commerce Commission it proposed to retire from the passenger service field at the end of this month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States gold reserve was cut by almost $1,700,000,000 in 1960, according to the yearend statement published today by the Treasury.
TRENTON, Jan. 5 -- Fourteen persons died of a liver disease and thirty became ill after having received injections from a doctor near Camden, the New Jersey Health Department disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The National Planning Association declared today that the growth of the United States economy can and should be raised to a sustained annual rate of 4 1/2 per cent.

A United States organization favorable to Premier Fidel Castro called yesterday for a Congressional investigation into what it called increasing press reports "about involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency in the financing, arming and training of forces for an invasion of Cuba."

Trustees of the United States Trust Company declared a 5 per cent stock dividend yesterday. The dividend is payable on Feb. 1 to stock of record of Jan. 12. It is the first stock dividend to be paid by the company.

The Leonard L. Farber Company of New York has acquired land at the intersection of Hylan Boulevard, Old Town Road and Dumont Avenue in Old Town, S.I. The property was bought from Frank J. Pacifico and Nicholas Vlassenko in a deal negotiated by Charles J. Bartels, vice president of Kolff Kaufmann, Inc., brokers.
HONOLULU, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The British passenger liner Arcadia ran aground on a reef at the entrance of Honolulu's harbor today but was pulled off two hours later.

Potatoes future dropped prices as much as 10 points yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where a total of 942 carlots changed hands. The decline was attributed to a heavy supply of Maine potatoes. At the same time Canadian supplies also were reported as larger than usual at this time of year.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 5 -- George Wells Beadle, whose research on bread molds led to a Nobel Prize, is a geneticist who is equally adept at molding men's minds.
The seventh annual charity ball of the Hungarian League of America, Inc., will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Jan. 21.

The Transnation Realty Corporation, Henry Goelet, president, has sold the sixteen-story office building at 71 Nassau Street, northwest corner of John Street, to Downtown Realty Associates. The buyers leased back the property to Transnation, which made the deal in the name of the 220 Rittenhouse Square Corporation of Philadelphia, a subsidiary.
UNITED STATES NAVY BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba Jan. 5 -- Rear Admiral Edward J. O'Donnell casually advise the 10,500 men, employes and dependents in his charge too to carry on as usual.
YONKERS, Jan. 5 -- Firemen who were fighting a fire in a private residence here today had to rush back to their firehouse. Part of it was on fire.
HACKENSACK, N.J. Jan. 5 -- A 49-year-old paraplegic war veteran will preside from a wheelchair when he takes over at the Bergen County District Court soon.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Surrounded by a score of grandchildren and great-grandchildren and beaming with pleasure, Chancellor Adenauer celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday today by giving a show of his undiminished vigor.
DALLAS, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Abner Haynes, a halfback, today was named the new American Football League's player of the year in a league-conducted poll of coaches and writers.

Before many weeks have passed we will know whether this Country can manage to end its seven-year-old Algerian crisis or is about to plunge into political chaos. Any such chaos might make the present Belgian disorders seem like an amiable picnic.

The Wellington Fund, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of almost $70,000,000 in net assets for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30. The period covered was eleven months since the company recently switched to a fiscal year ending on Nov. 30.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Carl Sandburg spent his eighty-third birthday today as he spends most other days: writing.

An exhibition of modern paintings and sculpture will be held at M. Knoedler Co., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, from Feb. 1 through 25 for the benefit of the Museum of Modern Art's library. A preview will be held on the evening of Jan. 31.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 6 -- Joe Haggerty of the home club led the way into the second round of the twenty-ninth annual Luckenbach squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club tonight.

THE ninth season of a series of concerts known as "Music in the Making" began in the Great Hall of Cooper Union last night. Howard Shanet was back as conductor, and as usual he had lined up a program of contemporary works previously unheard here.

Production of lumber in the holiday-week ended last Saturday fell sharply below that of the week before, according to reports from regional associations. The output totaled 111,570,000 board feet, compared with 179,612,000 the week before and 172,500,000 in the comparable year-ago period.
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 6 -- An informal ceremony this morning marked the first sale of diamonds mined in Ghana through the Government diamond market, which has been established here.

Carrots, spinach, tomatoes or corn, to name a few possibilities, can be cooked and pureed for the soup.

A new bi-monthly magazine dedicated by its youthful editors "to providing a vehicle for a second coming of the American intellect" will appear on newsstands in eleven cities next week.
Carmine G. De Sapio said yesterday he saw nothing "unusual or extraordinary" in Mayor Wagner's increased involvment with the Democrats trying to oust Mr. De Sapio as New York County leader.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was told today that measurable progress was being made toward eliminating discrimination in Federal employment.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Norm Van Brocklin charged today that a head coaching offer was used to lure him here three years ago although the Philadelphia Eagles "never intended to give me the job."
NEWARK, Jan. 6 -- James M. Landis observed at first hand today what he termed a "lack of coordination" between a state and Federal regulatory agency.

Events today: The Metropolitan Opera, "Boris Godunov," at 2 P.M. and "Nabucco," at 8 P.M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, Joseph De Pasquale, violist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Enid Miller Katahn, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, conductor, Rohan de Saram, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The new head of the Division of State Police, Arthur Cornelius Jr., would be the answer to a casting director's dream of an F.B.I. agent -- square-jawed, efficient, polite and largely uncommunicative with strangers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, the outstanding golfer in 1960, took a 12 on the final hole today as Ted Kroll of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., shot a 66 for the opening-round lead in the $45,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.

The key domestic problem that will face the Kennedy Administration when it takes over later this month is obviously the current recession. Yesterday's publication of the report of the group headed by Professor Samuelson provides the first extensive statement of the new Administration's thinking in this field. Both the President-elect and the nation are in debt to the authors of this responsible and realistic document.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Retail sales of new cars in December came to 488,168 units, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Plans for changes affecting four of the strategic air commands within the Eighth Air Force were announced today by the Eighth Air Force headquarters here.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The Detroit University basketball team withstood Seton Hall University's last-half rally tonight to win, 84 -- 79, before 3,150 fans.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 6 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China denounced in an address here today what he called "aggressive acts of armed intervention" in Laos.
HONOLULU, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Castle Cooke, a diversified Hawaiian investment and management company, is planning to absorb Dole Corporation and Columbia River Packers Association.

It is over. The great annual guessing game. It is over, at least, until next year when it will be played again, in all its wild foolishness and intensity. "Game," perhaps, is not the right word; nor is "gamble," although the situation referred to has, to the participant with a profit potential, an apparent element of chance in that the outcome is, like the result of a horse race, not foreknown to him.

A TALL, dark and handsome young man, who designs sports fashions for tall, slender and elegant young women, has come to the rescue of a damsel in distress. The pregnant woman, whose Joy at the prospect of motherhood is often slightly dimmed by the problem of finding attractive clothes, can look forward to wearing spring and summer maternity fashions by John Weitz.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Communist China broke its recent silence on the Laos situation tonight, to warn the United States that it was "at the brink of the precipice."

Wherever American's international sports prestige may be at the moment, there is little hope for any upgrading today when the United States National hockey team opposes a touring sextet from the Soviet Union.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Jan. 6 -- The African-Asian "summit" conference here adopted tonight a final resolution approving "the enlistment of African and other volunteers" to aid Algerian insurgents fighting for independence from France.
Visiting royalty and young leaders of local society were partners last evening for the dancing of the quadrille at the Quadrille Ball.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 -- The federated organizations collecting funds for charities in Westchester are having difficulty meeting current quotas.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Senator Clifford P. Case has decided to assume the leadership of the Republican party in New Jersey.

The chief executive officer of the nation's largest railroad took a look down the track yesterday and found the prospects for the rail industry, "not at all optimistic." James M. Symes, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said he did not believe business would be good in the first half, and "especially" not in the first quarter of 1961.

Fourteen individuals were invested yesterday as associate commanders and associate officers for the American Society of the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem. The ceremony was in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee announced today that it would hold a public hearing tomorrow on what it termed "the payments of a Castro subsidy" to the "Fair Play for Cuba" Committee.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Tom Heinsohn and Bob Cousy paced Boston to its fifth straight victory tonight as the Celtics defeated the crippled Detroit Pistons, 108 -- 102, in a National Basketball Association game.

Cyrus S. Eaton said yesterday that he was planning to convene a conference of economic and industrial leaders from Communist and non-Communist countries to draft a treaty on disarmament for submission to the governments of the world.

CLAYT SEAGEARS, who is soon to retire as Chief of Conservation Education and who knows more about New York State woods and their fish and game than anybody else, has been looking back to see what he could find in old notes.

A City Council resolution opposing the construction of bowling alleys over the main rotunda of Grand Central Terminal was offered yesterday by Councilman Louis Okin. The resolution will be introduced Jan. 17.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6 -- John M. Beckmann, the Commissioner of the Nassau County Police Department, disappeared under mysterious circumstances today. His pistol and wallet were found in an abandoned car on a bridge near Jones Beach.
Four airline captains testified yesterday that on the day of the airliner collision here they had had trouble with a radio beam that one of the doomed planes might have been using to navigate.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- Moscow has become a city of lighter work days and heavier rubles. If joys have accrued from that they have been seasoned with considerable confusion.

The Federation of the Handicapped, whose executive offices are at 211 west Fourteenth Street, is a non-profit rehabilitation center founded in 1935, by three amputees. Its highly laudable main objective has always been to enable severely disabled adults to lead independent lives and to become at least partly self supporting.

A professor of law at the International Christian University in Tokyo said here yesterday that Christians had participated in the mass demonstrations in Japan last year, but not out of any hatred for the United States.
Three new members of the Art Commission were appointed and sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner at City Hall.
ALGIERS, Jan. 6 -- About 60 per cent of those registered were officially recorded as voting today in the first day of the French national referendum on Algeria. Nearly 600 communes in Algeria voted.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations dedicated its new twelve-story building today. The building is situated across First Avenue from the world organization's headquarters at Forty-fifth Street.

About eleven and one-half acres in the former Entin Industrial Terminal at Clifton, N.J., have been purchased by Lester M. Entin Associates and Troast-Sletteland Enterprises for improvement with a one-story building.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- The State Department of Health today identified thirteen of the fourteen persons who died of liver ailment after having been given injections by an osteopathic physician.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 -- President Sekou Toure of Guinea flew to Belgrade today for a six-day official visit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A civilian employe of the Navy at Brooklyn refused today to tell Senate investigators the source of almost $100,000 they said he had spent between 1955 and 1959.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- A suit challenging the constitutionality of New Jersey's property assessment reform laws was filed in State Superior Court here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
