Prices on the New York commodity exchanges generally advanced yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns are a 5-point favorite over the Detroit Lions tomorrow in a football game in the Orange Bowl that will set some precedents.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 6 -- The driver of a "souped up" car was fatally injured early today when his vehicle struck three trees and a utility pole on Jericho Turnpike at a speed estimated at 135 miles an hour.
President-elect John F. Kennedy discussed civil rights yesterday afternoon with Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for Advancement of Colored People.
Leaders of the American Medical Association pledged their cooperation yesterday to Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, Secretary-designate of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
NANETTE FABRAY'S new series, to judge by its first episode, is no world beater, but it does have its moments and, most of all, Miss Fabray.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The fact that herds of deer had to be moved from Georgia's offshore islands to the mainland brought about the issuance of a patent this week. It was granted to a team of investors consisting of a game commission official, three university faculty members and a manufacturer.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The Catholic Archdiocese of New York has signed a contract to buy the fifty-five-acre Gilbert Burck estate near here.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 6 -- Turkey's new House of Representatives, which will serve as a temporary parliament until general elections are held, was opened today.
By his own declaration, Carmen Basilio's boxing future depends on the outcome of his ten-round main event with Gaspar Ortega in Madison Square Garden tonight.
The Bronx Zoo was doting yesterday on its first acquisitions of the year -- a nyala and a woolly monkey. Both animals were reluctant, but reluctant, about different things.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz opened his annual legislative offensive against sales and repair cheats today.
Ingrid Bergman's ninety-minute television special, which has seen about as many changes as anything in the medium, underwent another one yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 6 -- Gov. Jimmy H. Davis' Administration, obviously, lacking votes, delayed a vote in the Senate today on the proposed 1-cent increase in the state sales tax. At the same time, opposition forces made a blistering attack on the Governor.
Prospects for heading off a strike of about 660 railroad marine workers against eleven port railroads dimmed yesterday. The strike is scheduled to start at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

Arnold A. Gordon has been named assistant vice president of the Mills Factors Corporation, here, commercial finance and factoring organization. He was the divisional manager of the commercial finance department.

Consumers, who have been repaying installment debt almost as fast as they have been borrowing anew, may be ready to begin a new buying spree. Sparked by a sharp increase in automobile purchases on time, new credit extensions in November amounted to $4,132,000,000, on a seasonally adjusted basis, $37,000,000 above the October level.

NOW that action painting has become deliberate, popular style, we need no longer look at it as a manifestation of the unconscious mind, as was the fashion a decade ago. It has come to be as consciously adopted as any other historical style.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 6 -- An appeal for the liberation of Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Premier, was broadcast today in the name of the army security chief who said he arrested him five weeks ago. The security chief is a prisoner himself in Mr. Lumumba's bailiwick.
HAVANA, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Major league baseball clubs with Cuban players can relax -- the hired hands will be available for work when the spring training camps open next month.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Arthur Cornelius Jr., a former special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has been named to head the Division of State Police.

The bond market's first trading week of the new year closed yesterday with gilt-edge debt investments showing the same mixed trend that had been visible over much of the week. Corporate and local government bonds of high investment quality were strong, but Treasury obligations tended to drift downward in price.

The New York Times of Dec. 13 published a letter from Mark G. Field in which he said that the Soviet Union was "outdistancing us" in medicine and, particularly, in the training of physicians. He said that the Soviet Union is turning out far more doctors than American medical schools; so many, in fact, that the Russians soon will be "exporting doctors, particularly to the new and under-developed countries."

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Jan. 6 (UPI) -- A Los Angeles business executive and four other persons were killed today when their twin-engine privatep plane crashed only fifty feet from the busy Imperial freeway, the police said.

The Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity will hold its first annual meeting beginning tomorrow in Williamsburg, Va.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Soybean futures swung over their broadest price range in more than two years today on the Board of Trade and finished with gains running to more than 5 cents a bushel despite a late steep slide. At long last Russians and other Soviet visitors to this country are now permitted to visit Brooklyn. Such formerly prohibited pleasures as bathing at Coney Island, strolling in Prospect Park, or viewing the historic site where the Dodgers once gamboled are open to them. This is one of the results of the latest changes the State Department has announced in the list of areas in our country Soviet citizens may and may not visit.
With 207,563 passengers carried on its ships last year, the Cunard Line reported yesterday that it had handled more trans-Atlantic travelers an any other shipping company.

Friday noon on Capitol Hill in Washington was a pleasant occasion. Vice President Richard M. Nixon, whose duty it was to announce the results of the Electoral College vote for President, performed this little drama with grace and magnanimity. Nobody doubted him when he said he wished to extend "heartfelt best wishes" to President-elect John F. Kennedy and Vice-President-elect Lyndon B. Johnson.
Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland recently paced a field of ten in a Central European chess tournament at Ubbergen, the Netherlands, with six victories and three draws.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 7 -- A constitutional deadlock that had threatened to delay the inauguration of Governor-elect Otto Kerner was tentatively resolved today by a compromise.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Workmen have entered the final stage in making the Niagara power project ready for start of commercial generation of hydroelectric power next month. Two units, each rated at 150,000 kilowatts, are scheduled to produce first firm power Feb. 10.

Consumers often are confused by the cleaning instructions that come with garments nowadays. All too often the instructions are in the form of a tag that quickly disappears, and then the confusion is compounded.

VENICE, Fla. -- This town's newest tourist attraction is nothing less than the Greatest Show on Earth. The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus has decided to make Venice its permanent winter home, and it is now established in its new quarters, which are still under construction.

Post-Christmas liquidation of retail stocks was successfully accomplished and department stores finished their first week of the new year with figures slightly on the plus side. Final figures for 1960 bore out earlier predictions that sales would be 1 per cent ahead of 1959 levels.

Betting and attendance at thoroughbred race tracks throughout the country reached a record high in 1960, a United Press international survey revealed yesterday, with 32,429,859 persons wagering $2,480,775,161.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7 -- Latin America has reacted to the United States decision to sever diplomatic ties with Cuba with another of the curiously ambivalent attitudes that all along have characterized the uneasy position of this region toward the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 7 -- The final session of the African conference on the rule of law adopted a resolution today inviting all African governments to study the possibility of adopting an African convention of human rights. The purpose would be to assure that the conclusions of the universal declaration of human rights of 1948 would be safeguarded.

NEW HAVEN, Jan 7 -- Yale University announced today the appointment of fourteen young faculty members as Morse Fellows for 1961-62. The appointments give them a year's leave at full salary for research in their fields.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic legislative leaders charged today that Governor Rockefeller had failed to live up to his promises to speed the highway building program.

Retail business held its own in the first week of the new year and sales were about equal with the good volume scored a year earlier. With the holiday reports compiled, it was disclosed that sales in the Kansas City area were the largest on record and a 10 per cent gain for December pushed the year into the plus column by 1 per cent.

MONTREAL, Jan. 7 -- The Montreal Canadiens gained a 3 -- 1 first-period lead over the New York Rangers tonight and went on to score a 6-3 victory over the New Yorkers. The triumph enabled the Canadiens to maintain their 2-point edge over Toronto for first place in the National Hockey League.

WHEN Joe Lapchick no longer could endure the agonizing pressures that were turning him into a physical wreck as coach of the New York Knickerbockers, he quit. He would leave the violent, storm-tossed waters of pro basketball, he decided, and return to the placid millpond of college play -- no pressures, no jitters, no nervous tension, no emotional turmoil, no nuthin'. Oh, yeah?

Easter this year falls on April 2, which doesn't give producers much time to turn out goods in sufficient numbers.

THE latest triumph of sentiment over progress is the revival of heating stoves. As a glance at the examples here indicates, the stove can be a highly decorative addition to a room. A PAIR of skillful guides, Irving Robbin and illustrator Herb Mott, take a reader on a happy spin through the history of great automobiles. En route we encounter colorful cars, snappy slogans and characters both daring and inventive. The Stanley Steamer and the Stutz Bearcat, the Model T and the Mercedes, the "beetle" (the Volkswagen) and the "big brute" (the Bentley) and others are here pictured in full color and set in a well-designed format.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- The United Nations is planning to extend a small but significant aid program to help Laos develop basic medical facilities for her people, especially the children.

For the first time since World War II, the nation's banks can boast that they are doing better than most of their customers.

KITCHEN range hoods that require no ducts or outside vents can be installed over any stove in less than one hour. Containing a powerful, built-in fan which draws air in from directly over the burners, these units automatically filter the air to remove all smoke, grease and odors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton denied today that he had suggested that Vice President Nixon might replace Senator Thomas H. Kuchel of California in 1962.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 7 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's short visit here this week and the arrival for a prolonged stay of an Afro-Asian conciliation commission mark a new United Nations effort to bring some order into the chaos of the Congo.

It's not that R. Dragon isn't a lively companion, as readers of "Green Smoke" will know: he's a fine singer and story-teller, and he quickly ingratiates himself with the St. Aubyns townsfolk by agreeing to act in their historical pageant.

He has also been called the most controversial playwright producing in Europe today -- and that, at least, is true.

THE current dialogue over "the gold crisis" reminds me of similar discussions in President Roosevelt's oval study during the early days of the New Deal. Then as now, gold was being drained from the United States. Widely differing analyses of the cause of the trouble led to a variety of remedial proposals, ranging from the ultra-orthodox to the fantastically radical.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The referendum taking place in France and Algeria this Sunday represents a show-down contest between traditional French Cartesian logic and the pragmatism of President de Gaulle. The toy industry set a record in unit sales and retail dollar volume last year, but many manufacturers and retailers realized little or no profits.

The natural gas and pipeline industry showed itself recession-proof in 1960. And the outlook for the present year is for greater gains.

The National Cash Register Company will open today what it calls a new kind of automation center. Facilities at 50 Rockefeller Plaza will make a computer available for the first time to businesses as small as a neighborhood grocery store with only one cash register.
SEATTLE -- Despite the likelihood of sizable unemployment for several months, the economic outlook for Washington State and particularly the Seattle area in 1961 is one of cautious optimism.

How much he spends and what he buys will have a direct bearing on industrial activity, employment, corporate profits and just about every phase of economic activity.
Six of every 1,000 American holders of ordinary life insurance policies died in 1960 and three-fourths were victims of heart disease or cancer, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.
Negroes have now won admission to virtually every business and industry in New York State, the chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination said yesterday.
The market for gilt-edge debt securities is bullish with the start of 1961, after having moved uncertainly during the last year away from a period of acute stringency in the winter of 1959-60.

In a rare spell of competence, the New York Knickerbockers extended their winning streak to three games yesterday. They resembled anything but a last-place club as they rallied to down the Philadelphia Warriors, 121 -- 119, in a National Basketball Association contest at Madison Square Garden.

Private pension plans, the bulwarks of security for retired workers and one of the biggest sources of investment funds, rose to new dominance in employe coverage and benefits in 1960. The plans benefited, too, from changes in the Government's Social Security program.

Printing, which is the second largest manufacturing industry in the New York metropolitan area, rang up a record volume of sales in 1960 although there was a downturn in the July-November period. Sales for the year came to $1,218,000,000, a rise of 5 per cent over 1960.

Despite the slump in some other sections of the economy, the food industry continued to boom last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, having won himself a second term, waxed a bit nostalgic this week over some bygone Senatorial customs.
Although the room occupancy rate of the nation's hotels last year dropped 1 per cent below the 1959 figure, their sales rose slightly.
Consumers, who apparently have decided to "pay now, buy later," are worrying the installment credit industry.

President-elect John F. Kennedy was urged yesterday to address himself directly to Premier Khrushchev in his inaugural speech in an effort to "halt the drift toward war."

MINNEAPOLIS -The business dip and its effects will be "very mild" in the Ninth Federal Reserve District in the first half of 1961, according to a forecast by Oscar F. Litterer, vice president and business economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Dealers in soybean futures left little doubt this week about their belief in the direction of the soybean market. They bid prices up to their highest ranges of the year for all contracts and extended the gains for the last three weeks to about 20 cents a bushel.
MASS-PRODUCED home fur-furnishings have taken most of the honors in the annual American Institute of Decorators awards, which were scheduled to be presented in Chicago last night.
Railroads turned to mergers during 1960 in a struggle with what one observer in 1958 called their chief difficulty.

The value of the nation's mineral output in 1960 reached an estimated total of $17,800,000,000, a rise of 4 per cent over 1959 totals, and second only to thee record $18,100,000,000 established in 1957, according to the Department of the Interior.

PARIS, Monday Jan. 9. -- France gave President de Gaulle a new mandate for leadership and specific endorsement of his Algerian policy by an impressive majority in a national referendum yesterday.

Burlap purchases in the United States market dropped 4 per cent last year.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York recommended yesterday that the city close an unspecified number of municipal hospitals not affiliated with medical schools or with major voluntary teaching institutions.

There is further evidence that output and activity this week will match market conditions that prevailed in November. And there is more than hope that new order volume will soon be above 50 per cent of capacity -- a figure not seen for many months.

The natural gas and pipeline industry spent $76,000,000 of its 1960 construction budget on expanding underground storage. This increased the total to $700,000,000 invested in underground pools by year-end. The American Gas Association expects this total to go above $1,000,000,000 during 1963.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- France's two leading advocates of a "yes" vote on Algeria -- President de Gaulle and Premier Michel Debre -- said "yes" today in their home towns.

Shoe production dropped last year to about 605,000,000 pair, from the record figure of 638,201,000 in 1959. The record figure caused inventory accumulation that cut last year's output. Forecasts of production for the current year vary, but few more than a slight gain over 1960.

President-elect John F. Kennedy attended mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as unobtrusively as he could, considering that next week he will be inaugurated President of the United States.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell has thrown a challenge the new Congress should accept -- the enactment of a minimum wage for farm workers, which he maintains is "both feasible and desirable." ATHENS -- This country's major economic headache is still unemployment, with the total now above 275,000. The Government, headed by Constantine Karamanlis for the last five years, has provided no cure for the situation.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Puerto Rican Legislature opened tonight with a move to unseat the Christian Action party's two delegates. The party is backed by the Roman Catholic church.

LAUNCESTON, Australia, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- Alf Valentine, a West Indian spin bowler, took five wickets for 33 runs today as the touring cricket team set down a Tasmanian squad for a first-innings total of only 123.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that a union representative might be given consecutive sentences on convictions for conspiracy to violate the Hobbs Act against racketeering and for extortion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9 -- Otto Kerner, Illinois' new Democratic Governor, warned today that his state faced a "serious financial crisis."

GENEVA, Jan. 9 -- The member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) today postponed until next month any attempt to reschedule the already delayed opening of their major negotiations for a further reduction in the tariff barriers to world trade.

KUALA LAMPUR, Malaya -- The possibility that the Federation of Malaya will introduce its own currency is causing some concern to the four other Commonwealth territories in Southeast Asia that use the Malayan dollar as a common currency. The Malayan dollar is pegged to the pound sterling and is valued at eight and a half to the pound.
The State of Louisiana sold yesterday an issue of $17,000,000 of general obligations to finance public improvements for the Port of New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Four officers of Cuban consulates in this country have asked for asylum in the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The grain futures market ran into stiff resistance today after an early broad run-up on the Board of Trade and closed mixed to weak.

Alan Schneider, a director who has won plaudits on and off Broadway, as well as a Ford Foundation grant, will go to London this month to stage "The Connection," Jack Gelber's off-beat and long-running drama about narcotics addiction.

Binghamton, Johnson City and Endicott, N.Y., business men, civic leaders -- even the Sarah Jane Memorial Methodist Church in Johnson City -- have joined together to keep control of the Endicott Johnson Corporation upstate.
THE Yale University Art Gallery has announced that it would open on Thursday an exhibition that should add envy-green to the college colors of many a school.

The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy (ANTA) will benefit from four theatre parties. Blocks of seats have been taken for "The Unsinkable Molly Brown" at the Winter Garden Theatre next Monday, for "Critic's Choice" at the Barrymore Theatre on Jan. 23, for "Camelot" at the Majestic on the evening of Feb. 1 and for "Do Re Mi" at the St. James on Feb. 20.
CAIRO -- Egypt, at the beginning of 1961, is moving quietly ahead on the road of economic expansion and, it is hoped, to the more abundant life.
LONDON -- This year appears to offer some opportunity for British exporters to regain some of the ground lost in 1960.

The First National Bank of Atlanta is offering to shareholders of record of Dec. 30, 1960, rights to subscribe for 150,000 additional common shares at $35 a share at the rate of three shares for each twenty held. The rights will expire at 2 P.M. on Jan. 20.
The city was asked yesterday to spend $11,000,000 more on its children next year than it is spending this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Brooks Hays, Democrat, whose moderate position in the Little Rock school crisis cost him his Congressional seat, will be named Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations, sources close to the incoming Kennedy Administration said today.
GENEVA -- "I am not an economist or a sociologist," said the African editor, "but I can figure some things out.

The country's retail stores are going in more and more for automatic handling of their work, from the receiving and selling of merchandise to the handling of billings and payments, along with salaries, payments to vendors and other disbursements.
Supporters of the Community Service Society have arranged a cocktail party and sale of paintings for Saturday evening at the Feingarten Galleries, Madison Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- The Security Council has been called to meet Thursday at 10:30 A.M. to take up the Congo crisis again.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Supreme Court struck down today a $1,867,545 award to the Dixon-Yates power group for the cancellation of its contract with the Government.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce proposed today that the Federal, state and local governments provide financial relief for the railroads serving Massachusetts.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 9 -- The Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity met its first test today.
RETALHULEU, Guatemala, Jan. 9 -- This area is the focal point of Guatemala's military preparations for what Guatemalans consider will be an almost inevitable clash with Cuba.
CARNEGIE Recital Hallers were treated last night to an Introduction, a Dialogue, a Discussion, Progressions and a Sequence, not necessarily in that order.
James John Sweeney, who resigned last July as director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue, has been appointed director of the Museum of Fine Arts of Houston.

DON'T look now, but those creatures throwing up dust and trumpeting primitively may be rhinoceroses debouching from the Longacre Theatre. Or better still, look and listen, for they are comic and they are serious, too.
NEW DELHI, India -- India entered the new year with a multitude of overwhelming problems and a substantial measure of hope.

The plans of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers to stop cutting cheap clothing materials from Japan after May 1 should be taken seriously by the Government and private interests not only in Japan but in other countries as well.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Assemblyman John Robert Brook of Manhattan was appointed chairman of the Assembly's powerful Judiciary Committee tonight.
Mayor Wagner shied away from committing himself yesterday to Councilman Earl Brown, the choice of five Harlem Negro leaders for Borough President.
KATMANDU, Nepal -- Putting the economic clock forward is not an easy task for this small kingdom, which emerged from isolation only a decade ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- Indonesia, an archipelago reaching for socialism, embarked Jan. 1 on a vast eight-year development plan against an economic background of accumulated gloom mixed with a few glimmers of hope.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The International Longshoremen's Association has ordered a boycott of Bermuda cargoes in Canada and the United States because stevedore companies in Bermuda have refused to enter into negotiations with Local 1885.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Unbeaten Ohio State posted its eleventh basketball victory of the season by beating Evansville, 86 -- 59, tonight.
Every now and then, Pier 6, that legendary brawling place of the longshoremen, is moved uptown to the St. Nicholas Arena for a bit of the same brand of no-punches-barred slugging.
LONDON -- Investors in the London Stock Market, who began last year with high hopes, face 1961 in a decidedly sober mood.
Marine employes of eleven railroads in the port of New York went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The State Department expressed satisfaction today with France's endorsement of President de Gaulle's self-determination policy for Algeria.

The Superior Oil Company of California reported yesterday a net income of $5,620,630, equal to $13.32 each on the 422,000 capital shares outstanding for the three months ended on Nov. 30. Gross operating income was $35,342,987.

The appeal by the World Zionist Congress to Jews throughout the world to go to Israel for the "reconstruction of their own lives" was "categorically rejected" yesterday by Clarence Coleman Jr., president of the American Council for Judaism.

IN Charles Goren's "Championship Bridge" television show on Sunday afternoon, when this writer played with William Seamon of Miami against Bertram Lebhar Jr. of Palm Beach and Miss Carol Ross of Detroit, there was apparently time to show only three of the four deals actually played.

SCHWECHAT, Austria -- Little known as an oil-producing power, Austria is non-Communist Europe's second largest producer. Here at Schwechat, just outside of Vienna, the Austrian Oil Administration is completing a new refinery that is to have an annual capacity of 1,600,000 tons.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt issued today the results of a study recommending that the state assume the entire cost of Civil Service pensions. The Democratic official said he agreed with the proposal.

PARIS -- Despite some of the worst weather in recent years, there are good indications that 1960 was another banner year for tourism both in the number of visitors to France and in the amount of money they spent.
RANGOON, Burma -- Burma finally regained in the last year its pre-war levels of agricultural production.
LONDON -- American industry's candidate for "Briton of the Year 1960" could well be a sandy-haired 62-year-old Irishman who says he feels "as much at home in Dearborn as in Dagenham."

LONDON -- Now that the British aircraft industry has merged under three main groupings, its objectives for 1961 are to increase exports of aircraft, engines and parts and to proceed with design plans for a supersonic airliner.
In the Dec. 26 issue a story was carried in which an inquiry absolved Lavon of giving orders to Israel armed forces to stage a military attack on Gaza in 1955.

President de Gaulle has won an impressive mandate for his Algerian program. He had so arranged matters that it would have been astounding if there were any other result. He staked his Presidency on the outcome, used the army to bring out the vote in Algeria and, in any event, knew that most Frenchmen in France wanted to see an end to the Algerian conflict at all costs.
OSLO, Norway -- Norway's economy in 1960 reached a peak unsurpassed in her history.
PARIS, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Davey Moore of Springfield, Ohio, the world featherweight champion, scored a ten-round decision tonight over Gracieux Lamperti of France, the European champion.
OTTAWA, Jan. 9 -- Lester B. Pearson, Opposition leader, urged tonight that Canada end her present role in the North American Air Defense Command.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Buck Shaw, who this Sunday will end a thirty-nine-year coaching career, was named today to the Helms football Hall of Fame along with eight players.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 -- The cloak of anonymity that customarily enfolds Harvard Overseers attending bimonthly meetings in the college Yard was torn asunder today for a member from the Class of 1940 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy.

Maurice Podoloff, the president of the National Basketball Association, testified yesterday in Federal Court that he was justified in not reinstating Jack Molinas, whom he barred for life from N.B.A. play for betting on his own team to win in 1954.

TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that a taxpayer whose real or personal property is assessed above the prevailing average rate in his community is being illegally discriminated against.
CAESAREA,, Israel, Jan. 9 -- Sam Snead defeated Harry Weetman of England today in a match that introduced golf to Israel.
Weakness in the prices of two leading nonferrous metals, zinc and copper, were reported yesterday.
A two-way traffic in alcoholic beverages between this country and abroad began to shape up last year. Previously since World War II, the flow had been all one way -- into the United States.

Two books of which President Eisenhower is the principal party will be published next week. One will be "Peace With Justice, Selected Addresses of Dwight D. Eisenhower," which Columbia University Press will issue on Monday.
Spokesmen for commercial interests were reported yesterday to have stressed the citywide benefits they expected from a $52,000,000 proposal to build sixteen municipal garages in midtown Manhattan.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- The Yugoslav economic scene at the end of 1960 was one of intense activity looking toward inauguration of the nation's planned foreign exchange and trade reforms.

BONN, Germany -- Automobile production in West Germany rose to a record total of 1,500,000 passenger cars and 500,000 trucks and buses in 1960. But for the first time more cars were sold at home than abroad.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 -- An outwardly mellowed Leo Durocher came back today as a coach for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

ALGERIA, Jan. 9 -- The size of the "yes" vote that President de Gaulle obtained from France and Algeria in the referendum on his policy has left the Europeans of Algeria bitter, discouraged and apprehensive.
The Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that charter revision, while needed here, would not solve the problem of getting good municipal leadership.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 9 -- Premier Chou En-lai ended a week's visit here today by concluding an agreement under which Burma will receive a loan equivalent to $85,000,000, without interest, over a period of six years.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 9 -- The security committee of the Belgian Cabinet met twice today -- once at 4:30 A.M. -- to "take urgent measures against the wave of criminal acts of sabotage in certain regions of the country."

MADRID -- Halfway through her economic reform program, Spain is reacting like a middle-aged man halfway through his morning calisthenics. Every new bend seems more painful and the temptation just to halt and pant is increasingly sweet.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Jeff Corey, an actor who says he was blacklisted ten years ago, was facing a camera last week. He was working in a television series called "The Untouchables."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration modified today its ban on use of the color formerly known as FD C Red No. 1.
A mortgage of up to $70,000,000 said to be the largest ever made in New York for a single commercial property, has been arranged for the fifty-nine-story Pan Am Building

Junie McMahon was a bowler few persons would bet against when the competition became close. His ability to win in the last few frames, even against the nation's best, helped carry him to two national championships.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Jules Roy, author of France's controversial best-seller, "The War in Algeria," has a play about the war in Indochina running to capacity audiences at the Theatre in the Round in Montmartre.

The dearth of drawing room comedy was deplored by Cathleen Nesbitt, the actress, at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk at Sardi's, 234 West Forty-fourth Street. The subject discussed by the organization of stage reporters was "Broadway Humor."

The election of Representative Paul A. Fino as Bronx County Republican leader was assured last night. Opponents gave up the fight against him in deference to the wishes of L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Five persons, two of them Admiralty civil servants, were remanded today in custody for a week in an espionage case apparently involving Britain's secret anti-submarine research.
TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will propose a multi-million-dollar bond issue tomorrow to promote private construction of housing for persons in the middle-income bracket.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan, 9 -- Fairfield University's basketball team scored its seventh straight victory tonight by beating Iona, 94-79. A strong second-half surge by the Connecticut team proved decisive. The Red Stags had lost their first two games before starting the winning streak.

Prof. Seymour E. Harris' endorsement in The New York Times of Jan. 3 of the Heald report's proposal to institute a $300 tuition fee for undergraduate matriculants at public colleges in New York indicates a misunderstanding of the special character of the City College and the other four-year colleges in the municipal system.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 -- Oklahoma's indefinite suspension was lifted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- Following is the text of President-elect John F. Kennedy's speech before the Massachusetts Legislature today:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- The Reading Railroad announced today a 10 per cent reduction in payroll expenses, effective Saturday. It will be accomplished through a combination of salary cuts and lay-offs.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 -- The Martin Company disclosed today that it had begun preliminary design work on a manned space station that would orbit the earth with a thirty-five-man crew.
LONDON -- More tourists visited Britain last year and spent more money here than ever before. Of the estimated total of 1,600,000 visitors, more than 430,000 came, from the United States.

T.S. ELIOT stirred a fine broth of controversy the other day by suggesting that contemporary poetry -- including his own -- should not be studied formally in school. Now here is a splendid book by Archibald MacLeish, called "Poetry and Experience,"* that should guide thousands to the enjoyment and understanding of poetry from the days of Lu Chi (302 A.D.) to the latest Eliotic mysteries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission moved today to reduce its workload by delegating much of the commission's business.

Charles T. Ireland Jr., 39-year-old lawyer, yesterday was elected president of the Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company that controls the $2,500,000,000 New York Central Railroad and the $3,000,000,000 Minneapolis investment company complex, Investors Diversified Service, Inc.

"SAFETY in the Skies -- the Jet Age" was the topic of "Open End" on WNTA-TV (Channel 13) on Sunday night. Five authorities on the subject of modern aviation joined moderator David Susskind for a forthright and intelligent discussion of a serious problem and the possibilities of solving it.
LAGOS, Nigeria -- As Nigeria enters 1961, the country's economic outlook looks brighter than it has been in recent years. But Nigeria still faces some real problems.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Indiana's new Democratic Governor and Republican Lieutenant Governor took their oaths of office in separate ceremonies today. They pledged cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today an order striking down Delaware's grade-a-year school desegregation plan and ordering full integration to begin next fall.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) up to 5 points (25 cents a bale) down yesterday.
Copper futures showed one of the sharpest price declines in recent months in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange.

Windsor Industries, Inc., is planning an "aggressive acquisition campaign," the company's new top executives said yesterday. Windsor's chief asset now is its 57 per cent interest in the Bates Manufacturing Company, a producer of cotton products.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 9 -- A proposal to expand the powers of Westchester County officials ran into heavy opposition at a public hearing here tonight.
VIENNA -- Austria's national economy enjoyed a good year and a fair year is forecast for 1961.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 9 -- The former president and secretary of the East Rutherford Board of Health, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to extort $150 a month for allowing the illegal dumping of cesspool wastes in the Hackensack Meadows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Government argued today that the Governors of New York and New Jersey had gone beyond their legal powers in ordering the Port of New York Authority to defy a subpoena from a House Judiciary subcommittee.
TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell is considering running for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey at the suggestion of Senator Clifford P. Case.

The Salvation Army's 1961 Appeal began yesterday morning with the setting up of a large plastic reproduction of a telephone replacing the usual starting dinner or pep rally. The mock phone is set up in the office of the city-wide drive chairman, Donald M. Elliman, president of the Bank of New York, at 48 Wall Street.
The Board of Health voted yesterday to ban three classes of gas refrigerators because of the carbon monoxide hazard and warned that at its next meeting it might ban all gas refrigerators from homes.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- President de Gaulle's victory yesterday in the referendum on his Algerian policy constitutes an urgent challenge to him to obtain peace quickly, in the opinion of observers here.

DUBLIN, Jan. 9 -- A number of prominent Irish business men and United States citizens active in industry in the Irish Republic attended a luncheon at the Gresham Hotel here today to form an American Chamber of Commerce in Ireland.
The item and picture in your Dec. 29 issue of students cramming for examinations in the main reference room of the New York Public Library missed a vital and tragic point.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- The economic surge on which Sweden rode into 1960 continued strong during the year.
AFTER two and one-half years of struggling with the conscience of an American scientist, the United States of America has given way a little.

A gloomy forecast for business for the year ahead, but one appreciably brighter than a few weeks ago, was made before the country's leading retail merchants last evening by Malcolm P. McNair, Lincoln Filene Professor of Retailing at the Graduate School of Business Administration of Harvard University.
ROME -- In 1960 the Italian economy experienced a real boom, with results that economists described with adjectives ranging to sensational.
ALGIERS -- Despite the continuation of the long, bloody and costly Algerian war, this strife-torn land made some significant economic progress in 1960.
Composers Showcase and Jazz Profiles will move from Greenwich Village to the Museum of Modern Art.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller's bill to provide a 10 per cent across-the-board rebate on 1960 income taxes was approved by the State Senate tonight.

Following is a reprint of an account in Harper's Weekly, dated Jan. 19, 1861, of the firing on the Star of the West in Charleston harbor on Jan. 9. The firing, which took place 100 tears ago yesterday, was the first incident of the Civil War.

LONDON -- A world-wide complex of sixty companies has a new chief, although it's all in the family. The vast organization is the Hunting Group of Companies, with headquarters here. The new chairman is G.L. Hunting, who succeeded his brother, Sir Percy Hunting, at the beginning of the year.

The Reliance Insurance Company, of Philadelphia, plans to acquire the Standard Accident Insurance Company, of Detroit, through an exchange of stock on a share-for-share basis, it was announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Week-to-week auto production figures during 1961 probably will be lower than the comparable 1960 levels, although not by as much as in the first week of this year.

TOKYO -- Japan's amazing economic growth continued through 1960. Every indication points to a progressively brighter future as the demand for this country's manufactured products increases in the less-developed nations and other established markets abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Senate Democratic leadership today scheduled the first confirmation hearings on President-elect John F. Kennedy's Cabinet appointees.
HONG KONG -- Hong Kong has entered 1961 with some qualms about the future but with no real signs of a break in the economic boom that has created an industrial revolution here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower opened the White House Conference on Aging today with informal remarks that noted the conflict on medical care within the conference.

IN "The Potting Shed," which is this week's attraction on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13, Graham Greene quite reasonably might be accused of taking an inordinate amount of time to come to grips with his theme.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The beatification of a seventeenth-century Indian maiden and of a nineteenth-century American Roman Catholic Bishop will take a long step forward at a public consistory that Pope John XXIII will hold Jan. 19.
ANKARA, Turkey -- Several "ifs" becloud the forecast for Turkey's economy in 1961.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 9 -- In the annual reorganization of Westchester County's government today, Owen M. Quinn of Mount Pleasant was re-elected Chairman of the Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower arranged today for a second meeting with President-elect John F. Kennedy. It will take place Jan. 19, the day before the inauguration.
BONN Germany -- West German production has tripled since 1936.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- George Ivan Smith, an Australian, has been appointed director of the press, publications and public services division of the United Nations Office of Public Information, officials announced here today.
President-elect Kennedy is making one kind of news. His wife and family are quite involuntarily making news of another kind.

NAIROBI, Kenya -- Kenya's major development project for 1961 is a 14,000,000, ($39,200,000) scheme that would take thousands of Africans from their overcrowded reserves and resettle them in the highlands formerly occupied by whites.
Among the contributors to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday were many children, who have demonstrated their open-heartedness year after year during the annual appeal for the fund.

The American Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday that James C. Hagerty, press secretary to President Eisenhower, had been appointed vice president in charge of news, special events and public affairs. He begins his new job Jan. 23, three days after leaving the White House post.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Mississippi judge told a Northern audience today that in his state Negroes and white "work together, plan together and make progress together -- but under segregation."

BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy told applauding Massachusetts legislators today that he hoped his Administration would be judged finally on its qualities of courage, judgment, integrity and dedication.

WALTER FLORELL has joined the general rush toward cocky, forehead-perching hats for spring. Tiny berets, pillboxes and bandeaux shown in his collection yesterday were tipped forward, often set off with a bunch of violets.
KARACHI, Pakistan -- Good housekeeping and disciplined planning made 1960 a good economic year for Pakistan.
A contract to act as agent for renting 4,660 apartments in midtown Manhattan has been awarded to Herbert Charles Co. by Webb Knapp, Inc., builder of the four projects involved.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- Northern Ireland made economic progress in 1960, but heavy industry suffered setbacks toward the end of the year. As a result, questions have again been raised as to the area's ultimate ability to match Britain's full employment.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Northwest Airlines, the nation's sixth-largest air carrier, ordered all its domestic flights grounded today as a strike by flight engineers spread through the system.

THA THOM, Laos, Jan. 8 -- This typical Laotian mountain hamlet is emerging as a vital staging area in the Laotian Government's preparations for an offensive against the pro-Communist forces in the northeast.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 -- A Moscow audience gave a rousing ovation tonight to London's Old Vic players in their opening-night performance of Shakespeare's "Macbeth."

ATLANTA, Tuesday, Jan. 10 -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver acted early today to close the University of Georgia temporarily. The implementation of a Federal Court desegregation order, he said, left him no alternative but to cut off state funds to the 175-year-old institution under an anti-segregation law.
DUBLIN -- The most encouraging economic development in Ireland during 1960 was a sharp rise in exports, particularly in manufactured goods.
Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo said yesterday that he had canceled a dance scheduled for Friday night when he learned that persons outside the department had been asked to buy tickets.

Claudius C. Philippe, successor to the famed Oscar of the Waldorf, where he had been vice president in charge of sales and catering, and his latest employer, the Zeckendorf Hotels Corporation, have parted company.
VIENNA -- The governments of Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Rumania, and Bulgaria reported substantial economic successes last year and forecast more gains in 1961.

Irregularity among some of the favorite specialty stocks failed to check a virtually general advance of prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Aggregate market value rose almost two-thirds of 1 per cent.

HAVANA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The United States aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt sailed into Guantanamo Bay today, setting off new Cuban charges of imminent invasion. A high official said all Cuba was under the equivalent of martial law.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 9 -- A $70,000,000 airport system for Suffolk County was proposed today by County Executive H. Lee Dennison.

CHICAGO, Jan 9 -- A university professor, who is an authority on the subject of spending money, denied today that women are emotional spenders. However, he did admit that psychological factors motivate their purchases.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Leopoldville Government formally denounced the United Nations today, charging failure to support it against seizures of power by pro-Lumumba rebels.
LAKEHURST, N.J., Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Navy blimp with two men aboard tore loose from its mooring atop a fifty-four-foot mast today and was driven by the wind into a wooded area about fifty yards away.
GENEVA -- Economically speaking, the Swiss never had it so good.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 -- Federal District Judge William Augustus Bootle likes to keep things moving in his court. He is a native-born Southerner and a "life-long" Republican, a rare combination in Georgia.
PARIS -- Most of the questions that hung over the French economy at the beginning of 1960 have been resolved in France's favor during the last twelve months. Prosperity is busting out all over.
MOSCOW -- Soviet economists have made their annual assertions of dramatic strides toward industrial growth.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- New Zealand is on the verge of its greatest industrial expansion.

A program to replace the merchant fleet at the rate of twenty-five ships a year is the minimum requirement for the country's future needs, Ralph E. Wilson, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, declared last night.
WARSAW -- Poland is setting out on another year of tight belts for the consuming population and strenuous efforts by the authorities to push industrialization.

King and country lawyers seldom indulge in direct communication, but nearly two centuries ago a forthright member of the Virginia bar felt no hesitation about warning the King of England in ringing tones from the floor of Richmond's House of Burgesses.
The jet airliner in the Dec. 16 collision here was traveling more than 500 miles an hour when it swept past its assigned circling point, an official inquiry was told yesterday.

Mayor Wagner called on the public yesterday to help him stamp out gratuities for city employes. He announced that 500,000 copies of a printed appeal signed by him had been mailed to citizens, business men and taxpayers.
TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Nationalist China is facing the new year with optimism, working to strengthen this island base, just 100 miles off the mainland.
A 16-YEAR-OLD girl glided onto the ice at Wollman Memorial Ice Skating Rink in Central Park recently after telling some friends:
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9 -- Sant Fateh Singh ended today the fast that began Dec. 18 to support the demand of Sikh religious followers for a separate state.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- The United States, Britain and France have decided to maintain for the time being their restrictions on the travel of East Germans to the West.
Efforts to spur action on overdue debts due American exporters in shipments to the Congo were reported yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 9 (AP) -- A special Federal court refused today to restrain the State Corporation Commission from inspecting membership lists of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9 -- The Administration of President Jorge Alessandri Rodriguez said it had achieved a major advance in Chilean labor-management relations today with the averting of a strike of 6,500 workers against the Braden Copper Company.

SEOUL, Korea -- South Korea maintained relative economic stability in 1960 despite widespread fears that a major economic crisis might overrun the country. The fears were aroused by transitional social and economic dislocations in the wake of the April uprisings last year, that toppled President Syngman Rhee's twelve-year-old regime.
The Board of Education has established a new legislative committee that will take legislative maters away from the immediate jurisdiction of the law committee.

Rapid economic changes in many lands is becoming more than industrial and trade expansion or increased use of lipstick, washing machines and other gadgets. A touch of culture is being added with music -- a new field of trade beyond the exchange of juke boxes for bongo drums.
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Heavy winter rains are causing hope to sprout high for a prosperous 1961 in the Arab hinterland of the Eastern Mediterranean.

ELISABETH SOEDERSTROEM sang her first Musetta at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. In doing so the Swedish soprano added a fifth well-sung and effectively characterized role to her local repertory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Supreme Court decision "in the Dixon-Yates" case today, to which three of the nine justices dissented, will make it even more difficult for the Government to induce private citizens to assist it, even as temporary consultants, in matters for which they have special qualifications.

The McCulloch Corporation, Los Angeles maker of Scott outboard motors and McCulloch chain saws, announced yesterday the promotion of George P. Eichelsbach Jr. from division vice president and general manager to executive vice president.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- The economy of Israel rolled through 1960 still in high gear. The problem has become how to keep it from going off the road.
BERLIN -- Industrial expansion, full employment, mounting investments and rising exports marked 1960 in West Berlin -- an economic success unparalleled since the end of World War II.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Industrial production in the six countries of the European Common Market was still rising gently at the end of last year, the Common Market Com mission reported today. The commission's special indicator for the six countries -- France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- totaled and adjusted for seasonal and "accidental" factors, showed a slow but uninterrupted rise through October.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended Dec. 27, and remained unchanged through the week ended Jan. 3, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index for both Dec. 27 and Jan. 3 was 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base, compared with 119.5 for the week ended Dec. 20.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Bob Goalby of Crystal River, Fla., posted a key birdie on the twelfth hole today and won the $45,000 Los Angeles golf open with a 72-hole total of 275.

HELSINKI, Finland -- Close dependence on international trade became increasingly clear in Finland's economic development during 1960, and the question of participation in the European Free Trade Association dominated all others.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 6 -- The ninth Winter Olympic Games are scheduled here in three years. But it seems more like three months from the feverish manner in which the Austrians have been preparing. Ski-club volunteers and sixty army troopers have spent 40,000 man hours getting the big lay-out started.
The gymnasium of the West Side Y.M.C.A., generally a drab sweatshop for overweight men and underweight boys, became a ballet stage yesterday under the terpsichorean artistry of Soviet gymnasts.

The Navy ended its public hearings yesterday on the fire that swept the aircraft carrier Constellation and claimed the lives of fifty workmen. The closing came after a statement by the "interested parties" that the fire was an accident for which no personal responsibility could be fixed.

IT IS unusually early for dogs to be giving the deer a hard time in the snow, but it has started already in the farmlands of Putnam and Dutchess Counties. The problem is already serious enough for an official appeal to dog-owners.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 9 -- Troops of the Congolese National Army supporting Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier, have penetrated in strength into North Katanga.
ROME -- The outstanding characteristics of Italian foreign trade in 1960 were a healthy 26 per cent increase in exports and -- even more surprising -- a 45 per cent increase in imports.
ROME -- All Italian records in industrial production were broken in 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A foreign aid task force appointed by President-elect John F. Kennedy will propose that economic assistance to under-developed nations be doubled in the next four years.
BANGKOK, Thailand -- Communist China's "Great Leap Forward" drive for economic expansion limped seriously in 1960, the third year of the Great Leap effort by Peiping.

A greater average volume of loans and a rise in the level of interest rates combined to produce gross income of $175,216,133 in 1960 for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. This was 14.8 per cent greater than the 1959 total of $152,561,340, according to the bank's annual report made public today.
DENVER, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The University of Denver today dropped intercollegiate football. The school has had a football team since 1885.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower joined in singing "Happy Birthday" to Richard M. Nixon tonight as the Republican party honored the Vice President and gave him a fond farewell.
LONDON -- The year that began so auspiciously for Britain ended on a distinct note of uncertainty.
Soviet-bloc trade with the world set a record last year. It increased about a quarter over 1959 and reached a value of $7,000,000,000 in exports and imports combined.

A TOUR of the resort departments of several stores around town makes it clear that a woman does not have to travel far to have an international wardrobe. Regardless of price, this seems to be what the sun followers are buying.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Treasury short-term bill rates jumped again today, presumably influenced by the fact that the Government is also selling a $1,500,000,000 issue of one-year bills on Wednesday.
Mr. Kennedy flew to New York last night, dined at the Twenty One Club, and then went to see the musical, "Do-Re-Mi," where the audience gave him a five-minute ovation.
ROME -- An appreciable reduction of Italian unemployment, which began to manifest itself in 1959, continued in 1960.
A libel and breach of contract suit filed against the Columbia Broadcasting System in 1957 by Judy Garland was withdrawn yesterday. The network also withdrew a counter claim against Miss Garland.
BONN, Germany -- The super charged West German economy surged on in 1960 to record levels and at year's end gave no sign of slowing.
BONN, Germany -- Continuing a trend that has held for several years, West Germany's foreign trade expanded again in 1960.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- This year the Danes will be seeking to learn whether the establishment of the European Free Trade Association offers them increased export opportunities with fellow member countries.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo -- The economy of the former Belgian Congo was badly buffeted in the turbulent first half-year of independence, but its robust mechanism of production and distribution remained intact.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg should grow lustily in its first year, judging from the charts. The union started Nov. 1, 1960.
HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- A material witness in a Newark shooting was found shot to death this morning in the back seat of a stolen car.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Majority leader Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, offered the Senate a package of election changes today.
AFTER a hectic spell of holiday cooking, eating out is a delight and a relief to most homemakers. The main problem is that holidays also have the habit of depleting the bank balance.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 9 -- The shot that started the Civil War was duplicated today at an hour convenient to hundreds of natives and vistors and children let out of school for the occasion.

At least one of the four top talent hunts for top executives now under way should end today. The Prudential Insurance Company of America has called a press conference at Newark headquarters, for this afternoon when management is expected to announce the successor for Carrol M. Shanks, who resigned as president on Dec. 23.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Jan. 9 -- The World Zionist Congress expressed tonight its "deep anxiety" about the future of Jews in the Soviet Union and called upon the Soviet Government to permit those who would leave to migrate to Israel.

OF several nice things about the concert of the Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall, the nicest was the violin soloist. Like the orchestra, she was making her first appearance in America.
Steel production rebounded sharply last week from the low levels of the Christmas and New Year's holiday weeks, but the industry continued to operate at less than half of rated capacity.
TUNIS -- Last year was one of "economic decolonization" for Tunisia.
A campaign to raise $7,000,000 for the New York Zoological Society was announced last night.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 9 -- Archbishop Abel Isidoro Antezan y Roias, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Bolivia, excommunicated yesterday all members of Congress who had voted for the nation's new divorce law.
WHEN Lynwood Rowe was 15 years old, he pitched against a team of former major leaguers and beat them. They were embarrassed and dismayed.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Football League made its "final offer" to professional soccer players today in an effort to avert the strike the players have called for Jan. 21. The league is now ready to annul its rule on maximum pay.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- The United States was reliably reported today to have given up trying to get a long-range commitment from West Germany for vastly increased purchases of United States arms as a step toward solving the American balance-of-payments problem.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
"Reckless and ruthless competition" in international air freight was held largely to blame last night for the industry's failure to realize its potential earning power.
PARIS -- A year ago at this time Western Europe was wondering if it could possibly have a business year in 1960 as good as 1959. On the whole, it did.

"The Facts of Life," with Bob Hope and Lucille Ball, will be the next attraction at the Astor Theatre, following the current run of "The Grass Is Greener." The United Artists release, a comedy of marital infidelity, was directed by Melvin Frank and produced by Norman Panama, with Ruth Hussey, Don De Fore and Louis Nye in other roles.

BERLIN -- East Germany reported an 8.4 per cent increase in gross industrial production for the first nine months of 1960, compared with the same period in 1959. Productivity rose by 7.8 per cent, according to an official Government statement.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 9 -- Turkish Finance Minister Kemal Kurdas and Vance Brand, managing director of the United States Development Loan Fund, signed an agreement here today providing a credit of $129,600,000 to the newly established Eregli Steel Company of Turkey.

New York's claim of possessing the richest vein of basketball talent in the country is being strengthened this year. More than 3,000 players, representing 95 per cent of the city's junior high schools, are competing in Public Schools Athletic League tournaments for the first time.
A number of recommendations for reorganizing, expanding and improving this country's cultural exchange programs were made yesterday to President-elect John F. Kennedy.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Martin Company today approved a two-for-one stock split voted by the board of directors last November.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Estimates for the year ended in June, 1960, indicated that South Africa's economy had returned to the tempo of development experienced before the 1957-59 recession and that a per capita increase of 3.1 per cent in real income had occurred.

Boat Show Week began yesterday with a presentation to Representative Herbert C. Bonner of North Carolina. Representative Bonner, the author of the Federal Boating Act of 1958, received the Ole Evinrude Award.

The city's Department of Commerce and Public Events said yesterday that two Japanese high school students were expected here about the middle of March for a three-week visit under an exchange program.
Members of the younger generation who form the junior board of directors of the George Junior Republic have started a series of meetings to plan for the fifth annual Junior Republic Ball.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -Senate investigators sought today to show that James R. Hoffa, Teamsters union president had encouraged continued corruption by New York City Teamster officials.
The Board of Education will begin a three-year study next month of its program for raising the educational goals and performance of underprivileged children.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had purchased a new communications system that would provide automatic bid and asked prices and up-to-the-minute volume figures through printed and voice networks.

A feature of the economy in several Central-American countries has been the recent growth of small businesses. The result is an emerging middle class, made up of artisans, craftsmen, small business men, farmers and professional people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The "atomic calanedar" used for dating ancient objects has been made more accurate through a redetermination by the National Bureau of Standards of the decay rate of radioactive carbon 14.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The state's top education official, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., today rejected an offer to be United States Education Commissioner.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- Chile's plans to check inflation and stabilize the economy, instituted by President Jorge Alessandri, were severely shaken early last year, but they are firm as a rock today.

MONTREAL -- The Canadian National Railways, whose problems of adequate revenue have been a source of parliamentary and public discussions for years, is quietly operating in a field of commercial and industrial development that augurs well for the future.

The Broadway Theatre Alliance, which employs buses and trucks to bring stage attractions to eighty-two cities, will be absorbed next season by United Performing Arts, Inc. The announcement was made yesterday by Harlowe F. Dean, president of the United group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Guatemalan authorities stressed today the defensive nature of army and air force training in their country. They also announced plans to start naval training with the help of the United States.

For the first time in its thirty-five-year history, Madison Square Garden will present boxing on closed-circuit television when it carries the third heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson on Monday night, March 13.
Dr. Thomas D0oley, the jungle physician, was reported here yesterday to have a recurrence of the primary cancer discovered in his chest wall in August, 1959.

SUBSCRIBERS to the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert last night at Carnegie Hall heard the program they were originally scheduled to get on March 7. It came about because of a switch between William Steinberg and Leopold Stokowski.

Abraham D. Beame, city budget director, proposed yesterday that the Federal Government undertake a broad program of English language instruction in Puerto Rico. He indicated that Mayor Wagner favored the idea.

Should the redistribution of seats in the House of Representatives under the new census figures allow New Hampshire to retain two seats and dock Massachusetts by two, or should each state lose only one?

Many Latin-American nations are disappointed with the type of government that has developed in Cuba and dislike the strained relations between Cuba and the United States. However, many of the countries have reaped a windfall.
THE average New York apartment dweller has two problems when decorating and Barbara D'Arcy has a dozen solutions that may prove helpful.
New that Nigeria had withdrawn as a seller from the world cocoa market drove cocoa futures up to the 1-cent-a-pound a day limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A "compelling engagement" here will keep one of the prime sponsors of the Throgs Neck road-bridge project from attending the opening tomorrow.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 10 -- The Government asserted today that a substantial but undetermined number of Soviet and North Vietnamese troops had invaded Laos.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Industrial shares, led by the blue chips, responded to increased but selective demand on the stock market here today.

MIAMI, Jan. 10 -- A proposal to put Cuban refugees into a camp here was received with dismay today by refugees and by the officials of the Cuban Emergency Refugee Center directed by President Eisenhower's personal representative, Tracy S. Voorhees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A Cuban physician who helped organize the Fair Play for Cuba Committee told Senate investigators today that most of the money for an advertisement favorable to the Fidel Castro regime came from the son of Cuba's Foreign Minister.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 10 -- Israel's envoys were instructed today to convey expressions of "disappointment and profound surprise" to the leaders of Ghana, Mali and Guinea over a resolution referring to Israel as "an instrument of imperialism and neo-colonialism."

DENVER, Jan. 10 -- The nation's colleges, in trying to do too much, are weakening their programs and often neglecting their basic purposes. Dr. Earl J. McGrath, former United States Commissioner of Education, declared here today.
The Throgs Neck Bridge, connecting the Bronx and Queens, will be opened to traffic today.

The mysterious disappearance of the diamond necklace that Marie Antoinette was purported to have bought is presented in three forthcoming books. The first account is given in "The Queen's Necklace," by Frances Mossiker, which Simon Shuster will issue Jan. 23.
TORONTO -- Despite the ravages of the predatory lamprey on lake trout and whitefish commercial fishing in Ontario has remained remarkable healthy.

Roger Maris, the most valuable player in the American League, is seeking more money. The New York Yankee outfielder plans to go to bat sometime between Jan. 21 and Jan. 26 for an undisclosed salary increase.

FLYROD anglers, who are invariably confused and bemused anyway, will have to learn a new system for buying lines to fit their rods along toward the end of this year. It is simpler, and makes more sense than the old letter-system denoting diameters, but it is another exasperating piece of systematism, just the same.
Many centuries of the arts of Thailand will go on view today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

One of New York's finest improvements in years opens to public use today, the Throgs Neck Bridge over the East River between Queens and the Bronx, built by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. An essential part of the advancing metropolitan arterial system, it makes a new route between Long Island and New England, and serves as a convenient by-pass to and from other areas.

There was a time when the Studebaker Bros. Manufacturing Company of South Bend, Ind., was the largest farm wagon and carriage manufacturer in the country. It was at that time -- back in 1905 -- that the company, trying to reach the country's farmers, inserted an advertisement in Farm and Garden.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Lower margins for buying stocks and an overhaul of the present system of regulating credit in the security markets were proposed tonight by Keith M. Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange.
MEXICO CITY -- This country witnessed a slackened economic momentum in 1960 compared with the startling activity in the three previous years.
A religious leader of Reform Judaism last night criticized the efforts of Christian missionaries to convert members of the Jewish faith. He said the movement was doomed to failure.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Residents of the Triple Cities -- Binghamton, Endicott and Johnson City -- have gone on a stock-buying spree, but for principle, not profit.
BUENOS AIRES -- Argentina came within reach of a major expansion of national production in 1960, as President Arturo Frondizi's recovery program completed its second year.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Bolivia's sound-money program came through an agitated Presidential election without damage last year. Then the new administration took steps to attack the country's main problem -- tin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Senator Alexander Wiley has opened a campaign for $145,000 to conduct a full-scale study of water levels in the Great Lakes to take best advantage of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
KINGSTON, Jamaica -- This island's economy was marked by continued rapid growth last year. Foreign private investment in the island was close to $300,000,000.

TODAY in Africa the only certainty is change. After the long parade of centuries in which such changes as did occur made little difference to the pattern of living south of the Sahara, the present headlong rush into a doubtful future is no cause for rejoicing. Will it bring back the past instead of a new day, the past of tribal warfare, of hundreds of petty but absolute despots, of hunger and pestilence?

Sympathy tie-ups by truck drivers and railroad freight handlers yesterday deepened the impact of the day-old strike on New York's railroad ferryboats and other harbor craft. The new moves threatened to paralyze most of the city's freight operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- The United Nations Sub-commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities opened its thirteenth session today by voting to give priority to a study of the "right of everyone to leave any country."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- Technical assistance, much of it from the United Nations and its specialized agencies, has helped to awaken Mexico from an economic siesta that lasted for generations.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 10 -- A series of proposals designed to rid the Protestant Episcopal Church of all vestiges of racial discrimination was presented today to delegates attending the first annual meeting here of the Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER was honored last night by the National Broadcasting Company in an hour-long taped program entitled "Tributes to a Patriot." All in all, the title was perhaps inadequate to the occasion; the theme was closer to adulation, at times ecstatic to a point inviting a trace of embarrassment.
HAVANA, Jan. 10 -- Three Americans have been sentenced to ten years' imprisonment for "activities against the security of the Cuban state."

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- The Soviet Union's Communist party leaders have set Oct. 17 as the opening date for the party's twenty-second congress, which will take up a new program that has been in committee since 1952.
OTTAWA -- As one of several measures to combat growing unemployment, the Canadian Government will prime the pump of housing this year.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed Assemblyman William F. Hyland, Democrat of Camden, today as a member of the Public Utility Commission, and the Senate quickly confirmed the appointment.
Venezuela, formerly second only to the United States as the world's largest oil-producing nation, apparently lost that ranking last year to the Soviet Union.

Allie Sherman, an energetic, resourceful young man whose body and soul have been wrapped up in football for twenty-five of his thirty-eight years, was named head coach of the New York Football Giants yesterday.

Events today: "Alcestis," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Bach Aria Group, Frank Brieff, conductor, Roberta Peters, soprano, Columbus Boys Choir, Town Hall, 8:30; "Lakme," presented by the Opera Department, Manhattan School of Music, 238 East 105th Street, 8; Robert Rudie, violinist, Judson Hall, 8:30.
Howard K. Smith's future on the Columbia Broadcasting System's 7:15 P.M. television news show appeared to be in doubt yesterday.

MONTREAL -- The Province of Quebec's recent agreement with the federal government on participation in the Trans-Canada Highway system reflects increasing dependence on the national communications network to bolster the industrialization of Quebec.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today nominations of three present members of Federal regulatory agencies for new terms.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- Although the number of jobless in Newfoundland in 1960 was generally higher than the Canadian average, a large proportion of the population was steadily employed at a higher level of wages and salaries than ever before.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Soviet Government presented to the United States today a statement of its views on the situation in Laos.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Banana production in Costa Rica, which has shown an up-and-down graph -- usually more down than up -- since the peak year of 1952 with 10,500,000 stems, was up slightly in 1960.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. (AP) -- Thomas R. O'Connor, president of the Woolnor Corporation and the Vieques Island Corporation, has announced the sale of his stock in both concerns to Norman B. Woolworth. The transaction will assure the development of the two large tourist projects in Vieques Island and in San Juan.
TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Following are excerpts from Gov. Robert B. Meyner's annual message, delivered today be[ore the New Jersey Legislature:
Sir John Cockcroft, British physicist and Nobel Prize winner, was named yesterday to receive the 1961 Atoms for Peace Award.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Winthrop Hiram Smith, chairman of the board of directors of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, died early today in his home here after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
The Bankers Trust Company and the County Trust Company, White Plains, N.Y., gave the details yesterday of the merger proposal they announced last September.
REGINA, Sask. -- Saskatchewan's economy in 1960 lacked the forward momentum of recent years but considering everything it held up exceedingly well.
By acting swiftly on a complicated tariff case, the Federal Maritime Board has awakened "joy and hope" among admiralty lawyers, who have been accustomed to long delays in such cases.
MONTREAL -- The Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges have ended a year of activity that has been called one of the most noteworthy in their history.
LIMA, Peru -- After a rapidly improving economic situation during 1960, Peru is looking forward to a period of unprecedented growth.
Two Mississippians stood in front of a New York University classroom yesterday and defended segregation.

BACK in 1936, when the "Ice Follies," with a cast of twenty-eight, made its debut in Tulsa, Okla., the audience was somewhat thin. After counting the customers, one of the producers, Oscar Johnson, went backstage and turned to the cast.
Swiss bankers haven't wavered in their support of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's efforts to obtain control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Measures with far-reaching implications for the state judicial system will be recommended to the Legislature by the State Judicial Conference.
Railroad piggy-back traffic -- the moving of loaded highway containers and trailers on flat cars -- has come full turn.
The owner of the Detroit Pistons basketball team testified yesterday in Federal Court that he became "supicious" of Jack Molinas during a game at Madison Square Garden in 1953.
