WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A five-man board was named today to consider proposals from private companies wishing to participate in the Government's helium conservation program.

ARMONK, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- A 15-year-old boy who did not want to go back to school chained a Westchester couple with handcuffs and leg irons last night and held them in terror for five hours with a loaded revolver and tear gas gun.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Directors of the Procter Gamble Company decided today to ask shareholders to vote on a two-for-one split in the common stock. The direc tors also declared the regular quarterly dividend of 65 cents a share on the present stock. It will be payable on Feb. 15 to shareholders of record on Jan. 27.

GUATEMALA CITY -- Business and financial circles in this country, after the first successful year of the economic stabilization program, looked to 1961 for relaxation of the drastic measures that have shored up the national currency but have stifled economic activity.
TORONTO -- Grapes have become the top fruit crop in Ontario. The biggest factor in their boom is the increasing popularity of Canadian wine.
BALBOA, C.Z. -- Long-range projects to widen and deepen the channel of the Panama Canal to expand its capacity to serve world shipping is at a record pace.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Otto Mayer, the chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today that Armin Hary, the German Olympic sprint champion suspended on charges of padding his expense account, would be barred from future games and might be forced to give up the gold medals he won at Rome.
OTTAWA -- The penomenal growth and expansion of the Canadian economy since the war appears to have slowed, at least temporarily. Shadows loomed as the new year dawned.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 10 -- Two Negroes enrolled in the University of Georgia today after Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver Jr. had been enjoined from cutting off funds and forcing the school to close.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Jan. 10 -- Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga has threatened military action against the armed invaders of the northern part of his province unless United Nation troops evict them.

SAN SALVADOR -- The new military-civilian junta controlling El Salvador plans to carry forward this year the public works projects started by the ousted administration of President Jose Maria Lemus. Several of the projects are concerned with the national electrification program.
TOKYO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Japanese shipping is still haunted by floating mines planted during World War II.
Louis R. Menagh Jr., pronounced (Me-nah), is the type of insurance man the public rarely sees and seldom hears about -- an actuary.
The Canadian interest rate structure turned upward in 1960. This reflected the volume of Government borrowing, provincial and municipal, that came into the market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Six of seven work groups in the National Conference on Aging voted today for medical care under the Social Security system. The seventh was opposed.
Uncommon lending terms for a sovereign nation have been demanded of Greece by the European Investment Bank. The bank is a new financial institution set up by Europe's six Common Market countries.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The proposed revision of New York City's Charter is precipitating a sharp split between Mayor Wagner and Democratic party leaders in New York City, it appeared today.
TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner offered a plan today for more than doubling New Jersey's public park and recreation sites in the next decade.
FREEPORT, Grand Bahama Island -- The Bahamas Government has created a tax-free haven on this 100-mile-long island.
A total of 648 persons were hurt in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was down 107 from the 1960 period.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 10 -- A senior army officer, who has been involved in a six-year debate with a former Defense Minister over which of them had ordered a disastrous security mission, was discharged from the Israeli armed forces today.
YELLOWKNIFE, N.W.T. -- The first highway connection between Yellowknife and Edmonton, Alberta was opened last October.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Britain's exports to Communist China were reported to have increased about 50 per cent during the first eleven months of 1960 compared with the same 1959 period. Imports from Communist China also were up, but not so much.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 10 -- Consumer intentions to buy new automobiles are as high now as at any time since late 1956, the University of Michigan Survey Research Cen ter reported today. In its latest report on consumer attitudes and inclinations to buy, the research center gave an unusually optimistic view of the prospects for automobile sales in 1961, in contrast to the more dubious predictions of some economists.
CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- Cairo relaxed today after clearing up the mystery of a Coca-Cola bottle bearing "Hebrew characters and a Star of Israel."
MEXICO CITY -- Central America found little cause for joy about its economy last year.
Textbooks used in American secondary schools present a distorted view of minority groups, according to a study made public yesterday by the Anti-Defamation League.
RANGOON, Burma, Wednesday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Burmese Army North Command has begun a series of offensives against the remnants of Nationalist Chinese forces near the Thai and Laotian borders.
The city administration bill designed to end cheating in fuel oil deliveries came under heavy attack by spokesmen for the industry yesterday at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Government said today that the operations of the Port of New York Authority affected Federal interests and therefore Congress had the right to investigate the agency.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- Ecuador, for the last several years the "top banana" in international trade in that fruit, has moved toward exploitation of her marine resources.

LIMA, Peru -- Construction of a plant for the production of wallboard from sugar cane bagasse -- bagasse is what is left over after the sugar has been extracted from the cane -- is now under way by Primadera Nepena Peruana at the San Jacinto sugar estate in northern Peru.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Eisenhower was honored by two national organizations today for helping to build a better world in his own time and for promoting better understanding and brotherhood among its peoples.
VANCOUVER, B.C. -- The worst feature of the forest production industry that pays many grocery bills in British Columbia was the crisis that overtook plywood manufacturers in 1960.

ATLANTA, Jan. 10 -- If Gov. Samuel Ernest Vandiver Jr. found himself on the horns of a dilemma in the racial integration controversy at the University of Georgia, it could be said that he got there largely by his own efforts.

A boat show will open today -- the fifty-first National Motor Boat Show in the New York Coliseum. But for the panting general public, suffering from cold weather and eager for spring and summer, the show will be a teaser. The public won't be admitted.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The 1960 state income tax was cut 10 per cent today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy spent this afternoon discussing problems of the balance of international payments, the Federal budget and space exploration.
TORONTO -- Expansion of this city's natural, Island-rimmed harbor has gone about as far as it can go. Plans are being laid for a wholly manmade port that will jut a mile into Lake Ontario.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Andrew Crevolin's Mighty Fair, under a strong ride by Johnny Longden, raced to a neck victory today at Santa Anita in the $17,950 La Centinela Stakes for 3-year-old fillies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Senate's Democratic majority assigned its members to standing committees today, apparently adding slightly to the strength of its conservative faction.
TORONTO -- Canada's once-booming uranium industry is shriveling, and hopes for its return to health are dim.

Intensified development of new foreign markets for agricultural produce was called essential yesterday to the general export expansion needed to correct the United States' large international payments deficit.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- A new financial device will be put into operation in Western Europe later this month. Citizens in five countries will be offered $10,000,000 worth of bonds of a large Portuguese company, denominated in a new international "unit of account" instead of in any national currency.
WASHINGTON -- The Inter-American Development Bank, for more than fifty years the dream of many Latin Americans, has become a reality.
Ohio State, the National Collegiate basketball champion, made it four consecutive weeks as the undisputed No. 1 team in the Associated Press poll yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Professional soccer players rejected as "completely unacceptable" today the wage and contract concessions offered by clubs in the Football League. The players still plan to strike a week from Saturday.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil begins 1961 with this question: "What will Janio Quadros do about the economy?"
Net income of the Illinois Central Railroad plummeted 28 per cent last year to an estimated $10,873,377, while gross revenues of $259,878,638 were only about 4.3 per cent below those of 1959.

HAVANA -- The Cuban Government enters the new year looking only to the Soviet Government and its bloc for aid to remedy a critical economic situation. The United States, always the island's best customer and greatest supplier, broke off diplomatic relations with Cuba last week after more than a year of steadily worsening political and economic relations.

President-elect Kennedy set high standards for himself and his associates in the eloquent speech he made to the Massachusetts Legislature in Boston. It was sound in its history and its ideals. It was given in a place hallowed by the memories of much that was great in our annals, and at a time whose significance was awesome -- the eve of assuming the Presidency of the United States.
MASERU, Basutoland, Jan. 9 -- African opposition to Government policies in South Africa's Transkelan Territories is reported here to have reached an "explosive point."
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Uruguay joined the "stabilization club" of Latin-American countries fighting inflation last year.

Joseph J. Lordi was elected unanimously to his third successive one-year term as president of the New York Athletic Club last night. He is a former Notre Dame baseball captain and was the national squash racquets champion in 1937.

PANAMA -- President Roberto F. Chiari, who campaigned on an austerity platform, took office Oct. 1 facing an inherited funded public debt of about $89,000,000, together with a combined floating debt and other obligations of $19,400,000.
The plan to build bowling alleys in Grand Central Terminal rolled into a municipal veto yesterday.
ASUNCION, Paraguay -- Paraguay's economic and financial situation fell to pieces during 1960, forcing President Alfredo Stroessner's military-backed regime to weigh some radical cures.

THE twenty songs that constitute Schubert's "Die schoene Muellerin" make a relatively brief, but extraordinarily rewarding program. It was good to hear this cycle performed alone last night in Carnegie Recital Hall by Walter Carringer, tenor, and David Labovitz, pianist.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 10 -- The appointment of Dr. Myron Tribus, Professor of Engineering at the University of California at Los Angeles, as dean of Dartmouth Colleges Thayer School of Engineering was announced today. He will take the post in the fall.
TORONTO -- Last year was a difficult one for the Toronto Stock Exchange. It was marked by low volume, low employment and low spirits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Senators reported today that Robert S. McNamara, 44-year-old millionaire designated as the new Secretary of Defense, proposed to put more than $1,500,000 into a trust outside his control while he held office.

YELLOWKNIFE, N.W.T. -- The closing of the Eldorado Mining and Refining operation at Port Radium on Great Bear Lake last summer brought a sharp cutback in the freight hauled by Northern Transportation Company, a subsidiary of the Government-owned uranium mining company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration received today a high bid of $446,255 for Springwood Village, a garden-type apartment development at Hyde Park, N.Y.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association clamped down today on three more member colleges for violating the rules on recruiting and financial aid to athletes.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The Government steered an uneasy course last year through the choppy waters of recurrent financial shortages.
MONTREAL -- A major civic development project may change the face of this colorful city into a combination of nineteenth-century graciousness and twentieth-century efficiency.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Based on Export-Import Bank credits amounting to $30,000,000, Chilean railroads are in the first stage of a vast modernization program. The purchase of 113 Diesel locomotives has meant an expenditure of $18,000,000.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 10 -- Hope for an end to the twenty-three-day-old strike spread today after a Socialist party statement denouncing violence and an exchange of conciliatory speeches in the House of Representatives.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil's motion picture producers and artists are protesting a bill that requires the dubbing of foreign films into the Portuguese language.
January's dearth of new films, an annual aftermath of the year-end holiday openings, is being filled this year by an avalanche of revivals.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Rod Laver, an Australian Davis Cup player, was involved in a racquet-tossing incident today during the quarter-finals of the South Australian tennis championships.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 -- The Liberal party convention unanimously agreed tonight to press for a series of measures designed to make the Canadian economy more independent, particularly from United States interests, and to lead it out of its present slump.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Africa's future has hitherto been obscured by simplified and misleading slogans. "Integration" was the battle cry of conservatives for Algeria at the continent's northern edge. "Segregation" -- in this case Apartheid, meaning the same thing -- is that of conservatives in the Union of South Africa at the continent's southern tip.

A warning that "a very grave threat" was contained for retail stores in the proposed imposition of Federal wage and hour standards, aside from a minimum hourly wage rate, was sounded yesterday by Edward L. Field, director of personnel of Allied Stores Corporation.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Cliff Hagan went on a 33-point scoring spree and led the St. Louis Hawks to a 119-110 victory over the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game tonight. The Boston Celtics defeated the Detroit Pistons, 118 -- 98, in the first contest.

MEXICO CITY -- The average "capitalino" -- the person who lives in Mexico City -- looks upon the citizen of Monterrey as a crude materialist, a seeker of wealth and a disdainer of the finer things in life.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Cautioning against the danger of renewed inflation, Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, urged Britons today to show restraint over wages, prices and profits.
For Trinidad, the sun-washed capital of the British West Indies, 1960 brought economic progress almost unmatched in the Caribbean island's history.

WHEN New York's commercial galleries double as small museums they can do first-rate jobs on a miniature scale. Two exhibitions of this kind that have just opened at the Perls Galleries, 1016 Madison Avenue, and the Sidney Janis Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, back each other up very nicely, by coincidence, and are worth a couple of hours of anyone's time.
A reader Who has followed the progress of the Neediest Cases Fund wrote, "I've begun to feel that everybody who is anybody gives to the Neediest."
The state Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that corruption exists "at virtually every stage" of operations in the plan-examining division of the city Buildings Department.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 10 -- The ten New York City offices acquired from the Colonial Trust Company and the Queens National Bank showed a profit in their first month of operation as units of the Meadow Brook National Bank, Augustus B. Weller, chairman, told the annual meeting today.
A campaign to attract more tourists to this country was announced yesterday by foreign and domestic travel officials.
HAVANA -- The regime of Premier Fidel Castro has vertually destroyed Cuba's mining industry in its two years of power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The nation's Class I railroads had a net income estimated at $34,000,000 in November, 1960. This was $7,000,000 less than that of November, 1959, and $29,000,000 below the level of November, 1958.

Robert Holbert of Warrington, Pa., and Gaston Andrey of Framingham, Mass., the winners of The New York Times awards as the outstanding sports car drivers of 1960, received their plaques yesterday. The occasion was the Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society luncheon at Sardi's on West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A "restoration of science to the community" could result in "more knowledge, used more wisely, to enrich the lives" of human beings, Dr. Detlev W. Bronk said today.

"WE have made wedding dresses for Saks-34th for twenty-six years and this year is the first time you won't see one ruffle." George Maurer thus introduced his spring and summer collection of Maurer Originals at the store yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

EARLY in the season, the New York City Opera gave us Monteverdi's "Orfeo" of 1607. Last night in Town Hall the American Opera Society presented the "Coronation of Poppea," which Monteverdi composed in 1642 at the age of 76.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazilian efforts to dispose of her enormous coffee surplus depend on President-elect Janio Quadros.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua -- This Central-American nation has been in a recession for the last three years. Major export crops of coffee, cotton and sugar were hit last year by unfavorable weather conditions and a decline in world market prices. But crop diversification was stressed in 1960 and an improvement is expected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Senate leadership moved today to defer action on filibuster curbs until later in the session.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The words "Catholic" and "Protestant," as commonly used now, are "completely out of date," Dr. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, the Archbishop of Canterbury, said today.
OTTAWA -- All portents indicate that unemployment will continue to be one of Canada's major economic ills this year.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -- In 1960 Honduras failed to shake loose from the economic doldrums that have prevailed for several years.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Prime Minister Macmillan is being kept informed of the widening investigation of a Communist espionage network uncovered here.

A record of $2,586,000,000 in individual life insurance was sold last year by the 116-year-old New York Life Insurance Company, Clarence J. Myers, chairman and president, reported yesterday. New highs also were established for premium income received, benefits paid out, and life insurance in force.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 10 -- President Francois Duvalier ordered Bishop Remy Augustin exiled to Buenos Aires today. The action marked the second time within five weeks that Dr. Duvalier had moved against ranking members of the Roman Catholic Church in Haiti.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- Louis R. Menagh Jr., an executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America since 1957, was elected president of the company today.
SOMEONE new has been added to Saks Fifth Avenue's talented family of designers. That someone is Madame Tilly, the Viennese director of the store's newly enlarged custom corset and bra salon.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A high-climbing rally pulled most soybean futures out of a generally broad setback today but the grains yielded to persistent profit-taking and closed with losses all around.

Recent Congressional reports on Africa and your Dec. 30 editorial on colonialism once more display that admirable quality of not seeing the beam in one's own eye while chiding everyone else for their motes.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's oldest retailing organization, has embarked on a "Canadianizing" project. This means, in effect, that the ant organization intends to expand its operations outward from western Canada and the Canadian North to throughout the Dominion.
IT is unfortunate that "The Times [of London] Cookery Book" is beyond most American homemakers, for it is inexpensive and has a fine collection of recipes from all parts of the world.
The market for United States Government securities was beset yesterday with bearish influences that a large afternoon rally failed to offset.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Everybody is now talking about the problems of the new Administration, but the Republican party also has a problem which concerns the political balance of the nation.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Evon Anyon rode four winners at Tropical Park today, including both ends of a $549.60 daily double.
AMONG the many words of advice offered over the years by the ageless Satchel Paige, pitcher and philosopher, was this gem:
EDMONTON, Alberta -- The chemical industry came to the Edmonton area during the last decade in the wake of the vast oil development that began with the Leduc discovery in 1947.

Sales and earnings of the Magnavox Company set records in the fourth quarter of 1960, lifting results for the full year to the highest levels in the company's fifty-year history, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by Frank Freimann, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- The Nigerian Embassy said today that a Nigerian diplomat had been handed his breakfast in a bag and told to "get out" of a Virginia restaurant. It protested to the State Department.
HALIFAX, N.S. -- The brightest spot in the economies of the maritime provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island is tourism.
Los Angeles, Calif., borrowed $30,000,000 yesterday in the public market to finance construction of schools.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- A disappointing coffee crop hurt this country's economy last year. Coffee, the largest export, is Haiti's chief earner of foreign exchange. The outlook for 1961 is not very encouraging at this time.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 10 -- The University of Bridgeport was involved today in a controversy with the Connecticut Anti-Communist Committee over an editorial in the student newspaper.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 10 -- Of the eleven national daily newspapers printed in Istanbul, nine have decided to close, effective tonight, for a three-day protest against the press and advertising laws adopted Saturday by the ruling National Unity Committee.
AUTHORITIES advise passing partner's opening bid on a nearly worthless hand, as West did in today's deal.

OTTAWA -- The second season of the St. Lawrence Seaway did not meet expectations. There was a variety of reasons for a drop in cargo tonnage in 1960, but officials are looking for an improvement this year.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Jan. 10 -- Management forces beat down an attempt by an insurgent stockholders group to maintain representation on the board of the Valley National Bank of Long Island here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will cut short his visit to Africa to attend a new meeting of the Security Council on the Congo. The meeting was called for Thursday at the request of the Soviet Union.

Armour Co. increased its earnings in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 29 to $16,221,137 from the $14,068,731 cleared for the preceding year. Sales of the big meat packer, however, fell by 7 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Man. -- Northern Manitoba held the spotlight in the province in 1960. It promises to be in a similar position in 1961.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- On his most recent trip to South America, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold relates, he invited the executive secretary of the Economic Commission for Latin America, Dr. Raul Prebisch, to travel with him.
SAN SALVADOR -- The economic outlook for El Salvador appears to be tied in closely with the nation's political future.
President-elect John F. Kennedy was reported last night to be giving Mayor Wagner strong support in his efforts to obtain new leadership for the Democratic party in New York.
HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Bermuda enhanced her claim last year to being the wealthiest twenty-two square miles on the globe.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- A the end of 1960 Venezuela find herself in a paradoxical situation -- a potentially rich country in the midst of a depression.
BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 10 -- Panama's Ministry of Government and Justice put restrictions today on the propaganda activities of all political refugees regardless of nationality.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Four community projects will benefit from proceeds of a theatre party to "Camelot" in New York on Monday. The Westchester Shore Section of the National Council of Jewish Women is sponsoring the fete.

THE prize-winning work for string orchestra by 10-year-old Jean Harris of Scarsdale will be performed this week-end by the Youth Instrumental Ensemble at the New York College of Music, 114 East Eighty-fifth Street. Performances are Saturday at 3:30 and 4:30 P.M.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) off to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday.
EDMONTON, Alberta -- Trucking might beat the railways to the base metals awaiting development at Pine Point on the south shore of Great Slave Lake in Canada's Northwest Territories.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- Aluminum producers have gone to great lengths to find new uses for their product. Some new uses are for oil pipe lines, and a new type of tank hopper car for railroads. Through these Canada expects to increase domestic consumption of aluminum by 10 per cent in 1961.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Shareholders of Marquette Cement Manufacturing Company approved plans today to acquire North American Cement Corporation, New York, for an exchange of stock.

The Trevyllian, a six-story apartment building at 136 to 142 East Seventeenth Street in the Gramercy Park area, has been sold by Sam Grosfeld, realty operator. The buyer, an investing client of Fred Chambers, lawyer, acquired the property in a deal negotiated by Joseph R. Ruffino of the Ruffino Realty Company of Kew Gardens, Queens brokers.

Many more stocks rose than fell in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but the net gain was moderate. Two-thirds of it came between the Monday close and the Tuesday opening. Almost all the advance registered from then until the peak at 2 P.M. was wiped out in the final ninety minutes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Northwest Orient Airlines was expected today to cut down to a skeleton staff of employes by tomorrow as a result of a strike of flight engineers that has grounded all domestic flights. The line employs 6,900 persons, most of whom were being laid off today.
THE title of the play that arrived last night at the East End Theatre, "The Sudden End of Anne Cinquefoil," is likely to be an accurate prediction.

OLEAN, N.Y., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- St. Bonaventure tuned up for Saturday's traditional game with Niagara by defeating Gannon tonight, 103 -- 71. The victory was the Bonnies' twelfth against one loss this season and their ninety-seventh in a row at home.

Awards for "enlightened handling of trans-Atlantic news" were presented last night to John B. Oakes, of The New York Times editorial board, and Nicholas Chatelain, United States correspondent for the Paris newspaper Figaro.
ALGIERS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Peace negotiations between France and the Algerian Provisional Government are expected soon, high French officials said today.

With a concern that is characteristic of The New York Times, a recent editorial (Dec. 30) draws attention to the famine conditions in the Congo. The Secretary General of the United Nations is quoted as reporting that "between 250,000 and 300,000 people are actually starving in South Kasai, with an estimated 200 people dying daily from sheer starvation."
The United States-Japan Trade Council opened a counter-Offensive yesterday against a threatened boycott of Japanese fabrics by unionized clothing workers in this country.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Latin America found it increasingly difficult in 1960 to make the expansion rate of her economy keep up with the quickening growth of her population.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The economy of Colombia in 1960 was characterized by continuing stability and a reasonable rhythm of growth despite political difficulties that plagued the bipartisan administration of President Alberto Lleras Camargo.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 10 -- A goal by Steve Ripley in the final minute of play overcame a Brown rally and led Yale to a 3-2 victory in an Ivy League hockey game tonight.

ST. CATHERINES, Ont. -- The Canadian Division of Yale Towne Manufacturing Company this spring will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary here. The facility produces a broad line of Yale lock and hardware products.

A one-story taxpayer occupying a plot 100 by 200 feet at 70 to 82 East 167th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Morris Rokowksy. It is near the Grand Concourse. The building contains six stores, including a Barton's candy shop and a supermarket.

The New York Legislature has responded with alacrity to Governor Rockefeller's call for a 10 per cent rebate on 1960 personal income taxes. Only a handful of Democrats expressed misgivings by nay votes. Thus the Governor kept the conditional promise he made in mid-June, 1960, a season dedicated to politics rather than hard thinking about future state fiscal needs.
The Bell System cleared more in the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1960, than any other company has ever earned in any twelve-month period.
United Air Lines' vice president for flying testified yesterday that he had understood that jet airliners were followed on radar scopes from take-off to landing.
HARTFORD, Jan. 10 (AP) -The state has ordered a Hamden real estate developer to sell a house to a Negro Who was rebuffed in previous attempts to buy.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao -- The Netherland Antilles experienced a slight recession in 1960, mainly because of reduced refinery operations.

The cold weather continues to cut sharply into stocks of light heating fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes. In the week ended last Friday supplies of that fuel dropped 7,014,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
The Dressmakers Joint Council, representing 90,000 workers here and in six other states, asked yesterday for a 10 per cent wage increase.

THE telephone rang. The conversation began without preliminaries or identification, but the voice was immediately recognized as belonging to Frank Frisch, a member of the idle rich as well as a baseball immortal in the Hall of Fame.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senate investigators sought today to show that "dummy" officials had been placed on a New York City teamsters union payroll to draw salaries destined for Antonio Corallo, a fugitive from the police.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Robert F. Kennedy, who will be the Attorney General in the new National Administration, called on college football coaches tonight to help mold strong Americans.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday threw out Jack Molinas' $3,000,000 anti-trust suit and refused to order his reinstatement as a player with the National Basketball Association.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 -- Twenty Nagas, including two leaders of the long agitation for independence of their area from India, were reported today to have been arrested on charges of anti-state activities. The leaders held are Lunghsim Shaiza and Miss Beilin Aneami.
YONKERS, Jan. 11 -- Policemen and firemen rescued twenty-one women when smoke from a basement fire mushroomed through the four-story nurses' home at Yonkers General Hospital today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy paid a courtesy call tonight on former President Herbert Hoover at a reception attended by about 500 other persons.
Directors of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company proposed yesterday a four-for-one split of the common stock.
Camp Fire Girls, Inc., has purchased the five-story building at 65-69 Worth Street, corner of Church Street, for a new national headquarters building. The General Realty Company was the seller.
PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 11 -- A revised flood control plan for the Passaic River Basin in New Jersey was made public today by the Army Corps of Engineers.

An abundance of investment funds seeking placement at short term flooded the money market yesterday, driving down discount rates on Treasury bills. Rates on short-dated bills fell to 2.14 per cent and those on bills due in ten months dropped to below 2 1/2 per cent.
The custom smelter price for copper was reduced by one cent to 29 cents a pound yesterday, and trade officials expected mine producers to make a similar reduction soon.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11 -- The largest collection of ancient Greek art ever bequeathed to Harvard has arrived at the university's Fogg Museum.

A new look has draped itself around the habitues of the swank hotel supper clubs on the East Side. Although no one has been waltzing in tennis sneakers, informality has become the theme for the uniform of the night.

With a steadily mounting threat of disintegration and civil war hanging over the Congo the United Nations Security Council meets today, not to cope with the Congo crisis but to consider new Soviet propaganda charges of Belgian aggression against the new state.

The largest volume of trading in cocoa since July 25, 1960, occurred yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. In all, 1,020 lots of 30,000 pounds each changed hands. Volume last July 25 was 2,126 lots.

" The basic facts of the current pattern of corruption in the plan section of the Department of Buildings are engagingly simple: If you want prompt service and fair treatment you have to pay for it. If you do not pay you may be subjected to interminable delays, 'lost' files, highly technical objections or other harassment. It is as simple as that: Pay or else.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The police stormed the headquarters of the Communist party today and seized 131 persons in a drive to check demonstrations supporting Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

Members of the Board of Education and a labor committee appointed by Mayor Wagner said yesterday that after nine weeks of meetings many of the issues that led to the recent teachers' strike had been resolved.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 -- The position of power that Alvaro C. Alsogaray, the Minister of the Economy, has held in the Argentine Cabinet for eighteen months is weakening rapidly, according to political analysts.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- With the accent on defense, St. Joseph's College upset St. John's of Brooklyn, 74 -- 71, tonight in the wind-up of a basketball double-header at the Palestra.
MOSCOW, JAN. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Union demanded tonight United Nations action to abolish Belgian trusteeship of Ruanda-Urundi and grant independence to that African neighbor of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy named George W. Ball today as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. This is the third-ranking post in the State Department and includes supervision of the principal foreign-aid agencies.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Britain has received a proposal that a new control commission consisting of representatives of India, Indonesia and Burma be sent to Laos to end the civil war there. The three nations are all neutrals in the "cold war."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 11 -- Belgium's political leaders searched today for a formula to end the strike that has crippled the nation since Dec. 20. But Andre Renard, "strong man" of the Socialist unions, indicated that he would be satisfied only by capitulation of the Government on a proposed law.
LONDON, Jan. 11-- Stock market prices generally weakened here today as buyers became hesitant and increasingly selective.

Patrice Jacobs' colt Hail to Reason and Mrs. Dodge Sloane's filly Bowl of Flowers were designated as the two top 2-year-olds of 1960 in the Experimental Free Handicap ratings made public yesterday by Frank E. (Jimmy) Kilroe, the track handicapper for the New York Racing Association.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- An exhibition of Japanese animal art at the Place des Vosges, which has attracted zoophiles as well as art lovers, has been extended until Feb. 15.
President-elect John F. Kennedy was reported yesterday to have advised Michael H. Prendergast to "sit tight."
DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- John F. Gordon, president of the General Motors Corporation, defended the automobile industry today against critics of fins and the annual model change.

Strong and prompt executive action by the new President -- not Congressional legislation -- will represent the first steps this year toward new civil rights gains, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey predicted last night.
HAVANA, Jan. 11 -- Cuba's sugar harvest is off to a slow start because thousands of workers in the civilian militia have been mobilized to repel a "Yankee invasion."
NEWARK, Jan. 11 -- The Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court wants the state's lawyers to start a share-the-work movement.

Truck trailers get longer and longer, almost terrifyingly so, as motorists may have noted. The railroads have been a little slower stretching out. But yesterday the North American Car Corporation demonstrated a flat car that measured 119 feet, 2 inches.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, and John Hay Whitney, retiring United States Ambassador, stressed tonight the need for continuing British-American cooperation in defending the non-Communist world.

Dr. Charles R. Dawson, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia College, and Frank H. Lee, Professor of Graphics at Columbia's School of Engineering, received "Great Teacher Awards" from the Society of Older Graduates last night.
Total net assets of the five mutual funds managed by Investors Diversified Services, Inc., increased by more than $200,000,000 during 1960, rising above the $2,500,000,000-mark at the year-end.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Yale's swimming team defeated Brown, 63 -- 32, tonight for its 200th straight dual-meet victory. An Eli varsity swimming team has not lost such a meet since bowing to Army in 1945.

Fairleigh Dickinson defeated Long Island University, 102 -- 80, in a Tri-State League game at the New York High School of Printing gymnasium last night. In the second game of the double-header, Pace beat the New York Aggies, 66 -- 50.
I appreciate the view expressed by Professor Kohn, whom I greatly respect, but I think he misinterpreted what I wrote when he says:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Ap) -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey introduced a bill today to provide Federal aid for mass transportation facilities.

MRS. BARBARA KACHMAR played the South hand in the deal shown, made her contract and game. Then she made the surprising statement that she would rather have been East, defending against three no-trump.

The practice of disqualifying cocker spaniels that exceeded the breed's height limits rounded out a full year at the American Spaniel Club's national specialty in the Hotel Roosevelt last week-end. It was working out fine, agreed Dr. John T. Eash of Westfield, N.J., the club president; W. Emlen Roosevelt of Bernardsville, N.J., chairman of the executive committee, and Herbert D. Roling of Niantic, Conn., the treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Vice President Nixon presented to President Eisenhower today a set of broad proposals to combat job and housing discrimination against Negroes where Federal funds were involved.
DR. Jerome Bert Wiesner of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is a man of many roles but that of the secluded scholar is not one of them.
DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- The Ford Motor Company announced four top-level appointments today.

While Jacob M. Kaplan, a director of the Endicott Johnson Corporation, last month traded his 60,000-share holding of the company's stock for Glen Alden Corporation stock, another director of Endicott Johnson added to his shares.

Brunswick Corporation is offering its common stockholders rights to subscribe for $25,634,400 of 4 1/2 per cent of twenty-year convertible subordinated debentures. Stockholders may buy $100 of debentures for each sixty-five common shares held on Jan. 11, 1961 at 100.

The Weather Bureau's transfer of its recording equipment from Battery Place to Central Park has resulted in a revision of the listing of degree days in the daily temperature data. The transfer was made Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Substantial and progressive expansion of United States information activities abroad to bolster the nation's prestige was urged in a report by a Presidential study group made public today.
Mayor Wagner last night described the record of his seven years in office as "possibly the most outstanding one in the history of the city."
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Shareholders of the First National Bank of Chicago approved a 20 per cent stock dividend at the bank's annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn announced plans today to enlarge the House Rules Committee, instead of purging a Southern Democratic member, to prevent the obstruction of President-elect John F. Kennedy's legislative program.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 11 (AP) -- About 3,000 jeering, screaming persons tonight surged around the Tapia Theatre, where Puerto Rican actors continued picketing the San Juan Drama Festivals production of "Auntie Mame."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- By only four votes, the Senate decided today to delay a showdown on ending the filibuster, the principal weapon of Southerners against civil rights legislation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Kennedy Administration will continue President Eisenhower's policy of checking judicial appointments with a committee of the American Bar Association.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- Unusual vibration marked the take-off of the Eastern Air Lines Electra that crashed in Boston harbor last Oct. 4, two stewardesses testified today.

A Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Negroes who picketed a Harlem liquor store owned by a white woman were guilty of "discriminatory racial practices." He enjoined them from further picketing.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers broke up a close National Basketball Association game in the last two minutes and scored a 109-104 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight before 2,631 fans.

Earnings of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation and its domestic associated companies for the nine months ended on Nov. 30 showed a slight decline from those of the 1959 period, according to a report issued for publication yesterday.

TORONTO, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., gold producer in Northern Ontario's Kirkland Lake area, cleared $335,685 in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, compared with $275,702 in the 1959 period.

The problems being faced by Latin America and in our relations with the area are being dramatized by the Cuban revolution. Those who wanted to see these problems in cold black and white, in statistics and other unromantic facts, had only to read the section on hemispheric economy in this newspaper yesterday.
The problem of "how big is enough" is the major defense question confronting the incoming Administration.

Health protection for the elderly, provided through the existing Federal Social Security system, has been given great impetus -- as it should -- by two developments this week. The first was its impressive endorsement by participating groups in the National Conference on Aging and the second was the report of President-elect Kennedy's special task force headed by Wilber Cohen, Michigan University Professor of Public Welfare Administration.
AS long as the United States remains a world power, the sun will never set on Bob Hope.
Howard K. Smith, Washington correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, said yesterday that he would make no more reports on "Douglas Edwards With the News."

Daily average deposits of the Manufacturers Trust Company rose $141,156,000 in the last six months of 1960 from the 1959 level, the bank said in its annual report issued for publication today. In the first half of the year they were $104,370,000 below the 1959 level.

Reporting on the symposium on the current Chinese science, The New York Times recently quoted Burton K. Adkinson, head of the Office of Scientific Information of the National Science Foundation, as saying that "the amount of Chinese scientific literature translated into English is negligible."

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley today called the bombing last night of a north side synagogue a "shocking thing to occur in our city." He ordered a full-scale police effort to catch those responsible.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard at Quincy, Mass., will build six new cargo ships for the United States Lines of New York, the Maritime Administration announced today.

TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- One of the patients of an osteopathic physician who is under investigation because fourteen of his patients died of hepatitis was disclosed today to have been suffering from the disease when she first went to the doctor.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 11 -- A proposal by a town official to permit the so-called preferred type of industry in a residential area here was assailed today by a civic group.

The New Zealand Mission to the United Nations has leased a tower floor in the twenty-four-story office building being constructed by the Durst Organization at 733 Third Avenue, southeat corner of Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Treasury announced today that it would borrow $100,000,000 of new cash next Monday, because the Federal budget surplus is not up to expectations. More cash borrowing than that probably will be necessary, but officials said no decision had been made.

THE doll-sized hat is the biggest thing in millinery for spring. From a wide range of silhouettes -- and designers have gone all out to show styles to suit every one, including the woman who is out of the habit of wearing a hat -- this miniature in straw, fabric or flowers emerged on top.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- More than 90 per cent of the shareholders in the British Ford Motor Company have accepted the United States parent company's offer to buy their shares, it was announced here today.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The following ski conditions were reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:

Until yesterday the Metropolitan Baseball Club, Inc., the group that will field the local National League team in 1962, had little more than a franchise, riparian rights to Flushing Bay and a burning desire to get going.

Morris A. Marks, who lost a proxy fight Tuesday to become a director of the Valley National Bank of Long Island, Valley Stream, said yesterday that he was considering legal action against the bank's management.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to keep Senator Harry F. Byrd as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, although he had opposed key proposals in the Kennedy Administration's legislative program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The United States is preparing to build an underwater missile range off the Bahamas as part of an effort to counter the growing Soviet submarine threat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Douglas Dillon, who will be Secretary of the Treasury in the Kennedy Administration, said today that there might be a deficit in the Federal budget next year.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 11 -- A blast like "a hundred claps of thunder" rocked an area of 200 square miles in central Westchester County at 9:31 tonight.

ATHENS, Ga., Thursday, Jan. 12 -- About 600 students and a few outsiders rioted last night at the University of Georgia. Early today university officials announced that two Negro students, targets of the demonstration, had been suspended.
The country's retailers, gathered here almost 5,000 strong for their annual convention, adopted a plan of action yesterday as a guide for stores in the present period of economic ferment.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The first Americans to travel an overland route arrived at the South Pole today.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A former brigadier general of the Nazi SS was charged with murder today in the wartime massacre of more than 2,000 Lithuanian and Ukrainian Jews. The SS was the elite corps in Hitler's armed forces.
HAVANA, Jan. 11 -- The Cuban Government put into effect today a requirement for United States citizens to obtain visas or special permission by the Foreign Ministry before coming to the island.

George Shaw, the 27-year-old quarterback who was unhappy with the Baltimore Colts and insecure with the Giants, yesterday moved from New York to the Minnesota Vikings, the newest team in the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Western diplomats here reported today that the Soviet Union had indicated in discussions with the United States that it did not wish to push the critical situation in Laos to the brink of war.
HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 11 -- Space agency officials estimated today that the cost of orbiting the first United States astronaut would exceed $400,000,000, about twice the original estimate.
The state's investigation into city affairs appeared yesterday to be on the verge of slowing down.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Governor Rockefeller urged industrialists in the area today to look to New York whenever they contemplated expansion. He said the "government's new attitude toward business" in New York insured a favorable climate for growth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- First response in the United States and abroad to the Youth Corps idea has been "overwhelming," Maurice Albertson, director of the Colorado State University Research Foundation, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- The most successful writing team in movies is laying violent hands on Ferenc Molnar to disprove the Hollywood conviction that the works of the late Hungarian playwright are box-office anathema on the screen.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 11 -- Dag Hammarskjold had his first look at the inside of an African home today. In a quick tour of Johannesburg's African townships the United Nations Secretary General surprised his escort by asking to leave his car and move among the people in a township, where the Government has resettled 14,000 African families who formerly lived in Sophiatown, a slum area.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston nominated Vice President Nixon today for "Goodwill Man of 1960."
The parallel in background and personality between Theodore Roosevelt, our twenty-sixth President, and John F. Kennedy, who next week becomes our thirty-fifth President, is striking indeed.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- President de Gaulle declared today that the national referendum favoring provisional autonomy for Algeria had shown that his liberal policy "must be applied without reserve in its spirit as in its letter."

Major political events in the Soviet Union are not usually announced almost a year in advance, yet that is precisely what has happened with the announcement that the twenty-second Communist Party Congress will convene next October. Whatever official reasons may be given for this departure from normal practice, the immediate political significance is plain.

Four Roman Catholic priests, expelled from Haiti by President Francois Duvalier, arrived at New York International Airport early this morning en route to France. The priests, all French nationals, came on a Pan American World Airways plane.

It may not appear to be important advertising news when M.J. Rathbone, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), says that "Shakespeare is in good hands with the British Broadcasting Corporation * * *."

MARK TWAIN said at the turn of the century that San Francisco had tripled its population and quadrupled its other prosperities since he left. He doubted whether anyone else ever did more for the place.
Applications for the construction of the Queensboro Hills middle-income cooperative in Douglaston, Queens have been withdrawn by the sponsor.

Electric power production in the nation rose to 14,245,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the holiday week ended last Saturday from 13,956,000,009 a week earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 14,308,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

Downtown service on the East Side line of the IRT subway was disrupted last night when the fifth car of an eight-car southbound local train was derailed at the Fulton Street station. Two hundred passengers were shaken up, but no injuries were reported.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Slackening demand and stiffer resistance lowered the grain futures market again today with losses running a bit broader.
Plans are nearing completion for a candlelight buffet dinner in the Terrace Room of the Plaza next Thursday to be followed by a theatre party to "Camelot" at the Majestic Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The high salaries of top officials of the Port of New York Authority and continuation of tolls on bridges long after they had been paid for were linked by the Government today as an unfair burden on interstate travelers.

Sea trials of the first nuclear-powered merchant ship are expected before June, an official of the Federal Maritime Administration said here yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The State Council of Churches called today for a temporary state commission to consider whether all legalized gambling in the state should be abolished.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has promoted Franklin R. Otto to vice president of its Puerto Rico branches and Julius J. Thomson to vice president of its branch in Beirut, Lebanon, David Rockefeller, president, announced yesterday.
Although Laurence Harvey is a busy film actor, he is willing to set aside twelve weeks to star in Jean-Paul Sartre's drama, "Loser Wins."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Two key groups of the White House Conference on Aging split today on the question of tying medical care to the Social Security System.
A revised system of proctoring examinations has been adopted by City College's Department of English to cut down on cheating.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- The Soviet Union has begun a new diplomatic offensive seemingly aimed at loosening the bonds between West Germany and France.
F.W. Woolworth Company giant variety chain, reported yesterday a dip in sales last month but a gain in volume for the year.
The harbor strike tightened its grip on the city's distribution lifeline yesterday as new peace efforts failed.

HALFWAY between the coming of winter and the advent of spring there comes a time when palates pall. It is a season of drab sameness when menus tend to be static and the appetite hankers for the first asparagus and the joyous welcome of shad roe.
Charles Poore remarked that one of the most uncomfortable trips he ever took was an ocean voyage on which he had read a defective copy of a Dashiell Hammett novel. The last few pages were missing.

Despite the city's refusal to permit bowling alleys to be built in Grand Central Terminal, the New York Gothams will begin play here in October in the new twelve-city National Bowling League.

Ingmar Bergman's "The Virgin Spring" has been named as Sweden's official entry for the Academy Award as best foreign language film of 1960, it was disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The staff of the Communist party newspaper for the Moscow oblast (region) was severely criticized today for failure to publish a recent message from Premier Khrushchev congratulating a collective farmer for his success in growing buckwheat.

Emil M. Keen, a Wantagh, L.I., builder, has been told that he will not be a management candidate for re-election to the board of the Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, L.I., Herman H. Maas, president, confirmed yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 11 -- A spokesman for the Government of the United Arab Republic declared tonight the Arabs were ready to resist any "pressures" President-elect John F. Kennedy might apply on them to fulfill "campaign promises" to Zionists.

IT is a dirty trick to assemble and make public a table by which a deerslayer may determine the live weight of a deer he has slain simply by looking it up opposite the dressed weight in the table. But the thing has been done now and nothing can diminish the harm that is bound to ensue.

SKI SKETCH: Last Sunday Boris Dernic, the Yugoslavian-bred general manager of the Davos area at Woodridge, N.Y., went through an experience that general managers pray will never happen. The main double-chair lift broke down early in the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower presented the Distinguished Service Award today to five career civil servants.
A former Guatemalan Ambassador to Belgium and the Netherlands was sentenced here yesterday to fifteen years in prison for smuggling millions of dollars worth of heroin into the United States.
The State of California borrowed $95,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of new buildings by fast-growing school districts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- John F. Kennedy has scheduled his first news conference as President for Jan. 25, five days after the inauguration, with live television and radio coverage.
MIAMI, Jan. 11 -- Cuban exile leaders here are struggling to overcome a lack of unity that has hindered their fight against the Castro Government.

In 1881, as part of an International Polar Year, the United States sent a party of twenty-five men, under the command of Lieut. Adolphus Washington Greely, to Grinnell Land, now called Ellesmere Island. During their first year on the ice members of the expedition went farther toward the North Pole than any man had gone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Although the Senators who want to ease Rule XXII acquired more votes than on previous occasions in support of their effort to get immediate floor action on specific proposals to this end, they failed once again to obtain even a simple majority of Senators "present and voting."
The election of Peter Campbell Brown as a director of the Federation Bank and Trust Company was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Shanahan, president.

At the beginning of the printed program for Robert Rudie's recital in Judson Hall last night, the violinist expressed his gratitude for the inspiration given him in his career by Fritz Kreisler, who celebrates his eighty-sixth birthday on Feb. 2.

John Ware resigned as chairman and director of the American Water Works Company, Inc., on Dec. 8, the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Democratic women who are shaping the course of the Inaugural Ball moved today to head off what could be one of the first touchy issues of the Kennedy Administration.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association adopted a rule today requiring athletes to complete their competition within five years after enrolling in college.

New York's annual mid-January extravaganza known as the National Motor Boat Show actually had a quiet unobtrusive opening yesterday in the Coliseum, although the official unveiling to the general public will be deferred until 10:30 A.M. Saturday.
The Throgs Neck Bridge was opened yesterday with no speeches, little fanfare and not much business. Toll traffic began moving over the six-lane span just before noon.
NOW that coin-operated machines for dry cleaning have been introduced to laundromats, many women are wondering how soon it will be before such a machine is developed for the home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Rufus E. Miles was promoted to administrative assistant secretary in the Department of Welfare today.

Lloyd Hauser and J.P. Sloane, realty operators, have contracted to buy the six-story town house at 10 East Sixty-fourth Street, near Fifth Avenue, which they plan to alter into luxury apartments. They were represented by Irving Lester Levitt, lawyer.

The Federal Aviation Agency announced plans yesterday to study the flight paths followed on about forty jetliner trips prior to the Dec. 16 collision here to see if pilots were engaging in dangerous practices.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The A.B. Dick Company, manufacturer of duplicating machines and stencils, was fined $7,000 today by Federal Judge Girard Kalbfleisch in criminal contempt charges brought by the antitrust division of the United States Department of Justice.

Stocks gave a ragged performance yesterday. Once again more issues rose than fell. Once again prices ended upward in the leading averages. But once again a genuinely strong major group of stocks was impossible to find.
Cotton futures in the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 6 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 -- A task force on space programs warned President-elect John F. Kennedy today that the United States was lagging behind the Soviet Union in ballistic missiles and outer-space exploration.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev has demanded a purge of "figure jugglers" and incompetent officials from the Communist party in order to help solve the Soviet Union's chronic agricultural problem, Izvestia, the official Government newspaper, reported today.

Sales of the General Instrument Corporation set records in both the quarter and nine months ended on Nov. 30, the company reported yesterday. Net income climbed 21 per cent in the quarter and 28 per cent in the nine months above 1959 levels.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Army upset Villanova, 64 to 49, in basketball today. Lee Anderson, a senior center in his first starting assignment, led the cadets.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa reported today that the economy of the Congo could be re-established if political security were assured.

Maj. Gen. Haim Laskov, who recently retired as Chief of Staff of Israel's Army, said here yesterday that 320,000 immigrants in Israel had still not been absorbed and were causing a serious social and economic problem.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11 -- Harvard pressed its claim to Eastern hockey leadership tonight by defeating Boston College, 4 -- 1. It was the second time in as many weeks the Crimson had beaten the Eagle six.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 11 -- The United Nations command moved reinforcements into northern Katanga today to prevent what it termed an acute danger of civil war.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to reorganize the city's health and hospital services.

I entirely agree with C.L. Sulzberger, in his column published Dec. 31, on the importance of NATO. We must help it grow from an ad hoc military alliance which by now has fulfilled its task into a "democratic community."

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A dispute between lawyers broke out in Federal court here today when a defendant in the alleged $2,000,000 Atlas Gypsum Stock swindle protested against a heavy jail sentence.

The third Roosevelt International Trot, a $50,000 invitation event, was scheduled yesterday to be held on Saturday night, July 15. It heads a list of fourteen feature races that will be offered by the Westbury harness track during the first part of its split season this year.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., the second largest Canadian distiller, reported yesterday that net income rose by 6 percent and earnings before taxes climbed 12 per cent in its first fiscal quarter, which ended on Nov. 30.
The Bach Aria Group provided a pleasant surprise in the concert it gave in Town Hall last night by introducing Roberta Peters as an interpreter of Bach's music.
TUNIS, Jan. 3 -- Ministers of the Algerian Provisional Government continued today their full-scale meeting here in the wake of the French referendum.
LYNDHURST, N.J., Jan. 11 -- One hundred firemen from five communities fought a roaring chemical blaze in the Jersey Meadows tonight.

The First National City Bank of New York will open its second branch in Nassau County today at 75 West Merrick Road, Freeport, L.I., in a former supermarket. Permanent quarters will be constructed three blocks to the west at West Merrick Road and South Bergen Place.

IF Paris has a magical appeal to many Americans, America seems to return the favor for some Frenchmen. At least this is true for Thierry Roger Delmas, who last week took over supervision of Helena Rubenstein's beauty salons in this country.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann was re-elected president of the World Zionist Organization early today in an acrimonious closing session of the Zionist Congress.

The First National Bank of Boston and two British concerns have joined to form a new international factoring organization, International Factors, Ltd. Initially, the concern will concentrate its activities on trade between Britain and the United States, imports into these countries from other lands, and domestic trade within Great Britain.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings tied the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game tonight that interrupted a seven-game Chicago winning streak.

OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- Lester B. Pearson, Liberal party leader, closed a three-day convention of 2,000 delegates here tonight with an appeal to his supporters to work hard for victory at the next election.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest general retail merchandiser, is planning one of the largest bank financing transactions ever undertaken, officials of the Chicago concern confirmed last night.

Those of us who have been fortunate enough to observe Dr. Robert C. Weaver at work over the past few years are in complete accord with your editorial on Jan. 1. DENVER, Jan. 11 -- The majority of students who enter college have read little literature, know nearly nothing about the classics and cannot write a page of good English, the annual meeting of the Association of American Colleges was told today.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The failure of the Diesel locomotive pulling the British Railways' business man's special, the Penman, provided Queen Elizabeth II yesterday with an experience familiar to thousands of her subjects.
Activity in the commodities futures markets was rather dull yesterday and prices closed mostly down.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The British, one of the most "mongrel" people of the human race, are still prejudiced about marriages of mixed color, Sir John Wolfenden said today.

As has happened several times in recent weeks, stocks went either up or down yesterday, depending on the measuring rod used. More stocks rose than fell. Aggregate market value gained about one-third of 1 per cent.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday attacked forthcoming proposals by the Moore state commission on revision of the City Charter, presaging an election-year clash between himself and Mayor Wagner.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -Three labor leaders were sentenced to prison today for extorting money from employers in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.
ROME, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- An American Cardinal-designate said today that integration of Negroes and whites in United States schools followed "the precepts of Christ."

Five Roman Catholic bishops in the Dominican Republic exchanged New Year's toasts Tuesday with Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, the Dominican strongman, according to reports from Ciudad Trujillo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Final preparations were well under way today aboard most of the twenty-one yachts slated to enter the Southern Ocean Racing Conference St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale thrash Saturday.
The largest railroad merger in the nation's history moved a step closer to realization yesterday.

A name for the unified transportation system that would result from the proposed merger of four Western railroads was announced yesterday. It will be called Great Northern Pacific and Burlington Lines, Inc.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- A rise in venereal disease among teen-agers presents new social problems, the World Health Organization said today in a year-end report.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- Everyone who had anything to do with the expulsion of two Bishops from Haiti was declared by the Consistorial Congregation of the Vatican today to have been automatically excommunicated.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The first big residential project in Sterling Forest will start early this year, Robert W. Dowling, the owner, said today. He is also president of City Investment Company.

After an absence of six years from the screen, Judy Garland is returning to the medium that made her famous. Stanley Kramer, director-producer, announced here yesterday that he had signed the actress for a "comparatively small but highly important" dramatic starring role in "Judgment at Nuremberg."
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 -- A weather research program that will soon become the largest in the Southern Hemisphere has just been started here.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -The price of gold is edging up steadily again on the free market here under the pressure of what dealers today reported to be heavy buying by speculators in Europe and the Middle East.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., had record earnings for the first nine months last year, according to a report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Even with lavish allowance for the excesses of Opposition oratory, the one-track mind of task forces, and the bias of those in office toward their own records, readers of President Eisenhower's final report to Congress today on "The State of the Union" must wonder if they are simultaneously citizens of two different countries.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Six hundred students of the University of Bridgeport gave a polite but restrained reception today to a film of student demonstrations in San Francisco last May.

HONG KONG, Jan. 12 -- Dr. Ma Yin-chu, who was dismissed from the presidency of Peiping University last year, has reappeared publicly after a period of obscurity.
TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell plans to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey early next week.

The steel-making furnaces of the United States poured 99,277,760 tons of metal during 1960, the industry's sixth biggest output for a year, according to the preliminary report of the American Iron and Steel Institute, released yesterday.

A water-main break halted service at thirteen stations of the IND Eighth Avenue line for more than twelve hours yesterday. At least 225,000 regular IND riders were directly affected, the Transit Authority said.
