WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The young Kennedy team is young no longer. In the last few days they have had to turn their eyes from the glow at the end of the tunnel to the shadows on the walls, and this has been a sobering experience.
ABILENE, Kan., Jan. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has sent one of his oil paintings to his old high school "with apologies for my nonexistent 'talent.'"

Six wooden inboard cruisers from the 21-foot Express to a new 33-foot Sea Breeze Express are being displayed by the Trojan Boat Company of Lancaster, Pa. They are part of the company's nine-boat inboard line. None of the Trojan outboard craft are being shown.

Mayor Wagner's appointment of the Task Force on Organization of Medical Services, with David M. Heyman, chairman, marks an important advance in the struggle to improve the city's health services. It is a logical follow-up of the work of the former Commission on Health Services, of which Mr. Heyman was also chairman, composed of leaders of industry, labor, medicine and related health activities.

TUNIS, Jan. 12 -- Algerian and Tunisian political circles are waiting tensely for "the next move" from President de Gaulle, now that the French referendum, in the North African view, has given him "freedom of maneuver."
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 12 -- The Caribbean storms of political strife, social crisis and economic collapse are returning to the venerable Negro nation of Haiti.
An eight-minute comedy sketch about President-elect John F. Kennedy and his wife, which was to be televised on "The Art Carney Show," has been deleted by order of the National Broadcasting Company.

OSTEND, Belgium, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A round-table conference on the Ruanda-Urundi trust territory ended today with most of the forty Africans present opposing the return of Swami (King) Kigeri V, who now is touring Europe.

Anyone who has developed a complacent attitude toward our rocket and space programs is likely to find the report of President-elect Kennedy's task force in this field a cold shower indeed. The report declares bluntly that our ballistic missile program is lagging, that the Russians are far ahead of us in rocket propulsion power and that there are deficiencies in the organization and operation of our program which badly need correction.
Eleven companies are showing a wide range of diesel propulsion and generating engines from 5 to 675 horsepower, manufactured in five different countries, at the show.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 -- William Block, chairman of the biennial citizens Conference on Community Planning, called today for closer cooperation between Federal and local agencies and the nation's voluntary welfare and community groups.
Students completing the sixth grade in one of 110 elementary schools will be permitted to request assignment next fall to junior high schools outside their regular districts.

The Franklin Corporation, New York, is investing $750,000 in Cylinders, Inc., of Linden, N.J., of which $200,000 is for a 25 per cent common stock equity and $550,000 is in installment loans. Arthur T. Roth, chairman and Herman E. Goodman, president of Franklin, made the announcement for the small-business investment company, which was organized by the Franklin National Bank, owner of 3.82 per cent of its stock.

NOW that the whirligigs of taste have swung back to Art Nouveau we are likely to see sculpture and constructions that reflect the rhythms of the grille of a Paris Metro station. Some such stylistic character belongs to James Metcalf's extremely accomplished sheet brass abstract sculpture at the Iolas Gallery, 123 East Fifty-fifth Street.

Construction is scheduled to begin in August on a $15,000,000 housing project for more than 2,000 New York University faculty members, married students and other persons who live or work in Greenwich Village.
The Port of New York Authority has budgeted $140,318,000 for construction and equipment and $71,143,000 for interest and principal on its debt.
OF course, this is an immoral assertion. But it is pleasanter to gaze at the winter sky in the Hayden Planetarium than on the wind-bitten roof of an apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The United States' surplus of exports over imports has taken a further turn for the better in recent months. This means a further basic improvement in the balance of payments situation, because exports and imports are the biggest ingredients in the balance.
The United States premiere of the motion picture "Two-Way Stretch," starring Peter Sellers, the British comedian, at the Guild Theatre on Jan. 22 will benefit Jobs for Youth.
The fourteenth annual Northern Area Conference of the Third Coast Guard District Auxiliary will take place Sunday at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and West Fifty-fifth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics scored a 124-118 triumph over the Syracuse Nats in a National Basketball Association overtime game tonight.

Events today: "L'Elisir d'Amore," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Morton Gould, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Concert Artists Guild, audition concert, Town Hall, 5:15; Handel's Joshua, presented by the Interracial Fellowship Chorus, St. Thomas Church, 7:30; "Cavalcade of Stars," in honor of the 100th anniversary of Italian independence, Carnegie Hall, 8:15; Eric Heidsieck, pianist, Town Hall, 8:40.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -Senate committee charged today that Pentagon restrictions on competitive bidding in military procurement were freezing small business out of the field. The result, it was held, was a wasting of "vast" sums of Government money.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- The speed of light is not fast enough for smooth conversation over a proposed system of communication satellites, an authority said here tonight.
NICE, France, Jan. 12 (AP) -The Riviera's newest celebrity is a slight, 60-year-old grocer named Georges Muller.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 12 -- An international conference on "Labor and Manpower Problems in Economic Development" opened here today.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 12 -The United States and Britain have protested strongly to Ceylon against the Petroleum Corporation bill introduced in Parliament.

William S. Krywicki, the baseball and football coach at Cardinal Hayes High School, yesterday was named athletic director at Cardinal Spellman High by Msgr. John P. Breheny, the principal of the new Bronx parochial school.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower rejected today a proposal by the Civil Aeronautics Board to open the way for more overseas business for irregular air carriers.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- Premier Khrushchev has accused Communist party leaders of the Ukraine and Kazakhstan of deceit and malpractice.
DUBLIN, Jan. 12 -- A showing by Irene Gilbert of her spring and summer fashions last night opened the Irish haute couture collections for 1961.

It has been said that there is good reason both to hope for the best and expect the worst, for both are arriving all the time. That remark was borne out in yesterday's paper -- in two stories involving the nation's youth.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- President-elect John F. Kennedy worked today on an inauguration address that he obviously wants to make one of the lasting documents of American history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended on Jan. 7 were 11 per cent below the level a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Senator John L. McClellan said today that a "new pattern" of corruption had developed in certain New York City teamster locals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today that the nation had advanced spiritually, morally and materially during his Administration, but that many domestic and foreign problems remained.
WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY'S novel "Vanity Fair" emerged as a well-cast and attractively mounted production in the first half of a two-part presentation on Channel 2 last night.

Two books to be published soon tell of the canoe raids staged by British-Australian Commando groups on shipping in Singapore Harbor in 1943 and 1944. One of the volumes will be "Return of the Tiger," by Brian Connell.

IT would have made a richly romantic story in the noble Alger tradition if Allie Sherman had finally attained a boyhood ambition when he was named coach of the New York Football Giants. But it would be grossly inaccurate. The fanciest dream Allie had in his boyhood days was to survive the squad cut on his high school team in Brooklyn.
William D. Cox, founder of the professional International Soccer League, offered men, money and ideas yesterday to improve American amateur soccer for Olympic and Pan-American competition.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Following is the text of a note from Walter Loridan of Belgium to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold regarding charges that Congolese troops had been permitted to cross the trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.
High-grade corporate bonds of recent issue moved into the spotlight of the bond market yesterday as trading in Government securities slackened.

MONTREAL, Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Interests in Cuba of the Royal Bank of Canada have been sold to the Cuban Government's central bank for $8,830,000 in United States funds, C.B. Neapole, general manager of the bank, said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The American Bar Foundation, the research division of the American Bar Association, started today on a broad ten-year expansion program to "provide the bar with decisive leadership."

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 12 -- The director of the Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity challenged two Virginia Protestant Episcopal Bishops to debate today after the bishops had disavowed resolutions on race adopted this week by the society.

Foreign governments and central banks bought $55,000,000 in gold from the United States Treasury in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. At $17,615,000,000 the monetary gold stock was down by $152,000,000 since the first of the year.
A marked decline in religious discrimination in medical schools was reported here yesterday by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- A disarmament task force warned President-elect John F. Kennedy tonight against any early disarmament negotiations with the Soviet Union until a basic United States policy had been defined within the new Administration.

That versatile designer, Mr. John, has added another item to his long list of creations. Noted for his custom hats, his designs also include furs, gloves, scarves and custom clothes. Now he has introduced his first line of cosmetics, called Royal Touch Custom Cosmetics.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A theory that starlings were sucked into the engines of an Eastern Airlines Electra received strong support today at an investigation of the plane's plunge into Boston Harbor on Oct. 4.
George Gobel, the television humorist who for months has been flirting with the idea of appearing on Broadway, has decided to try it next season.

The six-story warehouse building occupying the block bounded by McCarter Highway, Edison Place, Lawrence Street and the Central Railroad of New Jersey in Newark has been purchased by the Belar Realty Company.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The Chicago Cubs added Charlie Grimm and Verlon Walker to their strategy board of coaches today.
The forms of contracts, plans and specifications for the proposed sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

An urgent call for public help has been sounded by the New York Zoological Society, 30 East Fortieth Street, New York 16, which soon will open a drive for funds of greater magnitude than it has ever attempted before. Fairfield Osborn, president, has announced a campaign goal of $7,000,000 as the first phase of an ultimate program to raise $12,000,000.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Fred Zollner, the owner of the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association, tonight gave to W. Nick Kerbawy a leave of absence from his post as general manager because of what he called "Kerbawy's active participation in the Detroit Lions stockholders' fight."
Archie Moore, the light-heavyweight champion of the world, yesterday received a week's grace from the New York State Athletic Commission to sign for the defense of his title.
More than a half-billion dollars was wagered at the state's ght harness racetracks last year, the New York State Harness Racing Commission skid in annual report yesterday.
A 17-year-old Seward Park High School student threw an open pocket knife at a friend "in fun" yesterday and it stuck in the friend's back.

Fickle are the ways of sponsors, television stations, newscasters and the like.
More than $1,300,000,000 in grants was distributed by the Ford Foundation in its first ten years as a national philanthropy, Dr. Henry T. Heald, its president, said yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 12 -- Gov. Jimmie H. Davis today called a new thirty-day special session of the Louisiana Legislature and delayed until Sunday night a second attempt to pass a 1-cent sales tax increase.

The New York Chamber Soloists are aptly named. Each of the eleven members of the group is an expert performer. They can group and regroup themselves into various ensembles for the performance of delectable, rarely heard music.

Twenty-four young men and women about to embark on careers in the United States Foreign Service learned yesterday how New York City handles its commercial, security, welfare, administrative and diplomatic problems.

The proposed merger of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and the Chesepeake and Ohio Railway is the latest in a series of proposed or actual consolidations that has swept the railroad industry in the last two or three years.

Emphasis on refinements in existing motors rather than a further expansion in horsepower is the main characteristic of most lines of outboard motors for 1961. Only West Bend and McCulloch have produced a stronger engine than their highest horsepower motor of last year.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Eric Monti of Los Angeles shot a five-under-par 66 today and led the way through the first round of the $20,000 San Diego open golf tournament.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 -State Motor Vehicle inspectors who stopped Glasco Ryales in a routine spot check of motorists are not sure whether Mr. Ryales has been very lucky, very careful, or both, for the last thirty-two years.
The cast and producer of Eugene Ionesco's play "Rhinoceros," temporarily unlocked horns yesterday, but an uneasy truce exists at the Longacre Theatre.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 -The Chamber of Deputies cleared the way today for the transfer to private ownership and management of the San Nicolas state steel works.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Dean Rusk offered the Senate today the prospect of a new mood in the State Department. It was a prospect that was no less enticing for the muted tones in which it was presented.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Led by Sofya Muratova, the Soviet Union's women's gymnastic team last night defeated the United States women's team, 153.199 to 149.967.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- A Protestant Episcopal rector said today he would not welcome to holy communion any of his parishioners who had sanctioned the barring of a convert from Judaism at a country club Christmas dance.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The next step in President de Gaulle's effort to find a peace settlement in Algeria is likely to be a highly secret sounding of the state of mind and intentions of the Moslem rebel leadership.

BERN, Switzerland, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Betsy Snite of Norwich, Vt., was rated the world's second best woman giant slalom skier today by the Federation Internationale de Ski. Therese Leduc of France, who finished seventh in last winter's Olympics, was given the No. 1 spot.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -House Democrats were summoned to a binding party caucus today as leaders moved to carry out a plan for enlarging the House Rules Committee.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association council wound up the business of the fifty-fifth annual convention today by initiating an investigation into the importation of Canadian ice hockey players by United States colleges.
Representative Eugene J. Keogh of Brooklyn, a close personal and political friend of President-elect John F. Kennedy, yesterday was named chairman of this year's state Democratic fund-raising dinner.

Sales of individual life insurance by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (MONY) set a record at $1,012,175,000 in 1960, Roger Hull, president announced yesterday. This was about 20 per cent above the 1959 level and it was the first time in its 117-year history that the company topped the billion-dollar sales mark in individual life insurance.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York dropped $36,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $70,000,000 a year ago.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 12 -- Princess Astrid of Norway married a commoner, Johan Martin Ferner, today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 12 -- Premier Gaston Eyskens fainted in the House of Representatives tonight while the legislature neared the end of the debate on his economic program.
Allston Flagg of the Racquet and Tennis Club, seeded No. 3, was upset yesterday in the second round of the New York State squash racquets singles tournament at the Downtown Athletic Club.
ROME, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Italy launched her first successful high-altitude rocket today in a joint space-research program with the United States.

The Industrial Bank of Commerce yesterday reported record net earnings of $976,000 or $224,000 more than in 1959, a 12.8 per cent return on invested capital funds of $8,514,000. Gross operating income was $6,942,000, also a record and $210,000 more than in 1959.

Lower trans-Atlantic air cargo freight rates for large volume shipments were proposed here yesterday by Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., the only United States all-cargo airline offering daily scheduled service between this country and Europe.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -The fourth successive general decline in grain futures prices snipped major fractions to more than a cent a bushel off almost all prices today on the Board of Trade.
THE principal of "the Lavon affair," a controversy in Israel for almost seven years, is a man of calm persuasiveness and easy charm. But beneath the charm there is a stubborn will.

THE dedicated gourmet who usually prepares his specialty only as party fare spurns any substitute in the traditional recipe. But the home cook who prepares three meals a day every day for her family often does not discover until just as she is ready to start cooking that some ingredient is lacking in the larder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Congressional Democrats, conscious that their party soon will take over the Executive Branch, sharply attacked the picture President Eisenhower painted today of the state of the Union.
Young Rubicam, Inc., has appointed a new executive vice president and six senior vice presidents.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Charges that United States war planes are buzzing Soviet ships were expanded by the Soviet Union today to other nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The Navy and Army view in Washington is that the nation needs what is termed a "finite" strategic concept, an understanding that "enough is enough."

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Owners of the eight American Football League teams today filed protests against what they called "favoritism" toward the National Football League in television coverage of the Senior Bowl.
Thomas F. Jones was named to head the investigation section of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor yesterday, succeeding the late Paul A. Alfieri, under whom he served as chief investigator.

The growing shortage of mooring and winter storage space, brought on by yachting's population explosion, has caused more than one boatman to moan that the only answer is to have his own waterfront facilities.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 12 -- Party political activity, banned in Turkey since the coup d'etat last May, will be permitted again tomorrow.

FOR one hour last night the enormity of the problem of narcotics addiction in New York was explored in a WCBS-TV (Channel 2) filmed documentary entitled, "Junkyard by the Sea." It was a compassionate but realistic study of a shameful situation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The White House Conference on Aging closed today with a clear victory for medical care for the aging under the Social Security system.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Amory Houghton, United States Ambassador, paid a tribute to Preident de Gaulle today as "a great patriot and a wise statesman."

About three months ago Shell Oil Company officials estimated that profits for 1960 would be slightly above those of 1959. Yesterday M.E. Spaght, president, indicated a change in management thinking. He said that earnings "are not going to exceed" the net of $147,417,000, or $2.43 a share, cleared in 1959.

The "exchange student" project of the Sailboat Training Facility, New York, has been expanded to include Bermuda this year. The addition brings to six the number of participating countries. The others are Denmark, England, Norway, Sweden and the United States.

A preliminary plan for a 500-acre industrial park in the Mariners Harbor section of northwestern Staten Island was disclosed yesterday by Mayor Wagner and James Felt, Chairman of the City Planning Commission.
New Yorkers got an unplanned demonstration yesterday of how the city's brand-new emergency information service works in a serious subway tie-up.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 12 -- A skeleton crew of fifteen men fought tonight to save a slowly sinking tanker racked by an engine-room explosion and fire this morning. Its position was 360 miles southeast of San Juan.
The lives of such diverse persons as Staten Island rapid transit riders and business men whose freight crosses windswept Lake Michigan would be touched by the biggest rail merger in history.
The radar-controller who guided the piston-engine airliner involved in the Dec. 16 collision here indicated yesterday that he had waited for the pilot to request a change in course.

Lumber production climbed sharply, in the week ended last Saturday, to 143,629,000 board feet. This compared with 111,570,000 beard feet the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 220,718,000 board feet.

A 47-footer from California with hot and cold air-conditioning, the first aluminum-planked boat and the largest fiber glass cruiser ever offered at the show are highlights of the inboard cruiser display.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations left here by air for New York today to attend the Security Council debate on the Congo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Three Swiss officials have arrived in Havana to take charge of United States interests in Cuba.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The National Women's Christian Temperance Union said today that a proposed increase in the United States State Department's representation fund would endanger national security.
MONTREAL, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Billy Hicke scored two goals tonight in leading the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -More than 100 British admirers of Terry Downes flew into Boston from London today for Saturday night's title fight with Paul Pender of Brookline, Mass. Pender is recognized as middleweight champion in New York, Massachusetts and Europe.
Houston, Tex., Independent School District announced yesterday plans for the sale of $14,000,000 of serial bonds. The bids will be received on Feb. 6.

The inboard-outboard motors that made their first impression at last year's show are present this year in greater numbers at the Coliseum. The I.O., as the type has come to be known, employs a typical outboard lower unit connected to a compact inboard engine.
Acting Borough President Louis A. Cioffi's campaign for a less bumpy New York has been advanced this week as 1,700 street holes in Manhattan have been patched.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Gorton's of Gloucester, Inc., one of the nation's oldest seafood companies, is merging with Fishery Products, Inc., a relative new comer to the industry. E. Robert Kinney, president of Gorton's and Robert J. Gruber, president of Fishery Products, jointly announced that the merger, described as a "natural one," is being effected by an exchange of stock.
At the shore, a decent girl wouldn't think of scuffing the family cruiser with high-heel shoes. At the National Motor Boat Show, hardly anybody would think of asking her to take them off.
CLEWISTON, Fla., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Former President Herbert Hoover said today the nation was amply repaid for taxes spent on great public works that safeguarded citizens and increased national wealth.
PADO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 12 -- The Air Force technique of tracking and catching its Discoverer satellites was disclosed here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy has divested himself of all his personally held stocks and bonds within the last sixty days. His action was designed to avoid any possible financial conflict of interest when he assumes the Presidency Jan. 20.

IN the summer of 1323 Roger Mortimer, Baron of Wigmore and one of the greatest lords of the Welsh Marches, escaped from the Tower of London. No one had ever escaped from the grim fortress-prison before. Mortimer accomplished the feat only through the aid of the Lieutenant of the Tower, who drugged the archers of the guard.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 12 -The captain of a ship that sank yesterday off Alhucemas Bay with the loss of forty-three Jews who sought to reach Israel was questioned today by Moroccan authorities.
GREASE that skillet or heat that broiler, for frying chickens are one of the best bargains this week. Several stores are offering these small-fry birds for as low as 29 cents a pound.
The Grand Jury Association of New York County asked the Legislature yesterday to defeat a bill that would permit defendants in most criminal cases to waive grand jury hearings.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $125,000,000 to $51,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $496,000,000 to $507,000,000.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 12 -- Lawyers met with a Federal District judge today in an attempt to return two Negro students to the University of Georgia. Pending a further conference, no action was taken.

A huge consumer market is in the making in this country, based on a vast increase in population and an enormous expansion in the number of households, it was asserted last evening by Paul Mazur, a partner in Lehman Brothers, investment banking house.
Gerard (Jerry) Strivelli, a 35-year-old ex-convict with a record of ten arrests since 1943, was shot and killed early yesterday and his body left in a stolen car parked in the Bronx.
A Greek seaman who had turned hot dog vender and a waiter from Bermuda who hated New York's wintry blasts were ordered deported yesterday.

The board of directors of the New York Central Railroad decided yesterday to pass the dividend for the first quarter of this year, although preliminary indications are that the big carrier will wind up in the black for 1960.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 -- The Hudson County Chosen Board of Freeholders today reversed its resolution of a month ago to lease a forty-year-old former nightclub for use as a county geriatrics hospital.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation set new records last month and last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Jan. 12 -Three generations of honest dealings with employes is paying off for the Endicott Johnson Corporation here in an outpouring of loyalty and even love that is rare if not unique in industrial relations.
A tree surgeon gazed up at a century-old elm on Ward Island for the last time the other day, then climbed into the upper branches to begin a task he could neither relish nor avoid.
HOUSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -The University of Houston shattered Bradley's two-season, eighteen-game winning streak tonight with a 60-59 upset of the nation's second-ranked basketball team.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The observance of the New Year holiday last Monday produced mixed freight loadings in both the rail and truck industries.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The year-old New York City law prohibiting teen-agers from carrying knives and other sharp instruments was declared unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals today.

MADISON, N.J., Jan. 12 -Harold Sinley Buttenheim, editor emeritus of the monthly American City Magazine and a lifelong adviser to and leader of city planning movements, died at his home here last night. He was 84 years old.
Creation of a new international institution to be known as the World Development Organization was suggested yesterday by Stanley de J. Osborne, president of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Industrial shares again moved lower on the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today the Communists nations had not shown "serious interest in a responsible approach to disarmament."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 12 -- Six physicians who participated in the "mercy killings" of at least fifty-six children during the war will be permitted to continue their professional careers, the health department of Hamburg has decided.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Professional soccer players with northern clubs of the Football League today rejected the wage and contract concessions offered by the league in its attempt to avert a strike on Jan. 21.

A suspended employe of the Manhattan Motor Vehicle Bureau pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to a charge of accepting a bribe from a motorist facing disciplinary action before the state agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has started a safety survey of all reactors and allied equipment licensed by it. The action is an aftermath of explosion of a commission reactor in Idaho Jan. 3 in which three men were killed.

STRATFORD, Ont., Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Douglas Campbell will play the title role and Pat Galloway will appear as Anne Boleyn in "Henry VIII." The play is one of four to be presented at the 1961 Stratford Shakespearean Festival.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 12 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion accused Pinhas Lavon today of having organized Opposition parties in a campaign of "backbiting and slander" in a "poisonous war" against the party to which both men belong.

This year's National Motor Boat Show -- the 51st annual -deserves to be the best of all. It is taking three days to open. Finally it will unveil its grandeurs to the general public tomorrow morning at 10:30 for another week's indoor dry-land regatta.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- James V. Bennett, director of the United States Bureau of Prisons, said today he intended to follow through on his protest that "The Untouchables," an American Broadcasting Company television network program, defamed the Federal penal system last night.

James J. Smith of J.H. Winchester Co. has been re-elected president of the Association of Ship Brokers and Agents, Inc.
Roger Sessions, the composer, and William Zorach, the sculptor, have been named to receive the 1961 gold medals of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- A Lockheed Electra can fly with only two of its four turbo-drop engines, an engineer testified today at a hearing on an Electra crash in Boston Harbor last October. Sixty-two persons were killed in the crash.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- a tiny microphone patented this week promises householders better remote control over their television sets, garage doors, electric trains, and even dishwashers and cameras.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge of Delray Beach, Fla., gained a three-stroke lead in the Sea Island women's open golf tournament in rainy weather today. She had a first-round par 36, 36 -- 72.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 13 -- The lower house of Parliament approved today the proposed economic reforms that Socialist unions have been trying to defeat by a widespread strike since Dec. 20. Approval by the upper house is considered certain.

I read with amazement the statement of Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel, quoting from the Jewish law of the Taimud that "Whosoever dwells outside of the land of Israel is considered to have no God," and his more recent one that it is the duty of Jews in America to go to Israel.
A new roadblock was thrown yesterday in the path of the Glen Alden Corporation's drive to take over the seventy-five-year-old Endicott Johnson Corporation, the nation's second largest maker of shoes.
Religious programing, following in the footsteps of the entertainment shows, is increasingly going overseas in quest of fresh television fare.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Pennsylvania recovered from a lapse in the opening minutes against Yale tonight and then coasted to a 73-51 basketball victory at the Palestra.

The Manhattan Savings Bank has applied to the State Banking Department to establish a branch at 20 South Moger Avenue, Mount Kisco, N.Y. The application is the first by a Manhattan savings bank under the Omnibus Banking bill, which permits New York City institutions to apply for branches in the Nassau and Westchester County suburbs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 -- The great closing chord of Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," last heard in Communist-ruled Yugoslavia more than twenty years ago, echoed through Belgrade's Kolarcev University Hall last night.

After ignoring the Turkish r tion for six months you have had two editorials during the month, one on Dec. 5 entitled "Progress in Turkey" and one on Jan. entitled "Turkey's Second Republic. Both show a lack of awareness what is really happening in Turkey specifically and, what is more, attitude of mind which accounts some of our difficulty in the work today.
In his year-end summary of the activities of the State Commission Against Discrimination, Chairman Carter has given some interesting views on the changing status of Negroes in the community.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 13 -- An uneasy calm prevailed here today as the Government made plans to resist a major students' strike.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Belgium economic and administrative reform bill provides for tax increases that range from higher death duties and ,automobile levies to greater isocial-security contributions from individuals.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., guest of honor at a performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's "Iolanthe" last night, heard a lyric reference to "moonlighting" from the Village Light Opera Group.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The price of gold, which has been creeping up again on the London bullion market, today headed in the other direction.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 13 -- The expulsion yesterday of the Cuban Ambassador and a Soviet diplomat has sharply defined the political lines in this little democracy, which is considered among South America's most poltically and socially advanced.
Milwaukee County, Wis., is planning the sale of $10,320,000 of sewer bonds due serially from 1962 to 1981. Bids for the issue will be received on Feb. 3.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee could find nothing to quarrel with in Dean Rusk's testimony on Thursday. There was, in fact, reason to take heart and feel greatly encouraged at the thought that President-elect Kennedy has chosen a Secretary of State with so much balance, knowledge and thoughtfulness.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- The Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church gave his support tonight to the Scarsdale rector who had denounced anti-Semitism among his parishioners.

THERE is a story with the luster of probable truth that crops up occasionally in culinary circles. It seems that a bride of several months was visited one morning by a neighbor who noted that the young woman was sawing away at the end of a ham.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley and a Nobel laureate, has been offered a post on the Atomic Energy Commission by the Kennedy Administration, Congressional sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower, bowing to Congressional pressure, has decided the Migratory Bird Conservation Commission and the Indian Arts and Crafts Board can get along without their secrecy stamps.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy, in compliance with a court order, yesterday transferred nineteen more policemen who had been holding higher jobs to posts within their rank.

FONTANA, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Public participation in labor-management contract negotiations in the steel industry was recommended today by a study committee sponsored by the United Steel Workers of America and the Kaiser Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Austin J. Tobin testified today that personal venom, rather than true legislative purpose, had motivated an investigation by a House Judiciary subcommittee into the Port of New York Authority.
BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- If Dick Garmaker and Willie Naulls had received a little more help tonight, the New York Knicker-Bockers might have been able to post their fifth victory in six games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Conference of Republican Senators approved today committee assignments given to party members for this session of Congress, overriding a protest from Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Navy Department denied today the circumstances of the incident involving a Cuban worker at Guantanamo Naval Base, as related in the Cuban press. It issued the following explanation:
A fourth quarterback was added to the New York Giants roster yesterday. He is Jack Moynihan of Holy Cross, the National Football League club's twelfth draft choice.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 -- A Federal Court here today blocked two new attempts by the state to take control of the New Orleans public schools.

Your Jan. 7 editorial titled "Kennedy and the Recession, contains this statement: "Even if an upturn in the current recession comes relatively quickly, the more basic fact of the 'sluggish and tired' behavior of the economy in recent years remains a problem."

In Wall Street railroad analysts tended to give their blessings yesterday to the proposed merger of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, which moved a step closer on Wednesday with the approval of both boards.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Middlebury College set back Army, 11 -- 2, in hockey today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The Justice Department filed fourteen documents today in opposition to the proposed dismissal of an espionage case against a Soviet employe of the United Nations and a German free-lance illustrator.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- A sharp upswing in equity prices marked the last hour of trading in the stock market here today.

Though the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center closes tomorrow night, it made a red-letter occasion of its Tchaikovsky program last night by presenting Violette Verdy in her debut in "Swan Lake."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The White House took exception today to an article in today's New York Times stating that President Eisenhower, on taking office in 1953, turned over control of his investments to Clifford J. Roberts, New York investment banker.
NEW DEIHI, India, Jan. 13 -- This is what New Delhi calls winter, and the Indians are grumbling about it.

For three dress-rehearsal days, the fifty-first National Motor Boat Show has been polishing its wares in anticipation of New York's official inspection. This will begin this morning at 10:30 at the Coliseum on Columbus Circle.
The head of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that Judaism in this country "is uniquely healthy and faces a future of unparalleled promise and hope."
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- The captain and six crewmen were lost today when savage seas destroyed the 400-foot barge Arizona Sword in the Atlantic Ocean ten miles off Palm Beach.
A SEGMENT of the colorful career of Theodore Roosevelt was offered last night on Channel 4 in "The Invincible Teddy."
Aviation widened its lead over shipping last year on the North Atlantic, the world's busiest international travel route.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today that a Federal grand jury at Minneapolis had indicted Benjamin Dranow, former department store owner there, on charges of mail and wire fraud in connection with the 1958 collapse of his company, the John W. Thomas Co. The company went into bankruptcy owing general creditors $984,000.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Scarcely a day passes now without an announcement by some British automobile manufacturer of a new cut in production.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Sam Etcheverry, the Canadian pro football quarterback who signed last night with the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League, said today his Cardinal contract was "legal -- regardless of what they say in Montreal."

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- Garfield Sobers hammered the Australian bowling for a not-out 152 today as the West Indies cricket team built a score of 303 for five wickets on the first day of the third test match.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower presided for the last time today over a meeting of his official family. But when the time came to say good-by to the Cabinet members he choked up and wished them "good luck" instead.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- President de Gaulle has expressed his "entire satisfaction" with the general conduct of the French Army in Algeria before and during the national referendum that approved his liberal Algerian policy.

HAVANA, Jan. 13 -- The position of the United States in regard to its Navy's base at Guantanamo Bay has become "indefensible" before world opinion and the new Kennedy Administration must face that fact, Premier Fidel Castro said tonight.
BARFIELD, N.J., Jan. 13 -- A man and his 4-year-old daughter died early today as fire destroyed their home at 35 Chestnut Street.

Through the years the Citizens Budget Commission, in appearances before the Board of Estimate and the City Council, has been a forthright critic of city administrations, a foe of fiscal waste and a friend of business-like management. The tone at its dinners, attended by many leading city officials as guests, has often been that of a politely armed truce, with hostility threatening to break out at any time between the watched and the civic watchdog.

The price decline in United States Government securities continued yesterday in an inactive trading session. Treasury obligations of both intermediate and long term were affected adversely, with markdowns in quotations ranging from 4/32 to 12/32.

The International Business Machines Corporation recorded the highest gross income and profits for any quarter in its history in the final three months of 1960. The results for the full year also were new records.

A Puerto Rican and an Israeli bank have applied to the State Banking Department to establish branches in New York City under a new law that became effective Jan. 1. The law, enacted at the 1960 session of the Legislature at Albany, permits foreign and Puerto Rican banks to do a deposit business in the state for the first time.
Activity in potato futures increased somewhat yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but price changes were mixed.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 12 -- Six vice presidents were promoted today by the board of State-planters Bank Trust Co. Three were named executive vice presidents -- Carlisle R. Davis for branches, Edward F. Gee for commercial, and I. Burwell Gunn for trusts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Employment conditions became sharply worse in December, the Labor Department reported today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Elvis J. Stahr Jr., 44-year-old president of West Virginia University, was expected tonight to be appointed Secretary of the Army.

BOLOGNA, Italy, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A group of Italian scientists reported that they had achieved human fertilization in a test tube repeatedly and that they had kept one embryo alive for twenty-nine days.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 13 -- An osteopathic physician whose license was suspended after fourteen of his patients died apparently of hepatitis, petitioned the state today to end the suspension immediately.

Ten American-made movies have been chosen as official entries in West Germany's Seventh International Short Film Festival, to be held at Oberhausen Feb. 6 to 11. The United States entries, selected from more than 100 products made during the last year, will compete for honors with approximately 300 candidates from thirty countries.
Tax-exempt issues of state and local governments will dominate an active new capital marker next week. More than $210,000,000 of fixed-interest securities are on the docket.

A year ago, when small investors flocked to participate in a special $1,500,000,000 issue of one-year United States Treasury bills, savings institutions were hard hit by withdrawals. The bills were auctioned at prices to yield about 5.4 per cent at a time when the savings institutions were paying 3 1/2 per cent.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The first mass-production type of machine for extracting fresh water from the sea has been completed, Eleazar Preminger, director general of the Israeli Development Ministry, announced today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 13 -- A bill that would save the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad about $1,000,000 a year in state taxes was introduced in the General Assembly today.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va. Jan. 13 -- Mr. Stahr was appointed president of the University of West Virginia a year ago, after a long and varied career in education, law and the military.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The prelude to the Kennedy Administration has been sweeter on Capitol Hill than the prelude to Lohengrin: All soft fiddle music and soaring melody.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 13 -- A $140,000 winner in the Irish Sweepstakes has donated $10,000 to establish a memorial scholarship at C.W. Post College here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Evidence that the Hiroshima atomic bomb blast caused a four-f01d increase in cancer among survivors exposed to its radiation was reported today by two Japanese scientists.
A group active in Harlem affairs told Mayor Wagner yesterday that it endorsed City Councilman Earl Brown for election as Borough President to succeed Hulan E. Jack.

THE latest Russian import is a pianist named Dimitri Bashkirov. He came quietly, without fanfare into New York to give a concert at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium last night. Slender, black-haired, serious-looking, he is 29 years old and is a Georgian from Tiflis.

After fifteen years of a policy of plunder under which they confiscated the properties not only of their own people but also of foreign citizens, some of the Communist-dominated countries have discovered that this policy does not pay and have started to make amends.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization forecasts ample supplies up to mid-1961 of cocoanut oil and competing fats and oils on the world market. The agency expects prices to remain relatively low probably until next September, and on average, no higher than the 1956-57 level.
HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The fledgling American Football League lost $3,500,000 in its first season, it was estimated tonight.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 13 -- Andre Renard, Socialist leader and a major figure in the Belgian strike, lost one point and won another yesterday on the ever-shifting battle lines that have been drawn over Belgium's proposed economic and administrative reforms.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 13 -- Brazil and the United States signed an extradition treaty today to close Brazil as a refuge for United States fugitives. Three Americans who may be immediately affected by the treaty appeared unconcerned.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Three Asian and African nations gave support today to Soviet charges that Belgium had violated her obligations to the United Nations by permitting Congolese national troops to pass through the trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.
The Transit Authority's stepped-up campaign to make the city subways cleaner and healthier brought 130 persons into Magistrates Court yesterday. They were fined $275, in sums ranging from $1 to $3.
Ten colleges were represented on the All-America first team named yesterday by the National Soccer Coaches Association during its annual convention at the Manhattan Hotel.
BRIDGE books and bridge authorities since time immemorial have agreed on one bidding situation.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A United States jet bomber has eclipsed by hundreds of miles an hour six world speed records. Five were held by the Soviet Union.

Representative Charles Q. Porter of Oregon and Prof. Robert J. Alexander of Rutgers University have written a study called "The Struggle for Democracy in Latin America," in which they discuss the historical background that has brought about dictatorships in the region, the current forces for and against democracy there and the status of the republics and the position of the United States in relation to them.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- Paul Pender, the former fireman from Brookline, Mass., and Terry Downes of London completed light training today and announced their fitness for tomorrow night's world middleweight championship fight at the Boston Arena.

THE Census Bureau will be engaged the next several months in finding out how many hunters and fishermen there are in the United States and where they go and what they spend. There seems to be some fear here and there that the bureau may discover that fewer people are fishing.

Investors took the long view yesterday. Although unemployment in December was reported at 6.8 per cent of the civilian working force, the highest since 1940, and although corporation news remained predominantly unsavory, stock values gained almost one-half of 1 per cent.
ALGIERS, Jan. 13 -- A mood of depression and insecurity is becoming increasingly evident among the European settlers in Algeria.

IF nothing more than "See the conqu'ring hero comes!" and "Oh! had I Jubal's lyre" had resulted from G.F. Handel's setting of the oratorio "Joshua," his effort would have been worthwhile for us, if not for him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The nation's broadcasting industry must not create a false impression of America, Leroy Collins, former Governor of Florida, warned tonight.
ASTORIA, Ore., Jan. 13 (UPI) Gale winds and thirty-foot waves turned an attempted rescue into a tragedy today. Seven men were lost and four boats were wrecked.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended Jan. 10, at 119.8 per cent of the 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor statistics announced today.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Eighty gentlemen, ranging in age from the early 20's to the late 70's, are participating in their favorite sport at the St. Andrew's Golf Club here. But the game isn't golf; it's curling, a form of competition developed on the frozen ponds of Scotland many years ago.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 13 -- Federal District Judge William A. Bootle directed University of Georgia officials today to reinstate the institution's first Negro students.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The head of a Royal Laotian Army column advancing into north-central Laos has reached a point three miles south of the key rebel city of Xiengkhouang, a Government spokesman said today.

The nation's current strategic concept is keyed to a target list that includes Soviet cities as well as missile sites and air bases. It is a blend of the two clashing doctrines in Washington -- the Air Force "counterforce-preemptive" war concept and the Navy-Army "finite-deterrent" theory.
It was announced several days ago that New York State is out in front with new road mileage for 1960. This they say includes the New York Thruway. I suppose it also takes in the Northway.

Group Securities, Inc., announced yesterday that it was mailing to stockholders proxy material covering the proposed merger of twelve of its single-industry mutual funds into the company's common stock fund. At the same time, two specialized bond funds are to be moved into the General Bond Fund.
ERIC HEIDSIECK, a 24-year-old French pianist who rightfully bears a distinguished name in the field of champagnes, made his New York debut last night with a recital in Town Hall.
The city's Protestant clergy have been asked to preach on "the evils of gambling" a week from tomorrow as part of a new drive against efforts of Mayor Wagner to legalize off-track betting.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 13 -- Dartmouth defeated Cornell, 65 -- 51 in a poorly played basketball game before 1,200 fans in Alumni Gymnasium tonight.
WHATEVER objections may be made to contemporary art no one can possibly complain about its lack of variety, especially in a crowded week of exhibitions such as this one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The United States Air Force announced tonight it had detected an object with missile characteristics coming out of the Soviet Union and heading in the direction of the Pacific Ocean. There was a possibility the Russians might be attempting another space feat.

BUTTERFLY aficionados -- and there are more of them than one might think -- have a rare opportunity to indulge their particular passion to the fullest. For the next two weeks, Stern's will feature butterflies in almost every phase of fashion and home furnishings.

The pursuit of culture has always been evident in this city despite compelling pressures of various kinds. When the Harmonical Society in 1797 asked the Common Council for the use of "the lower back room" of the City Hall the privilege was granted, "provided they can incommodate with the Court for the Trial of Causes of Ten Pounds Under."

Your correspondent Saranne Rosner asks in a letter published Jan. 5 why all the tremendous expense of space exploration when there are so many fearful problems on this planet that are crying out for financial aid.

Max N. Hurwitz, realty investor, has sold properties containing thirteen buildings in Manhattan in a package deal with investors. The parcels are assessed for a total of $800,000 and have been acquired by clients of J. Stanley Shaw.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- There are now at least 15,000 political prisoners in Cuba, according to information that recently reached here from Cuba.
HOUSTON, Jan. 13 -- The International Maritime Workers Union withdrew today a picket line that had immobilized an American-owned Liberian-flag freighter in this port since Dec. 28.

Ronnie Bliey of Tilden, who led the Public Schools Athletic League in scoring with 138 points last season, was named this week to Scholastic Magazines' tenth annual all-America high school football squad.

Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club, seeded first, defeated Harry Yerkes of the host club, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 8, in the third round of the New York State squash racquets singles championship at the Downtown A.C. yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 -- Minister of Justice Pinhas Rosen said today that he had appealed recently to Premier David Ben-Gurion to end the crisis over the Lavon affair.
Two discussion groups for parents of infants and young children will begin later this month at the Child Study Association of America, 9 East Eighty-ninth Street.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Stan Leonard of Vancouver, B.C., shot a six-under-par 65 today and tied Al Balding of Toronto and Eric Monti of Los Angeles for the lead at the half-way mark of the $20,000 San Diego open golf tournament.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Marion S. Boyd continued indefinitely today a temporary restraining order outlawing evictions of tenant sharecroppers in near-by Fayette County.
The death of Samuel Levitas, editor of The New Leader, inspires a word of tribute to the memory of an outstanding editor.
" LAMENT FOR BARNEY STONE," by Robert Glynn Kelly, is an American college novel about a lonely scholar who stoops to folly.
A union cannot take disciplinary action against a member without a full hearing on the charges, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A bill to preserve Hamilton Grange -- the private home of Alexander Hamilton -- as a national monument was introduced today by Senators Jacob K. Javits and Kenneth B. Keating of New York.

Mr. Khrushchev's anger is understandable. Here he has been going all around the world singing the praises of everything Soviet to all who would listen. Now he is faced with the fact that Soviet agriculture has performed unsatisfactorily for two years in a row. Since he cannot admit that an efficient agriculture and Communist ideology are incompatible, he must find scapegoats and that is what he has been doing these past few days.

Last night was New Year's Eve according to the Julian calendar, and members of the Russian colony in New York and their friends made merry in the tradition of old Russia at the Bal Blanc at the St. Regis.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Art Hyland and Al Kaemmerlen, both sophomores, scored 19 points each in sparking Princeton to a 71-60 Ivy League victory over Brown in Dillon Gym tonight. The triumph gave Princeton sole possession of first place in the league.

VIENNA, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Reinhard Kamitz, president of the Austrian National Bank, warned the Government coalition parties last night that their financial and economic policies threatened the stability of the schilling, the national-currency unit.

MIAMI, Jan. 13 -- Exile sources here said today that military resistance to Premier Fidel Castro inside Cuba was growing rapidly. Two organizations made public photographs, which they said had just come from Cuba, showing heavily armed groups of anti-Castro rebels.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 13 -- Europeans and Congolese opposed to Patrice Lumumba, the deposed Premier, fled in near panic today following rumors that he had been freed from imprisonment. The rumors were officially denied later.

The two-story factory building at 1205 Southern Boulevard, near Freeman Street, the Bronx, has been leased by William Dancik to the Scafati Printing Company. It contains 11,000 square feet of space and will be altered for the manufacture of imprinted novelties.

TUNIS, Jan. 13 -- The Algerian rebel Provisional Government was reported today to be considering the "advisability" of issuing a "constructive communique" reaffirming readiness to negotiate guarantees of self-determination as a means of ending the six-year-old war in Algeria.

The election and installation of Captain James R. Ross, marine surveyor for the Insurance Company of North America, as commodore of the Rudder Club was announced yesterday. The Club is a social organization of men in the maritime industry.
A shortage of coins last summer, which became more acute before Christmas, has caused the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to resort to rationing pennies, nickels and quarters.
The Phillips Oilers rallied to defeat the New York Tuck Tapers in a National Industrial Basketball League overtime game, 92 -- 90, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
The woman owner of a gun shop drew a revolver on two teen-age boys yesterday as they were about to flee with two companions who had stolen a pistol from the shop.
The American Hospital Supply Corporation, Chicago, announced yesterday that it was negotiating the acquisition of Bruck's Nurses Outfitting Company, Inc., of this city.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A slim but lively field of seven 4-year-olds, headed by Tompion and T.V. Lark, were entered today for tomorrow's $50,000-added San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita.
AS the second conductor to fill the engagement with the New York Philharmonic left vacant by the death of Dimitri Mitropoulos, Paul Paray led the orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- House Republican leaders shied away today from taking a stand on Speaker Sam Rayburn's plan to liberalize the Rules Committee.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 12 -- A team of scientists here has discovered that dead viruses can be brought back to life by other viruses, just as dead but killed in a different way.

Representatives of the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York conferred yesterday with city officials on the commission's proposals for management of the city's long-term debt.
Official hearings on the Dec. 16 airliner collision here were adjourned yesterday after a bitter attack by United Air Lines on the nation's system for controlling air traffic.

ANY item that helps the busy homemaker to save time and steps is worth investigating today. Two such aids have just arrived at Gimbels. One is a loose-leaf notebook containing envelopes for canceled checks. Made of simulated brown leather, it sells for $1 in this store's stationery department.
Maj. Ernesto Guevara, president of the Cuban National Bank, reported in a speech last week some unusual steps the Communist bloc had agreed to take to insure the economic survival of Cuba.
Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Don Giovanni," at 2 P.M. and "Manon Lescaut," at 8 P.M.; Concert for Children, New York College of Music, 3:30; Lise Schneider, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30.
Efforts to end the four-day-old harbor strike made no headway yesterday, and the likelihood was that the tie-up would last through the week-end at least.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 13 -- President Romulo Betancourt, in a closed session talk at the annual convention of Venezuela's Democratic Action party, said today that all unassigned oil reserves would go to the state-owned Venezuelan Petroleum Corporation and that no further private concessions would be given out.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution laid before the Security Council today by Ceylon, Liberia and the United Arab Republic of the question of Ruanda-Urundi:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved without objection today President-elect John F. Kennedy's selection of his brother Robert as Attorney General.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points up on near March, but unchanged to 14 off on other months yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
HOUSTON, Jan. 13 -- Albert E. Hart Jr. of Cedarhurst, L.I., was re-elected president of the American Horse Shows Association at its forty-fourth annual meeting today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev has turned his ire about Soviet agricultural shortcomings to pig production, the Moscow press reported today.
Forty-one city departments have filed 1961-62 budget requests totaling $47,199,239, an increase of $5,076,515 over their 1960-61 allocations, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13 -- The Harvard basketball team took an early lead and went on to defeat Columbia, 67 -- 61 tonight. It was the Crimson's first Ivy League triumph against two losses.

The Squadron A polo team defeated Fairfield, 10 -- 4, last night in the first game of the Al Parsells Memorial nine-goal tournament at the Squadron A Armory. Dave Rizzo scored five goals and Allen Jerkens four for the victors.
Repairs were completed last night on a broken section of cast iron pipe that had burst, pouring millions of gallons of water into the IND Eighth Avenue subway on Thursday.

Top officials of organized labor in the state and city pledged their support yesterday to Michael H. Prendergast and Carmine G. De Sapio, the Democratic leaders who are under attack from reform elements in the party.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Alcoa Steamship Company, Inc., is withdrawing from the United States Atlantic and Gulf-Puerto Rico Conference, effective Feb. 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet Union has surprised Western governments by denying any connection with the airlift of military supplies to the Leftist rebels in Laos.

The producer of "Rhinoceros" changed his mind again yesterday. Having evidently decided that the curiosity gambit was still best, Leo Kerz announced that he would not reprint any of the play's reviews as advertising.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The world champion high jumper, a 39-year-old college freshman, two Yale seniors and a stubby dash man are expected to highlight the thirty-third Knights of Columbus track meet tomorrow night at the Garden.

The production of the first three acts of Shakespeare's "Richard II" over Channel 5 inaugurates a dramatic series unusual in its scope and subject-matter. During the next fifteen weeks the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will present Shakespeare's chronicle plays, eight plays that range almost a century in time and encompass the fates of seven English monarchs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- In its first general advance of the week, the grain futures market today recovered about half the losses accumulated over the four previous sessions.

Don Newcombe, the strapping and quick-tempered pitcher, will rejoin the Dodgers this spring.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Two attacks on imports from low-wage countries came today from labor and industry.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Art Hicks and Hank Gunter paced Seton Hall to a 93-85 basketball victory over St. Peter's last night. The victory broke the Pirates' three-game losing streak and made their record for the season 7 -- 5.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 13 -- Danish political leaders expressed hope today that the new Administration in the United States would change what they characterized as the protectionist policy of the United States in trade and shipping.
If ever there were a dependable man with a harpsichord, it should be Ralph Kirkpatrick. Yet his Carnegie Recital Hall program last night was full of un-Kirkpatricklike eccentricities.
Israel has begun a new five-year plan to increase its role as a copper producer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today notified American Telephone and Telegraph Company it could go ahead with its proposed new interstate flat rate "wide area telephone service," to be known as WATS, effective this Sunday, Jan. 15.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 13 -- An increase in industrial employment in this area in the next six months was forecast today by the Stamford-Greenwich Management Council.

The New York State Teachers Retirement System has made a commitment for a $5,500,000 first mortgage loan on a twenty-story and penthouse apartment building being constructed by the Louis J. Glickman Corporation at the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Twelfth Street.

A FAITHFUL translation is rare; a translation which preserves intact the original text is very rare; a perfect translation of Montaigne appears impossible. Yet Donald Frame has realized this feat. One does not seem to be reading a translation, so smooth and easy is the style; at each moment, one seems to be listening to Montaigne himself -- the freshness of his ideas, the unexpected choice of words.

CURTIS CATE, in his articles on French literary prizes, makes one extraordinary statement. He write, "In 1903, when the literary dandies, Jules and Edmond de Goncourt decided to establish an annual prize, etc." In 1903, Jules had been dead for thirty-three years and his elder brother for seven.

THE idea that a respectable American educational institution can risk a flier in art is hardly new. College and university museums are numerous and the senior dean of the group by tenure, the Yale University Art Gallery, is about to wind up its thirteenth decade, if arithmetic serves.

The historical novelist, operating under a freer license, can soon suggest why the surviving record is so spotty.

President-elect John F. Kennedy's re-discovery of the professors has momentarily obscured the fact that the universities are already deeply involved in the affairs of the nation. The two top figures in Soviet basketball, Nikolai Semashko and Stepan Spandaryan, are being made the scapegoats for the Soviet failure to win the Olympic basketball championship at Rome last summer.
Department store sales in the nation in the holiday week ended Jan. 7 fell 11 per cent from the year-ago level, the Federal Reserve has reported. There was no holiday in the comparable 1959 week.

The Army Engineers have many and varied responsibilities in New York harbor. These include dredging and maintaining channels; controlling structures built in, over and under navigable waterways; keeping the port free of floating debris; guarding against pollution and dumping in the waterways; studying the shoaling problem and removing obstructions and wrecks.

ON the day after the election, Robert K. Gray, secretary to the Cabinet, walking along the corridor of the White House executive offices, almost tripped over some paint buckets deserted by workmen for a coffee break. "Look," he said to his companion, "they're holding up our job on the inside while Jackie Kennedy tries to decide what color she wants on the outside."

LUKEVILLE, Ariz. -- This obscure, sun-filled corner of the southwestern desert country harbors no sleek hotels, swimming pools or comfortable dude ranches, as do the well-known Arizona resort cities of Tucson and Phoenix.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower is sure of receving at least $20,000 a year from the Federal Government when he leaves the White House, whether as a former President or a reinstated five-star General of the Army.

BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 14 -- Mr. Hernstadt denied tonight that he was a convert from Judaism, as had been suggested. He said that his father, who is Jewish, and his mother, who is a Roman Catholic, had brought their children up without affiliation, leaving them to choose their religion "when we were old enough and wise enough."

SOCIAL life is not inherited through the genes. It is a human creation, indeed, the supreme human creation. In the course of pre-historic time two features of group life became extraordinarily widespread. They were: the taboos on murder and on incestuous sexual relations within the kin or intimate group.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- With the expected departure soon of Ambassador Douglas MacArthur 2d as a new Administration takes office in Washington, the United States will close a critical phase in its post-war relations with Japan.

HONG KONG, Jan. 14 -- Communist China was somber during the transition from the old to the new year. This mood was in striking contrast with the exuberant claims and grandiose plans marking the transitions in the past.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 14 -- King Baudouin I received a delegation of Walloon Socialists today in their appeal for constitutional changes to give the French-speaking southern part of Belgium an influence equal to the Flemish north.
CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- The Ministry of Justice published today proposals for ten major changes in Egyptian marriage and divorce laws.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Grand Wizard, a 5-year-old gelding from the Argonne Stable, more than justified his heavy backing today by racing to a three-length victory in the $5,000 Marriage Purse at the Fair Grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- For the fifth consecutive year a birthday of the 104-year-old Academy of Music will be celebrated with a star-studded concert, gala champagne supper and ball. The celebration will be held next Saturday.
HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Cuba has called upon all Christians in the country to form a united front in fighting communism.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- President de Gaulle has obtained another blank check from the French electorate in the referendum on his Algerian policy last Sunday. But there are probably not more than half a dozen men inside and outside the Government who can predict with any accuracy how he will fill out the check, let alone whether he can cash it.

THIS story makes rather an interesting beginning in its description of a cave-dwelling boy and his family. It soon disintegrates, however, into a mild little adventure story which provides scant prehistoric information and practically no excitement.

The aluminum industry has always prided itself on growth. In short, the aluminum industry enters 1961 saddled with the same basic problem as that facing steel, oil, paper, copper and many other industries -- there is just too much of the stuff around.

William A. Carroll, former United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York who had earlier served six terms in the City Council, died yesterday morning at his home, 510 East Twentieth Street. He was 71 years old.

The Chris-Craft Corporation of Pompano Beach, Fla., the world's largest builder of stock motor boats, is showing five wooden inboard boats. They range from a 41-foot Conqueror to a 17-foot open utility ski boat, produced by three different corporate divisions.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Five second-period goals, including four by Doug Davis, powered Princeton's hockey team to a 6-1 victory over Cornell today. The victory raised the Tigers' Ivy League record to 3-0. Cornell, unable to beat an Ivy team since entering the league three years and twenty-seven games ago, is 0-4.

ROME, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Pope John XXIII urged today that social workers intensify their assistance to the needy in a changing world. President Eisenhower has wisely moved to plug a potentially serious leak in our gold supplies by prohibiting the purchase abroad of gold by Americans and American enterprises, and by prohibiting their ownership of gold abroad after May 31. Such a ban might have been justified long ago simply on the ground of equity, since ownership or purchase ofgold in this country, except for dental, jewelry, and similar purposes, has been prohibited since 1933.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- The parents of a debutante who withdrew from a ball because her escort had been rejected as "Jewish" today praised their rector for his condemnation of the rejection.

BOSTON, Jan 14 (UPI) -- George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party, was stoned by a crowd and rescued by the police today as he attempted to picket a movie based on Jewish emigration to Israel.
An Air Force radar tower with twenty-seven men aboard collapsed under gale winds and high waves and sank eighty miles southeast of here last night.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- At 30 years of age and after three retirements, Paul Pender appears to have a bright fistic future. At 24, Terry Downes of England may have seen his better days in the ring.

At a time when few people care to tour that troubled continent, a young New York art teacher and his wife are packing for a year's visit to Africa to study painting and sculpture.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 14 -- A month from today South Africa will change its unit of currency in still another step to divorce itself from British characteristics and establish an independent national personality.
A concert given for the benefit of the America-Israel Foundation was played in Carnegie Hall last night by Benno and Sylvia Rabinof, a violin and piano team.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 15 -- Pro-Communist forces have seized the initiative again in the Laotian civil war. The rout of royal troops from the Ta Viang staging area appears today to represent a major setback for Government plans for a counter-offensive.

"Black Monday's" stage potential will be gauged by the reaction to this week's video showing on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13. SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Two Olympic skaters, Arnold Uhrlass of Yonkers and Jeanne Ashworth of Wilmington, Mass., easily won the Eastern States outdoor speed-skating titles today.
The Rev. Dr. Lawrence L. Durgin declared yesterday that the United States was doing less than it should for less-fortunate nations.

The first New York performances of three compositions by Alfred Heller and two by Eda Rapoport were given in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Jan. 15 -- A proposal was made here today by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen to lend the Long Island Rail Road $250,000 for up to one year.
CAIRO, Jan. 15 -- As part of its drive to win influence in Africa, the United Arab Republic plans to exploit Cairo's considerable resources in Moslem teaching and culture.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 15 -- James M. Ethridge 3d and Carlton Badger of the Field Club of Greenwich won the Greenwich Country Club invitation squash racquets doubles tournament today for the third successive year. It was their eighth triumph in nine year.

Formation of a new five-member committee of economic advisers to the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce was announced over the week-end by Ralph T. Reed, council chairman. Mr. Reed is president of the American Express Company.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 15 -- Emilio Pucci, a designer who has invented some of the most practical, fashionable and functional sports clothes of the decade, did an about face today. His mannequins came down the runway in ruffled day dresses worn with poke bonnets, pink stockings and open -toed, sling-back pumps.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The New York Rangers, striving desperately for a station they enjoyed long ago in the National Hockey League, regained a bit of that lost prestige tonight by beating the Black Hawks, 3 -- 1.
United States distance runners had better start hustling or resign themselves to permanent second-class citizenship in their field.
A sixteen-story office building will be constructed at the southwest comer of Church and Murray Streets on a site that once formed part of a land grant by King George III to Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Republican women will open a fund-raising drive this week.

Thomas S. Gates Jr., who retires as Secretary of Defense on Friday, first went to Washington more than seven years ago as Under Secretary of the Navy. He has lived up to the highest traditions of the business man in government.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 15 -- Members of the United Nations Conciliation Commission said today they planned early consultations with Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier.

MERRICK, L.I., Jan. 13 -- Two teen-agers broke down the front door of a burning house early this morning and saved Augustus B. Weller, chairman of the board of the Meadow Brook National Bank, and his wife.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta moved one stroke ahead of Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge on the front nine, then matched her stroke for stroke on the back nine today and won the Sea Island golf tournament.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek's ruling Kuomintang (Nationalist party) scored an impressive victory in local elections throughout this Nationalist Chinese island yesterday.

Some commuters in Pennsylvania have taken things into their own hands. That is, they are trying to take a railroad into their own hands. The group involved is the Lehigh Valley Passengers and Shippers Association.
