The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said over the week-end that it had the world's largest private telephone system.

Twentieth Century-Fox, which developed CinemaScope, one of the wide-screen filming processes in use today, announced yesterday that it had developed an improved movie-projection system known as Grandeur 70.

Chester A. Allen, chairman of the Kings County Trust Company, Brooklyn, one of the few remaining wholesale banks, told stockholders attending the annual meeting yesterday that the bank was looking for acquisitions, preferably in Nassau County, so that it could enter the retail banking business.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The British Government announced today that its twenty-six airports operated at a loss of 5,520,100 ($15,456,296.80) in the 1959-1960 fiscal year.

TUNIS, Jan. 16 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government announced today its readiness "to begin negotiations with the French Government on conditions of a free consultation of the Algerian people." "Free consultation" was taken to mean a referendum to determine Algeria's political future.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower sent his final and biggest budget to Congress today. As presented, it was in balance, but events were already moving to change the outlook.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- The Harvard hockey team tonight placed another rival on its defeated list by downing Boston University, 6 to 4.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The Comedie Francaise primed tonight for its forthcoming American tour with a new production of Racine's "Britannicus."
ROME, Jan. 16 -- Four prelates, one of them an American, were elevated to the Sacred College of Cardinals today by Pope John XXIII.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court made it a little easier today for companies to bring treble damage suits under the antitrust laws on allegations of unfair competition. This was done through a unanimous decision holding that there need not be a showing of general injury to the public at large to sustain such suits. The decision reversed lower court rulings.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A South Carolina attorney sought in Federal Court today to have a group of children known as "Turks" admitted to white elementary schools in Sumter County, S.C.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 16 -- The San Juan Drama Festival will resume tomorrow with "On Borrowed Time," starring Boris Karloff. The resumption will be based on an agreement reached today by Actors Equity, Barry Yellen, the producer, and the Puerto Rican Association of Television Artists and Technicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth spurned today a suggestion that a unit of a proposed cultural center here be adopted as a memorial for her father, President Theodore Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs declined in today's sale of $1,500,000,000 of three-month and six-month bills. The new issues will replace $1,400,000,000 of bills maturing this week and provide $100,000,000 of new cash.

The board of directors of the Southern Company raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 37 1/2 cents a share yesterday. The company also reported that earnings in 1960 reached a record $46,100,000.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Seaborg does not match the layman's idea of an ivory tower scentist. He is gregarious, lanky, even rugged. He has mastered golf and half a dozen other sports and has the art of getting along with people.

The preferred and common stocks of the United Industrial Corporation were suspended from trading yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the company announced it had accepted the resignations of its president, Bernard F. Gira, and executive vice president, Herbert J. Petersen.

Everybody in the copper industry seems to be certain that the price of the metal is headed downward, but it has been slow coming about. Late last week custom smelters, the men who refine scrap and purchased ores, cut their price to 29 cents a pound, from 30, and that is usually the signal for a general reduction.

Plans were announced yesterday for a twenty-five-story office building at the southeast corner of Forty-eighth Street and the Avenue of the Americas. It will be built jointly by Dworman Associates and the Cooper-Bregstein Realty Company, investment builders.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 16 -- Two demonstrators were wounded by police gunfire during a battle today in an industrial suburb of Liege.

Tri-Continental Corporation's share value declined about 1 per cent last year but investment income was the highest on record, Francis F. Randolph, chairman, and Fred E. Brown, president, advised stockholders in the annual report mailed yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold refused tonight to recall his personal representative in the Congo, Rajeshwar Dayal of India.
An information network for channeling prospective realty deals to a New York real estate investment concern has been set up among ninety brokers in all parts of the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- A Christmas card sent in 1935 by John F. Kennedy -- who will be inaugurated Friday -- and his two Princeton university roommates is reproduced on the cover of the current issue of the Princeton Alumni Weekly.
Westchester and Connecticut commuters had a choice today of driving to work or using combinations of cars, buses and subways if the trains did not run because of picketing by harbor strikers.

MANILA, Jan. 16 -- Major powers have been deliberately left out of consultations scheduled among seven Asian nations on the deteriorating situation in Laos. The first of the talks are to be held Wednesday.
Commodity prices on the New York Exchanges generally fell yesterday in light trading.

Persons involved in the presentation of Jackie Gleason's new comedy panel television show, "You're in the Picture," indicated yesterday they did not know who would be in the picture when the program makes its debut Friday evening.

An account of the Montana cattle industry, from the earliest days of the fur traders to the latest Miles City Roundup, will be published Feb. 15 by the University Publishers. Called "Free Grass to Fences," it has been written by Robert H. Fletcher, the author of the original version of "Don't Fence Me In."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Hilaria, a fifty-five foot yawl owned by Hugh Schadelee of Fort Lauderdale, was reported leading twenty other racing yachts tonight as they rounded Key West into the last half of the 403-mile St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale race.
Thousands of pleasure-boat lovers and thousands of neophytes who would like to become skippers attended the National Motor Boat Show at the New York Coliseum yesterday.
THE annual three-city, four-team match played by the Cavendish Clubs of Boston, Philadelphia and New York and the Regency Club of New York will be held here Jan. 27 and 28.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Labor's radical Left Wing called on President-elect John F. Kennedy today to heed Richard H.S. Crossman rather than Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, on the party's policy on defense and foreign affairs.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru inaugurated today what is believed to the largest nuclear reactor in Asia at Trombay, twenty miles from Bombay. The project was said to have cost the equivalent of $21,000,000, with the assistance of Canada.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- President-elect John F. Kennedy has assured House investigators that he will give prompt attention to their request for foreign aid documents President Eisenhower has refused to turn over to them.
Events tonight: "Simon Boccanegra," Metropolitan Opera, "The Mikado," City Center, 2:15; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Clarion Concerts, Newell Jenkins, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Despite the Government's export drive, British sales in foreign markets fell markedly last month.
Franz Josef Strauss, West German Defense Minister, called last night for development of an "Atlantic consciousness" to make the North Atlantic Treaty Organization more than a mere military alliance.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- Retail sales of domestic cars totaled 104,768 units during the first ten days of January, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a statistical concern.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan received a suspended prison sentence of one year yesterday on his conviction for letting a contractor pay $4,400 for remodeling his apartment. The sentencing automatically removed him from his $25,000-a-year position.
A donation to the Neediest Cases Fund came yesterday from Morristown, N.J., in honor of the coming birthday of the donor's father.

EACH year about this time when the motor boat show calls all hands to the Coliseum Altman's turns its attention to sailing enthusiasts. This year the store has assembled in its third-floor vacation shop, a splendid assortment of apparel to wear aboard anything from the smallest skiff to the biggest yacht.
Texas Tower radar stations, designed to sight missiles or aircraft, are $21,000,000 manmade islands perched incongruously above the sea on three steel stilts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A State Department spokesman described as incorrect today a report in The New York Times today that the North Atlantic Council was discussing a possible cut in United States forces in the course of a review of strategic concepts.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Denison Mines, Ltd., had net profit of $10,473,685, or $2.34 a share, in the period from March 24 to Dec. 31, 1960 following the amalgamation of Consolidated Denison Mines, Ltd., and Can-Met Explorations, Ltd.

BOOM! Zoom! Wacka Donk, Clunk, Thud! The Manhattan Percussion Ensemble capped and rapped its collective way into Town Hall last night with a program of pure percussion pyrotechnics and poetry under the expert beat of Paul Price.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Ten members of two neighboring families were felled by carbon monoxide poisoning yesterday and today, one of them fatally.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer of Manhattan was named to the Appellate Division in the First Department today by Governor Rockefeller.
New York City's 731 Civil Defense air raid sirens will be tested at 11 A.M. tomorrow.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A pier at the Naval Base here was heavily damaged by fire today, and the Navy said six men were unaccounted for when the fire was brought under control.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The State Senate approved the annual budget deficiency bill tonight over Democratic opposition. The measure will raise the 1960-61 state budget by $24,000,000, bringing the total to $2,144,000,000.
St. Louis, Mo., is planning to raise $15,802,000 in the bond market to finance public improvements. The sale will take place on Feb. 15. The bonds will come due serially from 1963 to 1981.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. (UPI) -- Dr. Arthur L. Miller, Director of the Federal Office of Saline Water, said today that America's rising population would force more than 1,000 cities to convert salt and brackish water for drinking purposes within the next ten years.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it had received the first allocation of radio frequencies to private industry for experiments in bouncing signals off the moon and man-made satellites.
A.M. Sonnabend, Boston financier, and his associate, Arnold A. Saltzman, this week are expetced to be elected chairman and president, respectively, of the Seagrave Corporation.
A curator's long memory and acute eye led to the recent acquisition of two treasures by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A private examination of the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public today by the Bureau of the Budget, concludes that the commission "is, in general, performing its mission in a thoroughly effective manner."
Hope vanished last night for men believed to have tapped out a rescue call from the sunken hulk of an Air Force radar tower seventy miles south of Long Island.
The Eisenhower Administration has authorized the Navy to install Polaris ballistic missiles aboard the nuclear-powered cruiser Long Beach.

Hulan E. Jack lost his office of Borough President of Manhattan yesterday, but not his liberty. General Sessions Judge Joseph A. Sarafite, by suspending a jail term imposed for violation of the City Charter and conspiracy to obstruct justice, said in effect that Mr. Jack had suffered enough, a judgment in which we concur. The judge's mercy did not extend to his remarks from the bench condemning a betrayal of trust in public office.
Traditional prayers for the reunion of Christendom will be offered over the world this week by Protestants, Roman Catholics and members of the Eastern Orthodox churches.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- Capt. Arthur Chisholm scored three goals for Northeastern tonight as the Huskies defeated Dartmouth, 6-3, in a hockey game at the Arena.
A group of athletic trainers learned yesterday how to give first aid to an injured id.

Arc-120, a new film projection system designed to provide theatres of various sizes with a curved 120-degree angle screen, received its Western Hemisphere unveiling Friday at the Mar Del Plata Film Festival in Argentina.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will spend $305,000,000 this year for expansion.

The storm that brought gale winds to near-by coastal areas and snow to much of the northeast Sunday and yesterday morning tapered off later and left the city with only two inches of snow. Slush-spattered residents were irked rather than upset.
AN original drama on a contemporary theme is so distressingly rare on television that "The Play of the Week" is entitled to a suitable palm for keeping the medium's front door ajar.

The young man of the house is now back at school, presumably studying. Indeed, by now he may be well into his first semester's final examinations, so one hopes he studied when his winter holiday was over. One hopes, because it was obvious he did not study while he was home.
Municipal and voluntary hospitals today will lose the foreign-educated staff physicians who failed a recent examination. The hospitals are adjusting their programs to continue to meet patient needs.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Three of the five major auto companies may trim their January production even more than had been anticipated, the midmonth figures indicated today.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Dr. Edith Summerskill, who was named a life peeress by Queen Elizabeth II today, is a slender, striking woman who has dedicated more than two-thirds of her fifty-nine years to the proposition that a woman's place is not in the home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 3, today that a railway union was entitled to the casing of an anti-union-shop agreement with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad now that he Railway Labor Act allows a union shop.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy's physicians have declared him to be in "superb physical condition," an article in a medical magazine reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The Bureau of Public Roads reported today "a definite indication" that heavier truck-trailers should be paying a larger share of the cost of building Federally aided highways.

The price slide that had been going on in United States Government securities since the turn of the year continued yesterday. The further setback was influential in bringing a halt to the price rise in high-grade corporate bonds of recent issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower's retirement to private life Friday prompted his recollection today that he was "almost completely ignorant of party politics" when he decided to seek the Presidency in 1952.
The refusal of an eleven-member ship conference to round out its membership to an even dozen has led to a $45,000 reparations suit against the North Brazil/United States-Canada Freight Conference.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 16 -- The Louisiana Legislature opened a fourth special session today and immediately adjourned until Feb. 13, the day before the session is set to end. However, segregation leaders predicted the legislators would be back earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Output of the nation's mines, mills and factories dropped in December for the fourth time in five months, reaching its lowest level since the crippling 1959 steel strike, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A system of compensating sales executives by permitting them to keep all of their profits after sharing a predetermined minimum of commissions with the broker has been instituted by a New Jersey real estate agency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The House passed today a bill to exempt tickets to President-elect John F. Kennedy's inaugural parade and ball from the 10 per cent amusement tax.

Maintaining, as is our purpose, private initiative in looking ahead to meet the changes that are taking place, there must be some point where private industry will encourage the Government to meet situations, especially when we think of the necessity of protecting our exports in competition with Russia and other Iron Curtain countries.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Opposition to downgrading New York City's Borough Presidents began developing tonight as the Legislature formally received the Moore Commissions Charter-revision recommendations.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The 1961 season at Stratford will be composed of a quartet of Shakespeare's tragedies and two of the major comedies.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- South African gold-mining shares were in strong demand on the stock market heer today -- the first day of trading after issuance by Washington of a decree that United States citizens must sell any gold, or gold certificates, held abroad.

Those bowling alleys in Dallas, the boat company at Henderson, Tex.; the motel outside Joplin, Mo., and the ore mine near Albquerque, N.M., have been pushed into the background. From now on, baseball is to be Mickey Mantle's primary concern, chief interest and main source of revenue.

PORT-AU-PRINCE Haiti, Jan. 16 -- An overwhelming majority of the 1,000 Haiti University students peacefully but effectively boycotted the reopening of classes today despite last-minute appeals and concession from the Government.
The Theatre Guild has taken an option on Brendan Behan's latest play, "Richard's Cork Leg," and plans to put it on Broadway early next season.

The decade of the Sixties will pit the Communist nations against the democracies in a struggle for the friendship of the newly developing former colonial countries, Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said last night.

A statement was issued yesterday clarifying a discussion Communist China by a greet of delegates to the second "Conference to Plan a Strategy Peace." The conference held Sunday at Columbia University's Arden House near Harriman, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Soybean futures today added their broadest net gains for a single day in the current bullish trend and carried above $2.50 a bushel for all old crop contracts except one.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 16 -- An English taxicab with a meter and a "For Hire" sign is running around town these days -- but with no prospects of attracting paying customers.
Ingemar Johansson arrived at Idlewild Airport last night, and said he was ready to start "hard training" for his rematch with Floyd Patterson.

HAVANA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The restrictions on travel of United States citizens to Cuba is likely to curb the efforts of the Cuban Government to organize active support in the United States as it has in some parts of Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee said today that the slogan "peaceful coexistence" was serving to cover likely new Communist aggressive moves.
The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday authorized the Delaware Realty and Investment Company to merge with the Christiana Securities Company, the nation's largest investment company.

The recent announcement by the Chinese authorities that the seasonal conditions experienced during the past year had been the severest recorded in 100 years, and that these followed extensive disasters during the previous year, was a most unusual occurrence.
ROME, Jan. 16 -- A Trans World Airlines super-Constellation that left New York Saturday touched down on a runway near Fiumicino at 12:15 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Inaugural Week was started here tonight -- by the Republicans.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 -- The Phillips Petroleum Company was under a Federal Court order today not to acquire more common stock of the Union Oil Company of California.
More New York Stock Exchange issues rose than fell yesterday but the market surrendered its gains in the final thirty minutes of trading and closed with a tiny loss.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 16 -- Restoration of crude oil prices to the level prevailing before cuts were made last year and machinery to regulate production were cited by President Romulo Betancourt as the principal aims of the second conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which he officially opened here today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Adele L. Rand's Bourbon Prince, under a fine ride by Bobby Ussery, won the $61,400 Tropical Park Handicap on the closing-day program today.
Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries showed "satisfactory increases" in 1960 revenue and production figures over the 1959 totals, according to a preliminary report released yesterday.

The budget which President Eisenhower sent to Congress yesterday covers a period which will not begin until five and a half months from now and will not end until a year later. Even under normal circumstances, therefore, the budget thus presented has many imponderables and uncertainties surrounding it.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 16 -- Two Negroes attended classes without incident today at the University of Georgia. Their re-entry marked the second day of desegregation in the state's public education system.
Two women whose aching joints seem to anticipate weather changes began living in a climate-controlled room yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- State Department officials asserted today that the United States had "every right" to supply aircraft and weapons to the legal Government of Laos.

The big round-up of international trotters for races at Yonkers and Roosevelt is on and the rivalry between the raceways is proving much more interesting than some of the programs they present during the season.
It has been most interesting to me to note that over one-third of New York's Hundred Neediest of 1960 are in need as a direct result of mental illness.

The Federal Government is having a hard enough time enforcing the principle of non-segregation in the schools, as required by the Supreme Court decision of May 17, 1954. It cannot wisely or legally add to the difficulty of this task by subsidizing segregation at any level. Yet, this, as the Civil Rights Commission has just reported, is precisely what is happening.
"Forget about everything but the front rim of the basket," said Coach Mary Wertheim, bending his knees slightly and caressing the ball with his fingertips. He closed his eyes and sank his free throw.

The New Dramatists Committee, a nonprofit group that has been functioning since 1949, is undertaking an extensive fundraising campaign to continue its work in furnishing practical experience to talented young playwrights.
ALTHOUGH thousands of intellectuals congregate in American cities, they traditionally deplore and distrust cities, according to Morton and Lucia White.

The makings of future mink coats by the hundred were snapped up at auction yesterday. Something like 58,000 dressed skins -- the delicate shade known as "autumn haze" -- were put on the auction block and professional buyers, gathered from all over the world, bought 85 per cent of them, paying more than $1,500,000.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 16 -- Evidence is accumulating that the armed forces supporting Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier, are receiving outside aid.

HALIFAX, VT., Jan. 16 -- This ought to be the day of the snowshoe rabbit hunter, but it isn't. None of the inveterate hound followers laboring up and around these ledgy, scrub timber hills has been able to do any good lately.
MIAMI, Jan. 16 -- A Cuban exile leader declared today that Premier Fidel Castro could be defeated only by taking over his social revolution and destroying its ideals.
Premier Chou En-lai and Foreign Minister Chen Yi of Communist China have acknowledged in interviews with journalists in recent months that there are Soviet-Chinese differences.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower expressed more concern today over Soviet missile power and the threat of surprise nuclear attack than at any other time in his two terms of office.

Real Estate Commissioner Ferdinand Roth said yesterday that his department's budget would have to be increased to maintain city-owned buildings properly under strict new regulations put in force in the last year.

Hemphill, Noyes Co., Estabrook Co. and associates are offering to the public today 175,000 common shares of Pneumo-Dynamics Corporation at $9 a share. Proceeds from the sale will be applied toward payment at loans.

In one of his last official acts in the international field, President Eisenhower greets again today a welcome visitor from across our nothern border, Prime Minister Diefenbaker of Canada. The Prime Minister has come to Washington to sign a treaty for another vast joint enterprise by the United States and Canada.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -- West Germany's "little man" took a big step today toward becoming a stockholder.
New York, Boston and most of the raliroads serving them have taken another step in their struggle for raft freight-rate parity with the Atlantic ports to the south.
Yama Bahama from the island of Bimini and Ted Wright from Detroit boxed to a ten-round draw in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- Eight of the eleven Republicans in the State Senate declared tonight their opposition to the candidacy of Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell for Governor of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Supreme Court was urged today to resolve a legal and moral "quandary" for district attorneys in New York State on the issue of wiretapping.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The Legislature completed action tonight on the first major reorganization of the New York court system in 113 years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- James C. Hagerty, Presidential press secretary, was honored by the Marine Corps today in one of the most informal ceremonies ever held in the White House.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller reported today that a "group therapy" program for persistent traffic law violators had cut violations by a third among those "treated."
The country's wholesalers were urged last night to note great changes in the economy and to aggressively seek new markets.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham declared tonight that the election of John F. Kennedy, a Roman Catholic, had promoted a better understanding between the Protestant and Catholic churches in the United States.

ON the way into New Delhi, Prime Minister Nehru jumped out of the Cadillac. He took the lathi stick from an overwhelmed policeman and tried to help clear a way for President Eisenhower through the wildly enthusiastic crowd.
Fluctuating values with a slight trend to firmer prices marked the ship sales market at the end of 1960, according to one of the world's leading ship brokers.
A defendant in a murder case here has been found sane by one team of city psychiatrists and insane by a second team of city psychiatrists.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 16 (UPI) -- A state police laboratory report was awaited today by investigators seeking the cause of the death of an 15 year-old Arlington, N. J., honor student.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Two groups of persons who refused to take shelter during air-raid drills in New York City were denied a Supreme Court review today of their convictions on misdemeanor charges.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 16 -- Everybody talked about expansion, but nobody did anything about it today at the winter meeting of the National Basketball Association.

Mayor Wagner gave his approval yesterday to the "strong mayor" provisions of the Moore Commission's Charter-revision report. But he said he wanted to give careful study to some of the other proposals before deciding whether to support them.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The price of gold tumbled on the London and continental gold markets today as a result of President Eisenhower's order prohibiting American citizens and businesses from holding gold overseas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower urged a slowdown today in efforts to put a man in spade until the scientific problems can be solved and it can be more clearly determined whether there are any reasons for such efforts.
Pickets posted by striking harbor employes disrupted commuter and long-distance passenger service on the New York Central and New Haven Railroads yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Chrysler Corporation has shut down all but one of its passenger car assembly lines in the Detroit area for one week, effective today.

Daniel J. Ferris, the honorary secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, said yesterday that "three to five athletes" in track and field undoubtedly would be selected to compete in South Africa in late March or early April.

The nation's mutual funds wound up 1960 with higher assets than at any previous year-end, but December sales and the number of new accumulation plans lagged behind comparable 1959 levels. These figures were disclosed in the monthly statement of the National Association of Investment Companies, trade association for the funds.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion has decided to yield, at least for the time being, to a ruling by his Cabinet that cleared Pinhas Lavon of all responsibility for a disastrous security adventure in 1954.
WARSAW, Jan. 16 -- Poles welcomed home today their long-absent Wawel treasures, symbolic of the golden age of Poland.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The B.F. Goodrich Company announced today purchase of the Rayed Manufacturing Company, the nation's largest distributor of shock absorbers, mufflers and seat covers.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The hottest crowd-puller in boxing? It may be Guilio Rinaldi of Italy.

NEWARK, Jan. 16 -- The Regional Plan Association announced today the formation of a New Jersey committee to increase the effectiveness of citizen participation in planning and developing the northern New Jersey area.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, Nobel prize-winning chemist, today was designated by President-elect John F. Kennedy to be chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower suggested today the creation of a Cabinet-level Department of Transportation embracing "presently fragmented" Federal activities.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Roger Maris of the New York Yankees was honored tonight as the "Sultan of Swat" for 1960.

THERE is an ancient wisdom that says Broadway creates and Hollywood scrambles for the film fights. "The Conquering Hero" has ignored it -- at its peril. The Preston Sturges movie, "Hail the Conquering Hero," may have been fun, but the new musical based on it is a dud.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 16 -- The Italian high fashion spring and summer collections got off to an elegant but mild start today with the showings of two Roman couturiers, Carosa and Antonelli. The ballroom of the Pitti Palace was as crowded as usual with European and American press and buyers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Eisenhower's version of the budget for the fiscal year 1962 attracted little more interest on Capitol Hill today than did the 1,160 postmaster-ship nominations he sent up last week.
Both the railroads and the unionists involved in the harbor strike are receiving insurance payments to help offset their losses.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Industrial shares advanced on the stock market here today under the lead of Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest industrial concern.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The president of the Air Transport Association of America called today for repeal of laws that permit the Government to obtain reduced rates from railroads, airlines and other carriers.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The future facing Britain's shipbuilding industry was described today as the bleakest since the years between World War I and World War II.
HAVANA, Jan. 17 -- Three Cubans convicted of counter-revolutionary actions were executed by a firing squad at 1 A.M. today in the old moat of La Cabana fortress.

LAST night's revue entitled "Everybody's Doin' It" was a forlorn and witless impossibility, the season's saddest affront to humor. What on earth can possess a medium with vast resources and across to fine talent to offer an hour that couldn't compare with an average high school vaudeville night?

COLRAIN, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Iron convention and the painted midwinter covers of all magazines dictate that when there is 2 feet of snow on the ground the American outdoor man must get out his fly-fishing tackle and work over it in the comfort of his habitation.
WASHINGTON Jan. 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker of Canada said today United States sales to Cuba were outstripping Canada's despite the United States' curbs on such sales.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold laid before the Security Council today a protest by President Kasavubu against some activities of the United Nations Command in the Congo and a request by Mr. Kasavubu for an "explanation."
The printers of The New York Times, members of the International Typographical Union, Local 6, added $355 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Jan. 17 -- Agreement was announced here today between President Joseph Kasavubu and Moise Tshombe, head of the separatist Katanga Province Government, on the proposed roundtable conference of Congolese politicians.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $296,176,935, equal to $27.06 a share, on Dec. 31, 1960. The net asset value is after deducting a capital gain distribution of $12,915,593, or $1.18 a share, declared last on Dec. 20, and payable on Jan. 30.
Patterson House, a new residence for boys named in honor of Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight boxing champion, will be opened soon by the Wiltwyck School for Boys.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Robert S. McNamara offered today to amend a controversial $1,100,000 investment trust fund and to make "full disclosure'' of his financial affairs.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Australia battled its way back into the thick of the third cricket test match against the West Indies today but still needed 282 runs tomorrow for victory with eight wickets standing.
TWO art exhibitions of much more than usual interest open today, utterly unrelated except for the coicidence that puts them both in this column.

THE Little Orchestra Society will be joined by Lisl Well, illustrator, at an all-Stravinsky children's concert on Saturday at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The finance ministries and central banks of six European countries have begun a study to see whether the present world monetary systems, which is based mainly on gold, dollars and pounds sterling, ought to be changed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower and Canadian Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker signed today a treaty for joint United States-Canadian development of the Columbia River resources. They hailed it as a milestone in international relations.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Assembly gave final approval today to the second money bill of the young legislative session.

Patients at Lenox Hill Hospital have good cause to rejoice. With rare wisdom, the hospital has seen fit to replace the traditional ill-fitting, white muslin gown with a new model, improved in fabric, fit and color.

Prof. Thomas Schelling has good credentials as a student of arms control, but this does not guarantee that his pessimism about Soviet intentions is accurate. In fact, his expert knowledge may have misled him.
The appointment of Dr. Henry David as president of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, was announced yesterday, effective March 20.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- June Allyson filed suit for divorce today from Dick Powell after the actor-producer signed a settlement that will give the actress $2,500,000.
Alfons Landa, who helped depose Leopold D. Silberstein as president of Penn-Texas Corporation, has moved into the General Fireproofing Company picture.
West Germany has proposed increases in German military procurement in the United States with increased prepayments, Franz Josef Strauss, West German Defense Minister, said yesterday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- With a performance that was almost too good to be true, Pipe Dream tonight won the first annual St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale yacht race.
Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond a Democrat, announced yesterday that he would run for re-election this year.

Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, founder and director of the Frontier Nursing Service, will be the guest of honor at a reception and tea to be given by the organization's New York committee in observance of her eightieth birthday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers endorsed today the Civil Rights Commission's proposal to withhold Federal aid funds from public colleges that discriminate against Negroes.

One should not be surprised that a goodly amount of authoritarianism marks the South Vietnam Government of Ngo Dinh Diem. WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today that he had decided against withdrawing Federal aid funds from Louisiana, where some 20,000 illegitimate children have been removed from the public assistance rolls.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 -- Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon declared tonight that Communist China's "stupid" attitude in its border dispute with India had cast doubt on the whole concept of peaceful coexistence.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A late rally sent all old-crop soybean futures to their highest levels of the season again today on the Board of Trade, with gains generally about 2 cents a bushel.

A $70,000,000 petrochemical complex to supply Argentina's requirements for synthetic rubber, benzene and chemical intermediates will be built 250 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, Argentina, it was announced yesterday.

The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad reported yesterday a net income for 1960 of $12,031,000. This was equal to $2.87 a share and compared with earnings of $13,288,922, or $3.20 a share, reported in 1959.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP) -- In a speech published today, Premier Khrushchev declared that victory "is no longer far off" for world communism.

Two of the three coffee contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose yesterday. Traders ascribed the higher trend to a technical situation, following the recent sharp decline. Stock prices reacted yesterday from the headlong advance that set in on Jan. 4. DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 18 (AP) Great Lakes vessel operators are softly humming the blues in the midst of praise for the St. Lawrence Seaway, a shipping leader told closing sessions of a Seaway Institute today.
TORONTO, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- The New York Rangers stretched their unbeaten streak to five games by tying the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 4, in a wild National Hockey League game tonight.

The cold weather throughout the country again cut sharply into stocks of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes. According to the American Petroleum Institute, supplies of that product dropped 6,408,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday to 127,567,000.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A group of eleven Negroes and three whites today asked state permission to start the first Negro savings and loan association in New Jersey.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- William C. Newberg, former president of the Chrysler Corporation, filed a suit against the company today, charging that he was forced to resign because he refused to be silent about top-level practices concerning favoritism and nepotism.

Rails dominated yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Market value of the list as a whole rose a little more than one-half of 1 per cent. Market value of rails rose more than 2 per cent.

August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that net operating income rose 31 per cent in 1960 from the 1959 level to $1,018,000 after interest payments to the savings banks of $3,150,000.

Passage of the Erwin-Lounsberry Resolution by the State Assembly by a vote of 135 to 8, following its unanimous approval by the Senate, throws the court-reorganization issue into the hands of the voters themselves.

The buildings and land formerly occupied by St. Lawrence Academy at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street have been sold for $1,100,000. The site will be cleared and improved with a sixteen-story co-operative apartment house costing $4,500,000.

Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates won the awards of $3,825,000 of equipment trust certificates of the New York Central Railroad on its bid of 98.173 for certificates bearing a 4 3/4 per cent interest coupon. Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., bid 98.803 for a 4 7/8 per cent coupon.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 18 -- The Government of Premier Gaston Eyskens seems to have defeated the strike of the Socialist unions against the proposed economic reform law.
The last train left Grand Central Terminal at 8:25 o'clock last night, leaving in its wake the frantic pounding of tardy feet and futile pleas of "Wait! Wait!"

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Russell W. Young, the outgoing president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, said in an interview as the group's four-day meeting ended today that there were indications that more newspapers would offer "frequency and bulk" discounts this year.

There has been at least one unsuccessful attempt by a third party to prevent a full-scale proxy contest for control of the Alleghany Corporation between its incumbent management led by Allan P. Kirby and the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex.

UNIONS -- New York Railroad Harbor Council, composed of units of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, and the Seafarers International Union.
Legal action was begun yesterday to push freight through the picket lines of the striking railroad marine workers. But the efforts would have no effect on commuter service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower took sharp issue today with Premier Khrushchev's attempt to represent the Communist bloc as the only friend and supporter of peoples aspiring to national independence.

A major truck and bus connection between the Bronx and the Manhattan approaches to the George Washington Bridge -- the 155th Street Viaduct -- will be closed for about a year beginning at 11 A.M. today.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller tonight pledged a "vigorous and thorough" review of the current milk-pricing formula.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The imprisonment of Mme. Ivinskaya and her daughter was viewed by an authoritative source here today as foreshadowing an attempt by the Soviet Government to "rehabilitate" Boris Pasternak.

Governor Rockefeller invited the four-member State Investigation Commission yesterday to confer with him and legislative leaders in Albany at 10 A.M. next Wednesday. They will discuss the future of the commission's inquiries into New York City affairs.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 -- Residents here who have been startled by a steep rise in their assessments were assured today that the city did not intend to increase its expenditures accordingly.
A 39-year-old finance company president was accused here yesterday of stealing $1,327,431.

Production of electric power in the nation rose to 14,684,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Jan. 14 from 14,245,000,000 in the holiday week that preceded it, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

The New York Central Railroad, in a last-minute effort to thwart impending acquisition of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, apparently began pouring out millions of dollars yesterday to acquire B. O. shares on the open market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy will meet With his incoming Secretary of Labor, Arthur J. Goldberg, and top labor leaders tomorrow.
A stockbroker who had admitted fleecing clients of $103,000 was jailed yesterday when a $12,000 check for the reimbursement of his victims proved worthless.

During the first week of March, 1933, a numbr of world-shaking events took place. Franklin D. Roosevelt was inaugurated and took the first action he had promised the voters to counteract the economic stagnation that gripped the country -- the closing of the national banks.

In reference to C. Forbes' letter of Jan. 10 I would like to express another view of the mass pilgrimage of students to the New York Public Library during Christmas week. As a scholar he should be encouraged by the fact that thousands of New York's high school and college students were willing to stand hours in line awaiting books and materials.
The election of Edward J. Morehouse, Lester T. Potter and F.E. Burnham as directors of the Chance Vought Corporation was announced yesterday by F.O. Detweiler, president.

OTTAWA, Jan. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Government's new $100,000,000 public bond offering will be a 3 1/4-year issue, with coupon interest at 4 per cent. It will be offered at a discount price of $98.50 to yield about 4.5 per cent to maturity, the Department of Finance announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Air Force and defense industries were accused today of building up an "unhealthy competitive atmosphere" in space research aimed at "degrading" the civilian space agency.
The New York Telephone Company agreed yesterday to abandon its LX exchange, which stands for nothing, and to replace it with LW, which also stands for nothing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy arrived today from Palm Beach, Fla., for the inauguration ceremonies. Nobody was at the airport to greet her as she stepped down from the family plane, the Caroline.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Fred W. Hooper's Crozier, the favorite in the field of twelve, withstood a stretch drive by Vapor Whirl today to win the $25,950 Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Darling June won the $10,000 El Monte Purse today at Santa Anita but Henrijan moved into the spotlight earlier by equaling the track record of 1:08 4/5 for six furlongs in the sixth race.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The inauguration may become solemn historical occasion noon Friday but the mood this city, which knows solemn and dotes on the historical, was openly jubilant tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a tentative decision to permit a major test of pay-TV at Hartford.
The highest award of the Bolivian Government, the Decoration of Grand Officials of the Condor of the Andes, has been presented to A.N. Spanel, chairman of the International Latex Corporation.

The Federal Maritime Board has been asked to determine whether an accounting concern employed by a shipping company can browse at will through the files of a competing operator and yet maintain the aspect of a "neutral body" in a dispute involving the two companies.

A leading Baptist spokesman said yesterday it was "most unfortunate" that at the outset of the new Administration, Cardinal Spellman had attacked a basic position on education taken by President-elect John F. Kennedy.

SKI SKETCH: Although he has the desire, the coach and the natural ability, Art Tokle Jr., a handsome 11-year-old sixth grader of Lake Telemark, N.J., may find it difficult to keep the Tokle name prominent in the jumping sport.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin, the quarterback who led the Philadelphia Eagles to the National Football League championship, was named head coach of the new Minnesota Vikings today.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 -- The dispersal of Cuban exiles to jobs in other areas was speeding up today while registration of new job-seekers continued to increase.

ROME, Jan., 18 -- The four new Cardinals elevated in a secret Roman Catholic consistory on Monday were urged by Pope John XXIII today to comport themselves in a manner that would gain them recognition by all as shining examples of the Christian virtues.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 18 -- Roberto Capucci's spring collection stirred up a storm of controversy last night. Immediately after the presentation at the Pitti Palace, the spectators split up into warring factions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 11:
CORNWALL, Ont., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Wage negotiations between Canadian workers on the St. Lawrence Seaway and the Seaway Authority, a Crown corporation, were broken off today.
Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the new common stock, payable on March 10 to holders of record of Feb. 20.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 18 -- A small bomb exploded in public high school here today as striking students tried to persuade some of their colleagues to join them. There was some panic among the children, but no injuries were reported.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- A record budget of $18,752,957 for this year was presented today before the Bergen County Board of Freeholders. This is $1,030,566 above the 1960 appropriations of $17,722,391.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- By Hollywood standards, George Peppard is shirking his duties. He fails to fulfill the obligations that are expected of a young star away from the camera. But by his own criteria, which he explained today, Mr. Peppard does not think he is short-changing his employers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Each morning, for the last two weeks an attractive woman has stepped outside the front door of her home here to check the weather. She has with her a copy of The Hagerstown Almanac, and should the weather and the almanac pre diction differ, she considers the day a success.

IT was a case of the old and the new jostling shoulders at the concert Richard Korn conducted last night at Carnegie Hall. But the old was so much of a rarity that it, too, came as something new. Edward MacDowell is not played much these days, and the MacDowell music performed by the Orchestra of America was altogether unfamiliar.
Consolidated earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1960 were 16 per cent higher than those of 1959, P.C. Spencer, chairman, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Following are the texts of the summary and conclusions of the revised master plan of the State University of New York, made public today:
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Antony Armstrong-Jones, husband of Princess Margaret, is going to work in a non-salaried capacity for the Council of Industrial Design.
The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority borrowed $20,600,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction in seven counties.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Jan. 18 -- A member of a family of Indian artists opened the first exhibition of their paintings to be held outside his nativeland today in a church parish house here as a gesture of friendship toward an American family.

President-elect John F. Kennedy commended support of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem yesterday "as a constructive force in the Middle East and for educational assistance to the new nations of Africa and Asia."
The chauffeur for Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan, who received a ticket for speeding last Nov. 16 on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, was found not guilty yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 18 -- The removal of former Premier Patrice Lumumba to a "safe" prison in Katanga Province was announced today in Leopoldville and Elisabethville.

HANOVER, N.T., Jan. 18 -- Paced by Phil Latreille's five goals and three assists, the Middlebury hockey team defeated Dartmouth, 10 -- 7, before 2,500 fans in Davis Rink tonight. In stretching their season won-lost record to 9-1, the Panthers overcame a 2-0 Dartmouth first-period lead, with Latreille, the nation's leading scorer, tallying four times in the second period.
The Kratter Corporation increased its stake in Jacob Ruppert, the brewing company, last month by purchasing 5,600 shares of the brewer's common stock.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange fell to 3,780,516 shares on Jan. 13 from 4,400,050 on Dec. 15, 1960.
Idaho did the best job of getting its voters to the polls in last year's Presidential election, the American Heritage Foundation said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Following are the major events of tomorrow's pre-inaugural program:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to stand behind a $3,000,000 loan negotiated by the Boston and Maine Railroad.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -- Israel charged the Government of Morocco today with "heavy responsibility" for the tragedy a week ago in which forty-two Moroccan Jews were drowned in a clandestine attempt to flee to Israel.
LAKE WALES, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham has been denied the use of the Bok Singing Tower for sunrise services Easter because of "the hubbub and confusion" likely to occur.

IN "Donogoo," Jules Romains, the noted French writer, has attempted a spoof of scientific accuracy, high finance, trade, patriotism, pioneering, the French Academy and a host of momentous and minute matters.

The Japanese Finance Ministry has approved plans of four leading American banks for the issuance of American Depositary Receipts -- A.D.R.'s -- representing shares of sixteen major Japanese companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted two business men and a former legal aide to the Securities and Exchange Commission in a conflict-of-interest case. Payments of more than $60,000 were alleged to have been passed.

The Frick Collection confirmed yesterday that Miss Helen Clay Frick, a director of the museum and the daughter of its founder, was at odds with a majority of the directors over their decision to accept a bequest of "inferior" art objects from the late John D. Rockefeller Jr.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Lance Gibbs took five wickets today, as the West Indies cricket team routed Australia by 222 runs in their third test match and squared the five-match series at one victory each.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Soybean futures ran into their sharpest reversal today of a six-week upward trend that had been seldom interrupted since the Government ceased being a competitor in the market.

A SERIES of nine bridge lectures at the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn began yesterday afternoon and will continue on Wednesday afternoons through March 22, omitting Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22.
It is an open secret that Guido Panzini, the witty gentleman who appears now and then on the Jack Paar television show, is as Italian as the hot dog.
BOSTON, Jan. is (AP) -- Bob Pettit, Clyde Lovellette and Cliff Hagan paced the St. Louis Hawks to a 125-114 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.
SOUTH, BEND, Ind., Jan. 18 (UPI) Studebaker-Packard Corporation announced today it was joining three other companies in creating a new space and missile industrial concern.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones ruled today that four Negro ministers who are codefendants with The New York Times in a libel case have forfeited their chance at a new trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Western diplomats expressed growing concern today over signs of a build-up of Communist-supported forces in Eastern Province in the Congo.
Colgate, which had been making a scant impression in basketball, moved into University Hall against Columbia last night and made a formidable impression.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's right to forbid policemen to hold outside jobs was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein.

Some thirty-five miles northwest of the city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra in the Bolivian tropical forest the Caranda oil camp has been added to Bolivian place names. Caranda is "A name with a sort of hope in its meaning to all Bolivians," says an official of the Petroleum Ministry.
THERE are more splendid flavors for food in this city than the average Manhattan cook dreams of. Count among them kirschwasser, that extraordinary distillate of cherry wine.

A granite monument honoring the brave of World War I shuddered slightly yesterday as workmen dug beneath its one-thousand tons on a Brooklyn bluff, almost completing the first stage of its removal to another site to make way for a bridge anchorage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn won formal endorsement of House Democrats today for his plan to enlarge the Rules Committee and thus forestall obstruction of liberal legislation favored by President-elect John F. Kennedy.

JADOTVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Former Premier Patrice Lumumba, who was locked up today in Katanga Province's most secure prison, nursed cuts and bruises from a severe beating by the provincial police.

A number of the Moore State commission's proposals for a new City Charter were attacked yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission as "weakening the built-in controls that are necessary to prevent error, waste, abuse or worse."
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A leader of the Zionist Organization of America criticized the president of the American Jewish Congress today for suggesting the Zionist movement be dissolved.
Hundreds of pornographic books and photographs and dozens of films were collected by the police yesterday in raids on thirteen novelty shops in the Times Square area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- John B. Connally was praised today at a Senate hearing for his knowledge of the oil business instead of being criticized for his past connections.

In his generally constructive and judicious report to President-elect Kennedy on the regulatory agencies, James M. Landis has included one dismaying recommendation which, if put into effect, would seriously set back consumer protection in the United States.
In his Boston speech on Jan. 9, John F. Kennedy remarked that one needed "the courage to stand up to one's enemies -- and the courage to stand up, when necessary, to one's own associates."

WHEN Washington has a raging fever, New York catches the sniffles. Or so it seems from a look at specialty shops that are enjoying a pleasurable frenzy in selling fashions to be worn at the inauguration festivities.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner held a series of conferences tonight designed to produce a Democratic organization candidate for Governor of New Jersey.
President Eisenhower has now completed his official farewells and will retire tomorrow as the most popular and the most criticized American of the day.
Schools to help develop dog judges may not be far away, George F. Foley of Philadelphia, the professional show superintendent, told the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club at Luchow's Restaurant yesterday.
MANILA, Jan. 18 -- Foreign ministers of four anti-Communist Asian countries met here today to assess the role of Communist China in the Far East.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Bob Purdy scored 24 points and set up the winning basket tonight in leading Penn to a 63-62 basketball upset of Villanova at the Palestra.

Ten Barnard College students will change places with ten Southern college women -- five from all-Negro Spelman College in Atlanta and five from all-white Wake Forest College in Winston-Salem, N.C. -- from Feb. 8 through 15.

Viktor Jaanimets, 30-year-old Estonian seaman who fled from Premier Khrushchev's ship, the Baltika, to sanctuary here last October, visited district headquarters of the Immigration and Naturalization Bureau here yesterday to report his current address.
The Military Order of the Loyal Legion has arranged a dinner dance for Feb. 13 at the Plaza to mark Abraham Lincoln's birthday and the 100th anniversary of his inauguration as President.
National policy on the country's merchant marine will remain unchanged under the incoming administration, Thomas E. Stakem, vice chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, predicted last night.

Horizon House, Inc., a subsidiary of the Tishman Realty Construction Company, has leased a tract of land in Palisade, N.J., a mile south of the George Washington Bridge. The concerns plans to erect Horizon House a group of seven fourteen-story apartment buildings with penthouses.

Casey Stengel, the former manager of the Yankees, and Bill Mazeroski of the Pirates will be among the honored guests at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America at the Waldorf-Astoria a week from Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Americans will be introduced not only to the "New Frontier" Friday, but also to the "new front" -- the new East Front of the Capitol.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The principal industrial sections shook off the early weakness of the stock market here today and small net gains predominated at the close. Demand, however, was selective and most changes were no more than a few pence.
SHELDON, Iowa, Jan. 18 -- The assistant cashier who embezzled more than $2,000,000 from the bank her father headed here isolated herself in her Sioux City jail cell today.

THERE may be, as dealers maintain, a shortage of first-class antiques. However, the visitor to the Seventh Regiment Armory, where the annual and lavish Winter Antiques Show opens today, will find this hard to believe.
Centre futures on the New York Stock Exchange rose 5 to 20 points (25 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The far months showed the most strength on expectations of a higher loan level.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Highway "stop" signs that would apply to trains operating within city limits have been erected at grade crossings. Officials made plans today for enforcing them.
Several years experience with a contraceptive pill in Puerto Rico and elsewhere has raised the possibility that the drug also has some cancer-preventive effects.

TWENTY-TWO years after "The Rules of the Game" was made, and twelve years after a mutilated print was exhibited here, the full version of Jean Renoir's study of the manners and mores of prewar France opened yesterday at the Eighth Street Playhouse and completely justified its European reputation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- More than 200,000 employes of 7,000 trucking companies in thirteen Midwestern states received wage increases of 28 to 32 cents an hour, plus fringe benefits, in new three-year contracts announced today by James R. Hoffa.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The United States must avoid at all costs Government ownership of railroads, the president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society said today.

While Stalin lived, world public opinion had become accustomed to the idea that no horror was impossible in Moscow. But since the old tyrant's death we have been led to believe that the Soviet state recognized there were limits of elementary decency on the actions it might take against any of its citizens.

ARCHIE MOORE, a scene-stealer by instinct, was merely doing what came naturally at the dinner of the Boxing Writers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria the other night. The more-or-less light-heavyweight champion of the world deftly filched the show.
Even the best advertising slogan in the world needs to be allowed to rest occasionally -- at least that is one popular advertising principle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower urged today that election and inauguration dates be advanced to allow a new President about eighty days to organize his work before outlining his policies and program to Congress.

A group of Iranians calling themselves The Committee for Free Elections charged here yesterday that the parliamentary elections being held in Iran are a farce. The elections began Jan. 10 and are expected to continue until mid-February.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
A special hearing officer announced yesterday that he would recommend the dismissal of charges against two employes of the Real Estate Department accused of accepting bribes from a contractor.

Nine bus routes are available to New York Central and New Haven Railroad commuters seeking alternate transport routes into the city. In addition, there are three large parking fields in the Bronx and one in Queens, and a number of parking garages in northern Manhattan convenient to subway stations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the United States would have to face the possibility of Communist China's admission into the United Nations.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru ruled out today a revival of the three-nation Control Commission on Laos unless specifically requested by Britain and the Soviet Union.

The fifteenth annual campaign of the Catholic Bishops Relief Fund, announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting, will open Feb. 15, Ash Wednesday, in the 16,500 Roman Catholic parishes in the United States.
GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- A high United Nations official defended today the record of the Arab governments in dealing with the problem of the Arab refugees of the 1948 war in Palestine.

Confusion, dissent and recrimination lay siege to the National Basketball Association yesterday following a hectic but apparently successful business meeting at Syracuse in conjunction with the league's annual all-star game.
Activity broadened in the market for United States Government securities yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- The meeting of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party ended today with the election of two new candidate members to the party's ruling Presidium.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 18 -- The Strategic Air Command began flying some of its heavy bombers on an around-the-clock basis today in the second stage of a plan to make possible an airborne alert.
Phil Jordon returned to the roster of the New York Knickerbockers yesterday after a three-year sojourn with rival teams in the National Basketball Association.

Acting Borough President Louis A. Cioffi of Manhattan received official praise yesterday for requesting a 1961-62 expense budget that was smaller than the allocation his office had received in the current city budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A new and unexpected borrowing this week of $200,000,000 to meet routine Government costs was announced by the Treasury today.

William Inge's next play, "Natural Affection," is to be put on by Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens, possibly with Shelley Winters in the cast. The producers are planning to bring it here next season under Frank Corsaro's direction.
The city Board of Higher Education said yesterday it would "vigorously oppose" attempts by the state to gain control of the municipal colleges here.

The report of President-elect Kennedy's Natural Resources Advisory Committee is important not only for what it says but also for the fact that it has been made at all. The publication of such a report just prior to the inauguration of the new President emphasizes the significance of the double problem of wise utilization and effective conservation of natural resources, a problem that is mounting in urgency every day.
Boat show folks who converge on New York City every January from fifty states and many other nations were doubly busy yesterday at the New York Coliseum. They had boats to buy and meetings to attend.
Dr. Thomas Dooley, the medical missionary, died here last night at Memorial Hospital. Death by cancer, which he had calmly awaited for two years, came at 9:40 P.M.
All public garages north of 110th Street in Manhattan agreed yesterday to a uniform parking rate of $1 a day from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the duration of the shutdown of commuter service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Following is the text of a statement by Adlai E. Stevensun before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on his designation to be head of the United States delegation to the United Nations:
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The State University trustees proposed today that free tuition for nearly 30,000 students be ended as part of a master plan for expanding the State University system.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev has declared that the Soviet policies of peaceful coexistence and disarmament are to be used as primary weapons to bring about the final defeat of capitalist "imperialism" and the establishment of communism throughout the world.
The shifting of the guard in Washington tomorrow puts an end to a military era and initiates a new one.
PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, Jan. 19 -- Thousands of gallons of highly flammable and poisonous chemical poured into the Delaware River last night after a ship smashed a pipeline on a pier.

JOHNSON CITY, N.Y., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Frank A. Johnson, president of the Endicott Johnson Corporation, said today that he was seeking legal ways to acquire control of Endicott Johnson stock held by the Glen Alden Corporation and its associated interests.

The J.I. Case Company had a net loss of $39,814,973 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. In fiscal 1959, the manufacturer of farm and construction machinery had a net profit of $6,200,111, equal to $1.75 a common share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today that economic activity should pick up shortly. He also said that present signs pointed to an improvement in the balance of international payments this year.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- Daniel Pollack, young American pianist, capped a highly successful tour of the Soviet Union tonight with a recital in Moscow's hallowed Conservatory. He received a long ovation and was called back for seven encores.

CLAYT (Clayton B. when he is a co-signer) Seagears has retired from the Conservation Department, leaving a considerable hole in it. Seagears knows more about hunting and fishing in New York State than anybody else and can tell it better than most.
Canadian Finance Minister Donald M. Fleming asserted yesterday that his measures to end tax concessions on payments to foreign holders of Canadian securities were in no sense anti-American.
SEATTLE, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Federal judge halted last night, for the present at least, possible suspension of Northwest Orient Airlines' recently resumed daily DC-8 jet flight to the Far East.

The men's and women's North American sailing championship regattas will be moved about the country more than they have been heretofore under changed policies made public last night. The occasion was the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union in the New York Yacht Club.

I was appalled to read Max Frankel's references to the Government of Guatemala in his article "Troubled Caribbean Looks to Kennedy,'' published in Section Four of The Times of Jan. 15, because it contains false assertions and insinuations highly detrimental to the dignity of the republic, which I categorically repudiate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Secretary of State-designate Dean Rusk, in his final speech as a private citizen, appealed today for twofold support of the Kennedy Administration in this "critical phase of history."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- There is common acceptance of the cliche that the benefit or the damage the leaders of nations have contributed can be justly appraised only by honest historians of their distant posterity. That is generally true, particularly of acts and policies whose effects are not completely registered until a considerable passage of time.
An Air Force board of inquiry began an investigation yesterday into the collapse of an offshore radar tower with twenty-eight men aboard in a storm Sunday night.

Informed, sources reported yesterday that the Soviet Government had given an eight-year prison sentence to the late Boris Pasternak's closest literary collaborator and intimate friend, the woman who inspired the novel "Doctor Zhivago" and served, as the model for its heroine, Larisa.

When Jacob Maxin competed in the Franz Liszt Piano Competition last year, one of the judges was sufficiently impressed by his piano-playing to regret that there was only one first prize to be awarded. Mr. Maxin did not get that prize, but last night he made his New York recital debut in Town Hall as a result of the interest and generosity of the aforementioned judge -- the pianist, Moura Lympany.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Ron Harmon, first captain of the corps of cadets, sank a one-handed jump shot at the final buzzer to lift Army to a 60-58 victory over Williams College today. The cadet quintet never led until the final shot.

The Toronto Stock Exchange may soon be "shaping up" with somewhat more military precision than before. Yesterday in his first address since assuming the presidency of the exchange this month, Lieut. Gen. Howard Graham (Canadian Army, ret.) talked firmly to a meeting of exchange employes.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York has no present plans to merge, Henry C. Alexander, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- A 13-year-old schoolboy was cited as a hero today for the rescue of an elderly man off Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Supreme Court pondered today whether a state could make all its lawyers join an official bar association that took positions some lawyers did not like.

Lawrence A. Wien, realty investor, has purchased a net lease for thirty-three years on the Fuller Building at 595 Madison Avenue, corner of Fifty-seventh Street. The lease, with two twenty-five-year renewals, was bought from the Fuller Building Corporation through Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker.
The New Haven Railroad shut down its New York service last night as a result of the picket blockade established by striking harbor workers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower has replied to a Cambodian suggestion for a fourteen-nation conference on the problem of Laos.
ALBANY Jan. 18 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations yesterday honored three women for outstanding achievements. Awards were presented at the group's sixty-fifth anniversary convention and luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CYRUS SULZBERGER'S "My Brother Death"* is a profoundly moving threnody on man's fate. After journeys on all the continents and experiences in many wars of our day, he has set down this fiery tribute to the valiant.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Republicans on a Senate Banking subcommittee protested today what they described as undue haste in opening public hearings on a $389,500,000 depressed-areas bill.

"I am not sure," Douglas Southall Freeman, the biographer of Robert E. Lee, once wrote, "I understand all the reasons for the steady increase in the numbers of those who read deeply of the South's four-year struggle."

The New York Philharmonic has been struck by misfortune for the fifth time this season. The latest conductor to be incapacitated, Igor Markevitch, was to have started a two-week engagement with the orchestra on Feb. 23.

Free lunches at the Hanover Bank seem doomed if merger of the bank with the Manufacturers Trust Company goes through as proposed. So does a bridge five stories above New Street connecting the bank's offices at 70 Broadway with those at 20 Broad Street.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The strike of professional soccer players on the ninety-two clubs of the Football League, which was scheduled to begin Saturday, was called off today.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., cleared $2,400,000 in the final quarter of the fiscal year ending on Nov. 30, reducing its loss for the entire year to $19,400,000, the concern reported yesterday. It had a deficit of $33,822,229 for fiscal 1959.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- A Tiger is loose on the Southern Ocean racing circuit: Paper Tiger, a sharp, new forty-foot yawl owned by John Powell of the St. Petersburg Yacht Club.

A state-aided $2,267,678 housing project, with tenant priority limited almost solely to aged victims of Nazi persecution, is soon to rise in Queens. These persons, from Germany and Eastern Europe, have come to the United States since World War II.
Heavy trading in copper and cocoa futures was the major feature of activity on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Prime contractors have been asked to submit new proposals on the delayed Minuteman missile base at Great Falls, Mont., Army spokesmen said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Orders to reduce the number of dependents who may accompany service men overseas have caused a serious decline in military morale, the outgoing Administration reported today.
BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 18 -- Transits of the Panama Canal by ocean-going ships rose 2 per cent during the first half of the 1961 fiscal year.
AGADIR, Morocco, Jan. 18 -- Survivors of the earthquake that devastated this resort and took 15,000 lives in February began to move back today to a prefabricated emergency city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Americans were asked today by President Eisenhower to open their homes and hearts to Cuban refugees as they did to those from Hungary four years ago.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson suffered a hemorrhage of the left pelvic blade as the Cincinnati Royals bowed to the Detroit Pistons, 144 -- 128, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- An urban renewal plan for twenty-three blighted acres on the edge of the business center here has been approved by the City Council.
Snow is expected to start here tonight and continue into tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President-elect John F. Kennedy agreed today to make Puerto Rico "a meeting place and workshop" for the United States and its Latin-American neighbors for solving mutual problems and planning "great achievements."
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The French Cabinet declared today that it was Government policy to seek negotiations with the Moslem rebel leaders to end the six-year-old guerrilla warfare in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
CHRISTOPHER PLUMMER and Farley Granger engaged in a spirited duel in the next to last scene of "The Prisoner of Zenda" over Channel 2 last night.

The Socialist strikes in Belgium have petered out to the point where they can be considered virtually over, barring accidents. It has been a distressing experience for a sorely tried nation which, during 1960, had lost the Congo and was facing economic difficulties.

If a half-hour television program has been popular for nearly six years, can it be twice as popular by expanding to an hour? The Columbia Broadcasting System will find an answer next fall, when "Gunsmoke" becomes an hour-long show.
