The Citizens' Committee for Children gave its support yesterday to a proposal to repeal the Youth Court Act and substitute "youth parts" in existing courts. Such a proposal is expected to be made by the State Judicial Conference.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 -- United States officials acted today, apparently in vain, to end a hunger strike against them by the eminent British-born biologist, Prof. J.B.S. Haldane.

A happy combination of religion and psychiatry in the counseling of Jewish couples was reported here yesterday by the Marriage Counseling Bureau of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and the Rabbinical Assembly of America.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Pressure on the New York Legislature for a change in the law that permits persons under 21 years of age to drink alcoholic beverages is rising. But it is not yet high enough to give immediate hope to advocates of a change.

A nine-state planning body to guide the orderly development of the almost continuous urban area from Boston to Norfolk was proposed yesterday by Herbert H. Swinburne, former chairman of the research committee of the American Institute of Architects.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 12 -- The development of new suburban parks at the expense of real estate subdivisions suffered a setback today in State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee refused today to accept in its present form the $1,100,000 trust fund plan of Secretary of Defense-designate Robert S. McNamara.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Union has asked that Soviet citizens be placed in at least fifty key United Nations posts. It also has asked that promotions be given to some of its citizens now on the staff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Union News Company to stop demanding bonus payments from publishers who want to keep their magazines and books on the company's newsstands.

Fourteen women from six Latin American countries began a six-month visit to the United States yesterday. They will work in Young Women's Christian Associations here and in other ways attempt to get to know the United States.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19 -- The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that Milovan Djilas would be released from prison tomorrow.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 -- The Government today announced details of its ten-year development program, based on investments of the equivalent of $10,000,000,000 between 1961 and 1971.

MANY readers of modern fiction know a little, but only a little, about New Zealand: fragmentary impressions gleaned from the short stories of Katherine Mansfield, odds and ends left over from some of the detective stories of Ngaio Marsh and misty vistas seen through the disturbed minds of the heroines of Sylvia Ashton -Warner's brilliant novels.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda's Cabinet adopted today a record budget of 1,952,776,000,000 yen ($5,424,377,000) for the 1961 fiscal year, which begins April 1. It will be submitted to the Diet (Parliament) at the end of this month.
The spotlight in the running battle for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad shifted yesterday from Wall Street to Washington.
Following are the chief factors in the harbor strike here:

A city prison chaplain yesterday challenged the theory that narcotics addicts were just sick. The Rev. E. Frederick Proelss Protestant chaplain at Riker's Island Penitentiary, told the Academy of Religion and Mental Health that addicts were also sadly lacking in moral values.
The lack of standardization in cargo container sizes is a major barrier to the successful use of this new form of cargo handling, experts said yesterday.

THE old grads had assembled at West Point and the television cameras were out in force. They concentrated on one alumnus, a certain Dwight D. Eisenhower of the class of '15. That's how they happened to capture an incident of such heart-warming spontaneity that it brought a happy glow to all who understood its significance.

The problems before the Kennedy Administration on Inauguration Day are much more difficult than the nation has yet come to believe, and in the long run the solutions are likely to be more radical than anything in American politics since the first Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower's mellow mood on leaving the Presidency has not been shared by all his predecessors.

Three buildings on the southwest corner of Ditmars Boulevard and Thirty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, have been purchased by the Jacsline Realty Corporation, representing Jack Schleifer, realty investor. The property includes the Grand Theatre, which will be reconstructed into a bowling center with forty-eight lanes at a cost of $800,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Jan. 14 were 7 per cent above the year-ago level, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

For its second offering of the season at the City Center, the Gilbert and Sullivan Company turned to "The Pirates of Penzance" last night. Some cast changes and a new first-act setting marked differences from the production given at the Center last fall during the New York City Opera season.

METROPOLITAN galleries, the meeting-places of a wide number of styles, offer this week a typical variety, in which Katherine Schmidt's paintings at the Isaacson Gallery, 20 East Sixty-sixth Street, are by far the most conservative inclusions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Continued seasonal declines combined with a general downward business trend were today reflected in the weekly freight loadings reports issued by both the rail and truck industries.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Nathan Leopold, convicted in 1924 of the slaying of a 14-year-old boy, won permission of his parole board today to marry a widow in Puerto Rico.

Buyers from stores all over the country are heading home, their big task of assembling merchandise for spring and summer selling almost completed. They are highly optimistic for business volume, and they are worried only about how they are going to get home to do the job of selling to the public.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The flow of commercial and civilian traffic between West Berlin and West Germany in the last month was described today by Government authorities as "the smoothest ever."
TUNIS, Jan. 19 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government gave another clear indication tonight of its conciliatory attitude toward France.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- President-elect John F. Kennedy, by nature not an early riser, lost an hour of sleep today.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Delegates to talks here on a Southern Rhodesian constitutional revision agreed today to the drafting of proposals for a Bill of Rights. ThTe proposals will be put before the full constitutional conference when it reassembles later this month, a statement said.

Daily average borrowings of member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped 16,000,000 to $35,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $118,000,000 to $693,000,000 from a revised figure a week ago.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Albert W. Twitchell today was named director of athletics at Rutgers University, effective July 1. He will succeed Harry J. Rockafeller, who made known his retirement effective at the end of the academic year.

The aroused citizens of three upstate communities -- Binghamton, Endicott and Johnson City -- won an emotion-charged battle yesterday to prevent outsiders from taking control of the largest employer in the area.

The National Industrial Basketball League leaders, the Cleveland Pipers, will make their first New York appearance of the season when they face the Tuck Tapers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 18 -- Trudi Garcia, a gentle-voiced woman from Baltimore who operates a flower shop here, looks forward to an interesting but inconspicuous life with Leopold in Puerto Rico.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Stock market prices advanced on a broad front here today, with demand stimulated by the easement of installment buying restrictions.

" Connelly vs. Connelly" will be presented Feb. 17 at the Blackfriars' Guild, 316 West Fifty-seventh Street. The author is the Rev. Brendan Larnen, editor, of the Holy Name Journal, who has had three other plays done by the Blackfriars, "Up the Rebels," "Derryowen" and "Angelic Doctor."
BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The Federal Bank decided today to lower the West German bank rate by one half of 1 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent. The new rate twill go into effect tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The story of John Fitzgerald Kennedy's inauguration tomorrow will be told in more tongues and seen in more lands than any previous American political event.

SHELDON, Iowa, Jan. 19 -- The investigation of a $2,000,000 shortage that has closed the Sheldon National Bank here centered today on the relationship of the admitted embezzler and a Sheldon company that has expanded rapidly in the last year.

A legal question as to the eligibility of Councilman Earl Brown to be elected Manhattan Borough President by the borough's members of the City Council was disclosed yesterday to be under serious study in political quarters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 --There was a quiet mood at 3307 N Street late today as Mrs. John F. Kennedy prepared to move to the White House.

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Two fires burned almost 4,000 acres of brush today. One blaze threatened to force evacuation of 3,000 Marines when it burned within one mile of a camp settlement near here.

President-elect John F. Kennedy was reported yesterday to have selected John S. Stillman, Orange County Democratic chairman, for a sub-Cabinet office without consulting Democratic state leaders in New York.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. John Eyrand's unbeaten Het's Pet, with Bill Shoemaker in the saddle, captured the $17,300 Santa Ynez Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita Park today. It was her fifth victory, and the fifth stakes victory of the meeting for Shoemaker.
Despite the downturn in steel production over the last seven months, the steel industry sharply increased its capital spending during 1960, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A.J. Pupino's Black Darter, showing good speed from the break, won the feature, a six-furlong dash at Hialeah today before a crowd of 14,602.
Two Board of Education architects were accused yesterday of having accepted a $2,340 "free-loading and joy-riding" excursion from a company whose plant they had been assigned to inspect.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- A small quantity of plutonium, a radioactive material, is missing from the Naval Research Laboratory in southeast Washington, the Defense Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Behind the big party Americans are giving their new President tomorrow lie months of decisions on such things as the size of the inaugural cake, what venders cannot sell and the price of parade route hot dogs.

GENEVA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three American business men and a Swiss lawyer were under arrest here today in connection with transportation of $400,000 worth of securities stolen in Miami, where a fifth man was arrested yesterday.
The New York Philharmonic is going to Japan in the spring. On the way back it will give a concert in Anchorage, making it the first major symphony orchestra to visit Alaska.

The New York Board of Rabbis called on its members yesterday to designate an Inauguration Sabbath in honor of President-elect John F. Kennedy. The board suggested the period beginning at sundown today and ending at sundown tomorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, Archbishop of York, was nominated today to become the 100th Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of all England.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points up to 8 points off yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale. The near months -- March and May -- showed the only rises.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was boisterous but generally inconclusive yesterday.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Bob Goalby led at the end of the first round of Bing Crosby's $50,000 golf tournament today with a tremendous finish and a six-under-par 66.
The New York Football Giants yesterday confirmed that they were trying to trade Lindon Crow to the Los Angeles Rams.
Twenty-three hockey players will pay a price -- $25 a man -- for their part in Wednesday night's brawl in Toronto.
At Inauguration exercises yesterday in City Hall, Dr. Edward Joseph Mortola assumed the presidency of Pace College. The liberal arts institution is at 45 Park Row.
A take-off run that ended in flames was described by shaken survivors and witnesses of the DC-8 crash at Idlewild last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
St. Paul, Minn., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $10,634,000 to finance public improvements. Bids on the issue will be received on March 8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The board of directors of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, headed by Norman Thomas, appealed to President-elect John F. Kennedy today to "press vigorously ahead" in 1961 for an agreement with the Soviet Union to ban nuclear tests.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted four companies and two individuals on charges of conspiring to fix prices in the sale of electrical resistors to commercial companies and the armed forces.

The head of the American Jewish Congress called yesterday for a world Jewish movement composed of Zionist groups and "like-minded bodies" to strengthen Jewish unity and "forge vital links with Israel's people."
The Board of Education answered critics of its building construction programs yesterday with a progress report showing it had made a record commitment of $110,000,000 in 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States and Britain were close to agreement today on a plan to revive the International Control Commission in Laos as a fact-finding body.
Sixty city departments and agencies have submitted 1961-62 budget requests totaling $292,587,457 to dat, an increase of $33,257,265 over their combined appropriations in the current expense budget.
Your editorial of Jan. 10 entitled "Low Wages and Trade" requires some elucidation if a wrong impression is not to be conveyed to your readers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today cut off virtually all exports to the Dominican Republic of petroleum and petroleum products, trucks and auto truck parts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower's last full day in office today included the highly unusual as well as much that was routine.
THE result of the deal shown today, which was played in Hawaii, was sufficiently striking to cause comment, but perhaps the bidding is more worthy of comment.

Another snowstorm and a biting wind that drove the flakes horizontally served yesterday to clear the streets of New York of people and to chase thousands of folks into the Coliseum on Columbus Circle. There a shiny, shimmery, alluring boat show made them think of warm weather and summer.

The third in a series of seven Bach programs the Metropolitan Museum of Art is presenting this season was given in Rogers Auditorium there last night by Janos Starker, one of the finer 'cellists in current circulation.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- It used to be routine for a movie to be financed and released by one company. Now the prestige of a movie can almost be measured by the number of companies involved.
The Government filed two antitrust actions yesterday in Federal Court here against companies manufacturing, distributing and selling copper and electrical wires and cables.
HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- Premier Fidel Castro's Government stepped up its hate campaign against "United States imperialism" today.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Two British shipbuilding concerns will submit a joint bid to build a new Cunard liner to replace the 81,000-ton Queen Mary, it was announced here today.

Grand Central Terminal became the world's most elaborate short-cut yesterday. It was also a steam-heated shelter from the snow, a museum of railroading for tourists, a shopping center, a meeting or resting place -- almost anything but a destination.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 19 -- The first violence in the railroad marine workers strike was reported this afternoon. Six members of the Seafarers International Union were arrested after they allegedly beat a truck driver who had ignored a picket line.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Two organizations and two individuals will receive the Interior Department's conservation awards, retiring Secretary Fred A. Seaton announced today.
Harry Stern, supervisor of real estate maintenance for the city's Department of Real Estate, was indicted yesterday on a charge of perjury in the first degree, a felony.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Hollywood came to the financial rescue of the Democratic party tonight with an Inauguration Eve theatrical extravaganza.

State Supreme Court Justice M. Henry Martuscello upset a ruling of the Board of Education in Brooklyn yesterday. He directed the board to grant a permit to an independent Democratic club for the use of a high school auditorium for two meetings.

A PORTRAIT of Representative Howard W. Smith, Democrat of Virginia, whose power as chairman of the House Rules Committee is scheduled to be clipped next week, was offered last night on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Postmaster General-designate J. Edward Day took a look at his new office today. James A. Farley went along with him for a sentimental visit.
The Club of Champions Medal for 1960, highest award of the New York Catholic Youth Organization, was presented last night to William J. Stoutenburgh by Cardinal Spellman.
GARDNER, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Gardner's biggest industry, the Heywood-Wakefield Company, reopened today after a six-day shutdown that might have become a permanent closing.
Julie Harris has started work on the first of two starring roles in television shows that will be presented in the next few weeks.

Directors of the Louisville Nashville Railroad voted yesterday to cut the quarterly dividend to 75 cents a share. The road paid $1 a share each in the quarters ended Dec. 31 and Sept. 30. Previously $1.25 a share was distributed quarterly.
Five national Jewish organizations and a Protestant group for the separation of church and state took issue yesterday with Cardinal Spellman's attack on a proposal for Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The heads of twenty-three railroad labor unions pushed today a request for a Government investigation of train-truck collisions such as the recent nine-death crash at Magnolia, Miss. The group accused the Interstate Commerce Commission of "shocking" disregard for safety.
ROME, Jan. 19 -- Pope John XXIII completed today the investiture of four new Cardinals. They were elevated in a secret consistory Monday.
Spokesmen for school employes asked for salary increases yesterday as the Board of Education ended public hearings on its proposed operating budget of $512,938,523 for 1961-62.
New York's chief weatherman, always the villain when it snows or boils and never the hero when the sun caresses or the zephyrs kiss, announced last night that he was retiring from his job.
Frank A. Johnson is an example of a hereditary executive who is having to learn some of the competitive facts of life that his forefathers escaped.
The prevailing question among aviation experts following last nights jet accident was what part, if any, the weather may have played.

The United States monetary gold stock dropped $105,000,000 the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. at $17,510,000,000, the gold stock was down $257,000,000 since the first of the year.
A four-engined jet airliner with 106 persons aboard careened off a runway at New York International Airport last night in a blinding snowstorm and exploded in an adjoining swamp.

Diamonds, which are the best friend of the giant De Beers organization, have presented some worrisome facets recently. De Beers and its group produce and sell most of the world's diamonds through a virtual monopoly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Plans for tomorrow's inauguration became uncertain as a severe snowstorm tied up the capital tonight.
MIAMI, Jan. 19 -- The aluminum-hulled Ondine, the Class A winner of the St. Petersburg-Fort Lauderdale race, will be in the seventeen-yacht fleet when the Miami-to-Cat Cay race begins at 9 A.M.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 19 (AP) -- East German missile experts are working with Dominican military officers on secret guided-missile tests here, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The classroom shortage in the nation's public schools rose from 135,200 to 142,100 during the last year, the Office of Education reported today.

Events today: "La Gioconda." Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Zadel Skolovsky, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "The Pirates of Penzance," New York City Center, 8:30; Ars Nova Orchestra, Robert Mandell, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; James Caldwell, oboist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON. Pray silence for the new wives who have come to Washington, the side-kicks of the big shots who are about to become our masters.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- New York City renewed its campaign today for a law that would give the city's Investigation Commissioner the power to grant immunity from prosecution to witnesses to encourage them to testify.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The president of the International Lawn Tennis Federation today proposed Davis Cup "open" competition and dropping the definition of an amateur from the world tennis code.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The Most Rev. Arthur Michael Ramsey, who is to become the 100th Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, has attained a reputation for the highest scholarship and acceptance on an equal basis by miners and factory workers of his be loved Yorkshire.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that Senator Jacob K. Javits would make "an excellent candidate" for Mayor of New York in next fall's election.
NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- A 1961 budget of $41,436,554 was approved today by the Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders.
Mrs. Isaac Stern has saved "The Wall," an anti-Nazi Broadway drama about the underground Jewish fighters in the Warsaw ghetto, from extinction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon said today he was not a candidate now but he was not ruling out the possibility he might run for President again in 1964.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and Nobel Prize winner, has asked Premier Khrushchev whether it is true that tile Soviet Union has imprisoned a close woman friend and literary collaborator of the late Boris Pasternak today.

I wish to add a few words to the letter of W.L. Shirer with regard to the postal service. Until two months ago I was a temporary resident of London, England. I lived in the central zone of London, as I do now in New York City. Mail deliveries were three a day, one in the early morning, another at noon and still another at mid-afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- A spokesman for Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that Soviet citizens could get fifty or sixty more professional posts in the United Nations and still remain "far short" of the allowable Soviet quota.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- The merger of California Bank, Los Angeles, and the First Western Bank and Trust Company, San Francisco, was approved today by the Federal Reserve Board in Washington. It will result in a new state-wide banking chain to be known as United California Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Chester Bowles, President-elect John F. Kennedy's choice for Under Secretary of State, opposed vigorously today formal recognition of Communist China or its entry into the United Nations.
New approaches to mental illness place heavy responsibilities on the community for long-term recovery of patients, Dr. Marvin E. Perkins said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- George McGovern, who will direct the "Food for Peace" program in the Kennedy Administration, said today the distribution of agricultural surpluses should be an important and permanent part of foreign policy.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Many nations bade President Eisenhower an affectionate farewell today and sent greetings to his successor, John F. Kennedy.
Rutgers alumni in Monmouth County have remedied a situation that had irked traditionalists on the banks of the Raritan.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 19 -- Hazel Chung, a New York dancer, scored a triumph tonight when she performed a traditional Javanese dance at the State Palace here during a cultural program.
LANCASTER, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Along with the oath of office as President, John F. Kennedy will receive title tomorrow to a cemetery in Ohio.

Ann Ronell, who supplied the English translation for the forthcoming revival of Flotow's "Martha," next Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera, has asked that her name be removed from all program credits. The Metropolitan has agreed.

FORT MEYER, Ga., Jan. 19 -- The four chaplains of the U.S.S. Dorechester, who gave up their lifebelts to other men when their ship was torpedoed in the North Atlantic Feb. 3, 1943, and who were last seen by survivors with their arms linked in prayer, were posthumously awarded a special Medal for Heroism in ceremonies here.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The 1960 victor needed an eagle on the eighteenth hole to win and two former champions were stunned by one-sided defeats today in the first round of the twenty-ninth Helen Doherty women's amateur golf tournament.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 19 -- Dress designers here, there and everywhere are labeling their new spring collections "The Jackie Kennedy look." However, the one designer who should have, did not. Last night Patrick de Barentzen presented his spring collection at the Pitti Palace.
MONTICELLO, Utah, Jan. 19 (AP) -- An Air Force B-52 jet bomber exploded in flight north of this Southeast Utah town tonight. Two of the seven men aboard survived.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Government authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to establish the first space communications link between the United States and Europe on an experimental basis.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 19 -- The determined minority of Socialist trade unions in the Walloon region continued today the month-old strike against the Government's economic program despite signs that some industries were moving from the area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower vetoed today a major expansion of trans-Pacific operations of Pan Amercan World Airways and Northwest Airlines on the ground that it "would unsettle our international relations, particularly with Japan."
ATLANTA, Jan. 19 -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver's legislative leaders introduced measures today that would allow public schools to comply with Federal Court desegregation orders.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 19 -- The United Nations command disclosed today that it had advised its Ethiopian troops in Stanleyville to be on guard against anti-white reprisals following the removal of Patrice Lumumba to a prison in Katanga Province.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Federal Government filed Suit today charging eleven business men in Louisiana with using "serious economic coercion" against a Negro cotton farmer who testified at a Civil Rights Commission hearing last September.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- A leading economic analyst today predicted another year of prosperity and economic growth for Europe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Presidential inaugurations over the years have ranged from the dramatic to the colorless, the orderly to the raucus, the sublime to the ridiculous.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A jury tonight found Mrs. Dorothy Abramo not guilty of a charge that she conspired to murder her estranged husband, Dr. Edward J. Abramo, a physician of Wyckoff.

Among a multitude of problems the Kennedy Administration has inherited a dangerous dilemma in the Far East. There exists in the West a strong antipathy to the Chinese Communist regime. Yet if the arms race and the proliferation of nuclear powers are to be halted, it is clear that mainland China must be a party to whatever agreements may be reached.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 19 -- The right of a parent to inspect his child's public school records was upheld today in the State Supreme Court here.
Futures prices for commodities on the New York exchanges were irregular yesterday in dull and listless trading.

May I voice my admiration of the incoming Secretary of Treasury, Douglas Dillon, who in accepting the post in President-elect Kennedy's Cabinet was courageous enough to put his country above party politics.
An off-duty policeman killed one man and critically wounded another in an exchange of shots during an attempted hold-up of a Queens tavern early yesterday.

Yesterday's combination of snowstorm and strike-disrupted transportation from Westchester and other suburbs cut attendance substantially at the wholesale furniture market here. This was reported by J.J. Melniker, president of the New York Furniture Exchange, focal point of the annual winter event.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- After a visit from President-elect John F. Kennedy, George Meany said today he was still "disappointed" that a fellow union leader had been turned down for the Pentagon's top manpower job.
CHRISTCHURCH, N.Z., Jan. 3 -- A new communications network is going up between here and the Antarctic Continent, 2,100 miles to the south.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers rallied in the last half tonight to gain a 129-122 victory over Cincinnati in a National Basketball Association contest. It was the seventh loss for the Royals in their last eight games.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold a portion of its stockholdings in the Nippon Electric Company, Ltd., of Japan, for "more than $12,000,000."
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The South honored the 154th anniversary of the birth of Robert E. Lee today with quiet ceremonies in Virginia and a legal holiday in ten other Southern states.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- House Republican leaders agreed today to fight the proposed enlargement of the House Rules Committee. But they were not optimistic over prospects of defeating it.

Eight years ago a newly elected President of the United States brought into office with him certain convictions which were destined to play a significant part in his Administration. One of these was a deep respect for the traditional separation of powers under the American system of Constitutional government. Another was a belief, fostered by years of military experience, in the desirability of a chain-of-command delegation of responsibility down the line from top to bottom.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Insurgent members of Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union picketed T.W.U. headquarters yesterday to emphasize earlier protests they said had gone unheeded.

With the New York Athletic Club favored to capture team honors for the fourth straight year, the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships will be staged tonight at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Young American conductors "at strategic points in their careers" will be assisted by a Ford Foundation grant announced yesterday. The project will be carried out by the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore, which is being given $397,500 by the foundation for this purpose.
Robinson Jeffers, a poet of craggy meter and bleak imagery, received the 1960 Shelly Memorial Award for poetry last night.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Jan. 19 -- Tomorrow's inauguration will be celebrated by a Youth for Kennedy group here at an ice cream inauguration party.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Coast Guard reopened the Port of Philadelphia at 4:30 A.M. today after it had been closed for seven hours as a precaution against fire. The closing was ordered after 7,000 gallons of a flammable chemical had spilled into the Delaware River from a pipeline shattered by a ship.

Continuing review of the necessity for expansion of higher education in New York, made by the State University trustees, the Board of Regents and recently by the Heald commission, stimulates confidence that, with the aid of private colleges also, the state will at last assume its appropriate responsibility in this field. The statistics of a new survey by State University trustees show the magnitude of need and cost.

A bid for control of Jacob Ruppert, the brewing company, by the Kratter Corporation, has been abandoned because of Kratter's unwillingness to meet a union demand for severance pay. It was learned yesterday that Kratter, a large real estate organization, would not exercise an option it held to purchase stock from members of the Ruppert family, which would have given it 80 per cent control of the brewing company.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet Communist party has put its stamp of approval on Premier Khrushchev's expressed desire for peaceful coexistence between Communist and capitalist states.
Snow that caused traffic jams here and in the suburbs yesterday threatened new troubles for commuters today.
The city's program to build apartment projects especially for families displaced by slum clearance and other public works took definite shape yesterday.
MANILA, Jan. 19 -- Four anti-Communist Asian nations announced today a solid front against any territorial or political expansion of communism in their area.

FORTUNATELY for the inner Manhattan man, neither snow nor strike has so far caused any crisis in food supplies. Grocery stores afford well-stocked ports in the current storm and the major chains continue to tempt shoppers to buy specially priced items.

The Rev. Daniel Alvarez, Cuban refugee Presbyterian pastor, published an open letter to Cuban Evangelical Christians yesterday voicing "our revulsion over the governmental tyranny which our country is suffering."
Many ski operators in the north were still hoping for a fresh snowfall last night as another storm hit metropolitan New York, powdering streets and highways with new cover.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union renewed today its criticism of United Nations policy in the Congo, charging that it had played into the hands of "Belgian colonialists."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three Democratic Governors and Walter P. Reuther supported today a Democratic bill to help depressed areas. The United States Chamber of Commerce opposed it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A golden clue has helped establish definitely that the explosion in an atomic reactor in Idaho Jan. 3 was caused by an accidental nuclear "runaway."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Harvard has produced more Presidents than any other university. John F. Kennedy, the sixth President with Harvard connections, has turned to his alma mater for many high-echelon members of his Administration.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Bill Tucker of Rockhill, Mo., and Mrs. Laverne Carter of St. Louis today took leads in the men's and women's divisions in the sixth round of the national all-star bowling tournament finals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The stinging bombardment of snow and sleet which a furious north wind hurled today against this inaugural city is a dismal reminder to the American people of the unreliable nature of the luck on which they rely to shield them from the consequences of neglecting essential repairs in their Presidential electoral procedures.
A donor to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday apologized for her "tardy" gift of $5, but said she felt that "poverty knows no special season."

IT is a brave writer who undertakes a modern treatment of the Faust legend. In "A Banquet for the Moon," which opened last night at the Theatre Marquee, John Cromwell throws off scattered diabolical sparks.

BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The dean of the University of North Carolina Graduate School said today that the South needed money badly for higher education and that it must turn to the Federal Government for continued and expanded financial help.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Gene Fullmer-Sugar Ray Robinson bout for the National Boxing Association's middleweight championship was set back today from Feb. 25 to March 4 because lawsuits had delayed Robinson's training.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Soybean futures galloped over a broad range again today in active dealings on the Board of Trade, but closed with the smallest net changes in more than two weeks.
A flurry of legal action on the harbor strike developed yesterday, but when the last precedent had been cited the situation was about where it had been before.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The New Orleans School Board, which has kept its newly integrated school system working since November despite the state government's opposition, admitted today it could not meet tomorrow's payroll unless the Legislature helped out.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- John Fitzgerald Kennedy of Massachusetts will take the oath tomorrow as the thirty-fifth President of the United States.
SOMETHING is always new or looking new in the world of the press agent, though it may not always outrank in importance the inauguration of a President. A few fair and recent samples:
More buyers than sellers were in the bond market yesterday and prices, in consequence, moved upward.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Whether to swear or affirm? The Constitution gives a President-elect a choice.
BAMAKO, Mali, Jan. 18 -- President Modibo Keita of Mali urgently appealed to the incoming United States Administration tonight to proclaim a drastic change in policies toward France and Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Army awarded the Legion of Merit to Lieut. Col. John S.D. Eisenhower today, telling the son of the President that he had done "illustrious service" as a White House staff officer.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The last-place Boston Bruins ran up a three-goal lead and defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 2, tonight before a National Hockey League crowd of 6,899 at the Garden.
Mayor Wagner yesterday directed the City Administrator and six agencies to take prompt action to check the trend toward increased unemployment in the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A photograph of John F. Kennedy, much used as a poster in the last campaign, has just been approved as the basis for an engraving to be added to the collection of the Presidents at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Yielding to increasing demands from business and industry, the Government relaxed installment buying restrictions today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- The Communist party said tonight that Soviet agriculture had failed to meet the estimated rates of increase in food production.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Court of Appeals supported today the application of retired teachers for increased pension benefits.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The State Health Department notified hospitals and foreign-trained physicians today of a new state program of intensive refresher courses designed to enable the doctors to pass American medical examinations.
Renault will cut the price of its biggest selling Dauphine model by $200 effective tomorrow. The price will be $1,385 at the East Coast port of entry.
Efforts by Governor Rockefeller to end the crippling harbor strike failed early today after a night of high hopes that an agreement was near.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today began a series of talks that he hopes will result in the selection of William F. Hyland as the Democratic organization candidate for Governor of New Jersey.
Some bird-world oddities were reported in the greater metropolitan area yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Sentiment is building up in the Legislature to bar the use of state scholarships by students attending segregated institutions.

A tour of the Far East to help promote the 1964-65 New York World's Fair will be started today by William L. Laurence, science editor of The New York Times; Ben Grauer, National Broadcasting Company reporter, and H. Dickson McKenna, an architect.

ANNE MOFFO, Philadelphia soprano whose previous appearances at the Metropolitan were three Violettas in "La Traviata" last season, assumed her second role at the opera house last night. It was Gilda in Verdi's "Rigoletto."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Welfare Arthur S. Flemming said today he disagrees completely with a recommendation to President-elect John F. Kennedy that the Food and Drug Administration should be transferred to the Federal Trade Commission.

St. John's, Newfoundland, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Liberal Government of Premier Joseph Smallwood outlined plans yesterday to prop up Newfoundland's vital forestry industry and promote trade with the Caribbean through a new Government- subsidized steamship service.

Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, and Ingemar Johansson signed contracts yesterday for their third fifteen-round title fight. It will be staged March 13 in the Miami Beach Convention Hall.

ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The United Nations command said today that Patrice Lumumba's transfer to a Katanga jail was an internal matter, but it appealed to Congolese authorities to place the deposed Premier under Red Cross protection.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Two students suspended by the University of Georgia after last week's demonstration against integration were indicted today on riot charges.
The family of an Air Force sergeant lost in the collapse of an offshore radar tower Sunday has forwarded to Congressional investigators his letters warning that the tower was unsafe.
The Citizens union, a non-partisan organization, yesterday announced its opposition to the creation of new judgeships on the State Supreme Court in New York City at this time.
Parents of deaf pre-school children will be told tomorrow of the importance of early beginnings to ease their children's speech and lip-reading problems.
THREE sages appeared at The Players (the home of the sages) to discuss a specific topic.
Earnings of the Monsanto Chemical Company for 1960 fell from the 1959 level, despite a slight rise in sales, it Was reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- Anatoli Kuznetsov, a Soviet novelist, has filed suit against a Roman Catholic publishing house in France on a charge that it had slandered the character of one of his literary heroes.
Thomas Moore Harp, who emerged from a pile-up of 129 candidates with the Cornell football coaching job and three years to go, met some of his non-playing quarterbacks yesterday.

An apartment house for seventy-nine families at 3344 Fort Independence Avenue, near the Kingsbridge Reservoir in the Bronx, has been purchased by Morris Rakowsky, realty operator. Mr. Rakowsky resold his contract of purchase to the Fort Holding Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain's 3-point play with 46 seconds remaining gave the Philadelphia Warriors a 129-127 victory over St. Louis before 7,733 fans who braved a snow storm to see a National Basketball Association double-header tonight.
There may be snow on the ground and it may be January, but plans already are being stirred for the observance of Mother's Day.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday was 177,731,000 board feet, compared with 143,629,000 board feet a week before, which included New Year's, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 242,075,000 board feet.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 -- Former Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos bitterly blamed the United States, particularly J. Graham Parsons, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, today for the warfare in Laos.
The Global Gala will bring together at the Plaza on Wednesday leading members of the United Nations, persons prominent socially in New York and forty students from thirty-two lands.

Today's new film is "Don Quixote," a Russian-made color adaption of Miguel Cervantes novel, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, east of Seventh Avenue, and the Sixty-eighth Street Playhouse, on Third Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- Eastern Pennsylvania lay buried under twelve to twenty inches of swirling, wind-blown snow today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 20 -- Pinhas Lavon, who has been involved in a bitter dispute with Premier David Ben-Gurion, declared today that he would neither resign from his labor-federation office nor submit to a "one-sided" investigation by his party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy seemingly gave one clear sign today that he did not intend to be the nation's most talkative President. His inaugural comprised 1,355 words, far fewer than the average.
Tugboat men not involved in the present strike against railroads will decide tomorrow whether to pile more woes upon the already disorganized port transport industry.
A mysterious regularity in the distances of the planets from the sun, first observed about 200 years ago, is the basis for new consideration of an old idea about how the solar system was formed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Although President Eisenhower's term ended at noon today and President Kennedy did not take the oath until 12:51 P.M. the country was never without a chief executive.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 -- Shareholders of the National City Bank of Cleveland today approved a two-for-one stock split and elected five new directors and two new vice presidents at their annual meeting.
HAVANA, Jan. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro said tonight that the Cuban Government would "begin anew" in its relations with the United States.
State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman reported yesterday that the housing shortage had eased considerably in upstate cities but remained critical in the metropolitan area.
BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Methodist Board of Missions today appropriated $23,583,419 for mission work in the United States and forty-four countries overseas.
Directors of the Central of Georgia Railway at a meeting held yesterday in Savannah, Ga., omitted the quarterly dividend on the common and cumulative preferred stocks of the company.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 20 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced today that the first major legislation to be adopted by the new session of the South African Parliament would be a bill establishing the Republic of South Africa.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 20 -- William R. Chapman, president of Midland National Bank of Minneapolis, was designated chief executive officer at the annual meeting of directors. He succeeds Arnulf Ueland, who announced his retirement this week, Mr. Ueland will continue as chairman.
Two separate legal moves failed yesterday to break the back of the harbor-railroad strike.
The Port of New York will extend its traditional harbor welcome this morning to a new 11,500-ton Philippine cargo ship.

Net assets of the One William Street Fund fell by more than $30,000,000 during 1960, according to the annual report issued for publication yesterday. The big mutual fund reported that net assets on Dec. 31 were $265,810,100, equal to $12.91 a share.

SOME of the New York Philharmonic musicians who live in the suburbs spent yesterday morning digging themselves free from snow. A tiny handful never did make the concert. But, after a fifteen-minute delay, the substantially complete Philharmonic assembled on stage for the afternoon's proceedings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The first day for the new Democratic Administration was cold and blustery, but Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy greeted it, and went through it to the end, with a warm smile.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Senator John O. Pastore today scheduled hearings for Jan. 31 to review radio and television's news coverage of the 1960 Presidential campaign.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 20 -- Anti-European violence has flared again in the Congo's northeast in retaliation for the removal of former Premier Patrice Lumumba to a prison in Katanga.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The right of a restaurant operator to refuse service to Negroes was upheld by the North Carolina Supreme Court again today in cases growing out of last year's lunch-counter sit-in demonstrations.
A pair of obscure relay runners who have never won a major individual race are among the top attractions today in the twelfth annual Cardinal Hayes Games.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Foreign Ministry today called Edgar Snow, an American writer, a man who has been "paying court to the Chinese Communists ever since the Nineteen Thirties."
CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that it was investigating the possibility that Ohio Turnpike bonds had been counterfeited.
The nation's production of paper, paperboard and wood-pulp rose to record levels in 1960, the American Paper and Pulp Association has reported.

The North Jersey Playhouse, which for several years has presented stars of Broadway and Hollywood in recognized dramatic works for theatre buffs of Bergen County, has received clearance to sell the company's stocks and debentures to the general public.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bowie's management announced today its forty-eight-day meet will open tomorrow as advertised. It will lift the curtain on the East's major horse-racing season.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. (AP) -- Flames that shot 100 feet above downtown St. Paul demolished the 102-room Frederic Hotel today. Eight persons were overcome by smoke.
The Cleveland Pipers lost a 14-point lead but rallied to defeat the New York Tuck Tapers, 94 -- 92, in a National Industrial Basketball League game last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -Washington's new African diplomats are uneasy over the continuing housing difficulties and slights they suffer in the United States.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Prospects for a negotiated solution for the six-year-old Moslem nationalist rebellion in Algeria brightened perceptibly today.
Yesterday's storm shut out a sizable amount, of business from the bond market but did not put a damper on the market's bullish tone.
Central and northern New Jersey were again brought to a standstill yesterday by the second big snowstorm within little more than a month.
Following are excerpts from newspaper editorials on the Inaugural of President Kennedy:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Some of them brought formals and tuxedos thousands of miles, then stayed in their hotels. Some of the women shivered in their fashionable and frail gowns while some of their men wore long johns under their white-tie formals at the Inaugural Ball here tonight.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- This is a European capital where Wednesday-night bingo at the American Embassy Club is a major event. Ambassadors and teen-agers alike hang breathlessly on the chant of numbers until the tension is relieved by the call "Bingo!"

Two Navy men and a civilian were feared drowned at the height of the snowstorm early yesterday morning when the truck in which they were riding went off a pier at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. One body was recovered later in the day and the two other men were being sought.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The throngs of celebrating Democrats who saw John F. Kennedy sworn in as President today had to conquer snow, cold and traffic that was only partly cleared of a monumental overnight jam.

HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- A school bus was missing and wind and fire damage was mounting tonight as a winter storm with winds up to ninety miles an hour pounded the Atlantic provinces.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- When Dwight Eisenhower still commanded NATO's armies, he told me his ultimate ambition was "eventually to become a sort of elder statesman, free from political attachments and therefore in a position, if and whenever needed, to advise or influence people for the sake of the whole country."
Several million dollars' worth of boats and nautical accessories went virtually unnoticed yesterday at the National Motor Boat Show.
Jimmy Wright, a charioteer of fabric for bouffant petticoats, was celebrated as a gentleman and scholar in the Garment Center yesterday.
VIENNA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The police arrested today a man named Franz Novak and said he had admitted having served as an aide to Adolf Eichmann in the Nazi program to exterminate the Jews.

As the stock market sagged during most of last year, would-be investors were scared off to some extent and trading activity decreased notably. That 1960 development was underscored by a report on electric utilities' financing last year.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev has ordered a sweeping reorganization of supply and distribution in Soviet agriculture.

NEW ROSS, Ireland, Jan. 20 (AP) -- On the same stone quayside from which the Kennedy's sailed in the days of Ireland's famine, the people of County Wexford danced and sang tonight in honor of President Kennedy.

MASERU, Basutoland, Jan. 10 -- The mingling of ancient tribal ways and contemporary culture is no more striking anywhere in Africa than it is in this small, mountainous British-administered enclave in South Africa.
At the traditionally "interesting", age of 30, Robert Wagner is reshaping his profitable movie career in two significant directions.
Sophia Delza appeared at Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a program of "action dances" from the classical Chinese theatre, which she studied at first hand during some years' residence in China.

BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The University of Buffalo and the State University of New York announced tonight the start of negotiations on the merger of the University of Buffalo into the State University system.
BAMAKO, Mali, Jan. 20 -President Modibo Keita asked France today for the "rapid" removal of her troops and military bases from Mali.

PART-SCORES are valuable chiefly because of their effect on the opponents' bidding. No less an authority than John Crawford has estimated that at times it is worth 150 or even 200 extra points to have a part-score.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman returned to the White House today for the first time since he left office eight years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- American military dependents in West Berlin were declared exempt today from Defense Department regulations reducing the number of such persons abroad. The military dependents in West Berlin will not be affected if there are adequate housing facilities.
HONG KONG, Jan. 16 -- Hong Kong has added to its growing status as the foremost shipbuilding port in Asia outside Japan by turning out a record volume of work in 1960.
THE open door policy is adhered to broadly in two large exhibitions of American art outside of New York, but participated in by numerous artists from this area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, today urged the Senate to undertake an election law study and look into the plight of the 19,000,000 Americans he said were unable to vote in the election of President Kennedy.

In their first response to President Kennedy's assumption of what is generally recognized as "the biggest job in the world," Governments and peoples in many countries have joined in offering him congratulations and best wishes for his success. These expressions of goodwill, mingled with respectful and appreciative salutes to now ex-President Eisenhower, are a tribute to America's standing in the world.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- Milovan Djilas declared today that he had not changed "in essence" any of the ideas for which he spent the last four years in prison.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 20 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower left the official Washington scene today and became an elder statesman.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 20 -- Stockholders in Denver's Central Bank and Trust Company approved a 5 per cent stock dividend at their annual meeting. Each stockholder will receive on Feb. 6 five new shares for each 100 shares now held.

Legal authorities said yesterday that an amendment to the City Charter might be needed to put the propose election of Councilman Earl Brown as Manhattan Borough President beyond challenge in the courts.

NDOLA, Northern Rhodesia, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- Rhodesia's official hangman confirmed today that he had offered his services to Israel as executioner of Adolf Eichmann if the accused wartime murderer of millions of Jews was found guilty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Richard Milhous Nixon became a man without public office today for the first time since Jan. 3, 1947.

A meeting of the Baseball Hall of Fame Committee on Baseball Veterans will be held Sunday, Jan. 29, at the Hotel Commodore. The twelve-man board will be polled in an effort to elect two men to the Cooperstown (N.Y.) shrine.
SANTOS, Brazil, Jan. 20 -- Janio Quadros, who will become President of Brazil in ten days, quietly returned today from an extended stay abroad.
Investigators failed yesterday to turn up any solid clue as to why an Aeronaves de Mexico jet airliner crashed on take-off from a snow-whipped runway here Thursday evening.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in 1960 declined to $42,580,335, or 1.54 a common share, from $46,517,987, or $1.68 a share, in 1959.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the invocation, payers and benediction delivered today at the inauguration of President Kennedy:
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- Dr. Jose Miro Cardona, the first Premier of Cuba under Fidel Castro, predicted today the formation of a rebel government inside Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Mr. Truman and his wife drew a big cheer from the crowd and a standing ovation from both Houses of Congress when they walked onto the platform where Mr. Kennedy was to take his oath.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- France found a "new tone and a new style" today in the Inaugural address of President Kennedy.

Most people think that snow comes when the water vapor of the air is condensed into crystals at temperatures lower than 32 degrees Fahrenheit. A few are beginning to think it is caused by Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte."

Capitalizing on the absence of several weather-bound New York Athletic Club stars, New York University took a commanding lead last night in the race for the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union track and field team title.

PAWCATUCK-STONINGTON, Conn., Jan. 20 -- A purchase agreement under which the Yardney Electric Corporation will take over the 250,000-square-foot building formerly owned by the Raytheon Company here has been announced. The price was not disclosed.
Cold and windy weather plagued the city yesterday in the wake of a twenty-four-hour snowstorm that almost paralyzed the East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Kennedy was widely acclaimed in Congress today for an Inaugural that stirred Republicans as well as Democrats. Diplomats and other public figures also joined in the praise.

A moderately active week is ahead in the market for new capital, with about $115,000,000 of fixed-interest securities concentrated in a few major issues slated for offering. Several major offerings of equity securities are also expected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The United States Government is disturbed by what is regarded here as foot-dragging by the Japanese Government about reaching a settlement of Tokyo's post-war foreign aid debt.
Religion is often more acceptable to a very young child than to an older one, a psychiatrist told the Academy of Religion and Mental Health yesterday.
DALLAS, Jan. 20 -- A flying career that spans the days of canvas-winged open-cockpit planes to 600 mile an hour jets has come to an end for Capt. Ray C. Shrader.
The 7,657 Protestant Episcopal churches over the country will observe Theological Education tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy gathered their family, including fourteen grandchildren, for a buffet luncheon at the Mayflower Hotel after their son took his oath as President.
The snowstorm yesterday gave most city and suburban school children a day off from classes, and many college students a respite from end-term examinations.

The Russian request for more U.N. jobs, as reported to this newspaper by Kathleen Teltsch, illustrates a sharp difference of opinion between the Communist and the non-Communist nations as to what the U.N. is. The Russians have renewed an old discussion by asking Secretary General Hammarskjold to put at least fifty Russian citizens in key U.N. posts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The storm that had raged all night relented with the dawn, and Washington glistened under the sun and snow.
BAIE STE. ANNE, N.B., Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Yvon Durelle is the latest of a long list of professional boxers to travel the route from riches to rags.
MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The transfer of the Continental Air Command (Conac) headquarters from New York City to Macon, Ga., began today.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Bill Collins and Ted Kroll, a pair of conservative professionals from Florida, shared the lead at the halfway mark in the $50,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament today with 36-hole scores of 135 -- nine under par.
John F. Walsh, Supervising Assistant Chief Inspector in the Police Commissioner's office, was chosen yesterday as the new Chief of Detectives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- For a few uneasy moments today it looked as though President Kennedy's inaugural ceremony might go up in smoke.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Discovery of a new oral vaccine for poliomyelitis is causing a delay in inoculation against the disease, the United States Surgeon General said today.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- London's theatre world is looking to Selwyn Lloyd, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, for the final word on whether Britain is to have a National Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are a preface in verse, which Mr. Frost composed for today's inauguration but did not read, and an earlier poem, "The Gift Outright," which he recited from memory:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 - Two top New Jersey Democratic leaders tonight urged Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton to become the party organization's candidate for Governor.

SHELDON, Iowa, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Harold Kistner Jr. was relieved of his duties as president of the Northern Biochemical Corporation by the board of directors late today. The company had been linked with the Sheldon National Bank, closed by a $2,000,000 embezzlement.
INVERCARGILL, New Zealand, Jan. 19 -- "We've been living in a fool's paradise," said the pilot, Jim Monk. "We are dependent to a dangerous degree on the sale of meat, butter and wool."
Webb Knapp, Inc., has announced transfer of its interest in its project to produce steel from waste copper smelter slag to a subsidiary, Gulf States Land Industries, Inc.

Writers who write imaginatively are reluctant to involve themselves in political or national or international turmoil. To do so almost invariably results in conflict of a disturbing nature. As writers are emotionally vulnerable (or they wouldn't be writers) this can seriously affect one of the most cherished things in their lives: their work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The University of Illinois Foundation received a patent this week for an instrument used in bloodless brain surgery. It modifies the nerve structure by focusing on the spot several beams of sound beyond the audible range.
Ralph T. Heymsfeld, executive vice president of Schenley Industries, Inc., was elected chairman of the Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., Thursday at the annual meeting in the Savoy Hilton Hotel.

Terms for a three-year agreement covering 5,000 workers on guidance systems for Atlas ballistic missiles were announced yesterday. The accord was reached eight months before the expiration of the current contract.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The stock market closed a week of steadily improving prices on a firm note today.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The British Government understands that President Kennedy will press the Soviet Union for an agreement on a nuclear-test ban in his first probe of Russian intentions in the East-West struggle.
Oils, steels and motors held back in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but most other major groups rose.
The New York Athletic Club defeated Long Island, 11 -- 7, and Westchester turned back Brookville, 11 -- 9, in a pop double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.
DETROIT, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that the automobile industry had cut proposed production schedules for January and February by 40,400 cars.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- A trust set up by the late Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, has pledged to match any further contributions by others up to half the amount by which a community fund drive falls short, it was announced tonight.

JACK LENOR LARSEN, whose name is well known for turning out fabric designs by the yard, has extended his talents to include fashions design as well.
