HOLYOKE, Mass, -- While some of the populace hover near the fire, or lament the high fuel bills, the rest of the people of western Massachusetts are having the time of their lives enjoying a winter sports season unlike any they can remember.
FORT WORTH, Jan. 21 -- This city's newest cultural institution, the Amon Carter Museum of Western Art, was opened to a preview audience tonight and will be dedicated tomorrow.

LITTLE more than a year ago WCBS-TV began combining entertainment with education in an offbeat half-hour called "The American Musical Theatre." The program, which has been seen most often on Saturday morning (subject to almost any and all pre-emptions) has now bedded down on Sundays at 12:30 P.M.
BUFFALO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- St. Bonaventure's fast break beat Canisius, 96 -- 76, in basketball tonight before 11,787 fans. The crowd was the largest of the season at Memorial Auditorium.

TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif. -- Crowds of winter vacationists are now heading for near-by Palm Springs for a few days of sunshine, a round or two of shirt-sleeve golf and a close-up of movie stars. People who prefer a little less Hollywood and a lot more desert can find them here, about forty-eight miles northeast of Palm Springs.

The Sebring (Fla.) twelve-hour world championship auto race on March 25 probably will be the introductory event for a lot of new racing machinery -- in the Grand Touring and Formula Junior classes as well as in the sports ear division.
"Things getting worse, tower shaking and beginning to get loose."

The White House changed hands last week. Mr. Eisenhower, moving out, had some final comments about the financial condition of the Federal Government and the economy as a whole. He said, in effect, that drastic action was not necessary to sustain the economic health of the nation and that a $3,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 increase in Federal spending, a move recommended by Mr. Kennedy's advisers, would not help the situation quickly enough to be meaningful.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy disclosed today her plans for redecorating the White House.

While I agree with the sentiment of Morton J. Horwitz' letter that if a crime against Jews is only a Jewish concern, humanity is exempt from responsibility, I submit that a very important argument has been overlooked concerning this issue.
The United States Golf Association will hold its annual meeting on Saturday at the Biltmore Hotel.
A two-day public auction of Georgian furniture, antique silver, paintings and rugs at the Parke-Barnet Galleries ended yesterday with sales amounting to $97,830.
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Sir Frank Roberts, the British Ambassador, called at the Soviet Foreign Office today to deliver an oral reply to the Soviet note of Dec. 22 on Laos.

DWARF delphiniums have been much sought by a number of serious hybridizers both here and abroad. Great advances have been made in tall varieties that produce huge stalks with large florets in delightful and novel colors.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 21 -- The long-heralded Congolese roundtable conference is at last to get under way this coming Wednesday. It may be a step toward political realism, cooperation, tolerance and moderation.

STAN BARSTOW'S first novel is so full of surprises that to list the surprises is to review the novel. The first surprise comes on about the third page, when the reader realizes that the setting of the story is the coal country of Yorkshire and not, as the prose suggests, some outlying and peculiar territory of the United States.

A GOOD many collective biographies of our Presidents have been published for both adults and young people, not so many about their wives. Now, thoughtfully issued on Inauguration Day, comes George E. Ross' "Know Your Presidents and Their Wives," which is, so far as I know, the only book to contain one-page sketches of both, right down to and including President and Mrs. Kennedy.

THIS is, on the surface, the most explicit of Elizabeth Taylor's fine, subtle novels. It has to do with conflict that seems more open and obvious than that in her earlier books, more easily caught and described.

Recomemndations designed to make promotion of United States exports more effective have been announced by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. The proposals, which stressed the need to increase manpower and services in Department of Commerce operations in foreign trade, were submitted to Secretary of Commerce-designate Luther H. Hodges.

WHEN Maurice (Rocket) Richard of the Montreal Canadiens sent the puck whistling into the Toronto net during the Stanley Cup playoffs last season, he made a gesture of unusual significance. Yet it had the same effect as a prophecy by Cassandra. No one believed it.
IN a brief five years, a young Baptist minister has emerged from relative obscurity to a position of power and prominence in the struggle against racial codes and customs.

The ten inches of snow that the city was shoveling aside yesterday brought the total snowfall for the season to more than thirty-three inches and left the city within striking distance of a modern record.
The Board of Education has canceled the use of public school facilities by the Queens Youth Center for the Arts, effective next May, on the ground that it is a private business corporation.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Ted Kroll of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., shot a four-under-par 68 at Pebble Beach today for a four-stroke lead at the end of three rounds in the $50,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament.

WYCKOFF, N.J., Jan. 21 -- A binding referendum on the rezoning of from 140 to 160 acres to permit the construction of research laboratories and office buildings here is being advocated by the Committee for Residential Wyckoff.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- Late last night, presumably after all the kiddies had been put to bed, the West German television finally showed Fritz Kortner's TV film "Lysistrata."
When backed up against a wall in a court room, a man, not unlike a mischievous child, is apt to come up with all manner of excuses.
In one of his last official acts as President, General Eisenhower last week appealed to Americans to aid the Cuban refugees.

The determination of the exact location of a radio source in space, regarded as probably "the first true radio star ever found," was reported last week by the California Institute of Technology. The location of the radio star was confirmed optically with the 200-inch Hale telescope on Mount Palomar.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- The 156th Annual Exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts will open tomorrow and continue through Feb. 28 in the institution's headquarters at Broad and Cherry Streets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The reaction to President Kennedy's inaugural speech was even more remarkable than the speech itself. Everybody praised it, from the conservative Republicans to the Communists in Moscow, which is quite a distance. The question now is whether it was a speech or a policy.
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Premier Khrushchev has demanded that the Premier of the Ukrainian Republic step down if he cannot raise farm production.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Within hearing range of riots and gunfire that have erupted so often in Leopoldville, a modern building in park-like surroundings and comparative quiet constitutes the hub of United Nations civilian operations in the Congo.
The frigate Constellation, oldest United States warship afloat, is undergoing a restoration of her history as well as her timbers.

Premier Khrushchev was obviously an angry and unhappy man at the recent Soviet Communist party Central Committee meeting on agricultural problems. Time and again he broke into the reports being made by the top party leaders from different parts of the country to demand the ouster of incompetents, the punishment of officials who were cheating and deceiving the state and the like.
The Boeing Airplane Company's new version of the 707 jet -- known as the 727 -- will make its first flight in 1962.

Although unemployment remained at high levels over the Southwest and was expected to go higher by mid-February, another facet of business looked brighter. For the first time in some weeks, department store sales in major Texas cities reflected gains from the comparable week of last year.

The self-righteousness of Congress on conflict-of-interest problems such as those raised in the McNamara hearings is apparent. The requirements imposed on the Secretary of Defense-designate, as on his predecessors, in disposing of stock holdings are "harsh" in themselves, as the committee chairman admits -- so harsh in our view that they go beyond all reason.

THE centennial observance of the Civil War has opened formally and most media of communications -- newspapers, magazines and books -- are taking extensive notice of the event. The exception is broadcasting, and the reasons for its abstention are anything but attractive.

THE present heavyweight champion of the world, Floyd Patterson, is writing his autobiography, in association with Arthur Mann. Mr. Patterson, that evening by himself, presently is to have a third match with Ingemar Johansson, at the end of which he'll either be champion still, or won't be.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Four of Army's winter sports teams scored convincing victories today.

MIAMI BEACH -- A becoming moderation in business forecasts seems to be the prevailing tone of hotel proprietors as this resort approaches the "big" February season this year. This is a variation from the resounding boasts that were prevalent until two or three years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Kennedy assigned top priority to foreign policy today by conferring for three hours with his Secretary of State, Dean Rusk, and Under Secretary Chester Bowles.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 -- Of all the efforts in Israel to find new supplies of water, nothing has taken so strong a hold on the public fancy as an imaginative plan to tap the ocean.

President Kennedy has been in office this morning less than seventy-two hours, but already it is clear that his assumption of his high office has introduced a major new element into the international situation. Starting with a clean slate, he devoted his eloquent Inaugural Address to making clear his and the American people's desire for peace with honor.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 22 -- The Israeli Government appeared today to have ended its long crisis over the struggle between Premier David Ben-Gurion and Pinhas Lavon to fix the blame for a disastrous 1954 security adventure.

By affiliating himself with a co-producer, Roger L. Stevens will find more time for his various activities. The busy producer's latest move is to align himself with Joseph Fields. They will introduce "Blood, sweat and Stanley Poole," which has to do with life at large Army basic training camp in the South in 1952.
PARIS, Jan. 22 -- European share prices have risen 70 per cent in the last two years, according to a new index just published covering the six Common Market countries together.
The purchase of six Lockheed Jet Star transports for the 1254th Air Transport Wing of the Military Air Transport Service, based in Washington, has been announced by the Air Force.

Myron Feltheimer, co-chairman of the mutual funds division of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, reported last week that industry response had been "spotty." Some concerns have contributed quite generously, such as Hugh W. Long Co., which gave $500, but many others have ignored the plea to date, he said.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- New measures against criminals on the New York waterfront were recommended today by Governor Rockefeller.
Mutual funds, like the times, change.
For the second week in a row prices of over-the-counter industrial securities climbed to a record high last week.

The southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-third Street, opposite the New York Furniture Exchange, has been sold by Louis Puro and Irving Weisner. It contains a four-story garage and several smaller buildings, which are being demolished.
DUBLIN, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Ireland's National Farmers Association called today for Government action to curb an influx of German buyers of Irish land.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Following is the text of statement announcing President Kennedy's appointment of a committee of ethics in the Government:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Kennedy, scarcely slackening his pace even though it was Sunday, set up a special panel today to advise him on problems of ethics in Government and conflicts of interest.
Three persons were burned yesterday when an oil burner explosion set fire to a two-story frame structure at 703 Rhinelander Avenue, the Bronx.
Probably the two coldest men in the city yesterday were a teacher and a college student who dived into the icy Hudson River yesterday afternoon in swim trunks at the Battery for a religious cross.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 22 -- The organization of veterans of the Waffen S.S., the fighting arm of Hitler's elite corps, has called its 75,000-odd members to battle stations against a television series called "The Third Reich."
Winter tightened its grip on the metropolitan area yesterday, with relief still not in sight.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz indicated approval yesterday for Mayor Wagner's proposal to give the city Investigation Commissioner power to grant immunity to witnesses under specified conditions.

The American Bankers Association threw its support yesterday behind proposed new legislation to provide more uniform tax treatment for commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations.
A number of Protestant ministers in this city appealed yesterday to their parishioners to oppose new offorts to get the Legislature to pass a bill legalizing off-track betting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- There will be no cameras or bright lights tomorrow in the conference room of the Association of Motion Picture Producers, but all of Hollywood will be concerned with what happens there.

Private information reaching Cuban exiles and published reports from recent visitors to Cuba indicate that Premier Fidel Castro is losing ground.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Mikhail A. Suslov, a top Soviet theorist, called tonight for a program of universal disarmament that "would abolish the very possibility of waging wars."

THERE is nothing painful about the process of learning when the lesson is about make-up. In a relaxing hour at Elizabeth Arden's salon, the learner reclines in a large tilt-back chair, her feet as high as her head.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana said today that he understood that Dr. Robert C. Weaver, appointed as Housing and Home Finance Administrator, would be questioned in Congress about allegations of pro-Communist activity.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- With 297 competitors still left in the Monte Carlo rally tonight, the rally director, Louis Chiron, said the weather had been so good it was "disastrous."
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg joined Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner yesterday in efforts to end the paralyzing harbor strike.

In these days of self-criticism and unkind comments from abroad it will be heartening to see the annual run-down of American philanthropy made by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. The association's 1960 "Giving U.S.A." will show that, in spite of the business downturn that developed last year, philanthropy went up -- although at a slightly slackened pace.
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Southern Assembly took a stand today in favor of private and state support to higher education over Federal aid.

I am disturbed by recurring proposals to abolish the Electoral College and to elect the President by popular vote. Attractive as these suggestions seem at first, they run directly counter to the principles upon which our nation was founded and upon which we have prospered while competing systems have foundered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The Department Commerce reported today that Americans spent a record of $328,200,000,000 for goods and services last year, or about $1,823 for each man, woman and child in the country.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 22 -- Seven-foot snowdrifts, glare, ice and temperatures as low as 35-degrees below zero helped the third annual twenty-four-hour Tri-State Rally live up to its promise of "winter conditions."

A new state enterprise whose object will be to create an industrial "Ruhr" for Venezuela was formed here recently. It is called the Venezuelan Guayana Corporation, and it is charged with the development of the vast natural resources in the Guayana area of southeastern Venezuela.
The State Commission Against Discrimination has embarked on a drive to eliminate questions about race, color, creed, national origin and age from official paperwork in New York State.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Donald A. Glaser, a University of California physicist who recently received a Nobel Prize and a check for $43,627, plans to "relax."

HISTORY is full of enigmas, unsolved mysteries and spectacular scandals that challenge and fascinate scholars in every generation. Was Mary Queen of Scots guilty of her husband's murder? Did Czar Alexander really die in 1825, or did he arrange a false death and live on for years in Siberian obscurity?
Tension was eased yesterday over a possible strike by 3,500 New York Harbor tugboat workers not involved in the current twelve-day-old walkout. The tugboat men voted to drop their top demand.

The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick in a guest sermon at the Riverside Church yesterday morning found an analogy to modern man's inability to understand God in the Biblical story of Joseph and his brothers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States will have to make a "far greater investment in the field of education than the nation has been willing to recognize" to meet its basic educational needs during the next decade, retiring Secretary of Welfare Arthur S. Flemming warned as he left office.

Preliminary plans have been announced for a twenty-two-story apartment building on the west blockfront of Eighth Avenue between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, three blocks south of the Coliseum.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Two controversial provisions of the Republican program for expanding New York's higher-education system will undergo tests in the Legislature this week. One proposal would encourage the growth of private colleges through state financial assistance; the second calls for uniform tuition charges at all units of the State University.

Msgr. John J. Dougherty, president of Seton Hall University, said yesterday relations had never been friendlier among Roman Catholics, Protestants and members of the Eastern Orthodox faith, but that only God could make them one.

Ohio State's basketball team met its match for about four and a half minutes last Saturday night, but the other thirty-five and a half minutes of play proved to be a continuation of the old Buckeye process -- win, win and win.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- British European Airways disclosed today that while its aircraft had carried 600,000 more passengers in 1960 than in the preceding year, its estimated profits were 500,000 ($1,400,000) less than in 1959.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Eighteen juniors from six colleges and universities have been chosen to spend the summer in Europe studying European nationalism, the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs announced today.
Foreign exchange market was moderately active during the past week as rates maintained a steady undertone. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar fluctuated within a narrow area.

The plan of Federal aid for education submitted to President-elect Kennedy by Dr. Frederick L. Hovde, chairman of the education task force, must be a source of growing confidence for those who believe that the United States is one nation, indivisible, the Government of which seeks to provide liberty and justice for all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Kennedy is considering the offer of an important position in the State Department to a Puerto Rican as part of his program to help Latin-American countries solve their problems.

A theatre party to Thursday evening's performance of the stage spectacle "Viva I'Italia!" and showing of the motion picture "Where the Boys Are" will benefit the Casa Verdi and the Italian Welfare League. All seats in the first mezzanine at Radio City Music Hall have been taken for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that some news reporters who had traveled with President Kennedy in his campaign had helped his cause by emphasizing his "human qualities"' in their articles.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 -- Steel industry sentiment took a dive last week because of auto steel cancellations and pushbacks. But the drop in optimism did not erase the fact that steel order volume does show meager signs of a pick-up in areas other than automotive.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- A pause for consolidation after the sharp price rises that marked the New Year lasted barely two sessions on the Swiss stock markets last week. Volume continued at a high level that rivaled the most active trading periods of last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The first bargain sale on the New Frontier takes place tomorrow.

AN associate was asked the other day to appraise the talents of Robert Osborn Boyd, the member of the National Mediation Board who is trying to find a formula for settling New York's irksome harbor strike.
A mother and six of her nine children were killed yesterday by a two-alarm fire that roared through three Brooklyn tenements.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 22 -- The accreditation of an Israeli Ambassador to Cyprus was hailed today as a triumph over the Arab boycott. The Ambassador, Zeev Levin, presented his credentials Friday to President Makarios in Nicosia.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 22 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower joined other worshippers at the Presbyterian Church here today in a prayer that President Kennedy receive the divine guidance to achieve a lasting world peace with justice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Radio Corporation of American announced today the appointment of Max Lehrer to direct long-range planning in its defense and scientific business.
Heavy winds and rough seas on the North Atlantic have been buffeting the incoming superliner United States to such an extent that the vessel will arrive here a day late.
Louis J. Lefkowitz, New York State Attorney General, said yesterday that he was not yet a candidate for Mayor, but might consider the job.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House of Representatives will probably put into effect this week the plan of Speaker Sam Rayburn to liberalize the Rules Committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Robert Rice of New York defeated Gopal Bhasen of East Orange, N.J., 15 -- 7, 15 -- 6, to win the Metropolitan Badminton Association championship at the Westchester County Center today. Bhasen is an exchange student from India.

Along with broccoli polonaise and bisque of tomato-rice, a veritable aperitif-to-eclair concoction of renowned athletes was served up last night at the annual B'nai B'rith Sports Lodge dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel.

AN apocryphal story once was told about two team-mates who spent four years together on a college football squad and yet never had the opportunity to become acquainted. One was on the offensive platoon, the other on the defensive platoon, and ne'er the twain did meet.
London, Jan. 22 -- The Government's announcement on Thursday of it slight easing of installment-buying restrictions helped the stock market last week.

Last year's unsatisfactory agricultural output in Communist China and the Soviet Union appears likely to have significant repercussions this year on world markets in agricultural products. Communist China has reportedly already entered the world grain market recently to buy 260,000 tons of wheat from Australia, more than 200,000 tons of wheat from Canada and substantial quantities of rice from Burma.
Hugh Gaitskell, British Labor leader, said last night that the Kennedy Administration was "a very strong team."
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- A subtle change is taking place, almost imperceptibly, in the manner of arriving at major state policy decisions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- President Kennedy walked part of the way to church today after picking up newspapers at his home in the Georgetown section of Washington and dropping in on a neighbor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull returned from the injured list tonight and scored two goals as the Chicago Black Hawks routed the Boston Bruins, 8 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game.
This is the week that the story of baseball's "Black-Sox Scandal" of 1919 finally will be put on television.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce predicted today "an economic boom and bust" if the spending proposals recommended to President Kennedy by his advisory groups were put into effect.
SACRED Jewish music, its origins and influence, was examined yesterday in an informative telecast over Channel 7.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- Soviet newspaper readers were told today that millions of simple Americans" held in their hearts great hopes that relations between the United States and the Soviet Union would improve under the Kennedy Administration.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg, the 1959 Professional Golfers Association champion, sank a 14-foot birdie putt on the final hole today and won the Bing Crosby $50,000 golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 282.
Plans of two industries to expand their quarters were contained in announcements of realty transactions in Newark. The deals were negotiated by the Archie Schwartz Company, brokers.
TRENTON, Jan. 22 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton was assured tonight of the Democratic organization designation for Governor if he wants it.
It is, perhaps, an indication of the increasing interest in the guitar as a concert instrument that duo-guitarists should now appear on the musical scene and attract considerable attention.

Buildings Commissioner Peter J.E. Reidy announced yesterday that he had no intention of suspending any of the fourteen employes of the Buildings Department charged with corruption by a state group. Mayor Wagner, who made a special trip to City Hall to make Mr. Reidy's letter public, approved the decision.
A Brooklyn high school girl with literary ambitions has spun an English assignment of three years ago into an exciting and continuing correspondence with a British author in the South Seas.
Protestant Episcopal clergymen over the nation appealed to their congregations yesterday to support theological seminaries.

Because of a sharply increased case load in 1960 the Legal Aid Society, 11 Park Place, New York 7, has been compelled to set its 1961 budget goal at $667,000. The society, founded in 1876, protects the legal rights of the city's needy. Known as "the poor man's lawyer," this agency provides legal representation only to those who cannot afford to pay a lawyer.
Verdi's "Aida" was given by the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night for the first time in nearly two months.

Radio Corporation of America announced over the weekend that it had developed basic circuitry capable of operating at speeds approaching that of light and 1,000 times faster than the circuits now used in most data processors.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The message for spring is that hemlines will be short, bosoms will be de-emphasized, waistlines will be unimportant and clothes will be constructed "casually," "on the, bias" or with flaring skirts. Also, hats will show the hair-line and hair will be short and shaped like an artichoke or cut as short as a boy's.
THE most difficult slam to bid, in the casual bridge game, is one in which a player has such a solid hand that he can jump to game quickly, either in a suit or in no-trump:
DETROIT, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Three goals by Dean Prentice and two by Pat Hannigan enabled the New York Rangers to beat the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 5 -- 3, before a crowd of 10,390 at Olympia Stadium.

PEIPING, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist press coupled mounting abuse of President Kennedy and his Cabinet today with predictions that United States policy would not change under the new Administration.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 22 -- There is an air of expectation in this baroque and gothic capital of Communist Czechoslovakia.

Gordon MacKenzie of the Bronx, a member of the United States Olympic track team in 1956 and 1960, paced the New York Pioneer Club to team honors yesterday in the Amateur Athletic Union's 30-kilometer championship.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 22 -- Six trucks with arms were reliably reported today to have arrived at Aru, a town close to the Congo's frontier with the Sudan. WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A renewed controversy seems to be developing over the naval career of Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, nuclear pioneer.
EDITH EISLER is a capable violinist and her Carnegie Recital Hall program yesterday afternoon was full of interest.

Investigators of the wreck here of a Mexican jetliner last Thursday urged yesterday that witnesses and passengers who escaped and walked away come forward to aid in the inquiry.
The president of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday urged Roman Catholics to "demand their place in the educational sun."
HAVANA, Jan. 22 -- Premier Fidel Castro has announced that youngsters from 10 years old upward will be taught to be farmers.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The long rampant soybean market appeared to have run out of steam this week as it bumped into three successive setbacks on the Board of Trade and finished narrowly mixed.

Governor Rockefeller's interest in assuring an adequately financed completion of the state's inquiry into corruption and mismanagement in the New York City government is encouraging. DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Gene Shue and Bailey Howell paced the Detroit Pistons to their fifth straight victory today. The Pistons defeated Philadelphia Warriors, 136 -- 128, in a National Basketball Association game.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" and Joseph Rosenstock, conductor, will return to the Metropolitan Opera together during the fifteenth week of the company's current season.

ALTHOUGH New York viewed from a great height is one of the most visually exciting places on earth, there are astonishingly few restaurants that take advantage of the fact.

The appointment of John A. Wallace as director of the city's new Office of Probation was announced yesterday. The office was created by the Legislature in 1960, to become effective Jan. 1 this year.

Novels by Jon and Rumer Godden, the well-known writing sisters, are planned for publication two weeks apart. Jon Godden's novel, "A Winter's Tale," will be issued Feb. 17 by Knopf. It is the story of a "careless love affair," set in a snowbound English country house.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 22 (AP) -- United States Shoe Corporation reported over the weekend record 1960 sales of $51,441,001 and earnings of $3,073,785, equal to $2.72 a share of common stock.
The Manufacturers Trust Company would pay a premium of about $4,300,000 to merge with the Hanover Bank, the First Boston Corporation says in a study of the merger proposal.
AKRON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The New York Tuck Tapers rallied in the last three minutes to defeat the Akron Goodyear Wingfoots, 92 -- 89, today in a National Industrial Basketball League game.
TOKYO, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- Work is expected to start soon at two Japanese shipyards on two 130,000-ton tankers for a Japanese oil refining company. They will be the largest in the world.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,691,267,639. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Miss Shirley Frances O'Neill of San Francisco and Donald McGregor of Brunswick, Ga., are the winners of the Government's Young American Medals for Bravery in 1959, it was announced today.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Legislative action on tax relief for nonresidents working in New York State will be discussed tomorrow at a conference of Republican leaders and Governor Rockefeller.
Nine days of artificial summer ended last night at the Coliseum: The annual delight known as the National Motor Boat Show hoisted its anchor at 7 o'clock and winter returned.

Charles Ufford, a 29-year-old lawyer, scored an appropriate victory yesterday at the Harvard Club. He became the first Harvard man in the fifteen-year history of the Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament to take the top award.

That a dispute over the jobs of less than a hundred men on ferries and tugs in the harbor could shut down traffic on two essential railroads serving several states, and that the personal and business lives of hundreds of thousands could be disrupted by it -- all this is truly intolerable. The situation calls for hard thinking by all concerned as to how this sort of thing can be stopped now -- and prevented.

New York Airways, the local helicopter service, will begin flights from American Airlines' new terminal at New York International Airport today. It had conducted its passenger flights from the old domestic terminal, which is to be torn down in the course of the airport's modernization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee has reported to President Kennedy that the United States merchant marine has declined alarmingly.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 22 -- The spotlight quickly swung today from Billy (The) Kidd, the young and aspiring campaigner from Stowe, to Les Streeter and Gordy Eaton, former Olympians, as the two-day Eastern Alpine Ski Championships ended.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- A new era began somewhat officially today in the ancient Japanese sport of sumo, a type of wrestling that matches two barefoot, long-haired giants on a raised clay platform in surroundings resembling the interior courtyard of Shinto shrines, where these matches were originally held about 2,000 years ago.
The Congo is not all gloom and chaos, Bishop Newell Snow Booth said yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The prestige of the United States abroad is by no means a mere reflection of our material power. It is not to be measured in terms only of military or economic strength, either absolute or relative. On the contrary when in times past we were poor and weak as compared with other lands, we have been both envied and admired for expressing philosophical ideals new to a jaded political world.

SOMEBODY'S urge to be cozy almost got the best of the third Town Hall Festival Concert, which was presented yesterday afternoon. It didn't, though, because -- despite their name -- the Fireside Players are professionals who can perform competently even when their scores are little better lighted than they might be by a candle or two and an open fire.

UNIONS -- New York Railroad Harbor Council, composed of units of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, and the Seafarers International Union.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit of Toronto won the Doherty women's golf tournament for the third straight time today. She defeated Phyllis (Tish) Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., 3 and 1, in the 36-hole final.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg expects to share in shaping the Administration's economic policy beyond the confines of "labor" matters.
BEST known as the characteristic ingredient of a fluffy cream dessert, quick-cooking tapioca also can be used to advantage in many main dishes.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Sgt. Vincent Nolan, head of the Movie Censor Bureau of the Chicago Police Department, hailed the Supreme Court decision today as a victory for Chicago and movie censorship.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- The Scarsdale Golf Club said today that its members could bring any guests they chose.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Orders worth 18,000,000 ($50,400,000) for 8,700 nautical miles of submarine telephone cable and 335 submerged amplifiers have been placed with British manufacturers for what was called the world's longest telephone cable.
The Soviet Union is shopping around to buy "something good" in New York real estate -- possibly a 200-room Park Avenue hotel -- to ease the pressure for housing on its mission to the United Nations.
Arnold Palmer and Sam Snead will be among those honored at the national awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association tonight. The dinner will be held at the Hotel Pierre.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- A United States District Court judge today ordered that Sumter County voter registration records be shown to Federal Justice Department agents within twenty-four hours. He threw out a state court order that the records be withheld from the agents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -The Republican minority in the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today against liberalizing the Rules Committee.

There were 957 ships of 1,000 gross tons or more in this country's active merchant marine on Jan. 1, according to the Maritime Administration. This represents an increase of eighteen in the fleet over a year ago and seventeen over last month.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Northwestern's basketball team knocked Purdue out of a tie with Ohio State for the Big Ten lead tonight with an upset 64-62 triumph. The Wildcats scored their last 8 points on free throws four in the final twenty-two seconds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk emphasized today their preference for unpublicized normal diplomatic channels over summit conferences in seeking solutions of world problems.

Carmine G. De Sapio, New York County Democratic chairman, announced last night that his organization would seek to purge all fifteen district leaders identified with the reform movement. In thus declaring all-out warfare, the Tammany leader accused dissidentswithin the party of using the banner of reform to "mask their hypocritical attempts at power-grabbing."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Horace E. Davila, 42 years old, a former newsboy who started with Puerto Rico's First Federal Savings and Loan Association twelve years ago as a janitor, was elected president today.
The results of a lie detector test yesterday freed a man charged with armed robbery in General Sessions court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Tobacco-State Congressmen told Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today that a 10 per cent increase was justified for burley tobacco acreage allotments.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Staff workers for the Air Line Pilots Association charged today that Clarence N. Sayen, the association president, had employed anti-union tactics against a union they had formed.
An unemployed mechanic whose wife and six of his nine children died Sunday in a Brooklyn tenement fire spent yesterday at a relative's home.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- The Chrysler Corporation is making major reductions in its white collar personnel, industry sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -President Kennedy intends to funnel political patronage through John M. Bailey of Connecticut, the newly elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

Modest gains in futures prices were the general rule on the New York commodities markets yesterday in mostly dull trading. A few of the commodities had mixed closing prices, while one or two showed declines.
Leaders of virtually all Zionist groups in the country last night called for the strengthening of their movement as the major force for intensifying moral and financial support of Israel.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -The Government is preparing an offer of $1,200,000,000 in various financial undertakings as a contribution to the solution of the United States' balance-of-payments problem.

Mayor Wagner called on Governor Rockefeller last night to halt what he termed the "smear and run" tactics of a special unit of the State Investigation Commission assigned to inquire into corruption in the city government.

The Stepan Chemical Company, Northfield, Ill., announced yesterday plans for manufacturing "anti-knock" gasoline additives. An Italian Company, Societa Lavorazioni Organiche Inorganiche which has produced anti-knock additives for the European market since 1935, will furnish the "knowhow" for making the tetraethyl lead and the tetramethyl lead, which are used making the anti-knock additive.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Norwegian shipowners and officials are concerned about the "Ship American" campaign in the United States -- and they are planning steps against it.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 23 -A major airport in a $70,000,000 airport system proposed for Suffolk County was rejected today by the County Board of Supervisors.

Staff reports on background research for the Moore commission, which is recommending Charter reform for New York City, show how badly the present every-borough-for-itself system of street repair and sewer construction and maintenance works. They also demonstrate the need for standards of manpower and equipment utilization, as well as an administration that will follow through once the statistics are in hand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The first money bearing the signatures of Douglas Dillon, the Secretary of the Treasury, and Elizabeth Rudel Smith, the new Treasurer of the United States, rolled off the presses today.
CAIRO, Jan. 23 -- The Government is ready to approve formally a plan to preserve twin monuments built by Rameses II at Abu Simbel, in Nubia, by lifting them 200 feet out of a rock mountain.

"NEW YORK SCRAPBOOK," the revue that began last night on "The Play of the Week," contains the old, the new and the borrowed. And although some of it has been done previously in night clubs, there's nothing blue about it. Altogether it represents a bright and enjoyable television attraction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Russia may be losing its traditional leadership in mathematics because of overemphasis on applied research.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said last night that the reunion of Christendom could best be achieved by cultivating a "spirit of unity" and cooperation rather than by the formal fiat of organic union.

A Queens physician was held yesterday on a charge of homicide in an attempted abortion. He was also charged with falsifying a death certificate.
NICE, France, Jan. 23 -- In the snowbound villages of the French Alps, hotel owners, shopkeepers, ski manufacturers and ski instructors are rubbing their hands with glee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- There is insufficient demand to support a strong advance in residential building this year regardless of the supply of mortgage money, members of the American Bankers Association were told today at their thirteenth National Credit Conference, being held at the La Salle Hotel.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -Although trade appeared to be rather listless, grain futures prices worked generally higher here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that an employes' union representation election might not be set aside because of error in listing the employer's name on the ballot.

The hat company that a union bought in a "rescue operation" two years ago has increased its business by more than one-third since its workers became its owners.

In May of last year, at the time of the summit meeting in Paris, a group of statesmen and educators met at the University of Chicago to consider the abatement of some world tensions. The discussions are presented in "The Promise of World Tensions," which Macmillan will issue Feb. 13.

S. Hazard Gillespie Jr., United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to President Kennedy, effective Jan. 31.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Hugh Gaitskell predicted today that the United States' foreign policy under the new Administration would show more flexibility in its approach to the problems of neutral areas such as Laos and the Congo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, called today for a Senate investigation of the country's decline of gold reserves.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Assembly gave final approval tonight to a constitutional amendment placing the state's credit behind $100,000,000 in securities to finance the purchase of railroad commuter cars.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Agriculture Department may purchase some foodstocks not in the Government's surplus holdings for distribution to the needy, Secretary Orville E. Freeman said today.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -Harold S. Geneen, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, estimated today that his company would report earnings of $1.96 a share from 1960 operations, not including a special net credit to income of 54 cents a share.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The body of M/Sgt. Roald Bakke, one of twenty-eight men who died in the collapse of a Texas Tower radar station 105 miles off the New Jersey coast Jan. 15, was brought ashore Sunday by an Air Force helicopter.

ARNOLD PALMER has been a blazing figure in golf over the past twelve months. He won the Masters, the United States Open and a record $80,738 in prize money. He was heralded as "Sportsman of the Year" by Sports Illustrated, and last night was acclaimed in Rochester as the "Professional Athlete of the Year," a distinction that earned for him the $10,000 diamond- Studded Hickok Belt.
ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived in this south Georgia city this afternoon for a vacation.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Workers on state farms in the Soviet Union are to get incentive bonuses in a move to stimulate an improvement in the quantity and quality of agricultural output.
The start of operations here by the privately run United Philippines Lines was hailed yesterday as a milestone in Filipino economic development by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -Nick Skorich, the line coach for the football champion Philadelphia Eagles, was elevated today to head coach.

A committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday gave qualified support to a Senate bil that would relax the Federal ban against wiretapping by state law enforcement officers.

The New York Rangers' Stanley Cup play-off chances received another jolt yesterday with the loss of Bill Gadsby, a seasoned defenseman. He will be out at least two weeks.

The Russian Orthodox Theological Fund will receive the proceeds of a cocktail reception next Sunday in the salons of d'Argout-Ferguson, Inc., decorators, at 6 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The Copacabana, one of the last Manhattan preserves of the vanishing species, showgirl, has put a new batch on display. Students of local fauna might want to have a look at them, as well as at their counterparts at the Latin Quarter, before the breed becomes extinct.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs declined again today, reflecting the continued easing of money conditions.

Conde Nast Publications, Inc., is getting out of the dress-pattern business by transferring its operations in that field to the Butterick Company, Inc., another pattern manufacturer.

The Minneapolis-St. Paul Metropolitan Airports Commission, Minnesota, borrowed $2,200,000 in the bond market yesterday. The money was raised on serial obligations due from 1964 to 1981 and callable in 1973.

The midwinter benefit for the Play Schools Association, a Valentine Bridge and Canasta Party, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Feb. 6. Traditional red and white decorations will provide a colorful setting.
Sales of the Allied Chemical Corporation rose to a new high in 1960 and earnings were the second highest in its history, the company disclosed in a preliminary report yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -The Labor Department reported today that the number of persons claiming unemployment benefits had risen to a record for the first week of January.

ON the day of President Kennedy's inauguration, an album entitled "The National Purpose" appeared on this desk. Recorded by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, it contains eight of the articles on this subject that appeared in Life magazine and The New York Times last spring.
There must be "no tampering" with the present price of gold, Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.
Pamela Cook gave a harpsichord program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was her first New York recital.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- Another former Chrysler official, Jack W. Minor, has sued the automobile company for $200,000 in damages he asserts that he has suffered as the result of his forced resignation.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Republican State Senators informally approved tonight the allocation of public funds for the expansion of private colleges and universities.

The presence of Primo Carnera and Antonino Rocca on the card drew a crowd of 14,783 to Madison Square Garden last night for a wrestling exhibition. The fans left happily after both heroes had won in tag-team matches.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 23 -The Westchester Board of Supervisors gave fifty miles of the county's chief parkways to the state today.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Pierre Cardin today revived the chemise, the Nineteen Twenties, and some of his own designs from last season. The result was a brilliant but divided collection. One half was as modern as tomorrow, the other half a period piece.
