Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose more than one-half of 1 per cent yesterday as speculative sentiment emerged from its week-end snowdrifts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A 5-to-4 majority of the Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of state and local movie censorship.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Demand for industrial shares was small and selective on the stock market here today.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 23 -- Ten years after Ghana's new oil refinery at Tema begins production, a half share of it will be given to the Ghanaian Government This was disclosed today when terms of the agreement were made public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court unanimously ruled today that Elijah McNeal Jr., an indigent man serving a twenty-year jail term in Florida, must be given a hearing on his complaint that his trial had been unfair.
The city Board of Higher Education called last night for the establishment of a City University of New York as a tuition-free institution independent of the State University of New York.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, reaffirming that he would not be drafted to run for Mayor, said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller "knows and understands my position thoroughly."

ATHENS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The United States aircraft carrier Saratoga caught fire at sea today and seven crewmen were killed by the smoke. Twenty-three men were injured, one seriously, in the second tragedy to strike an American carrier in little more than a month.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Swarms of blackbirds with a taste for corn, strawberries, cherries and peaches are costing New Jersey farmers $2,500,000 to $4,000,000 a year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- There is a tendency in the movie business to be skeptical of the motives of anyone who makes a movie based on the day's headlines.

The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday preliminary net income for 1960 at a record $112,400,000, equal to $3.27 each on the 34,358,474 shares outstanding. Gross income was placed at $1,225,000,000.

On Dec. 9 the U.N. General Assembly awarded the United Arab Republic a seat on the Security Council -- a position of great honor and power. As far as anyone knows or can find out, the United States went along with this action.

VIENTIANE, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Pilots landing at the Government-held airfield at Tha Thom in Xienghouang Province must look first for a code letter on the ground to be certain that the field has not fallen to the Left-Wing rebels.

DUNEDIN, New Zealand, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Jim Parks, the wicketkeeper, scored 82 runs in 112 minutes today to carry an English all-star team back into the thick of the first unofficial cricket test match against New Zealand.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Troops of the United Arab Republic are to be withdrawn from the United Nations force in the Congo, it was announced here today.
The Textile Workers Union called yesterday for a Congressional investigation of the National Labor Relations Board.

It will be in the best interests of the Democratic party and the people of the City of New York that the Democratic organization in Manhattan oppose and oust these self-styled leaders who seek to rule or ruin the party.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 23 -- Striking university and high-school students resorted to violence today to prove their strength to merchants whom they had implored in vain to close all businesses.

The Dreyfus Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that total net assets were $170,898,771, equal to $15.10 a share on 11,317,895 shares outstanding at the end of 1960. This compared with $95,086,377, or $15.10 a share on 6,298,344 shares outstanding, a year earlier.

Emphatic firmness was registered yesterday in all parts of the gilt-edge bond market -- United States Government securities, the serial obligations of local government, and the high-rated, long-term bonds of private corporations.

Talk about inflation is in minor key these days, but the National Industrial Conference Board has pointed out that the consumer price index rose in forty-eight of the last seventy months. It climbed from 114.3 in January, 1955, to 127.4 by last November, with the 1947-49 period taken at base 100.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy prepared today to implement her resolution to stress American creative arts in residential quarters of the White House.

Associates Investment Company, South Bend, Ind., the nation's fourth largest sales finance company, announced reductions yesterday of 1/8 to 1/4 percentage point on most maturities of its short-term obligations sold directly to investors.

Directors of Loew's Theatres, Inc., are expected to hold a special board meeting today that originally had been planned for last week. When the meeting is over the office of the president may be vacant or have a new tenant.
TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- The State Supreme Court was asked today to reapportion without delay the sixty seats in the State Assembly because the Legislature had not done so for the last decade.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The price of gold remained steady on the London bullion market in quiet trading today.
More than $150,000 in property stolen on the city's waterfront was recovered last year through the Security Bureau, Inc., James P. McAllister, president of the organization, said yesterday.

RONALD Turini made his Carnegie Hall debut last night. He is a young, handsome and talented pianist who has been winning all kinds of prizes in Europe and who has been working for the last few years with Vladimir Horowitz.

New public library branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and on Staten Island would be established from now on in rented structures built specifically for them by private capital, under a plan put forward yesterday by the New York Public Library.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, the United States Open and Masters golf champion from Latrobe, Pa., tonight was named winner of the $10,000 diamond-studded Hickok belt as the professional athlete of the year for 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate confirmed sixteen of President Kennedy's nominees for sub-Cabinet positions tonight with only minor opposition.

Chief Judge Sylvester J. Ryan of the United States Court of the Southern District approved yesterday the distribution by receivers of the defunct New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company of $8,805,149 to cover claims by the Government and creditors against the road.

HARTFORD, Jan. 24 -- The characteristic of the new Governor of Connecticut, John Noel Dempsey, that stands out perhaps most prominently at the moment is his deep loyalty to the old Governor of Connecticut, Abraham A. Ribicoff.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet charge that Mme. Olga Vsevolodnaya Ivinskaya, close friend of the late Boris Pasternak, had criminally accepted large sums of money from foreigners was described here today as "unthinkable" by the young Frenchman who was to have become her son-in-law.

The man who calls himself the "stormy petrel" of international finance -- Dr. Franz Pick -- told the International Executive Association yesterday that "nobody wants to hear unpleasant facts." But he proceeded to tell the import-export group about the troubled plight of the United States dollar.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 24 -- The United Nations command in the Congo is considering ways to meet the increasing threat of civil war with thinned-out troops.
The Dominion Tar and Chemical Company, Ltd., has offered to acquire all of the outstanding common shares of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., a leading Canadian paper manufacturer.
The Court of King Henri Cristophe d'Hayti has been chosen as the theme of the National Urban League Guild's Beaux Arts Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 17.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- A special camp for senior Boy Scouts who have skills in the sciences is being set up at Wingdale by the Siwanoy-Bronx Valley Council.

The third annual award of the American National Theatre and Academy wil go to the Ford Foundation for its "outstanding contribution to the art of living theatre," it was announced yesterday. It will be presented during the four-day assembly of the national organization, which takes place Feb. 5 to 8.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- With buyers increasingly cautious, a slight increase in selling brought widespread falls in industrial share prices on the stock market here today.
The Norfolk and Western Railway reported yesterday that net income in 1960 was higher than in 1959, although gross receipts declined.
Commuters who use the New York Central Railroad face the possibility of a new shutdown of the road this week-end.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks held Wilt Chamberlain to 16 points tonight in defeating the Philadelphia Warriors, 114 -- 112, in the National Basketball Association.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- A Roslyn, L.I., woman stockholder today filed suit charging that four top executives of the Fruehauf Trailer Company were given more than $700,000 in bonuses through an "illegal" act of the board of directors.
THERE was the splendid aura of a bygone era at Town Hall last night when Marcel Grandjany gave a harp recital there.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The estates and survivors of twenty-six persons who died last year in an airplane crash at Bolivia, N.C., have sued National Airlines for $6,240,000 damages.
Reached by telephone here last night, Dr. Travell, said with a laugh that the report from Washington was "a little premature."
ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 24 -- The Ghana Government published today a bill that will prevent gold mining companies from closing a mine without Government consent.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The University of North Carolina will not compete in the championship basketball tournament of the Atlantic Coast Conference.
The city's five District Attorney's joined Mayor Wagner yesterday in denouncing the "reckless" methods of the state agency assigned to investigate possible corruption in the city government.
Gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases reached a record yesterday as the contributions went to $562,025.80.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Federal Communications Commission's decision to cancel its grant of Boston Television Channel 5 because of attempted back-door influence has been affirmed by the Court of Appeals here.
A water-main break brought water pressure to zero yesterday at many points in lower Manhattan in a section two and a half miles long and up to a mile wide.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The state was urged today to grant about $153,500,000 this year in special aid to public schools, including $30,000,000 for "fast-changing" school districts.

Mrs. Lillian Malley Vernon, a lawyer, was elected president of the Police Athletic League yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of directors at Police Headquarters. She is the first woman civilian to head the P.A.L.
Adlai E. Stevenson will appear on the first of "The Great Challenge" shows this season on Sunday, Feb. 19.
The Portuguese cruise ship seized in the Caribbean was built less than nine years ago at a cost of $17,500,000, according to United Press International.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 24 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's Government angrily denied tonight reports that the Portuguese cruise liner Santa Maria had been seized for political reasons. A spokesman said: "The men who attacked the Santa Maria are not politicians or ideologists. They are just outlaws."

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The British Government said today that a Royal Navy frigate had acted properly and in accordance with international law in agreeing to pursue the Portuguese liner seized by political rebels.
No one who knows anything about Latin America will disagree with Dean Rusk's Senate pronouncements or with your editorial of Jan. 14. Since World War II we have neglected our southern neighbors.

For the second time in two months the management of the Alleghany Corporation has been ordered by New York State courts to give its stockholder list to the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., who seek to gain control of the vast holding company.
Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation proposed yesterday a split of the common stock on the basis of an additional half share for each share held.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
George D. Widener, the honorary chairman of the New York Racing Association, was re-elected chairman of The Jockey Club at its recent annual meeting, the club revealed yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- A unity meeting here of top Republican leaders in the state failed to achieve its major goals today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 off to 15 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
The city's Department of Hospitals yesterday renewed its request for funds to hire paid, full-time directors of hospital services.
BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- East German officials predicted today a record-breaking Western participation in the Leipzig Trade Fair.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the New Rochelle Board of Education had "deliberately" created and maintained a racially segregated school.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg ordered today an investigation of the arrangements under which James G. Cross would quit as president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union.

One reads about the seizure of the Portuguese luxury liner Santa Maria, her 600 passengers and her crew of 300 with a sense of incredulity. Mutiny on the high seas in 1961, and in the Caribbean, too! Shades of Drake and Hawkins, of Captain Kidd, Blackbeard and Henry Morgan!
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 --George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to Moscow, will return to the diplomatic service as President Kennedy's Ambassador to Yugoslavia.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24 -- Gen. Humberto Delgado, an exiled opponent of Premier Antonio de Oliveiro Salazar of Portugal, said today that the seizure of the liner Santa Maria was a political act carried out by his forces.
The Echo I saellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, ten times between Jan. 25 and Jan. 31, inclusive, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

IT is good to be an old master. Picasso can make a doodle on a piece of wrapping paper; and as long as he puts his name to it, the doodle is no longer a doodle. It is Art, and it is also now worth x numbers of dollars. Many x's.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 24 -- The Belgian Government fears that Communist penetration of the Congo is going on while public opinion in Western nations is concentrated on an alleged "double game" played by Belgium in her former colony.
ROME, Jan. 24 -- Pope John XXIII has transformed the whole of Indonesia from missionary territory into an ordinary ecclesiastical territory with a hierarchy and a clergy of its own.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24 -- A.C. Gilbert, founder and board chairman of the toy company bearing his name and inventor of the Erector Set, died today in Boston's New England Baptist Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 76 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The constitutionality of a law that regulates the erection of billboards within 500 feet of the New York Thruway was upheld today by the Appellate Division.

The insurgent group, which was unsuccessful in its attempt to unseat the management of Goldfield Consolidated Mines Company in a proxy fight last May, has increased its stock holdings in the company substantially in the last few weeks.

OVER the past two years the demand for diminutive sizes has doubled at one store here. When the Sutton Place opened on the third floor of Bloomingdale's in 1959 it sold mostly dresses and suits in misses' sizes and others (20 per cent) in sizes 3 to 15.
THE director of admissions at Princeton was singularly unprophetic when he filed his report on the interview.

The Yankees yesterday took the first step toward restocking their ranks for the 1961 American League campaign. General Manager Roy Hamey revealed the names of twenty-six players who will report to the Bombers' advance training camp starting at St. Petersburg, Fla., on Feb. 13.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Circulation of a newspaper with a strong anti-Semitic slant caused the Arkansas House to revive a resolution requiring approval of such material by the House Clerk before it can be distributed in the House.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Frank (Trader) Lane swung his first deal as general manager of the Kansas City Athletics today. He obtained five Baltimore Orioles for two outfielders, Whitey-Herzog and Russ Snyder.

A report urging that the Borough Presidents' administrative powers be transferred to city departments and the officials themselves transformed into members of a reorganized City Council was made public yesterday by New York Americans for Democratic Action.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 24 -- The West German Government announced tonight that negotiations with Poland on relations between the two countries would take place "through official channels."

Critical deficiencies and chaotic standards in training English teachers have seriously depressed the level of learning in the nation's elementary and high schools, according to the National Council of Teachers of English.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The War Office announced tonight that Gen. Sir Richard Amyatt Hull would succeed Field Marshal Sir Francis Festing as Chief of the Imperial General Staff.
ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Army Hawk guided missile has displayed new anti-missile ability with destruction at supersonic speeds of a Corporal missile.
Donald Gramm, who sings here on many occasions with orchestra, gave his first New York solo recital in two years last night in Judson Hall.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Lillian Fratantonio was sentenced to a year in jail and fined $500 today for feeding her two daughters sleep-inducing drugs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Old crop soybean contracts today advanced the 10-cent limit allowed for a single day on the Board of Trade, but retreated slightly before the close.
ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he considered the seeming peace overtures of the Soviet Union to be insincere and a repetition of earlier actions.
The coldest spell of the winter persisted over most of the nation yesterday. New York had its sixth day of sub-freezing weather, and the temperature headed toward a possible new low early today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Kennedy Administration embarked on an effort to coordinate its public relations policies today. It said the aim was to free, not shut off, avenues of news to the public.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson christened an 11,000-ton ship today, but high winds kept the big freighter on the ways, and the actual launching will have to take place later.
Robert Moses, president of the New York World's Fair 1964-65 Corporation, took issue yesterday with critics who contend that cities are becoming obsolete.
BABYLON, L.I., Jan. 24 -Bids for preliminary work on a vehicular bridge across Fire Island Inlet connecting Captree State Park with Fire Island State Park will be opened in Albany Feb. 23.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet Union has obtained major appointments in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for three of its citizens since Jan. 1.

ABILENE, Kan., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two of the nation's leaders in foreign affairs -- Henry Cabot Lodge and Adlai E. Stevenson -- will appear on behalf of the Eisenhower Presidential Library during the "United States Steel Hour" presentation tomorrow, at 9 P.M. C.S.T. over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The United States Civil Aeronautics Board has thrown its weight behind the drive of Seaboard Western Airlines to get lower trans-Atlantic air freight charges, it was learned today.

THERE is a far-flung theory that the natives of France have an intuitive knowledge of wine and food. In talking to Madame Herve Alphand, wife of the French Ambassador to the United States, one is inclined to believe that this is true.

The weather, which reportedly has increased consumption and disrupted marketings of potatoes, was held responsible for a 5 to 6 cents a hundred pounds advance in potato futures prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation said today it had cut supplemental unemployment benefits 7 1/2 per cent for the month of January, making a total reduction of 40 per cent.

Production of paperboard rose in the week ended last Saturday to 310,328 tons from 305,418 the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 322,114 tons.

Operating income of The Chase Manhattan Bank rose by $34,717,000 last year to a record of $305,044,000, the bank noted in its annual report made public yesterday. Almost four-fifths of the gain represented increased interest income on loans, the result of a higher average rate and a larger volume of loans outstanding.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Following is the text of a statement on the State Investigation Commission issued today by Governor Rockefeller, Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney, Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino and the commission.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Senate Majority Leader, Walter J. Mahoney called today for Federal funds to begin the construction of an all-American canal linking Lakes Ontario and Erie.

IT is agreed that Edward Albee has talent. "The Zoo Story," still running, established that point. "The American Dream," which arrived last night at the York Playhouse, reinforces it even as it raises questions as to the willfull manner in which it is employed.
FIRE ISLAND PINES, L.I., Jan. 24 -- The wreck of a nineteenth century sailing vessel has been found in the sand here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- When that gentle warrior Robert Frost went to the White House this week, he gave President Kennedy a bit of advice: "Be more Irish than Harvard," the old poet said. "Poetry and power is the formula for another Augustan age, and don't be afraid of power."

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., has signed a $47,750,000 agreement with the Prudential Insurance Company under which the latter will purchase and lease to the airline ten Boeing 720 jets for ten years, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A global food-for-peace program was recommended to President Kennedy today in a task force report. It called for subsidies to insure maximum farm production at home and gifts or cut-rate sales abroad of at least $3,000,000,000 worth of food and fiber a year.
Senator Stuart Symington told the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association last night that the American sports competitor abroad often attracts "a brighter spotlight than our diplomats."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- James R. Hoffa told Senate investigators today he was doing a better job of protecting the interests of union members "than anyone else in the country."

Associates Investment Company, South Bend, Ind., yesterday cut the rates on its short-term obligations placed directly with investors by one-eighth to one-quarter point for the second time in as many days. Other sales finance companies, meanwhile, trimmed their rates to the levels established by Associates on Monday.

The inexcusable disruption and financial loss suffered by the public as a result of the recent railroad strike here lend special interest to a recently formulated program that might have prevented all such trouble. We refer to the plan of the tripartite labor relations committee set up jointly by the Kaiser Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers after the 1959 strike.
JUAREZ, Mexico, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Marilyn Monroe, the actress, got a Mexican divorce from Arthur Miller, the playwright, in First Civil Court today while both she and Mr. Miller were in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy named Edwin O. Guthman of The Seattle (Wash.) Times today as public information director at the Justice Department. Mr. Guthman, Pulitzer Prize winner, will assume his duties on Feb. 6 with the title of special assistant for public information.
MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Charlie Hodge, the goalie for the Montreal Canadiens who took over for the injured Jacques Plante, has yielded an average of only 2.13 goals in twenty-four games.
MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- After long disuse old-fashioned diplomacy is again becoming the vogue in the Soviet capital.

The British Broadcasting Corporation has bought the British Isles radio and television rights to the third world heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson, the champion, and Ingemar Johansson, former champion, for $50,000.
MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Bob Ussery rode three long-priced winners -- including Be Cautious in the featured seventh race -- before 15,148 fans at Hialeah today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the award of a $100,000 contract for a study of the possibility of building ion rockets for long space trips, including orbits around planets.
The City of New York borrowed $76,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance additions to the public school, sewerage and transit systems and for other municipal purposes.
LISBON, Jan. 24 -- A high Portuguese official said tonight that if the United States arrested Henrique Galvao, "they can try him for piracy gladly."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Skip Boston of Mount Clemens, Mich., took a 2 3/4-point lead today after two heats in the national midwinter Thistle Class sailing championship on Tampa Bay.

Despite a 39-point scoring outburst by Jim Francis, the New York Tuck Tapers defeated the Akron Goodyears, 87 -- 82, in a National Industrial Basketball League game last night in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

The International Longshoremen's Association, faced with the possibility of tighter regulations in pending legislation, yesterday called for the creation of a watchdog committee to investigate the Waterfront Commission.

The Road Racing Drivers Club, which has most of the leading sports car drivers of America as members, has elected Dolph Vilardi of Tallman, N.Y., as president, succeeding Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N.J.

The decision by James P. Mitchell to seek the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey may get in the way of his continuing as chairman of the Presidential commission drafting a long-term formula for labor peace on the railroads and harbor tugs.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders rejected today charges by Mayor Wagner that "smear-and-run" tactics were being used by the state in its inquiry into possible corruption in the New York City government.
A Manhattan advertising man was grabbed by policemen and firemen at the window of his eighth-floor hotel suite yesterday after throwing furniture out and threatening to leap.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared today that "more than twenty" anti-Castro rebels captured by Government forces in the Escambray mountains of central Cuba would be shot for the murder of a school teacher in that district.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 24 -- The case of Tangier's "missing" bank is a typical Tangerine tale and a remnant of that former free city's licentious past.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet Union's leading specialist in poliomyelitis said today that a two-year campaign of mass vaccination with an American-developed live virus had convinced him that the chances of polio epidemics had been virtually eliminated in his country.
"K-Day" -- the annual appeal of the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York -- continues on from Jan. 24.
CASTRIES, St. Lucia, West Indies Federation, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Six shaken crew members of the Portuguese liner Santa Maria told today of the ship's seizure by political rebels.
GENEVA, Jan. 24 -- Two Soviet engineers arrived today at the European Organization for Nuclear Research at Meyrin, near here, for a two-month study of problems in high-energy nuclear physics.
The incipient debate as to whether there should be eight teams, instead of four, in the play-offs to determine the two Eastern entries in the National Collegiate hockey championships has been nipped.
With Lou Fontinato and Bill Gadsby still hospitalized, the New York Rangers return to Madison Square Garden tonight to meet the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Jules Francois Crahay of Nina Ricci is trying to bring the flapper back into fashion. He has produced a complete collection of line-for-line copies of Nineteen Twenties' clothes. This afternoon, the premiere of the Ricci spring, 1961, collection was the high spot of the second day of the Paris showings.

The Herald Square block bounded by Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets, has been bought by Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty brokerage and management company bearing his name, and an investing client of White Case, lawyers.

CALGARY, Alberta, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) Standard Oil Company (Indiana) was named today as the partner in a plan by Pembina Pipe Line, Ltd., to export surplus natural gas liquid by-products to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy started today her White House program of sponsorship of the creative arts. She spent a large part of the day with three art experts and her interior decorator, going over the wall space of the private quarters for the future hanging of masterpieces.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 24 -- Guy L. Brown, former Grand Chief Engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, called today for a government-industry program to aid railroad men thrown out of work by technological changes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The possibilities for improving relations between the United States and the Soviet Union provided the central theme of Premier Khrushchev's two-hour talk with Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson last Saturday, sources here said today.
Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Church's primate for North and South America, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Standing Conference of Canonical Orthodox Bishops in the Americas.
NAPLES, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs took the individual lead in the first round of the Naples pro-amateur golf tournament today with a three-under-men's-par 69.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon informed his department today that he was setting up an executive secretariat to "insure responsiveness" to his wishes and those of Under Secretary Henry H. Fowler.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Hypnosis would be placed under strict state controls as a medical technique in hospitals under a bill introduced in the legislature today.
ATLANTA, Jan. 24 -- The Georgia House of Representatives passed two open-school bills today, and the Senate passed one. There was little opposition.
The board of directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation has elected I.G. Davis and J.E. Bounds as executive vice presidents, it was announced yesterday.

Following, in translation, are the texts of a message yesterday from Henrique Malta Galvao, leader of the Portuguese rebels who seized the liner Santa Maria, to Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado, exiled opponent of the Portuguese Government, in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and of a message from Senhor Galvao to the National Broadcasting Company in New York.

Fifty members of the "West Side Story" troupe will be on their way to Tel Aviv tonight. Forty will be performers, who have been signed for thirty-nine weeks. The others will be musicians and backstage technicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nominations of George W. Ball, a Washington lawyer, and former Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan for high State Department posts.

Language synchronization, an unfamiliar technique to most American filmgoers, has become one of the most vital aspects of the internationally oriented Italian film industry, according to Susan Strasberg.
The city opened bids for construction of the Flushing Meadow sports stadium yesterday, and found that the lowest of them would bring the cost to $17,800,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- The nation's big cities must reclaim their slums as a "matter of survival," according to David Rockefeller.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Prime Minister Macmillan led a discreet British Government withdrawal today from vigorous advocacy of a summit conference with the Soviet Union.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Australian tennis championships were marred today by the defeat of the fourth-seeded player, Bob Hewitt, and the possible withdrawal of the defending champion, Rod Laver.

Benjamin Spier, formerly an assistant vice president of the Hanover Bank, has joined Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., as assistant vice president. In his bank position, Mr. Spier was in the real estate and mortgage department.

Another day, another defeat. That's how it goes with the New York Knickerbockers. The pattern continued at Madison Square Garden last night, with the unwelcome assistance of the Boston Celtics. The score was 125 -- 112.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Lark's Lassie today captured Santa Anita's feature race, a $10,000 allowance event for fillies and mares, and paid $53.20 for $2.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 24 -- A 24-year-old Brooklyn youth who earned a high school diploma while in the Nassau County Jail received a suspended sentence on a grand larceny charge in County Court here today.

The New York Times recently quoted Labor Secretary Goldberg's promise "to give the public the plain, unadulterated facts on employment and unemployment, regardless of political consequences." Indeed, a thorough study and searching analysis of all the facts concerning the nation's true labor situation is overdue.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The transfer of the Chargers of the American Football League from Los Angeles to San Diego was virtually assured today when the city council agreed to proposed improvements at city-owned Balboa Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The State Department disclosed today that United States citizens and Europeans were fleeing from pro-Lumumba forces in the eastern provinces of the Congo.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A Citroen driven by two Frenchwomen was the first car to complete the road test of the Monte Carlo auto rally today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 24 -- The 165,000 members of Kenya's European community rejected the multiracial policies of the New Kenya party in yesterday's primary elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A question of whether or not President Kennedy left his hand on the Bible when he took the oath of office at last Friday's inauguration was answered yesterday by his press secretary, Pierre Salinger.
Instead of Leonard Bernstein leading other people's music with the New York Philharmonic on Feb. 13, other people will lead the orchestra in his compositions.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- Ernest L. Rushmer, vice president of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, said today that company officials felt the suit by Mrs. Sibyl Reichel was "unfounded." Company lawyers, he explained, were still studying the complaint and would probably have a more detailed answer later.
By noon today, the names of ninety-six established -- and expendable -- National Football League players will have been turned over to the Minnesota Vikings.

Word that directors of International Business Machines had recommended a three-for-two stock split disturbed the statistical record of the stock market yesterday but did not change its downward course.
Adlai E. Stevenson is strengthening the top echelon of the United States delegation to the United Nations by the appointment of three deputies of ambassadorial rank, it was reported yesterday.
Winters throughout the world have been getting steadily colder since 1940, according to a study carried out by the United States Weather Bureau.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Norman Siegel, editor for a national screen magazine and a former publicity chief for Paramount Pictures, leaped or fell to his death at noon today from the top floor of a thirteen-story downtown building, the police reported.
A resurgence of bullish buying yesterday carried most of the bond market out of the sensitive equilibrium of recent trading sessions.
Mayor Wagner was reported last night to be ready to break completely and openly with Carmine G. De Sapio within the next two days.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 -- Twenty-one Cleveland companies will give a minimum of 1 per cent of their income before taxes as aid to higher education over the next three years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Department of Agriculture said today it would buy pork, dried eggs and dried pea beans to put protein and variety in food packages for the needy.

New York City and the America-Israel Cultural Foundation honored S. Hurok, the impresario, last night for "distinguished service in the cause of cultural exchange."

FOR four days the train had been crawling inland toward the front. Through industrialized regions of mines and factories and on across a dreary area of exhausted farms and arid soil, it slowly carried the ninety-six members of a symphony orchestra. The order had come from the ministry of war, and now they were already in the combat area where they were expected to entertain the troops.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller started the legislative machinery rolling today on his plans for a $40,000,000 expansion of medical care for the needy aged.

Anselmo Colzani, one of the Italian baritones who was engaged last year by the Metropolitan Opera after the death of Leonard Warren, sang his fourth new role of the season last night. It was the name part in Verdi's "Rigoletto."

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 24 -- The Laotian Government was said today to be beginning to look upon the proposed reactivation of the International Control Commission as the only immediate means of averting an unpromising military situation.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru acted firmly tonight to squelch a report that he was determined to resign.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Jean Monnet, a leading French economist, said today there was a "crisis of confidence" in the United States dollar that must be dealt with promptly by cooperative action of the main European nations and the United States.

By the narrowest possible majority the Supreme Court has endorsed the right of local authorities to impose prior administrative censorship on the movies. In this 5-4 decision we think the minority, headed by Chief Justice Warren, took the sounder view and the one that in the long run will prevail.

HARTFORD, Jan. 24 -- John N. Dempsey, a 46-year-old immigrant from Ireland, was inaugurated today as Connecticut's seventy-seventh Governor.
The appointment of Pierce J. Gerety as chairman of the Far East Refugee Program of the International Rescue Committee was announced yesterday.
Affluent Long Island yacht clubs and Kansas dirt farmers are but two of dozens of kinds of customers served by new "two-way radio communications for the masses."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 --President Kennedy decided today to seek a brief postponement of the nuclear-test-ban talks with Britain and the Soviet Union that were to have been resumed in Geneva Feb. 7.
THE National Broadcasting Company and the Windward Islands Broadcasting Service did not quite see the news alike last night.

A study of eighteen leaders of newly independent or reorganized nations from Cuba to Kenya will be published on May 1 by Holt, Rinehart Winston. It win be titled "Builders of Emerging Nations. The author is Vera Micheles Dean, editor of the Foreign Policy Association. She outlines the life stories of the men, their political principles and aims and their views in regard to the West.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- European sporting circles are confused and convulsed by the implications of a malady known as the African Horse Sickness. The report that this ailment is rife in the Soviet Union has caused British racing authorities to ban the entry in Aintree's famous Grand National Steeplechase of three Russian jumpers, Epigraff, Grifel and Reljef.

Henrique Malta Galvao, who is reported to be the leader of the group that seized the Portuguese cruise ship Santa Maria in the Caribbean Sunday morning, has combined the roles of political agitator and swashbuckler.
A small group of gentlemen, quiet in voice, somber in attire and circumspect in their persuasion, took their places last year in the strident world of big business.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings traded youth for experience today in sending Gary Aldcorn, Murray Oliver and Tom McCarthy to the Boston Bruins in exchange for Vic Stasiuk and Leo LaBine. All five are forwards.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues, net income and sales of electricity, gas and steam for 1960. Share earnings, however, declined because of the increase in shares outstanding -- 15,517,723 at the end of 1960, against 15,091,363 at the end of 1959.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- President Joseph Kasavubu of the Congo asked the Security Council tonight to look into alleged interference with his regime by the United Arab Republic.

The two six-story apartment houses at 44 and 48 West 139th Street have been sold by the St. Paul Realty Corporation to the Small Parcels Syndication in a deal negotiated by R. A. Solove and the Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company as co-brokers.

TUNIS, Jan. 24 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government issued a declaration today underlining its position that there would be no peace and no cease-fire in Algeria unless the French Government first negotiated political guarantees for free self-determination.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons had to fight off a last-quarter rally tonight to down the Cincinnati Royals, 106 -- 104, in a National Basketball Association game. It was the Pistons' tenth victory over the Royals in eleven games this season.
An intense search by sea and air continued early today along the Lesser Antilles of the West Indies for the seized Portuguese liner Santa Maria.

The Texas Power and Light Company sold $12,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds at public auction yesterday to an investment group bidding 100.391 for obligations bearing 4 1/2 per cent interest coupons.

GOLDSBORO, N.C., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A B-52G jet bomber crashed in flames near here early today, killing three of its eight crew members. The Air Force said the eight-jet plane had two unarmed nuclear weapons on board.
MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto Maple Leaf players were favored for three of the four National Hockey League awards in the midseason voting announced today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- The school district policies of most communities in the North will require revision if Judge Kaufman's decision is sustained, a lawyer for the New Rochelle, Board of Education] said today.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- British exports to the United States fell by 38,000,000 ($106,400,000), or 10 per cent, last year from the 1959 level.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Navy was ordered today, on the basis of international laws against piracy, to find and board the seized Portuguese cruise ship Santa Maria.
Medical scientists were urged yesterday to think big as do the planners of space projects.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal appeals court today quashed two Alabama cases challenging the constitutionality of the 1960 Federal Civil Rights Act.

Mayor Wagner's complaint against the Seymour special unit of the State Commission of investigation has been rejected by Governor Rockefeller, and the inquiry into wrongdoing in the city government will be financed to completion. Acting on the theory that the best defense is attack, Mr. Wagner had telegraphed the Governor that his administration was being made the victim of a "smear group."
A kind of silent, horseless opera is a daily television attraction on the upper level of Grand Central Terminal.
Two freighters collided just before midnight last night in the East River near the Port Morris section of the East Bronx, off 138th Street. No casualties were reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The battle for liberalization of the House Rules Committee moved toward the decisive stage today. The outcome is in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 --President Kennedy has selected Dr. Janet G. Travell of New York as his personal physician. She is the first woman ever chosen for the post, and the first civilian since the Administration of Warren Harding.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Assembly Republicans cleared the way today for Governor Rockefeller to submit his program on higher education to the Legislature.

Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado, head of the opposition to Premier Antonio de Oliveiro Salazar of Portugal, has proposed in a colonial policy manifesto the creation of a Federal Republic of the United States of Portugal.

THE mysterious East has influenced Western fashions in numerous ways. Its latest effects appear in Rosette Pennington's collection of spring and summer wedding gowns. Mrs. Ruth English, the store's inventive bridal buyer, has merged the best of East and West in two new designs that are a happy foretaste of things to come.
Bouncy belles from the Soviet Union skipped through intricate and graceful routines at Madison Square Garden last night.
Six hundred and thirty-one persons were injured in city traffic last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was 140 fewer than the number injured in the comparable period of 1960.

The New York Central and New Haven Railroads went back into full operation yesterday following the settlement on Monday of the two-week strike of railroad marine workers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Atlas Power Company of Wilmington and the Stuart Company of Pasadena, Calif., agreed today to merge in a transaction involving a four-for-one split of Atlas stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- United States officials expressed disappointment today at the contribution that West Germany was prepared to offer toward a solution of the United States' balance of payments problem.

The Dakota, New York's oldest luxury apartment house and probably its most picturesque, is being sold by its owner, the Clark Foundation, to a realty concern that may demolish it.

Officials of various theatrical unions are organizing the International Trade Secretariat for Entertainment Workers. The new organization would be linked with counterpart unions in all countries, except those behind the Iron Curtain.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 25 (UPI) -- President Kennedy made a personal telephone call to Mrs. Connie McKone tonight to offer his congratulations that her husband had been released from a Soviet prison.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Stan Musial signed a contract today for his twentieth campaign with the St. Louis Cardinals for a salary estimated at $75,000, raising his total baseball earnings to $1,128,177.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- A spokesman for Trans-Canada Air Lines said today many of the pilots the company planned to lay off this year because of new jet services might be hired by European air lines.
A reorganization of inspection procedures for school maintenance and repair work was announced yesterday by school authorities.

It was in a gaslit ladies' tailoring shop that Lottie Plump first went to work as a skirt fitter on a February day in 1903. Tomorrow she will celebrate her ninetieth birthday, still working in the same establishment. It is now Bergdorf Goodman.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that operating revenues and net income rose in 1960. The company also announced that it would spend a record of $300,000,000 on expansion this year.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Some members of the Tuscarora Indian nation will receive $600 to $800 apiece from the tribe's $863,000 settlement with the State Power Authority for land taken for the Niagara power project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Kennedy has selected Henry R. Labouisse of Connecticut to be director of the International Cooperation Administration.
New York State school districts borrowed $3,479,000 in the bond market yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Army's surprising basketball quintet extended its winning streak to seven games today, defeating Hofstra, 77 to 74, in overtime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk today called Chester Bowles his "closest comrade in arms * * * with whom I will be working as mutual alter egos of each other."

NEWARK, Jan. 25 -- Traffic problems growing out of snowstorms are man-made, not nature-made, a conference heard today.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Britain's clearing banks announced today that beginning on March 6 they would allow anyone, even those without bank accounts, to pay their bills through the banks. The clearing banks are the large commercial banks, usually with headquarters in London and branches throughout Britain, who are members of London's clearing house.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Drastic changes in the operations of the State Department of Social Welfare were recommended today. The proposals were made in a study prepared for the Temporary State Commission on the Coordination of State Activities.
Prices for commodities futures on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday in mostly dull trading.

Tonight at 8 o'clock, the zebra-striped, rubber welcome mat will be out in front of 307 East Fifty-fourth Street, the new address of one of the most caste-conscious, costly and cloistered night clubs in the world -- El Morocco.

Carlo Maria Franzero, author of "Beau Brummell: His Life and Times," goes back about 2,500 years in his forthcoming book about the decline of the Ethruscan civilization before the development of early Rome. Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 10 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The White House commended The New York Herald Tribune tonight for foregoing a nineteen-hour news "beat" on Moscow's freeing of the two American fliers.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller will ask the Legislature next week to raise the salary of almost every state employe except himself.

The bond market continued to be influenced strongly yesterday by a widespread and persistent demand for gilt-edge corporate bonds of recent issue. As in Tuesday's trading session, new high prices were scored by most representative issues in market supply.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Construction of a multimillion-dollar skyscraper office building, a third taller than Chicago's highest building, will begin in two years, its planners report.
Freezing cold prevailed over most of the nation for the seventh straight day yesterday. The mercury fell to 5 degrees in the city, making it the coldest day in nearly three years.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Dullness enveloped virtually every section of the stock market here today as buyers continued to stay away.

Water service was reported "tremendously improved" yesterday in that part of lower Manhattan where the pressure had fallen to zero Tuesday after a water main break. Engineers said service would probably be normal this morning.

The city school system will have to increase its expense budget by more than 50 per cent within the next five years if it is to attract qualified professional personnel, a commission of school finance experts said yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Madeleine de Rauch's collection today was like one of those rockets that never get off the launching pad. Jean Marie Armand, a former assistant at the house of Nina Ricci, was supposed to orbit into the rarefied atmosphere of first-rank designing with his initial collection for Madeleine de Rauch.

The first sale of both cooling and heating services through pipelines fed from one central utility plant is scheduled to begin in Hartford, Conn., next year. Utilities have supplied steam to their customers for heating and other uses for some time.
Sir Patrick Dean, Britain's permanent delegate at the United Nations, proposed yesterday that the United States become a "constructive and disinterested" leader of discussions of colonial problems.
HAVANA, Jan. 25 -- The second Latin-American Conference for Amnesty of Political Prisoners and Exiled Politicians of Spain and Portugal has been scheduled in Montevideo, Uruguay, Jan. 27 through 29.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- At a special meeting of the membership here tonight Dr. Logan Wilson, chancellor of the University of Texas, was elected president of the American Council on Education.

UNION, N.J., Jan. 25 -- In a move to thwart a bid by Amerace Corporation for a majority of its outstanding common stock, the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America announced here today the purchase of 36,600 shares of its own stock.

Electric power production in the nation rose to 14,817,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from 14,684,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1960 period the figure was 14,630,000,000 kilowatt hours.
The Global Gala, held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza, had an international flavor in its theme, decor, guest list and beneficiary.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Navy experts stressed today that when the hunt began for the Portuguese liner Santa Maria the chances of "cornering" the vessel were small.
WARSAW, Jan. 25 -- An education reform, designed to turn out better technicians and Marxists, was announced today.
Columbia University will begin a new orientation program for its 1,800 foreign students next month, Dr. Grayson Kick, the president, announced yesterday.

Elmer M. Shankland, financial editor of Forbes Magazine, has been elected president of the New York Financial Writers Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday following the annual meeting at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Representative Francis E. Walter charged today that a "number of persons" who signed a newspaper ad calling for the abolition of the House Committee on un-American Activities had been identified as Communist party members.

An unexpected, unsolicited gift of $150,000 to the Park Department has assured prompt city action in approving plans for the new 2,500-seat outdoor theatre in Central Park.
A national campaign was opened yesterday to raise $5,000,000 to build a Civil War Hall of Fame on the site of the First Battle of Bull Run.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Controller General Joseph Campbell recommended today that the Tennessee Valley Authority advertise for Ads in making small purchases of urgently needed supplies or services.

The directors of Revlon, Inc., cosmetics producer, proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday.

The hospitalized Eastern Air Lines pilot who was aboard the Mexican jetliner that crashed here a week ago was interviewed by crash investigators yesterday for the first time since the accident.

The appointment of John A. Wallace as Director of Probation for New York City marks a notable advance in the administration of justice here on two counts -- the nature of the task Mr. Wallace will perform and his qualifications for the job.

GIBBSTOWN, N.J., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania Air National Guard jet fighter on a routine training flight crashed tonight near this southern New Jersey community shortly after take-off, killing the radar observer.

The purchase by Ling Temco Electronics, Inc., on Jan. 11 of 119,700 shares of Chance Vought Corporation's 1,189,390 shares of common stock was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange in its latest insiders' list.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Cleveland Pipers defeated the New York Tuck Tapers, 90 -- 81, tonight to lift their won-lost record to 15 -- 2 at the midway point in the National Industrial Basketball League schedule.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The new-style Presidential news conference, which replaced "Popeye the Sailor Man" at kiddie time on the home screen tonight, looks like a hit.
The publishers of McCall's magazine are negotiating for the purchase of The Saturday Review, a thirty-six-year-old weekly devoted to literature and the arts and sciences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Two Canadian ministers conferred with three new Cabinet members today in an attempt to persuade the United States to accept more Canadian oil. The Canadians seek additional markets for their oil in the Midwest, particularly in the Chicago area.
The Coast Guard will start an inquiry this morning into the collision late Tuesday night between the freighters Mormacguide and Portmar. The two vessels collided in the East River of 138th Street.

Net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation last year was $79,057,000, equal to $2.22 a common share. In 1959, the country's second largest electrical manufacturing company cleared $85,947,000, or $2.43 a share.

The traditional welcome by the city's fireboats will be extended today to the new turbine cargo vessel Eurybates of the Marchessini Lines when she arrives this morning on her maiden voyage from Bremerhaven.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Kennedy publicly threw his support to enlargement of the House Rules Committee tonight in the interest of assuring action on his legislative program. The President made his position known as new uncertainty over the outcome of the rules battle arose with the postponement of a showdown until Tuesday.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- National League teams, which will open the 1961 season April 11, will play a record 318 night games.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- The Secret Service announced today the retirement of its deputy chief, Russell Daniel, as of Jan. 31 Paul J Paterni was named to succeed Mr. Daniel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Robert Derue of Sandusky, Ohio, took the lead today in the national Thistle Class sailing regatta. With 119 1/4 points for four races, he had a 2 1/4-point advantage over Skip Boston of Mount Clemens, near Detroit.

The New York State's Joint Legislative Committee on Tourists decided recently not to seek a state law to establish a uniform safety code for the operation of ski lifts at winter resorts. That decision has been received with a variety of feelings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, denied today that he was "afraid" to act against allegedly corrupt officials of Teamster locals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Kennedy said today that he favored binding Presidential electors to vote for the candidate who won the popular vote in their state.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The new Administration gave strong assurances today that the Government would act to deal with the country's balance-of-payments and gold problem.
Quick approval of the Flushing Meadow Stadium appeared unlikely after yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- President Kennedy appealed to Congress today for "prompt" passage of legislation aimed at providing jobs in areas of chronic unemployment.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Plum Cake and Black Darter, the favorites, ran off today with the two divisions of the Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Government failed today to connect Harold Eugene Kistner Jr. to a $2,000,000 embezzlement that closed the Sheldon National Bank.
