"Report on Hong Kong," a documentary program featuring William Holden as host and narrator, will be televised on Thursday from 9 to 10 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Quakers, reiterating their 300-year-old peace testimony, picketed the Mamaroneck Junior High School today to protest a week-long "Nike Goes to School" demonstration of Army air defense.

PRAGUE, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- This year's figure-skating championships will be staged at Prague next month, as scheduled, "despite an unfriendly and hasty decision" by the International Skating Union to change sites for political reasons, the official Czech news agency, Ceteka, reported today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A civilian shipfitter died in burning oil when he jumped from a scaffold on a blazing Coast Guar dcutter in a South Baltimore drydock today. He was Thomas Koerner,53 years old, of Baltimore.

FIFTY years after Picasso and the German Expressionists first gobbled up primitive art in their creative maw it is still difficult to look at artifacts from Africa and Oceania without being reminded of the pre-1914 European advance-guard.

A dreary, discredited Latin-American pattern reasserted itself in El Salvador on Wednesday. The outs have got in with a typical military coup. A government that was, itself, the result of a military coup was given no chance to hold the elections it promised or to start the social reforms that are so necessary in El Salvador.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would permit continued marketing of the drug Chloromycetin under new and stricter labeling requirements.
TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- Premier Havato Ikeda is planning to visit President Kennedy, Washington for personal possibly this summer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Kennedy indicated today that his Administration would move swiftly to cheek the economic decline and assist millions of unemployed.

Negotiations to avert a strike of tugs, lighters and tankers at midnight Tuesday bogged down again yesterday. At the end of six hours of talks, Federal, state and city mediators could report no progress.
"Bow, bow, ye lower middle classes!" sang a dozen robed and coroneted peers from the realm of Gilbert and Sullivan yesterday as they mounted the stage at Public School 61.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- New car sales in mid-January dropped to the lowest level for the period since 1958. Industry officials attributed the poor showing to the weather, particularly along the East Coast, and on the slow business pace which has been characterized by increasing unemployment in recent weeks.

THE shipping of supplies to city food shops has been hampered recently by glacial conditions. However, since sidewalks have been equally unattractive to pedestrian traffic, many shoppers have elected to stay at home and open cans.
The Park Association of Nov York City, 15 Gramercy Park, will begin a campaign for 2,000 new members Monday.

The Ford Foundation announced here yesterday long-term grants totaling $7,965,000 for non-Western and international teaching and research at four universities, with $5,400,000 going to Chicago. The others were Northwestern, $1,300,000; Pennsylvania, $1,000,000, and Notre Dame, $265,000.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has urged four states served by the New Haven Railroad to take prompt action in giving the line financial relief.
GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- Geneva authorities released today the second of three Americans who were taken into custody last week for questioning in connection with alleged dealings in stolen securities.
Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last month amounted to $2,717,701,000, a gain of 22 per cent over the volume of $2,224,060,000 in December, 1959.
Samuel Barber's "Vanessa" and Richard Strauss' "Salome" are the operas to be presented in the fourth Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy. The festival will begin June 15 and end July 16.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 26 (APA) -- A Pennsylvania housewife and a Florida school teacher teamed today to score a 1-up victory over Joanne Goodwin and Doris Phillips, the defenders, in the women's international four-ball golf tournament.
Alvin (Doggy) Julian, Dartmouth's ingenious basketball coach, will put into practice tomorrow night at Hanover his pet idea for improving the sport.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur last night celebrated his eighty-first birthday with eighty-four of his military colleagues at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano of West Germany is expected to be the first leading foreign statesman to have a personal meeting with President Kennedy.

General Motors Corporation achieved record dollar sales in 1960, while earnings were second only to those in 1955. World-wide unit sales of G.M. cars and trucks last year also exceeded those for every other year except 1955.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 26 -- The Government of Laos acknowledged today that it had cried "wolf."

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its 1960 sales and earnings had exceeded those of strike-torn 1959. However, Arthur B. Homer, chairman of the nation's second largest steel maker, said his concern now was operating at only 48 per cent of capacity and offered only the vaguest hope of any marked upturn in the first half of 1961.
Something new is about to be added in the world of humorous television commercials -- people who can do almost anything.

Twelve sewage-treatment projects were completed last year at a cost of $32,000,000 and work has started on fifteen other projects costing$55,000,000, the Interstate Sanitation Commission said yesterday.
The directors of Minneapolis-Moline Company have voted to recommend to stockholders that the name of the company be changed to Motee Industries, Inc.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City declined by $104,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 -- Migrants from Europe are having a decided effect on Australian diet and night life.
The consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for 1960 were estimated Yesterday at $688,000,000, or $3.18 each on the 216,533,000 shares presently outstanding.
Harlem Hospital's chief of dental services charged yesterday that two women patients had died within the last thirty days for lack of proper medical care.
A Dutch authority on climate change predicted yesterday that El Nino, a catastrophic ocean current, would sweep down the West Coast of South America this year.
The Huntington and Smithtown (L.I.) Union Free School District 10, borrowed $6,386,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1961 to 1990.

A long ordeal has ended for two brave airmen and their loved ones. Today, if all goes on schedule, Capts. John R. McKone and Freeman B. Olmstead, of the ill-fated RB-47, will be reunited with their families in Washington, the long nightmare of Soviet imprisonment but a memory. All Americans will rejoice that this terrible torment is ending happily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Despite the new atmosphere in Washington, the contrast between ends and means is still extremely sharp. Almost everybody has approved the goals stated so eloquently by President Kennedy, but the Administration's means of achieving those goals are running into heavy opposition.

As a lifelong friend of both Robert C. Weaver and Earl Brown I am writing to object to your editorial of Jan. 17 "Hulan Jack Sentenced." It is not necessary to run down one man in order to build-up the other; each can stand on his own feet.

Half to three-quarters of the authorized positions in key medical and professional specialties in the municipal hospitals are either vacant or are being filled on a provisional basis, according to a Department of Hospitals report.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Another strong push in soybean futures prices today again raised all the strictly old crop contracts to their highest levels of the season, with net gains running to about 6 1/2 cents a bushel.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A French team, Maurice Martin and Robert Bateau, was declared the winner tonight in the Monte Carlo auto rally.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Members of the Congregational Christian Church favor uniting with the United Church of Christ, according to first returns of a vote on the question.
LEOPOLDVILLE,The Congo, Jan. 26 -- The United Nations command declared today that it would assist in the evacuation of Europeans from Eastern and Kivu Provinces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Two major education bills were introduced today by Democratic Senators who expressed hope the measures would become a part of the Kennedy Administration's program.

The Men's Club of Congregation Emanu-El presented its annual award last night to Secretary of State Caroline K. Simon "for her many humanitarian services and contributions to the public welfare." She is the first woman to win the award.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The University of Chicago announced today an array of expanded international studies. The stress will be on the Soviet Union, South and Southeast Asia and the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- That President Kennedy would not reject a talk with Premier Khrushchev, if the Soviet leader attended the March meeting of the United Nations General Assembly and sought the conversation, was a conclusion reached by diplomatic observers here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Legislation designed to establish permanent rules of conduct for all Federal employes to guard against conflicts of interest was offered in Congress today.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $12,000,000 to $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $154,000,000 from a revised figure the week before to $947,000,000.
A low-slung cowpoke was coralled in the Brooklyn flatlands yesterday but only after a posse of lawmen had decided to double back on his trail.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York confirmed yesterday that it planned to establish a state-wide holding company with banks in major cities across New York State. It would be known as the Morgan New York State Corporation and would have headquarters in Albany.
American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries has announced that 1960 was a record year in most categories of its operations.
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Dissension in the French Communist party was said today to extend to about eight members of the party's ruling bodies.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The odds against Bowie Race Course's mid-winter gamble with the weather lengthened again today as a snowstorm forced cancellation of the track's programs for today and tomorrow.

Events today: "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Alfred Wallenstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Helen and Karl Ulrich Schnabel, duo-pianists, Town Hall, 5:45; "The Mikado," New York City Center, 8:30; Andres Segovia, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:40; Dessoff Choirs, Paul Boepple, conductor, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers described the Douglas depressed-areas bill today as unjustifiable and unworkable.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 26 (AP) -- In March of last year, Lennie Elliott of Rossmore, W. Va., lost his job as a trackman in the coal mines. He has not worked steadily, since.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Full diplomatic relations between London and Cairo were resumed today.
The managing agent and majority owner of a fourteen-story apartment house at 36 Central Park South was sentenced to ten days in jail and fined $500 yesterday for violating zoning laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges declared his opposition today to a separate Cabinet-level department of transportation.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The Navy released today the following list of crewmen aboard the Military Air Transport Service's C-118 missing off Newfoundland:
The pilot of a freighter that collided with another cargo vessel in the East River Tuesday night testified yesterday that high winds and the lack of a tug for one ship had caused the collision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, said today he had been told that the 1960 Presidential, Congressional and local election campaigns cost more than $175,000,000.

Sketches of the forty top American scientists in the areas of physics, chemistry, astronomy and biology are presented in "Great American Scientists," by the editors of Fortune magazine. Prentice-Hall will issue it Monday.
The National Association of Manufacturers warned yesterday that a shorter work week would aggravate unemployment, not relieve it.

Eleven New Yorkers have been re-elected trustees of the free-care nonsectarian National Jewish Hospital at Denver, a research and treatment center for tuberculosis, asthma, heart surgery and other chest diseases.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Moscow radio gave a report on President Kennedy's first news conference today and told its Soviet home service listeners:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- George Bayer of South Pasadena, Calif., and Charlie Sifford of Los Angeles carded six-under-par 65's today and shared the opening-round lead in the $57,000 Lucky international open golf tournament.
The 3,000-member Flight Engineers International Association, A.F.L.-C.L.O., has already spent in 1961 twice the sum it had budgeted for accident investigation for the entire year.
Earl (Butch) Buchholz took backhand swing yesterday at reports of misconduct by United States tennis players during the Davis Cup competition in Australia last month.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is under heavy pressure from his Belgian Socialist colleagues to quit his post to re-enter politics at home.

Howard Hughes who, on Dec. 30, bowed to demands of his creditors and had his wholly owned Hughes Tool Company put its 78 per cent stock interest in Trans World Airlines in a voting trust, now opposes the plans of the voting trustees to reconstitute T.W.A.'s board of directors.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 26 -- Haitian militiamen, in evident panic, began shooting wildly today when several bombs exploded in the center of the city. At least three persons were believed to have been killed and several school children were wounded by the shooting and the bombs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States Air Force began today the emergency airlift of food and supplies into the Congo that was announced by President Kennedy last night.
The Board of Education served notice yesterday that it intended to exercise control over its budget allocations.

Cocoa futures staged a spirited rally yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices rose 46 to 59 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on volume of 746 contracts. The rise resulted from reports that an agreement had been completed between Nigeria and Ghana that would stabilize prices.

If the concert given at the Museum of Modern Art last night proves representative of Thursday-night musical events scheduled there for the immediate future, one can safely say that the Composers Showcase lost none of its imagination and vitality in moving uptown from the Circle in the Square Theatre in Greenwich Village.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Macmillan deferred today a reply to demands for an investigation into the "monopolist trend" of British newspapers.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will have to raise about $225,000,000 this year through the sale of new securities, Charles B. Delafield, financial vice president, disclosed at a press conference yesterday.
Two hold-up men took an $8,400 payroll from an office at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre last night, after forcing the manager, a stagehand and a singer to lie on the floor.
ROWS of colorful fabrics for the home accompany the vignettes that introduce the William Pahlmann and Jack Lenor Larsen designs that go on view Monday in Macy's seventh-floor Plan-A-Home Row.
Check transactions in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation dipped in the week ended last Wednesday from the levels of the preceding week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Although late January boat shows will dot the American scene at Los Angeles, Cleveland and Kansas City, New Jersey also will be a center of attraction for at least two reasons. The eighth annual Jersey Coast Boat Show will have its run from Feb. 18 to Feb. 26 at the Convention Hall, Asbury Park, on the Boardwalk.

Metropolitan skiers again had cause to talk about the strange goings-on of the weather yesterday. While such famed frozen fronts as Canada's Laurentians were still awaiting their first major snowfall since Jan. 8, Gotham had its third big one in two weeks.
Henry Cabot Lodge called last night for a Republican party "more in tune with the times."
Angler Roy Hamey came up with two pretty good sized fish yesterday. But the big one, for the moment, got away.
A four-inch snowfall coated the left-over accumulation of previous storms here yesterday, but the snow began tapering off before midnight.

ARGENTIA, Nfld., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A United States Military Air Transport plane with twenty-three persons aboard was missing today over Canada's Atlantic coastline. At about the time the transport was due here a Navy plane reported seeing an explosion in the air.
Foreign calls on the United States gold stock amounted to $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- A Negro field representative of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was arrested in a registrar's office today while trying to gather information on Negro voting in Haywood County.
The merged labor federation does not feel the huge Americana Hotel in Miami Beach is big enough to hold its high command and that of the exiled International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

ALL is not black or white in bridge; there is not necessarily a right way and a wrong way to bid or play a hand. But seldom does a bridge hand come along that illustrates three different levels of bridge skill as clearly as the one shown today.
ANOTHER state bill poses a threat to the democratic safeguards of the grand jury system in New York.

ROME, Jan. 26 -- After three days of meetings and discussions in Rome, representatives of the European Common Market have decided to admit to membership Madagascar and fifteen African states that have recently acquired independence.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton today declined the Democratic organization's designation for Governor.

Production of all standard-size, non-electric typewriters by the Sperry Rand Corporation's Remington Rand division will continue at Elmira, N.Y. Last September, the company had announced that it would move such production to Europe this year to meet foreign competition.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- The Stanford University chapter of Alpha Tau Omega faces loss of its charter, its officers said today, because it pledged four Jewish students.
IT was chillier inside than out yesterday afternoon at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park as Chrysler Corporation Airtemp Division introduced its 1961 air conditioner units.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Cain Hoy Stable's All Hands scored by a head after a stretch duel with Rum Punch in today's feature race at Hialeah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- After investigating a work stoppage at the Cape Canaveral missile test center in Florida, a Labor Department-sponsored committee urged the affected local unions, in effect, to take a "no-strike pledge."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Among the millions of people who saw President Kennedy demonstrate last night his mastery of the technique of television, his remarkable range of information on public issues, and his quiet command of grammar and syntax, there could have been three American citizens who watched the brilliant performance with the best capacity to evaluate it.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Fashions are not the only things to bet seen at the collections during the great week of Paris couture showings. In the general excitement that goes on, there is a slight touch of the circus.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Jan. 21 were 5 per cent below the year-earlier level.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy's nomination of George Docking to be director of the Export-Import Bank was confirmed by the Senate today.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 26 -- A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that the chairman of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors could not cast a vote for a supervisor who abstained.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Net income of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway declined more than $14,000,000 in 1960 on a $19,000,000 drop in gross revenues, Ernest S. Marsh, president, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26 Henry F. McCarthy of 6 Carstensen Road, Scarsdale, vice president in charge of purchases and stores for the New York Central Railroad, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 54 years old.

Following are statements by Jacob Grumet, chairman of the State Investigation Commission; Mayor Wagner and Michael H. Prendergast, State Democratic chairman, on the state inquiry into corruption in the city government:

"LOOK at that," said Jack Kramer. It's pitiful." The youthful entrepreneur of professional tennis pointed at a newspaper item. It stated that fewer than 100 spectators had attended a semi-final match of the Australian doubles championships in Melbourne and that the total turnstile count for five days was under 500.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) -- When the Rose Bowl half-time card stunts flashed "Caltech" instead of "Washington" last Jan. 2, 100,000 spectators and a nationwide television audience were amused but confused.
General Electric Company has again called on Charles E. Wilson to help the company he served in various capacities for more than half a century.

TUNIS, Jan. 26 -- Why have the Algerian nationalist revolutionaries and the French Government not yet begun peace talks, when both sides in the last two weeks have repeatedly expressed readiness to negotiate?
A special concert honoring the memory of Dimitri Mitropoulos will be given at Carnegie Hall on March 5 as a benefit for the Musicians Aid Society, which the conductor helped organize.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Sam Jones and Tom Heinsohn scored 26 points each tonight and paced the Boston Celtics to a
Gerald J. Ryan, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, demanded last night that Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy "get his nose out of the affairs of firemen."
Women are in the news this week.
The Hochman family of Brooklyn, which has given to New York's Neediest Cases for many years, sent a donation again yesterday in honor of a marriage.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The Board of Regents proposed today that the state make individual tuition grants of "not less" than $200 a year to students enrolled in private and public colleges and universities in the state.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Dr. Albert William Tucker, Professor of Mathematics at Princeton University, was elected president of the Mathematical Association of America today.
In his first public comment on the Far East President Kennedy has made two significant statements.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 -- Leaders of the Jewish community here reacted with shock and dismay today to an assertion by Dr. Arnold Toynbee, the historian, that Jewish treatment of Arabs in 1947 was as morally indefensible as the slaughter by the Nazis of 6,000,000 Jews.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told the Security Council today that it might be necessary to remove the United Nations force from the Congo because of the withdrawal of some Asian and African military contingents.

Facing a major political setback, Mayor Wagner last night postponed a meeting of Manhattan's six City Councilmen that had been scheduled for today to elect a successor to Hulan E. Jack as Borough President.
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The Dior collection designed by Marc Bohan is a smash hit.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Famine has stricken wildlife in the snowbound countryside. A high mortality rate is feared, especially among deer.
City College, which discontinued its traditional basketball rivalries with four metropolitan powers this season, will resume its series with Fordham University next season.

YONKERS, Jan. 26 -- The Soviet Union's commissioner of harness racing today requested and received from Yonkers Raceway an invitation for two Soviet trotters to compete in the International Series here next spring.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Directors f Pfaudlero t Permutit, Inc. announced plansI today for a 2-for-1 split of the common stock and a rise in the

The letter from Senator Wayne Morse which you published Jan. 26 is a considerably tempered version of his speech in the Senate on Jan. 17 in which he attacked Arthur Krock for "gross misrepresentations."
Directors of the Great Northern, the Northern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroads, at separate meetings yesterday, approved unification of their lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Dr. Janet G. Travell, the first woman to serve as White House physician, stepped into the news conference of President Kennedy's press secretary today just as he was announcing her appointment.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 4 to 20 points (20 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Jan 26 (AP) -- Bill Tuttle, a center fielder, signed a 1961 contract with the Kansas City Athletics today and expressed a hope he could "hit better than I did last year."
James M. Landis proposed yesterday that an administrative conference with a permanent secretariat be set up to coordinate the work of Federal regulatory agencies.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Republican State Chairman Lawrence B. Lindemer said today that a spot check of 1960 voting records in heavily Democratic Detroit had disclosed the possibility that more than 80,000 persons voted from addresses where they did not live.

WARSAW, Jan. 26 -- Berthold Beitz, Chancellor Adenauer's unofficial envoy, suggested here on his recent visit that Bonn and Warsaw establish informal diplomatic contact through their envoys in a "neutral" capital, such as Paris.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- British physicians report that the flicker of a television set can bring on a convulsive attack.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Selective demand gave a slightly better tone to most industrial sections of the stock market here today, although over-all small losses far outnumbered gains.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -Rail and truck loadings of freight declined last week, mainly becauses of bad weather on the East Coast.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- With moderate increases in most industrial shares, the stock market closed the fortnightly account on a cheerful note here today.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The brother-sister combina tion of Otto and Maria Jelinek won the Canadian pairs figure-skating championship tonight at the Forum. They had a score of 56.7 points. Second place went to Gertrude DesJardins and Maurice LaFrance of Montreal with 51.8 points.
ATLANTA, Jan. 27 -- The Legislature approved today repeal of public school segregation laws in a retreat by Georgia from massive resistance to the Federal courts.

Phillip P Zipes, realty operator, has contracted to buy the six-story apartment house at 1114 Morris Avenue, near 168th Street, the Bronx, from a client of Nathan Greenberg, lawyer. Fred S. Weitzner was the lawyer for the buyer.

New York legislators are apparently moving to establish a plural school system in this state. A law was passed in 1960 providing for mandatory bus transportation of all parochial and private school children. This year the proposal is to subsidize private and parochial colleges and universities by the payment of $200 to each student enrolled, a device quite frankly described as a means of avoiding the constitutional ban on allocating funds to private institutions.
COLORADO SRINGS, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Monty Hoyt of Denver, last year's novice champion, captured the national junior men's figure-skating championship tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Saturday, Jan. 28 -- The United States Navy has apparently persuaded the captors of the Portuguese liner Santa Maria to release the 560 passengers on this side of the Atlantic, probably at a South American port.
TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Japan's ruling Liberal-Democratic party{ adopted a resolution today re-{ jecting "ideological neutralism."
NORTON, Va., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Francis Powers, the imprisoned U-2 pilot, has written to his father that Premier Khrushchev is "going to forget the U-2 incident and might let me come home."
JACKIE GLEASON appeared solo last night on his new Channel 2 show with a half-hour anatomy of a flop.
Efforts to extend the investment privilege of the tax-exempt bond issues are being furthered by a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Representative Emmanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said yesterday he was asking that the expansion plans of four New York City banks be blocked because of "grave antitrust dangers."
Andres Segovia guitarist of guitarists, returned to Town Hall last night for the first of three recitals he is to play there this season. The auditorium was sold out for the event.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

WHETHER teen-agers know it or not, their world has been subject to a minor invasion by their elders. Departments devoted to teen-age or young junior clothes, as they often are called, appear to be almost as popular among some women who are well on the other side of 19.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 9 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
The twelfth annual dinner and ball of the St. Nicholas Society was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

While Cuba follows a self-isolating Soviet pattern of seizing private enterprise and putting it under state ownership and control, a ground swell in the opposite direction which began in Europe some time ago is under way in other parts of Latin America. This finds expression in two related processes.

Invective and ridicule were conspiciously absent from Madison Square Garden last night as the New York Knickerbockers engineered one of their periodic escapes from the doldrums. Well-deserved huzzahs punctuated their steady drive to a 130-119 triumph over the Philadelphia Warriors.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- A field of seven horses was named today for tomorrow's Santa Anita Maturity, a race limited to 4-year-olds over the mile-and-a-quarter distance. If all start, the gross value will be $167,370.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Kennedy Administration indicated today that it was not irrevocably opposed to summit meetings.

The heavy snows blanketing much of the country are bringing unusually glad tidings to the winter sports equipment industry. In fact, the talk in trade circles these days is that this season may prove to be a memorable one.

Events today: "The Marriage of Figaro" at 2 P.M. and "L'Elisir d'Amore," at 8, Metropolitan Opera; "The Mikado," at 2:30 and "The Pirates of Penzance," New York City Center, at 8:30; Brooklyn Philharmonia youth concert, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 3; Joseph Schwartz, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Balalaika Symphonic Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30; Concert of Rococo Music, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- A three-man Federal Court upheld today the legality of New Jersey's county option ban on Sunday sales.

Despite President de Gaulle's smashing victory in the referendum approving self-determination for Algeria and an announcement by the Algerian "Provisional Government" that it is ready to begin negotiations, the high hopes for an early peace in that strife-torn land are beginning to fade. There are reports that contacts between the two sides, approved by the French Cabinet, are "imminent."

The incredible tugboat strike has been settled after doing grievous harm to hundreds of thousands of innocent persons. This could never have happened had it not been for the picket lines which were permitted to be set up under a legalistic interpretation of our labor laws.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A white boy in the third grade broke the total seggregation boycott of McDonogh No. 19 school today. His entrance into the school apparently set the stage for new tension in this city's seventy-five-day school crisis.

One of three American business men recently arrested in Switzerland for allegedly dealing in stolen securities was re-arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents when he arrived at New York International Airport last night.

The unsatisfactory state of the economy will certainly be one of the chief themes of President Kennedy's first State of the Union message next Monday. The evidence that action is needed to halt the present recession is plain. Unemployment this month is now estimated to be about 5,500,000. The steel industry's output continues to stagnate at a level which leaves roughly half its capacity idle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Kennedy is expected to ask Congress Monday for an immediate temporary injection of Federal funds into the unemployment compensation system.

PANAMA, Jan. 27 -- A number of large crates, reported to contain several tons of documents and records of the missing American and Foreign Bank of Tangier, were unloaded last night at Cristobal in the Canal Zone from the freighter Neptune.
In accepting the Government post, Mr. Murrow will end a relationship of more than twenty-five years with the Columbia Broadcasting System.
PARIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Jamin, a world champion trotter, will never race again.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- American lawyers here are mystified by proposals for curing the deficit in the United States balance of payments by removing special tax incentives for overseas investments by American corporations.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The St. Louis University basketball team held Tony Jackson to 11 points, half his season average, and upset seventh-ranked St. John's of New York tonight, 60-57, with slo-down tactics.
Many cocktail parties preceded the fifty-second annual Blue Ridge Ball, which was held last night in the ballroom of the Pierre.

Demand deposit turnover -- that is, the number of times the average checking account dollar was used -- slipped 4 per cent in December from the November level on a seasonally adjusted basis in the 337 reporting centers, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Herman Marks was known as Capitan Herman in the Cuban revolutionary forces. He went into the Sierra Maestra to join the Castro rebels almost a year before the victory of the revolution.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Legislature set the dates for public hearings today on the 1961-62 state budget, which Governor Rockefeller will present to the lawmakers Wednesday.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a "memorandum of understanding" that paved the way for a new 55,000-seat baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

"A Living Bill of Rights," a new book by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, will be published by Doubleday on Feb. 10. In it Justice Douglas relates the first ten amendments to the Constitution to today's major issues -- the racial problem, anti-Communist and loyalty questions and the educational system.

A dinner will be given next Friday in the Metropolitan Club by the New York Alumnae Association of the Holton-Arms School of Washington. It will commemorate the sixtieth anniversary of the school and will begin a fund drive to build a completely new plant in Potomac, Md.
The New York Community Trust yesterday named Second Lieut. Howard R. Mosley of Passaic, N.J., as the 1961 recipient of the Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Joao Cabral, a political foe on the Portuguese regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, said today Henrique M. Galvao would gain "active support" if he took the commandeered Santa Maria liner to Angola.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 27 -- The Westchester grand jury today indicted two Bedford Village Volunteer firemen on charges of setting fire to a twenty-room mansion Jan. 6.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 27 -- A code of ethics for this city's government was proposed today by a legislative committee.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that January car production in the United States was 412,000 units -- the lowest January output in nine years.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Boris Pasternak's Italian publisher said tonight that $100,000 in royalties had been smuggled into the Soviet Union at the written request of the Nobel Prize-winning author.
Prices swept forward in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange as investors looked forward to two addresses by President Kennedy in the coming week.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- The North American International Seafarers Union has come under sharp criticism for alleged interference in the domestic affairs of the British National Union of Seamen, it was disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- George Bayer of South Pasadena, Calif., powered his drives and putted precisely today for a five-under-par 66 and a four-stroke lead at the midway point in the $57,000 Lucky international open with a 36-hole score of 131.
LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 27 -- The Portuguese Government has received a report indicating that there was dissension among the group that seized the liner Santa Maria Sunday.

The recent Soviet debate on agricultural policies has indicated to analysts of Soviet affairs that Trofim D. Lysenko has won a key role in Premier Khrushchev's hierarchy and is again bidding to set up his own political-scientific "empire."

Enamels created by contemporary craftsmen will go on view and on sale at America House, 44 West Fifty-third Street on Thursday. A room divider, sculptures, ash trays, boxes and panels for wall hangings are included.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The White House backtracked today from what it called the "first blooper" of the new Administration.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- A three-year contract establishing a thirty-seven-and-one-half-hour work week for 1,350 women's handbag workers was ratified last night by members of the International Leather Goods, Plastics and Novelty Workers Union.

Messing Bakeries has sold its main plant and auxiliary buildings at 813-25 Bergen Street and 814-16 and 824-44 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, in a deal negotiated by Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker. The buildings, which contain a total of 94,000 square feet of space, are assessed at $381,700, including the land.
BERLIN, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The International Skating Union said tonight that the world figure skating championships would be held in Prague as planned next month.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Commissioner Keith S. McHugh of the state Commerce Department said today that Governor Rockefeller's efforts to increase job opportunities and improve the business climate in New York were paying dividends.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Rohan Kanhai scored 117 runs and helped the West Indies reach a total of 348 for seven wickets as the fourth cricket test match against Australia began today.
The New York Stock Exchange, it was learned yesterday, has begun an investigation into the recent wide market gyrations and active trading in the common stock of Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc.
A railroad strike set for 6 A.M. Sunday was averted yesterday when the New York Central reached agreement with the Order of Railroad Conductors and Brakemen on the issue of manpower.

THESE long, cold winter evenings can be dreary without an interesting project. Max Schling Seedsmen, Inc., at 538 Madison Avenue, a shop renowned for its seeds, suggests planting an indoor herb garden. A complete herb-growing kit can be purchased for $7.95.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Six Americans will go on trial for their lives at 11 tomorrow morning in La Cabana Fortress, across the bay from Havana.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Reports on two Government polls that were declared to have shown declines last year in United States prestige in some parts of the world were made public today on orders from President Kennedy.
Hydraulic jacks are at times supporting the Gowanus Parkway, which is being rebuilt while traffic is maintained.

A psychiatrist, a philosopher and a judge argued the merits of capital punishment here yesterday. The judge, who said he had sent many men to the death house, was the only one who favored the death penalty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Kennedy made the Cuban refugee problem a responsibility of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today. He instructed Secretary Abraham A. Ribicoff to investigate the situation of the exiles.
ATLANTA, Jan. 27 -- A major shift in Southern sentiment toward school desegragation has taken place since the Supreme Court handed down its historic decision six years and eight months ago.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Henrique M. Galvao, 65-year-old leader of the Portuguese rebels on the liner Santa Maria, eluded Lisbon's intelligence agents shadowing him in Venezuela by pretending to be dying, a spokesman for the rebels said here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ed Moran, John Macy, Bob Brown and Frank Bowens are defending 1960 Star games laurels but barely qualify as favorites in the Washington indoor track and field festival tomorrow night.

TUNIS, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- The military arm of the insurgent Algerian Government said today that it was prepared to "define guarantees" for the future of Europeans if the North African territory became free from French rule.

A light week is ahead in the market for new capital. Most of the major issues -- and there are a few of them -- are municipal issues. The large issues scheduled for offering aggregate $61,308,000 and a single moderately large corporate bond sale is planned.
THERE seems to be no limit to the lengths to which a single bridge hand can go in presenting problems.

Two major Twentieth Century-Fox projects edged closer to the screen yesterday with new disclosures about the adaptation of the highly lauded television drama, "Days of Wine and Roses," and with the signing of Joseph L. Mankiewicz as director of "Cleopatra."
LONDON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- World sugar production may reach 55,665,000 tons this year, 4,000,000 tons more than last season.
The Seaboard Air Line Railroad reported yesterday a net income for 1960 of $15,012,742, equal to $3.10 a common share. This compared with earnings of $17,032,672, or $3.52 a share reported in 1959.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Streit and Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone played two-under-par golf for twelve holes today and defeated the two-time former champions, Mary Ann Downey and Marge Lindsay, 7 and 6, to gain the semi-finals of the women's international four-ball championship.

An item in your issue of Jan. 23 reports that my friend Prof. Alexander Schmemann of St. Vladimir's Seminary, New York City, in an address in Detroit criticized the prayers at the inaugural ceremony as "too smooth."

Herman Marks, a former convict who served as executioner for the Castro regime in Cuba, was arrested here Wednesday night by Immigration Department agents. He is charged with having entered the country illegally from Mexico last July.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Court of Military Appeals ruled today that an enlisted man had a right to a social drink off duty.

Now that Andy Hebenton has lost teeth -- seven in two weeks -- in the cause of the New York Rangers, one would expect Madison Square Garden fans to relent in their vocal pursuit of the 30-year-old right wing.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- Lester L. Colbert, chairman of the Board of the Chrysler Corporation, said in a statement today that his wife, Mrs. Daisy Gorman Colbert, had formerly owned 444 shares of Dura Corporation, a Chrysler supplier. She sold all of this stock "early in 1960," he said.
SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Jan. 27 -- An incentive salary system Scotch Plains School District is provided for in the 1961-62 budget adopted today by the Board of Education.
MONTREAL, Jan. 27 -- Robert M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, came to the defense today of United States investors in Canada.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Dolph Schayes, the most prolific scorer in National Basketball Association history, crossed the 17,000-point mark tonight. He scored 28 points in leading the Syracuse Nationals to a 138-126 victory over the Cincinnati Royals before 5,177 fans.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics shattered Detroit's seven-game winning streak, 140-111, tonight, when the Pistons just couldn't keep up with the Joneses -- Sam and K.C.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Federal Judge Edward J. Devitt told strike-supporting boiler plant operators of North west Airlines today to return to work here or face loss of their jobs.

The literary African lioness Elsa, heroine of the current best-seller "Born Free," was found dead of natural causes yesterday in the Kenyan jungle to which she had returned last year upon the completion of her memoirs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Senator R. Vance Hartke of Indiana was named today to succeed Senator George A. Smathers of Florida as Senate Democratic campaign chairman. Senator Clair Engle of California becomes vice chairman.
Mayor Wagner suggested yesterday that "a little research" into corruption in Albany "would do Governor Rockefeller some good."
The New York Rangers yesterday purchased the contract of Floyd Smith, a forward, and recalled Noel Price, a defenseman. Both were with Springfield of the American Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- At least two compromises were offered and rejected today as both sides maneuvered to avert a showdown in the battle over liberalization of the House Rules Committee.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Bobby Ussery, completing his second riding triple in four days, rode Never Give In to an upset victory over April Skies today in the featured seventh race at Hialeah before a crowd of 14,804. Don Poggio finished third.

In an advisory opinion handed down Thursday night in Washington, the National Labor Relations Board asserted its jurisdiction over the operations of the League of New York Theatres, the organization of theatre owners and operators.
Singing for the second time in Hunter College Assembly Hall (the first was during World War II), the Dessoff Choirs again devoted an entire program to the music of Claudio Monteverdi.

The "due process of law" is so frightening to the average person that he approaches a courtroom for the first time with trepidation. If he had a chance to observe the functioning of the court beforehand he would understand that the process is geared to operate in his behalf. And, in understanding, he would be assured.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., Racquet and Tennis, won a first-round match in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A singles championship at the University Club last night. Bostwick scored by 17 -- 14, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 8, over Myron Solin of the Columbia University Club.
SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 27 -- Friction has developed between students of National University and the new Government.
In a basketball game marred by a brawl at the final buzzer, the Cleveland Pipers beat the New York Tuck Tapers, 118 -- 106, last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico indicated yesterday that James Hoffa, the Teamsters Union leader, would meet with strong resistance in his efforts to organize a rival labor federation in the Caribbean commonwealth.
MITCH MILLER, the bearded connoisseur of the echo chamber, is in the happy position of being able to afford an indulgent attitude toward those who think his "Singalongs" are aural nightmares.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Commitment to a mental hospital was ordered today for Richard Pavlick, 73 years old, accused of a pre-inauguration "human bomb" plot against President Kennedy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 27 -- Looking back on the month's strike by Socialist unions that ended this week, Brussels is saying that the strike was misunderstood abroad. Actually, they say, it was a "good" strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, declared today that the movie industry would find some method of retesting in the United States Supreme Court the authority of movie censorship boards.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- A new crisis now faces NATO, our most important alliance, already rocked by a series of blows during the past two months and fundamentally divided by Anglo-French economic differences and General de Gaulle's stern nationalism.
A forty-pound chimpanzee will take a rocket flight from Cape Canaveral within the next few days in Project Mercury's most critical test to date.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Prof. Raymond J. Strawinski, 44 years old, one of Louisiana State University's top research scientists, and a Finnish girl student died in flames at Dr. Strawinski's home today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Kennedy has chosen Edward R. Murrow, radio and television commentator, as director of the United States Information Agency. An official announcement is expected shortly.

Dick McDonough of Villanova, Fred Munsch of Long Island University, Jack Zackin and Alex Adamowitz of the host club and the North Jersey Swim Association were the victors in the New York Athletic Club invitation swimming meet in the clubhouse pool last night.
A spectacular four-alarm fire in an uncompleted apartment house at 196 East Seventy-fifth Street last night caused injuries to two watchmen and a fireman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Kennedy Administration has ordered stiff controls on "tough" policy speeches or other "inadvisable" statements by generals and admirals. The first to be affected is Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The names of twelve passengers aboard the Military Air Transport Service plane that disappeared yesterday near New foundland with twenty-three persons aboard were announced by the Pentagon today.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The calm of the waterfront was shattered briefly this afternoon by a piercing blast from the whistle of the tanker Mount Vernon Victory. The sound muffled the crash of a bottle of champagne on her foredeck, signifying the formal christening of the new vessel.

The new 500-seat Queens College Theatre in the Charles S. Colden Center at the college will open Thursday at 3:30 P.M. with a public performance of the Jean Giraudoux play, "Tiger at the Gates." The tragi-comedy, adapted by Christopher Fry, will have a preview Wednesday night for invited guests.
The State Bar Association yesterday urged prompt modernization of the State Labor Relations Act.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Moscow radio said tonight that the son of Mme. Olga V. Ivinskaya had also been involved in alleged currency offenses in connection with royalties from Boris Pasternak's novel "Doctor Zhivago."

Manny E. Duell, president of the 1014 Fifth Avenue Realty Corporation, has contracted to buy a sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 944 Park Avenue, between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets.

ALTHOUGH the jet age is with us, there are still a goodly number of Americans who would choose to go around the world in eighty days. Within the course of a year, between fifteen and seventeen ships depart New York for such exotic ports of call as Singapore, Bangkok and Hong Kong.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 27 -- Premier-designate Joseph Ileo warned the national round-table conference of Congolese leaders today that a failure in its efforts to solve the Congo crisis would force the United Nations to take "very grave decisions."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Two United States Air Force officers, held prisoner without trial by the Soviet Union for nearly seven months, came home today and were greeted by President Kennedy.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Universal Match Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., announced jointly today that plans for a proposed merger had been canceled because of legal and technical problems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose to a record in December for the fourth consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

Protestant teen-agers over the nation will begin their eighteenth observance of Youth Week tomorrow.
ALFRED WALLENSTEIN and the Berlioz "Romeo et Juliette" have been absent from the New York Philharmonic rosters for some time. They came back yesterday afternoon and were welcome indeed.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- John Thomas will warm up for his revenge on the Russians" high-jumping campaign tomorrow night in the seventy-second Boston Athletic Association track meet. But the chances are that the top events will be the dash and 600-yard run.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Rafer Johnson was honored today as the male athlete of the year for 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A new vehicle can slide over land or sea on a cushion of air. An engineer in the Bureau of Naval Weapons has now designed one to dip below the surface and become a submarine.
A strike vote will be taken at noon tomorrow by members of the union that mans virtually all harbor craft used to move fuel oil, coal and construction material to the five boroughs of New York.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the state's twenty-one Democratic county leaders will meet at Morven, the executive mansion in Princeton, tomorrow in another effort to pick an organization candidate for Governor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Robert F. Kennedy has decided to retain Joseph M. Swing as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization for at least the next few months.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- A battle among some of Britain's most powerful publishers developed today with the announcement by the Daily Mirror Newspapers of a bid for the Odhams Press.

The snowstorms and the prolonged cold have created an abnormal problem of leaking roofs in the suburbs.
A method has been developed that for the first time allows physicians to take movies of the delicate network of arteries that supply blood to the heart.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Something has happened to the famous Chanel suit. Today Mlle. Chanel gave one of the most widely known of all fashion classics some new twists. First, she shaped her familiar, loose, patch-pocketed jacket to the figure.

Capt. John R. McKone and Capt. Freeman B. Olmstead had a homecoming yesterday that they could not have dreamed of last July when they went on a reconnaissance over the Barents Sea. Russian fliers shot them down well outside the Russian frontiers. Four of their comrades were killed. Now after nearly seven months of imprisonment the Russians have sent them back.
Psychotherapists at an adolescent treatment center have been treating delinquents in their natural state -- in "gangs" -- rather than individually.
The United States Golf Association established a non-playing award yesterday.

Mayor Wagner succeeded yesterday in putting off the election of Manhattan Borough President until Tuesday despite the efforts of half the Manhattan members of the City Council to go ahead with the election.
New York's Democratic leaders came out yesterday for the repeal of the 2-cent tax on cigarettes and 15 per cent tax on cigars and tobacco products imposed by the Legislature last year.
BROWNSVILLE Tenn., Jan. 27 (AP) -- A. representative of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was adjudged guilty today of threatening a breach of peace and fined $50.

NEWARK, Jan. 27 -- The Port of New York Authority made a firm offer today to acquire the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Adlai E. Stevenson indicated today that President Kennedy would be glad to meet Premier Khrushchev should the Soviet leader come here when the General Assembly resumes its session in March.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation announced yesterday that it would purchase common and preferred shares of Fruit of the Loom, Inc., in any quantities offered at prices to be announced in newspaper advertisements early next week.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Following is the text of a statement by Adlai E. Stevenson, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, at a news conference today:
LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Princess Astrid of Norway and her husband John Ferner] arrived here by air tonight from Madrid to spend part of their honeymoon in Britain. i

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., told the Supreme Court today that the public interest would be fully protected under the plan approved by United States district court in Chicago for settling the antitrust case arising out of the company's holdings of General Motors Corporation stock.

Four-hand piano-playing, one of the pleasantest diversions in the music world, can be raised to a high art when the two pianists involved are sufficiently proficient, persistent, and friendly. A crush of people eight deep gazed at a shop window on Vesey Street yesterday, their eyes watering with nostalgia, their mouths with hunger.
A second bingo investigator for the State Lottery Control Commission has resigned after being questioned about his activities, the chairman of the commission announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Grain futures traders absorbed moderate flurries of profit taking today in all pits, then confidently bid prices higher all along the line with several contracts at or near their highs for the season.
SOUTH HUNTINGTON, L.I. Jan. 27 -- The romantic comedy side of William Shakespeare was brought to life here this afternoon for 500 ninth-grade students and they loved it.
A technicians' union moved yesterday a step closer to a strike Tuesday night against the American Broadcasting Company.
Bond prices ended the week's trading yesterday on a strong note.
If Alvin (Pete) Rozelle, the 34-year-old commissioner of the National Football League, has his way, a radical change soon will be made in the professional circuit's playing rules.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Leaders of the National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice said today that President Kennedy should appeal directly to the citizens of New Orleans to abide by the school desegregation decisions of the United States Supreme Court.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The United States made progress in combatting segregation last year, Tuskegee Institute reported today, but the "moral underpinnings were largely neglected."

Freezing cold, extra crowds, the four inches of snow that fell on Thursday and mechanical trouble combined to delay tens of thousands of commuters on the suburban railroads in both the morning and evening rush hours yesterday.

Daniel Chase, executive director of the New York City Park Association, and his wife Alice will be honored on their fiftieth wedding anniversary tomorrow at a reception in the National Arts Club.
Two heavy punchers, Rory Calhoun of White Plains and Florentino Fernandez of Cuba, meet tonight in a ten-round middleweight bout in Madison Square Garden, with Fernandez a 7-5 favorite.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States assured the captors of the Portuguese ship Santa Maria today that it would take no action against them or the vessel if they debarked her passengers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Seven governments have made a joint request for a meeting of the Security Council to take up "alarming recent developments" in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action asked the Defense Department today to revoke its order to buy prints of "Operation Abolition," the controversial movie about the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Congressional auditors said today that the Air Force would waste $183,000,000 this year in connection with unnecessary flight pay.

The Gerber Products Company announced yesterday that its directors had voted a two-for-one split of the common stock and increased the cash dividend on the shares now outstanding. The baby food concern also reported that sales and earnings in the nine-month period ended on Dec. 31 were higher than in the corresponding level of 1959.
The number of children in New York who have decayed teeth is 250 per cent greater than if the city had fluoridated its water, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner said yesterday.

A move to obtain city budget funds to permit the Metropolitan Museum of Art to open to the public on Mondays and the Brooklyn Museum to open Mondays and Tuesdays was made yesterday by the Citizens Union.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Humberto da Silva Delgado, head of a Portuguese rebel movement, named Henrique M. Galvao to be "delegate plenipotentiary" today for revolutionary action against the Lisbon Government of Premier Antonio de Oliviera Salazar.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 -The National Autonomous University of Mexico, hub of the nation's culture and one its great showplaces, settled down this week with a new boss and what appears to be a new and a much tighter discipline.

THE New York City Ballet does not hold with longwinded nineteenth-century sentimentality, but it has nevertheless made of "Swan Lake" a perennially experimental and consequently unaging item in its repertory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The motion picture censors still operating in a scattering of states and cities around the country found some support this week in an unusual place -- the Supreme Court of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -During the last six months of the Eisenhower Administration, 25,934 civilian employees left the Government payroll.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Hemmo Silvennoinen, the 28-year-old skier from Helsinki, Finland, made a notable American debut today. With leaps of 148 and 160 feet, he won the eleventh metropolitan invitation ski-jumping tournament.

Kurt Rosche's shot with a minute remaining enabled the Squadron A polo team to defeat Blind Brook, 6 -- 5, in a nine-goal tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 -- Indians forgot their troubles this week. Not completely, of course, but economic hardship, political squabbling and worry about Communist China, the Congo and Laos seemed to fade into the background. Queen Elizabeth II was here, and the capital, at least, appeared determined to make the most of it.

Resident buying offices reported brisk business in spring merchandise last week. Costumes, sweater dresses, knit suit as well as blouses, slacks and skirts were in good demand. Junior wear and budget and popular-price dresses were among the leading items that were reordered.

Employment in Illinois non-agricultural establishments slipped 32,000 persons last November, compared with the year before figures, the state employment service reported. The total at the end of the month was 3,414,200. The November total was 20,700 below the prior month.

JACK BENNY will make a nostalgic return on Feb. 9 to the National Broadcasting Company, the network on which he got his start in radio nearly thirty years ago. Among the most crucial puzzles of modern medical science is that of atherosclerosis. It is the underlying cause of most heart disease and ranks as the foremost killer of civilized man.

A new book by Lewis Mumford, "The City in History: Its Origins, Its Transformations and Its Prospects," is planned for April 12 publication by Harcourt, Brace World. The surf rolls in, colder now but implacable as ever. The waves sweep across the sands and eddy back in their endless journey to nowhere. This is the beach in winter. Short months before it teemed with laughing, pleasure-bent humanity. It gave joy to children and respite to their parents. Romance blossomed on sun-swept shore. The beach lies dormant now, forgotten and ignored by those who took its pleasures.
An 11-year-old boy was rescued yesterday after clinging for nearly an hour to an ice-covered ledge above the Harlem River Drive.

In Leningrad that evening, however, Valeri Brumel cleared a bar set at 7 feet 4 1/2 inches, the highest leap in history.

Tomorrow some 54,000 salaried employes of the General Motors Corporation will receive more than $11,000,000 in G.M. common stock, Government bonds and cash. They are members of the "first class" of a savings fund plan set up under the company's savings-stock purchase program on Oct. 1, 1955.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 29 -- Approval by taxpayers of a $2,296,000 school expansion program was hailed today by Dr. Cecil L. Rice, Superintendent of Schools, as "a tribute to the liberalism of the community."

ONE HUNDRED AND ONE MILES south of Tokyo between the mountains and Suruga Bay lies the village of Okitsu. Through Okitsu runs the Tokaido Road, the ancient highway that for hundreds of years linked the imperial capital of Kyoto and the administrative capital of Edo, called Tokyo since the end of the Shogunate. Between the road and the bay in Okitsu stands the Minaguchi-ya Inn, where travelers have found gracious hospitality for nearly four centuries.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet magazine Ogonyok said today that it had published an incorrect report regarding the fate of eleven United States airmen who have been missing since their Air Force transport plane crashed in Soviet Armenia in 1958.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan 29 -- Finland's ski-jumping stars, Hemmo Silennoinen and Ossl Laaksonen, again put on a rousing performance today in sharing top honors at the Palisades Interstate Park's 50-meter hill.
