CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice urged Roman Catholic laymen today to end the boycott of two New Orleans schools.

ATLANTA, Jan. 29 -- The Southern Regional Council has urged President Kennedy to adopt a sweeping program of executive action in the civil-rights field. In a forty -eight-page report to the President, the council makes eighteen proposals for strengthening the rights of Negroes. It is thought to be the most far-reaching blueprint of its kind yet received by the new Administration.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29 -- William P. Bundy, newly appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, has been elected a trustee of Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Edward R. Murrow, who gave up an income of $200,000 a year as a radio-television commentator to become director of the United States Information Agency, said today he planned to ask others to follow his example.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The first White House party given by the President and Mrs. Kennedy was the gayest here in many a year.
SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 29 -- A demand that the three civilian members of El Salvador's new governing junta be dismissed has been drawn up by six political parties.
WHAT was omitted from -- "A Neglected Education" were those essentials known as "the facts of life."

The Peoples Securities Corporation reported over the weekend that its adjusted share value rose by 16.2 per cent during the fiscal quarter ended on Dec. 31. Abraham S. Karasick, president, said that for the twelve months ended on Dec. 31 the gain amounted to 21.5 per cent.

A foreigner casually observing the American political scene might wonder at the power residing in Representative Howard Worth Smith of Broad Run, Va., chairman of the House Rules Committee. Mr. Smith is a veteran legislator -- or, in many instances, nonlegislator; he has been, as his biographical sketch in the Congressional Directory says, "elected to the Seventy-second and each succeeding Congress."
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Gary Player of South Africa posted a six-under-par 65 today and won the $57,000 Lucky international open golf toturnament with a 72-hole score of 272.

GENEVA, Jan. 29 -- Trading was again lively on the Swiss stock markets last week and a number of Swiss issues posted historic highs. Buying by mutual funds was held to have contributed to the strong showing of leading Swiss industrials.
What were the mutual funds buying in the final quarter of 1960? What were they selling?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The House Science and Astronautics committee warned today that the United States would probably face a critical water shortage by 1970.

PRAGUE, Czecholslovakia, Jan. 27 -- Heavy industries are feeling the effects of a growing labor shortage. This situation was stressed by factory managers interviewed during a four-day tour of the country's industrial centers, which have seen great expansion since the Communist takeover in 1948.
BALTIMORE; Jan. 29 -- Ch. Hassan-Ben of Moornistan, a red-cream Afghan owned, bred and handled by Dr. William Moore 3d, became best in show today in the 636-dog event of the Maryland Kennel Club.
A shortage of 135,000 teachers may be hard to visualize in terms of its effect on just one school. Such figures have real meaning only for statisticians.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 -- Janio Quadros, who takes office Tuesday as President of Brazil, was quoted today as having said that he would give asylum to the Portuguese liner Santa Maria and the rebels who seized her at sea.

Benjamin Strong, chairman of the board of directors of Union Theological Seminary, announced yesterday that Barr Barr. Inc. had received the contract t o build the seminary's new $4.018,000 residence building.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 29 -- Patrick J. Kenney, a 52-year-old executive with Sears Roebuck Co., was unanimously elected Mayor at a special meeting of the City Council here today.

RECIFE, Brazil, Monday, Jan. 30 -- A week-long pursuit of the rebel-held Portuguese liner Santa Maria will come to a conclusion later today when a United States admiral boards her near this port to negotiate the removal of the more than 560 passengers.

BY an uneasy mingling of fact and fiction, Howard M. Teichmann has come up with an embarrassing, unfunny comedy. "Julia, Jake, and Uncle Joe," which opened Saturday at the Booth, starts with identifiable people in a realistic situation, shifts into farce and becomes a concocton that is neither fresh comment nor lively invention.
Tax laws are complicated. No one denies it. But taxpayers persist in making routine mistakes on their income tax returns, and it's all a matter of reading, 'riting, and 'rithmetic.

WINE may improve with age but the acting at the annual Baseball Writers Show definitely does not. It gets worse. Another stirring maltreatment of the dramatic art sent the theatre plummeting to new depths at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. These pro tem disciples of sock-and-buskin put far more emphasis on the sock than the buskin in flailing at baseball's foibles.
After a week of discussions on the causes of climate change, an assembly of specialists from several continents seems to have reached unanimous agreement on only one point: it is getting colder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- At 8:30 A.M. the door of elevator No. 22, the Secretary's own, slides open on the seventh floor of the new State Department building, and Dean Rusk strides briskly into his office to start his twelve-to fourteen-hour working day.
Queens Borough President John T. Clancy indicated yesterday that he was not prepared now to pledge his unqualified support to Mayor Wagner as a candidate for reelection.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- There is a special kind of protocol for coping with foreign movies entered for Oscar competition that requires secrecy -- and some diplomacy.

A total of 3,080 public school children, now in second through the fourth grades, have asked for transfers to schools outside their own neighborhoods next fall. The transfers were requested under the Board of Education's open enrollment program, designed to improve the ethnic balance in the city's schools.
BOSTON, Jan, 29 (AP) -- Bob Cousy sparked a first-period scorinx burst today that put tile Boston Celtics off and running to a 128-115 rout of Philadelphia.
Devotees of the Bill of Rights will welcome and applaud your editorial of Jan. 26 on the proposed aid to sectarian schools.
A persistent cold wave continued to freeze the metropolitan area yesterday, with only a little relief in sight.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson and State Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney attacked Mayor Wagner's administration in separate television appearances yesterday.
EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 29 (UPI) -- A rocket expert said today that an all-out educa- tional effort in the United States to produce scientists would not result in scientific progress.

TORONTO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Hundreds of supporters and opponents of the Portuguese Government fought tonight outside the Portuguese Consulate in downtown Toronto, overturning one car and damaging several others.
Four large apartment buildings on Park Avenue have been purchased by their occupants and will be operated on a cooperative basis. They were sold for about $12,000,000.

In the Dar El Salaam suburb of Cairo, President Gamal Abdul Nasser's second five-year industrial program takes the form of a small but proud factory turning out the first television sets "made in Egypt."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Kennedy has ordered the State Department to re-examine United States policies in the Congo and to recommend changes.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Marsha Fletcher of Rutland, Vt., shared honors today with Gordon Eaton of Middlebury College in the United States Eastern giant-slalom ski championship.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The father of the 9-year-old boy who broke the white boycott at an integrated school was ordered today to vacate his apartment by next week.

Charles Ufford of the Harvard Club, the defending champion, was among the second-round victors yesterday in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A singles tournament at the University Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Even before President Kennedy's grand entrance down the center aisle of the House, it was clear that there would be no mighty triumph for him at the Capitol today.

Mayor Wagner pressed for a showdown with Tammany Hall last night by announcing he favored the election of Justice Edward R. Dudley of Domestic Relations Court as Manhattan Borough President. The six Manhattan members of the City Council will vote for a new Borough President today.

Plans to merge and establish a new corporation with assets of about $625,000,000 and sales of some $730,000,000 a year were announced yesterday by the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and the Bridgeport Brass Company.
The three-week-long improvement in steel production came to an abrupt end last week.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday its cancellation of a scheduled television drama about Soviet espionage activities in this country was a decision made solely by the company. It still declined to say why it canceled "The Spy Next Door."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Pentagon prepared today on orders from President Kennedy to speed Polaris submarine construction, increase the force of transport planes for limited-war situations and invigorate the lagging missile program.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- President Kennedy s State of the Union Message was received favorably by diplomats from Western and neutral nations here. Even some Eastern Europeans, while finding the over-all policy line "tough," also saw pleasing elements.

A lawyer for Fidel Castro's former executioner said yesterday that he would fight deportation of the man partly on the basic constitutional question of whether a native-born American can be deprived of his citizenship.
NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Luigi The Tomb, who once escaped the electric chair at Sing Sing prison, died of a heart attack in jail today with his appeal against a life sentence still pending.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Nearly all grain futures contracts hit new season highs today in a broad general run-up on the Board of Trade. Almost all gains were around 2 cents a bushel or more, with numerous advances well over 3 cents.

WHEN declarer has J-10- x-x of a suit in one hand and A-x-x in the other, without the nine in either hand, his hope of losing only one trick in the suit usually depends on finding a doubleton honor in the hand of either opponent.
A versatile elevator and moving stairway system will be incorporated into the new Bankers Trust Building that will rise on the west side of Park Avenue between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Three sophomore wings accounted for six goals and six assists tonight as the St. Lawrence hockey team defeated Princeton, 11 -- 2, at Baker Rink.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Eternal Mark, the second choice of a crowd of 8,123 in a field of six fillies and mares, passed Allchain in the stretch at Bowie today and won by a nose.
Four pedestrians were injured yesterday when struck by a axicab on a sidewalk.

The Board of Education yesterday canceled a special public hearing tomorrow that would have dealt with departmental charges against seven teachers. The seven were suspended for allegedly having lied about past membership in the Communist party in applications for teaching and supervisory licenses.
A larger-than-usual crowd of motorists, many of whom had put off the annual task of renewing their auto licenses because of this month's snow and cold, faced an hour of foot-stamping chill yesterday.
A reliable report has it that the Ronson Corporation is moving its billings of $1,500,000 a year for its Ronson Lighter out of Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc., and giving it to Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc.

Music students between the ages of 6 and 30 are eligible for the Music Education League Awards in the following categories: piano and piano ensemble, strings and string ensemble, theory, ear-training and sight-reading and former gold certificate winners.

Jean Anouilh's comedy, "Rendezvous in Senlis," which has been seen in Paris, London, Edinburgh and Dublin, will get a hearing in this country for the first time in an off-Broadway production on Feb. 27 at the Gramercy Arts Theatre.

Widening investment opportunities brought about by the newly organized real estate investment trusts, syndications and publicly held realty corporations have given nation-wide dimensions to the realty investment market.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Northwest Airlines, which has grounded all domestic flights since Jan. 9 because of a flight engineers' strike, announced today that it would open regular jet service in and out of Minneapolis and St. Paul on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Kennedy set forth today a broad array of proposals to stimulate the domestic economy and check the outflow of dollars and gold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The United States Information Agency released the controversial report today upon which President Kennedy based his campaign assertions that the nation was losing prestige abroad.

The National Association of House-to-House Installment Companies, at a meeting yesterday, elected Joseph M. Simon of the Boston Furniture and Supply Company, Wilkes-Barre, Pa., as president. He succeeds E.C. Faucett of the Dixie Supply Company, Tampa, Fla.

Two senior real estate managers were formally reinstated yesterday by the Department of Real Estate. Both were suspended last November after having been accused of accepting gratuities from a contractor.

Events today: "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Peter Herman Adler, conductor, Ivan Davis, pianist, Eric Friedman, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Samuel Baron, flutist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Nan Merriman, mezzo-soprano, Judson Hall, 8:30.

MEN whose jobs require a standard of dress their incomes ill afford have a friend at the Gentlemen's Resale Shop, 750 Lexington Avenue (near Sixtieth Street). Established by an actor and former model, John Rallo, the shop specializes in new and nearly new men's clothing at remarkably low prices.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Superintendent of Public Works J. Burch McMorran announced today that a six-tenths of a mile section of the Cross Bronx Expressway between Clay and Walton Avenues was scheduled to be opened to traffic Feb. 10.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 30 -- The Minister of Immigration, Alexander R. Downer, read with a frown today reports that George Lincoln Rockwell, head of the American Nazi party, had accepted an invitation to speak at a rally of an Australian racist group in Sydney on May 1.

A junior committee is aiding in final arrangements for the twenty-second annual White Elephant Party, which will be held at the Pierre on Thursday for the benefit of the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Society.

The United States national hockey team left New York International Airport last night for Munich, Germany. The team will play a series of exhibition games in Europe leading to the world championships March 2 through 12 at Geneva.
PARIS, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Erro, one of Italy's best trotters, tonight joined the field for the $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway in New York on April 20.
A gas explosion in the basement of Brooklyn's second tallest building injured thirty-one persons yesterday and sprayed the crowded downtown business district with shattered glass.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- The West German Government announced today that it would offer a single payment to ease the United States balance of payments problem.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has promoted Hugh W. Strickland and Charles F. Fogarty to senior vice president, it was announced yesterday by Claude O. Stephens, president.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 -- The Government of Premier David Ben-Gurion survived a motion for a vote of no confidence today following the turmoil created by the Lavon affair. The motion was defeated, 77 to 26.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Yesterday ranks as the grayest day in the history of this city's Racing Club soccer team. Not only did Racing lose to Rouen, 1 -- 0, before one of the biggest home crowds of the season, but it also lost the receipts from the match, about $18,000.
STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 30 -- Twelve European nations opened a conference today to discuss plans for using a British-French rocket to launch a satellite.
David Rockefeller said yesterday the projected World Trade Center on the East River was likely to be larger than originally planned.

It was an inspiring, eloquent and straightforward address that President Kennedy made yesterday when he delivered his first State of the Union message to Congress. This is an "hour of national peril and national opportunity" in our nation's history, and we do face again the test of whether a people and a society "organized and governed such as ours can endure."

PLAINVIEW, L.I., Jan. 30 -- A sharp rise in school tax rates was forecast today unless the state increased its share of the cost of local education. The warning came from A. Terry Weathers, president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association.
Thomas M. Messer, the 40-year-old director of the Institute of Contemporary Arts in Boston, has been named director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum here.

An abatement of bidding for high-grade debt securities was visible in most of the bond market yesterday, checking the upward inching of prices common in recent trading sessions. Prices of most gilt-edge debt securities closed the day little changed from Friday's levels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Government auditors accused the military today of spending more than $50,000,000 on construction without its approval.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The White House took a hand today in the battle for liberalization of the House Rules Committee.

The executive vice president of the United States Savings and Loan League urged yesterday that tax incentives be used to foster thrift and hence economic growth. Norman Strunk told the league's annual legislative conference in Washington that similar encouragement to savings by European nations were a major factor in their postwar recovery and expansion.
About fifty persons, most of them Cubans, appeared yesterday for employment assistance at a new state office opened to aid refugees from Latin-American countries.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 30 -- Manuel Cardinal Goncalves Cerejeira, Patriarch of Lisbon, appealed to President Kennedy today to take measures guaranteeing "full liberty of disembarkation for those crew members of the Portuguese ship Santa Maria who desire to leave the ship."

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- The Air Force canceled its first attempt to launch the Minuteman Intercontinental Ballistic Missile today. The efford was called off after the count-down had twice come within thirty seconds of zero.

It was with consternation that I discovered several months ago that the temple of Rameses II at Abu Simbel in Egypt might be destroyed by the backing up of flood waters from the new dam. The first formal commitment for the 1961 city election came yesterday as Bert J. Koehler, the Queens Democratic leader, said Mayor Wagner was "the first, last and only choice of the Queens Democratic party for this year's mayoralty campaign."
The Southern Pacific Company, a major West Coast transportation system, reported yesterday that net income in 1960 fell by 4 per cent from the 1959 level, while gross revenues declined by 7 per cent.
TUNIS, Jan. 30 -- The Tunisian Government announced tonight that it would resume its seat in the Arab League after an absence of more than two years.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Directors of Philadelphia Electric Company proposed today a two-for-one stock split to be followed by a dividend rise on the split shares.

Lewis D. Gilbert, a frequent protester at annual meetings, has written State and Federal officials protesting against any approval of applications for permission to form bank holding companies unless "elementary basic protections" are required.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- "The United States has extended more public and private credit to Latin America in the last eight years than we did in any previous period," Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower said here today.
Thirty of the world's leading fencers are expected to participate in the first New York Athletic Club International Invitation Classic here on Feb. 17, 18 and 19.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- The nation's auto dealers were advised here today, as a sound financial policy, to resist the manufacturing giants of the industry who try to overstock them with new cars.

Patrons and patronesses have been announced for the twenty-fifth annual benefit luncheon and bridge party of the Catholic Big Sisters, which will be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 14.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Industrial equities closed firm on balance on the stock market here today.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mercenary soldier-adventurers are arriving here daily from many parts of the world to join the Katanga security forces.
ATLANTA, Jan. 30 -- Carling Dinkier Sr., president of the Dinkier Hotels Company, plunged to his death today from his twelfth-floor suite in a downtown hotel. He was 66 year old.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller rejected today all of Mayor Wagner's requests for new taxing powers and most of his plans for more state aid.

Edward R. Murrow, giving up a large income as a privately employed commentator, turns to his new employment as director of the United States Information Agency with the assurance that "whatever is done will have to stand on a rugged basis of truth." Mr. Murrow's success as a radio and television commentator does not, of course, rest entirely on his respect for truth.

ON the night of March 3, 1933, William Hartman Woodin made a sacrifice that perhaps only another musician could truly appreciate. His "On the Prairie" was being given its first performance by the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington. Mr. Woodin did not go to hear it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Stand-by authority to help Communist countries of Eastern Europe with loans and grants was asked by President Kennedy today in his State of the Union Message.

Haaren High is an enclave tucked in a mid-Manhattan maze of truck routes, tenements and shops. Some of its educational and social problems are peculiar to Tenth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, but its athletic problems are shared by most of the city s seventy-odd public high schools.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning to borrow $80,204,000 on temporary loan notes to finance the development of nine low-rent projects subsidized by the Public Housing Administration and two projects subsidized by the New York State government.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Herberto Hinojosa, a 25-year-old jockey from Brownsville, Tex., booted home four winners at Hialeah today.

JAMES Dunscomb is a dedicated chef who takes pride in his work. But he is one of several cooks in this city who prepare meals under conditions that most housewives would find too exasperating to endure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Kennedy relied on the literary talents of his long-time collaborator, Theodore C. Sorensen, in the preparation of his first State of the Union message.

ONE sterling principle that is constantly being hammered home to the youth of our land is this: Honesty is the best policy. The impelling reason for the admission of Max Carey and Billy Hamilton into the Cooperstown shrine is that they were diamond thieves.
For team of the year in 1960, it's the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 to 1 -- and more.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Even further cutbacks may be in the offing in the auto industry. Everybody is having a rough time.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 30 -- The "Battle of the Millionaires" over a right of way for a new superhighway through northern Westchester County grew in intensity and scope today.
Major changes in navigational aids will go into effect tomorrow on the southern approaches to Delaware Bay, the Coast Guard said here yesterday.

Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, denounced yesterday "the complete inaccuracy and irresponsible content" of a report that he would be suceeded in the leadership by Peter J. Crotty, Erie County chairman.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Ohio State, the National Collegiate basketball champion, routed Wisconsin tonight, 100 -- 68, for its twentieth victory in a row.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner told the Legislature today that it "must" vote tax increases sufficient to provide $39,000,000 more a year in state revenue.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Europe's new-style bonds -- denominated in an "international unit of account" instead of a particular currency -- were a big success in their first public offering last week.
A New York doctor returned yesterday after what he called three months of invaluable experience as a volunteer teacher aboard the United States Hospital Ship Hope, anchored off Sumbawa, Indonesia.

Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday that net income for 1960 had been estimated at a record of $391,750,000, equal to $6.34 a share on 61,749,274 shares outstanding. This represented an increase of 10.6 per cent from the preceding peak of $354,346,323, or $5.85 a share, reported for 1959.

United Air Lines, Inc., has extended to April 30 the offer to exchange its common stock for Capital Airlines 4 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures as part of a merger proposal, Curtis Barkes, executive vice president of finance and property of United, announced yesterday.

LEONID Andreyev's tragi-comedy, "He Who Gets Slapped," is the current attraction of "The Play of the Week" in a production starring Richard Basehart as the clown and Julie Harris as the beautiful bareback rider.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Three aviation groups said today that almost half of the nation's 3,500 publicly owned airports need expansion and improvement immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today by voice vote President Kennedy's nomination of G. Mennen Williams, six-term Democratic Governor of Michigan, as Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Roy Emerson rallied today and upset Rod Laver in the singles final of the Australian national tennis championships. The scores were 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

Phil Jordon, who did such a good defensive job against Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors last week, will be called upon tonight to perform a similar operation on Johnny Kerr of the Syracuse Nationals at Madison Square Garden.

The Bates Manufacturing Company, textile concern, is bidding $20 a share for the common and $50 a share for the preferred of Fruit of the Loom, Inc. This was disclosed yesterday as Bates vied with the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation for control. Last week the shares, which are traded in the over-the-counter market, were quoted at $7.50 bid for the common and $46 bid for the preferred, with no offers.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson, playing his first full game in nearly two weeks, added 32 points to Jack Twyman's 41 as the Cincinnati Royals overwhelmed the Boston Celtics, 116 -- 88, tonight.
The highest high jump in history was made from a dirt take-off with outdoor jumping spikes, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- A sense of foreboding is settling over much of the Western European automobile industry -- and part of it stems from decisions taken across the Atlantic in the United States. The fear is that Europe may be heading into a period of overexpansion of auto-making facilities, agonizing competition and, finally, failures of long-established concerns, just as happened in the United States in the post-war period.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Kennedy challenged Congress and the nation today to face up to grave perils abroad and a worsening economic recession at home.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 30 -- President Sukarno presented to Parliament today a record budget, totaling almost 83,000,000,000 rupiahs ($1,859,200,000), to help build an Indonesian socialist society.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 30 -- A.C. Swann, Minister for Internal Security and Defense in Kenya, said yesterday there were indications that the terrorist Mau Mau organization had increased its membership during the last few months.

Digital computers, the so-called electronic brains, have "come of age" in masterminding industrial production processes, according to a report given yesterday at the winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

SCOTTISH PRODUCTS, INC., at 24 East Sixtieth Street is filled with colorful clothes and accessories. Kilts, Tam o'Shanters, clan crests, mufflers and everything except the heather are in abundance. Clothes for adults are made to order in Scotland, so six to eight weeks should be allowed after meas urements are taken.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets were 0.1 per cent higher during the week ended Tuesday, Jan. 24, at 119.9 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor disclosed yesterday that his office was investigating an allegation that three policemen had received bribes totaling $1,400 for helping to obtain the dismissal of charges against three men arrested as members of an auto theft ring.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Legislation to permit New York City to lease the proposed Flushing Meadow Baseball Park to private operators was introduced tonight.
On a blustery day in late September, 1917, a pert Salvation Army lass stationed in Montiers, France, fried a batch of doughnuts for her "soldier boys."

Phyllis Notaro had trouble learning how to bowl and has run into other troubles since perfecting her style. But she finally got everything working so well that she won the recent women's national All-Star championship.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30 -- Senhor Galvao received assurances today that President-elect Janio Quadros would allow him to enter and leave Brazilian waters in the liner Santa Maria after Senhor Quadros inaugration at noon tomorrow.

Long liquidation and hedge selling of potato futures touched off stop-loss orders yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trade and commission house buying and scattered short covering limited the losses. The May position dropped to a new low for the move.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- The State Senate voted today to reapportion the sixty seats in the State Assembly for the first time since 1941, but further action was blocked in the Assembly.

THOMAS M. MESSER bears little resemblance to the gilt-framed formality once associated with museum directors. He is closer to the lean lines of an abstract painting. As one of the youngest museum directors in the country, he has worked hard to emphasize the differ ence and for a purpose -- to create a more relaxed atmosphere to draw the public into the museums.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Senator Barry Goldwater accused the Kennedy Administration today of laying down a governmental information policy that might lead to "a dictaphone type of 'gag rule'" enforced by White House edict.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower thanked President Kennedy today for releasing his two-member clean-up detail from the shackles of bureaucratic red tape.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 30 -- The Arab states displayed some progress today toward patching up their old quarrels and uniting for common causes.

The Grand Ballroom of the Pierre will be transformed into a Grecian garden for the thirty-third annual ball to support the social service work of the Hellenic Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. The fete will be given on Feb. 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Treasury bill rates rose slightly on today's sales of regular weekly issues. They had been falling for two weeks.

The Composers Group of New York City presented music by seven authors last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 15 points (5 to 75 cents a bale) yesterday.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Gen. Thomas D. White announced tonight creation of an Air Force command to direct global communications vital to the defense of the United States.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- A rare feat by a spin bowler, Lance Gibbs, helped the West Indian cricket team to a lead of 177 runs over Australia today after three days of their five-day test match.
THE Metropolitan Opera opened its fifteenth week last night with Gluck's "Alcestis." Eileen Farrell again had the title role, but three of the male leads were in new hands.

Roger Marts flew home to Raytown, Mo., yesterday. Actually, the American League's most valuable player could have dispensed with the jet and floated back on Cloud Nine. The Yankees' slugging outfielder had just signed the best contract of his baseball career.

DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- A spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation said today that a supplier company in which one of Chrysler's directors had an interest was awarded orders for heat treating furnaces in 1959. But the awards were made only after competitive bidding, he said.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- The subject of movie censorship has been made more complicated by a mythology created by producers rather than by Supreme Court decisions. According to experts in the field, movie producers are often ignorant of what the movie censorship code permits or forbids.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- R. Sargent Shriver Jr. is the likely choice to head the National Peace Corps proposed by President Kennedy in his State of the Union Message today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the commission reject a proposal of the Southern Pacific Company and Illinois Central Railroad to get into the barge line business.
Eighty Cuban emigres on a Spanish liner won asylum here last night. The number was expected to rise as immigration officials interviewed additional passengers on the liner, the Covadonga.
The addition of several pieces of cardboard to the winter equipment of motorists was recommended yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The President's first State of the Union message to Congress was a noble utterance, nobly delivered. Even many of those who found themselves wondering how the earnest, eloquent young President could come near to accomplishing the programs he outlined and still not "distort the value of the dollar in any fashion" must have been impressed with his determined and pragmatic approach to this Herculean task.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- A 5 per cent increase in Canada's export sales last year helped trim the country's trade deficit to $100,500,000 for 1960, the smallest deficit since 1954, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
The General Electric Company has put a blacksmith to work at the Hanford, Wash., atomic power plant that it operates for the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- New York's Republican Senators took issue today with criticism that Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, had made against an immigration bill they introduced last week.
The board of directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company voted yesterday to omit dividend action on its two preferred stocks, as well as on the common.

A LIVELY curiosity is a splendid thing. It is one of the characteristics that separate spunky boys from sedate middle-aged men. In today's complex world, however, children must learn to temper curiosity with caution.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- President Joseph Kasavubu of the Congo has warned the United Nations that troops from outside the framework of the international organization would be called in unless it could end the revolt against his Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration announced today its first major decision on management of the national debt, adopting an idea pioneered last year by the Eisenhower Administration.
Information from a pilot injured in the wrecking of a Mexican jet airliner here Jan. 19 may not be disclosed "until we get all the facts together," a Federal investigator said yesterday.

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Prof. Arthur M. Schlessinger Jr., special assistant to President Kennedy, said tonight that the development of a welfare state in the United States was "the best security" against communism.

YOU can have a drink at your table before the new revue, "O, Oysters!" gets under way, and you can get a refill during the intermission. But you don't need distilled spirits to be diverted by the bright moments in the show that arrived last night at the Village Gate.
Jackie Donnelly, a 25-year-old lightweight from Buffalo, posted a unanimous decision over Benny Gordon of New York in a ten-round fight at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The British Admiralty came under fire in Parliament today for having decided not to include six Negro sailors on a goodwill visit to South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- George Washington University reached into the Western Conference for the second straight year today and chose Jim Camp, a top assistant at Minnesota, as its head football coach.

ROSEMONT, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The National Institute of Arts and Letters commended President and Mrs. Kennedy today for their "clear and consequential sense of the importance of literature and the fine arts in our American culture."
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Quick Federal action was pledged here today to intensify and expedite aid to refugees from the regime of Cuban Premier Fidel Castro.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- Expansion of exports and contraction of imports served in 1959 to shrink the trade deficit of twenty-two countries by more than $600,000,000 as compared with 1958, the Economic Commission for Africa reported in its first quarterly bulletin from that region.
Jurisdictional feuds, which have long plagued labor in its efforts to unionize production workers, are beginning to erupt with equal intensity in the white-collar field.

A $35,080,000 contract for the construction of four cargo ships has been signed by American Export Lines, the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., and the Federal Maritime Board, the board announced yesterday.

Massachusetts Investors Trust, the oldest and second largest of all mutual funds, reported yesterday net assets of $1,508,349,600, equal to $13.17 each on 114,515,115 shares outstanding last Dec. 31. This compared with $1,557,737,888, or $13.93 a share on 111,800,035 shares outstanding on Dec. 31, 1959.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale, the strikeout king of the National League the past two seasons, became the highest paid pitcher in the history of the Dodgers today either the Los Angeles or Brooklyn variety.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Britain pledged her full support today to the United Nations peacemaking effort in the Congo after acknowledging that the threatened withdrawal of some of the contingents in the United Nations force had made the task more difficult.

During the Presidential campaign last year, James A. Michener was chairman of the Citizens for Kennedy Committee in Bucks County, Pa. He made twenty to thirty speeches every week in the county and throughout the country.

The winter's coldest spell went through its twelfth day yesterday. Temperatures in the city ranged from a low of 15 degrees at 6:50 A.M. to a subfreezing high of 25 degrees at 3:30 P.M. while Suffern, N.Y., reported a reading of zero early today.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- An explosion in a statue was viewed here today as the start of a campaign of terrorism in support of demands by the German-speaking majority in Bolzano Province for greater self-rule.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Attorneys for The New York Times argued today that an advertisement in the newspaper that set off a series of libel suits was never intended to apply to Mayor Earl James of Montgomery.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 30 -- An air attack on the town of Manono in northern Katanga Province was reported by the United Nations here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The Christian Century, a non-denominational Protestant magazine, said today that Cardinal Spellman was doing "his country and his church a disservice" by his stand on Federal aid to parochial schools.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 -- They'll have to catch Ticonderoga in the Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- A Senate committee warned today that the economy would be handicapped, security undermined and health plagued unless the nation launched immediately a massive effort to clean up the rivers and save water.

Wall Street responded enthusiastically yesterday to President Kennedy's State of the Union message. Aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange rose about 1.2 per cent in the broadest trading ever recorded.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Jan 30 (AP) -- Softly repeating "I am guilty" thirty-five times, Mrs. Burnice Iverson Geiger entered her plea today to a United States Attorney's information in a $2,000,000 bank embezzlement.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has told a police organization that if he were Mayor he would discharge Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy for refusing to carry out policies laid down at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- The Interior Department said today that the Communist world made "substantial advances" in mineral production between 1953 and 1959, but that the United States and its Allies still held a commanding lead.
THERE will be little excuse for scruffy nails in the future if some of the newest nail products live up to their promises.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission warned today that continuation of the unpoliced moratorium on the atomic tests was a threat to the security of the free world.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Everton Soccer Club, one of the giants of the English League's First Division, was chosen today to represent England in the International Soccer League in New York this summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Kennedy, reverting to the major themes of his victorious election campaign, today called for great new exertions to reverse what he called the present "unfavorable tide" in the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- President Kennedy's State of the Union. Message today pictured the problems of the United States and the world as much more ominous and urgent than did former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's message to Congress eighteen days ago.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- A financial struggle between two rival press realms for possession of a third one today involved Prime Minister Macmillan and his Cabinet, Parliament, the trade union movement and newspapers and magazines with many millions of readers.
RECIFE, Brazil, Jan. 30 -- The United States Navy's conference at sea with the floating Portuguese rebel junta at dawn tomorrow will be a ceremony of pomp and happenstance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- The possibility of a strike that would have closed down the movie industry was averted today, one day before contracts expired between movie producers and the unions representing the movie crafts.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was out beating the bushes for quail before breakfast today in the pleasantest weather of his Georgia hunting vacation so far.
A contract covering 14,500 equipment installers and job clerks at Western Electric Company was agreed upon yesterday.
ATLANTA, Jan. 31 -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver signed today four measures that replace laws requiring public school segregation with a plan that allows local compliance with Federal Court rulings.

With the largest assemblage of top-flight track and field athletes under one roof to date this winter, the fifty-fourth annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Friday night seem certain to produce further record-breaking.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The turnover shrank and prices moved aimlessly on the stock market here today. However, small gains narrowly predominated in the main industrial lists.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Reporting on the State of the Union Message, Soviet newspapers stressed today President Kennedy's comments on weaknesses in the United States economy. Many positive aspects of the speech were ignored.

Bell Telephone Laboratories has developed a highly focused, "talking" beam of light that eventually is expected to replace radio in a number of communications tasks.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- New Jersey Blue Shield asked the State Banking and Insurance Commissioner today for the right to increase its subscriber rates an average of 23.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Frederick W. Ford, retiring chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, reported today that $14,650,000 was spent for television and radio appearances for all candidates in last year's elections.
Cotton futures prices fell 4 to 30 points (20 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California, told the 11th annual diocesan convention here today that McCarthyism was once more on the rise. He cited the House Committee on Un-American Activities a contributor to this revival.

ROCK HILL, S.C., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ten Negro college students ignored the warning of South Carolina's chief law-enforcement officer today and carried their anti-segregation demonstration to a white lunch counter. The ten, arrested for trespass, entered jail singing hymns and patriotic songs.

David Ben-Gurion is a modern patriarch. At the age of 74, he is still Israel's strong man the political and military leader who played a key role in creating the Jewish state, a member of all its Governments since 1948 except for thirteen brief months of retirement.

HONG KONG, Jan. 30 -- The virtual dissolution of centralized control of Communist China's rural communes caps a steady decline of these once-powerful organizations.

Three destitute but happy young Cubans told yesterday how they had schemed for more than a year to get out of Cuba and into the United States.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Marc Bohan, man of the hour here since unveiling his sensationally successful first Dior collection last Thursday, is not likely to be spoiled by this triumph. He seems to remain the same man -- naturally confident and assured, yet quiet, gentle and beautifully mannered. To some, his personality is reminiscent of the late Christian Dior.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Bergen County Judge C. Conrad Schneider today declined to act in a dispute over a seat on the Hackensack Board of Education.

In 1960, Bill Skowron, the first-string first baseman of the Yankees, appeared in more games (146), went to bat more times (538), collected more hits (166), punched more doubles (34), slugged more homers (26) and drove in more runs (91) than he did in any of his previous six years in the American League.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- It is an old saying here that a sneeze in Wall Street can cause pneumonia in Kabutocho, where Tokyo's stock exchange is situated. For this reason the Japanese took the keenest interest today in the passages of Mr. Kennedy s address dealing with the United States economy.

LISBON, Jan. 31 -- Rear Admiral Allen Smith Jr., commander of the United States Navy's Caribbean Sea Frontier, proposed to Portuguese officials at Recife during their conference Sunday that Portugal should send the Vera Cruz, a sister ship to the Santa Maria, to stand by and help transfer the liner's American passengers provided the negotiations with Henrique M. Galvao, the rebel commander on the ship, succeeded.

IN "Call Me by My Rightful Name," his first play to be produced in New York, Michael Shurtleff reveals a number of skills for the stage. He knows how to hold the audience's interest, he has an ear for the way human beings talk, and he can write smoothly about prickly people.
The value of real estate in New York City has reached a record of $26,330,568,252, according to tentative assessments for the fiscal year 1961-62.
The high cost of snow removal this winter sent Budget Director Abraham D. Beame to Albany yesterday seeking help.
Opening dates for a number of impending Broadway entertainments were designated yesterday.

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Charlie Osborne sparked a second-half Western Kentucky drive tonight for a 73-69 verdict over La Salle. With only three seconds remaining, La Salle trailed by 2 points. But Jim Duna of Western Kentucky took a length-of-the-court pass for an easy lay-up and the victory.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The George Putnam Fund, a balanced mutual investing company, reported today that asset value at the close of 1960 was a new year-end high of $15.12 a share, compared with $14.30 at the end of 1959, representing a rise of 5.7 per cent.
Stockholders of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc., approved the proposed acquisition of the F.W. Dodge Corporation at a special meeting here yesterday.
Futures prices for commodities on the New York exchanges closed generally mixed yesterday, in mostly light trading.
The Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council elected the Rev. Dr. John Lewis Zacker as its president last night.

IT was during the 1929-30 season that young Joseph Rosenstock made a brief appearance as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera. He returned there last night, some thirty years wiser and more experienced, to conduct the season's first performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde."

ABOARD THE U.S.S. GEARING, in the South Atlantic, Jan. 31 -- The Navy's air and sea hunters of the Portuguese liner Santa Maria received orders tonight to mass for a peaceful show of strength to dissuade the vessel's captors from sailing to sea again.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company reported yesterday a gain of 18 per cent in consolidated net income for 1960. At the same time, the company's preliminary annual report placed last year's operating revenues at more than $500,00,000, the first time this level had been reached.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Lehigh Valley Railroad today to discontinue its remaining interstate passenger trains.

James L. Farmer, a disciple of Gandhism who was named national director of the Congress of Racial Equality yesterday, said that "nonviolent action" against discrimination in the Deep South would soon spread from lunch counters to buses, bus terminals, restrooms and restaurants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The American Trucking Association, Inc., announced today support for a plan to have Congress impose compulsory arbitration on the industry's labor relations.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 31 -- Mergers are becoming a costly way to obtain new bank deposits, a leading practitioner of the art said here today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 31 -- Tunisia returned to an active role in the Arab League today in a diplomatic truce with the United Arab Republic.

Carl Foreman, the writer-producer whose credits include "High Noon," "The Key" and the forthcoming "The Guns of Navarone," has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to write the screen play for an independent production of "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh."

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Transit employes staged a walkout this morning that halted a public transportation system serving 700,000 persons in Greater Boston daily, but returned to their jobs this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- George Halas today set up temporary headquarters in a downtown hotel, a block from his Chicago Bears' offices destroyed by fire during the night.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Edward R. Dudley's election as Borough President of Manhattan will have wide repercussions affecting the political fortunes of Mayor Wagner, Carmine G. De Sapio, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., other Harlem leaders, the anti-Tammany Democrats and even Republi cans.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- An 8-year-old white boy joined his brother at integrated McDonogh No. 19 school today, extending the break in a ten-week-old segregation boycott.
Newspaper deliverers employed by thirty-five distributors in the metropolitan area walked out suddenly at midnight last night.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Mayor Earl James of Montgomery contended today that a full-page advertisement in The New York Times had "severely damaged" his reputation as a city official.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics put on a last-minute 5-point scoring burst that clinched a 109-103 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game tonight. The triumph gave Boston a 4-3 season edge over the Hawks.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday a state inquiry's bid to delve further into the affairs of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation. The company holds annual contracts of $5,000,000 with the city for electrical service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Kennedy today named Harold Francis Linder of New York to be president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day met rank-and-file employes of his department today. He told them that his aim was to provide an ever-improved postal service without "waste and frills."
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- The West Indies built a commanding lead and then dismissed three Australian batsmen for 31 runs today in the fourth cricket test match between the countries.

Production of paperboard rose for the fourth time this year in the week ended last Saturday. The rise was to 313,805 tons from 310,328 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 325,870 tons.

New securities offered publicly here in January dropped to the lowest level for the month in five years. The bonds and stocks marketed aggregated $1,296,245,000, against $1,776,810,000 in January, 1960. Last month's flotations were the smallest for a January since 1956 when offerings totaled $928,740,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A labor relations expert has been hired by the Governmtnt to try to head off union labor troubles in developing launching sites and vehicles to explore space.
Union cemetery workers agreed last night to extend a strike deadline against twenty Jewish and nonsectarian cemeteries from last midnight to midnight Tuesday.
Harlem Hospital surgeons angrily protested yesterday a recent transfer of "interesting cases" from their city institution to wards in Mount Sinai Hospital.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Only the national amateur champion, Deane Beman, Bethesda, Md., and his partner, Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone, Mason City, Iowa, broke par today as thirty-two teams qualified for the twenty-sixth annual national mixed foursomes invitation amateur golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Belgium charged at the United Nations today that her citizens had been abused in the Congo provinces under the control of forces supporting Patrice Lumumba, the imprisoned former Premier.
In the murky darkness of the New York Central's tunnel fifty-five feet under Park Avenue, a ground-breaking ceremony was held yesterday for the new thirty-story Bankers Trust Building.

THE Whist Club of New York held its annual meeting Monday night. Chiefly it was an occasion for the members to play bridge, with brief interruptions for a meeting that lasted perhaps fifteen minutes and for a dinner that was interrupted only by toasts to the President of the United States, John F. Kennedy, and the president of the Whist Club, Thomas F. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and the Kennedy Administration won a narrow victory today by liberalizing the House Rules Committee.

General Motors Acceptance Corporation, credit arm of the General Motors Corporation, announced yesterday plans for borrowing $150,000,000 in the public bond market. The money would be raised on an issue of debenture due in 1983.

Bowie, Md., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Carolina Joy, the 2-to-1 favorite owned by Cary C. Boshamer of Clover, S.C., was first home by three lengths in the featured Waldorf Purse at Bowie today, but was disqualified and placed last.

Dorothy Thompson was a phenomenal figure in American letters. A minister's daughter and suffragette, she turned to journalism with missionary zeal. She gave herseff her own assignment -- which was no less than the whole human situation. A tireless worker, traveler and talker, she rapidly became a legend. Parts of that legend were unflattering.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Floyd Patterson spent part of the afternoon sleeping and part of it working today in his Spring Rock Country Club training camp, where he is preparing for his heavyweight title defense against Ingemar Johansson in Miami Beach on March 13.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 31 -- The Belgian Socialist National Committee approved a plan today for M. Spaak to head the party's ticket in the Brussels district in the coming elections. This insures his return to Paliament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Kennedy won an important victory today to prevent the conservative Rules Committee of the House of Representatives from obstructing his legislative program, but he and his supporters cannot be wholly satisfied with the nature of the victory.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Robert S. Le Sage's Captain Fair captured his seventh stakes in six months as he defeated eight other Derby eligibles at Santa Anita in the $22,850 San Vicente Handicap today.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31 -- Communist China has agreed to grant Communist North Vietnam long-term loans totaling 141,750,000 new rubles ($157,342,500) according to the Hanoi radio.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Surgery was reported today to have a placebo effect, with enthusiastic proponents of a particular surgical operation appearing to get better results with their patients than skeptics do.
TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- A showdown on reapportionment of the sixty seats in the State Assembly appeared almost certain tomorrow for the first time since 1941.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The Great Lakes Commission today asked the director of the International Cooperation Administration to reconsider an order, scheduled to take effect tomorrow, that would halt United States payment of ocean freight costs on foreign aid cargoes shipped in non-American vessels.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:
THE Jazz Age fashions reissued in Paris last week were just a gag in the original, one of the flapper's best friends recalled yesterday. Why would anyone want to copy them now?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A $191,540 advance to enable New York City to begin preparing a general neighborhood plan for the Morningside Heights urban renewal area was announced today by the Urban Renewal Administration.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation will make known by noon today whether it will top the terms of the offer of the Bates Manufacturing Company to acquire Fruit of the Loom, Inc., or abandon the acquisition. Howard Newman, president, said yesterday that tle company was still undecided whether or not to pursue its previously announced plan to seek control of Fruit of 'the Loom.

The Arthur Judson Foundation, which was founded last fall to aid talented young musicians, presented its first concert last night. It consisted of a special program of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall. The event was designed to display the talents of Ivan Davis, 28-year-old Texas pianist, and Eric Friedman, 21-year-old violinist from Newark.

MONTREAL, Jan. 31 -- Israel's ambassador to Canada, Yaacov Herzog, and Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee agreed in a debate today that atrocities were atrocities and murder was murder, whether committed by Germans, Jews, Britons or any other peoples.
January was a banner month for the stock market.
MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP) -- S.M. Barton's favored Greek Star, leading all the way, won the featured seventh race at Hialeah today before a crowd of 15,462. Popperdopper was second and Bold Lark third.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Kennedy laid down a whirlwind schedule today for putting a broad, varied and controversial legislative program before Congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Paul C. McGee, a student at American University charged with holding up a theatre and wounding a policeman, has been sent to Elizabeths Hospital for a mental examination.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 31 -- Natal's United party leader, Douglas Mitchell, told Parliament in Capetown today, "we do not accept a republic in Natal."
Two water mains broke in the Sheridan Square area of Greenwich Village yesterday morning.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- The Chicago Heathers, skipped by Mrs. John Morrissy, and the Norfolk (Conn.) Curling Club rink, headed by Mrs. Edward Childs, led the way into the semi-final round of the seventh annual women's Empire State bonspiel for the Hovey Medal today:

"ASTRONOMY for Young People," a series of ten saturday morning lectures, will begin this week at the Hayden Planetarium. The series is designed for children 12 to 16 years old. The one-hour sessions begin at 9:45 A.M. The fee for the series is $10.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 3l (UPI) -- The Australian Lawn Tennis Association voted today to h01d the 1961 Davis Cup challenge round here instead of at Adelaide. It also imposed a ban on direct televising of challenge-round matches.
A United States airline expressed hope yesterday that a current parliamentary inquiry on the London Airport would temper a prospective one-third increase in British landing fees.

LITTLE girls thank heaven for Helen Lee -- or at least they ought to. The reason why is immediately apparent in the new spring collection Miss Lee has designed exclusively for Saks Fifth Avenue. sively for Saks Fifth Avenue. With it, she successfully achieves her dual purpose in design, to appeal to a mother's pride and a child's heart.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A state lottery and state or regional sales taxes were suggested today as new sources of revenue to help hard-pressed school districts meet constantly rising costs.
Exploding gas heaters in an apartment building under construction on the East Side caused a three-alarm fire last night. The blasts injured two watchmen and shattered windows in near-by structures.

WHILE most of the fashion press is turning to Paris for news, one Englishman has focused his attention on the United States. Alan Spiers, whose London beauty salon draws a clientele of international fame, flew to New York last Friday to pick up hairdressing trends in America.
BRASILIA, Jan. 31 -- President Janio Quadros pledged tonight that Brazil would take the democratic rather than the revolutionary way in solving her problems.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- New York newspaper editors asked today that more public records of legislative sessions be made available.

The Dayco Corporation, formerly the Dayton Rubber Company, reported yesterday that it had a consolidated operating loss of $5,968,990 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. This was in contrast to consolidated net income of $2,414,226 or $2.06 a share in fiscal 1959.
Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer, the only woman woh has served on the City Planning Commission, was honored yesterday both as a city official and as a volunteer leader in welfare activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Government said today it would bear down on one of the so-called "tax loopholes" that contribute to this country's balance-of-payments difficulties.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. GEARING, in the South Atlantic, Jan. 31 -- Rear Admiral Allen E. Smith Jr. announced today that the rebels in command of the Portuguese liner Santa Maria would bring her into Recife tomorrow if Brazil gave "the necessary clearance."
Your editorial makes no comment on two important aspects of the issue.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The visit in Rome last December between the Archbishop of Canterbury and Pope John XXII should suggest other "courtesy calls" between Roman Catholic priests, Anglican vicars and ministers of other Christian faiths, Dr. A.M. Ramsey, the Archbishop of York, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- James M. Landis, President Kennedy's overseer of Federal regulatory agencies, disclaimed today any intention of being a "czar" over them.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- New signs of nervousness were apparent today in the wake of President Kennedy's message.

Two major Protestant groups charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's plan to help students pay tuition to church supported colleges was an attempt to evade prohibitions in the state and Federal constitutions.

Among the many problems confronting President Kennedy one of the most important and urgent is the development of a new momentum and a new American leadership for the main bulwark of both our own defense and that of the free world -- the North Atlantic alliance.

Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., which is endeavoring to purchase any shares of the Chance Vought Corporation offered through next Wednesday at $43.50 a share, yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to solicit proxies of Chance Vought's shareholders.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Democracies are kept alive and vibrant when their leaders speak the unvarnished truth. Demosthenes told Athens, the first successful republic: "If you analyze it correctly, you will conclude that our critical status is chiefly due to men who try to please the citizens rather than to tell them what they need to hear."

Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that incoming orders for steel were showing a "slight improvement" over the level of recent months and that 1960 earnings were higher than in 1959.

Nan Merriman gave another of her entrancing recitals last night, in Judson Hall. The mezzo-soprano sang many works that are familiar in her repertory, but she made them come alive again with the seeming spontaneity of her performances.

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation and the American Express Company announced yesterday that they had entered the industrial financing field in West Germany as the first step in a joint oversea financing program.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- Approximately 8,000 physicians belonging to the Tokyo Metropolitan Medical Association closed their offices for one day today and held a public rally against the size of increases in medical payments proposed by the Government under the health insurance program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., a former Assistant Secretary of State, was appointed today chairman of a task force to coordinate policies on Latin America.

President Kennedy won his first victory in his first contest with Congress yesterday, but he won it by a margin so narrow as to be reminiscent of Election Day. He won it not on a substantive piece of legislation at all, but on an organizational matter.
A home building concern in New Jersey has established a sales consultant service for other builders.
WOMEN will have to find something new to complain about now that one manufacturer has developed a range and an oven that are easy to clean.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Judicial Conference urged the Legislature today to make "a fresh start" in dealing with youth crime.

Joey Archer and Don Fullmer, the middleweights who will meet in Saturday's main event at Madison Square Garden, had a fine opportunity to watch each other in action yesterday. However, each was so busy he had little chance to take advantage of the situation.
The recent snowfalls may have inconvenienced many, but for The New York Times Neediest Cases they carried a small silver lining.
The former director of food services at Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue and East 100th Street, was accused yesterday of having exacted $75,000 in kickbacks from food suppliers to the hospital.
The world's shipbuilders expect a scarcity of new orders "for at least the next few years," the head of one of the world's leading ship classification organizations said here yesterday.

Although he was shut out for the first time in thirty-eight games against Northeastern, Phil Latreille, Middlebury's sharpshooting forward, is well on the way to a third consecutive national hockey scoring title.

Grants to religious institutions, even though they may be channeled through students or their parents, are grants to these institutions, nevertheless. The United States Supreme Court has often held that one may not do by indirection what he is prohibited from doing directly.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 31 -- A male chimpanzee nicknamed "Ham" was rocketed 420 miles over the Caribbean today in a test of the Mercury capsule that is scheduled to carry a human astronaut into orbit.
A further rise in the investment yields on United States Government securities of shortest term took place yesterday, relegating to the background the day's other developments in the bond market.

WARSAW, Jan. 31 -- The Old Vic Company of London opened a five-day run in Warsaw tonight before an enthusiastic audience of diplomats and members of the Polish elite. The performance of "Macbeth" starred Paul Rogers.

Gold has become one of the most glittering topics of conversation these days -- and one of the cloudiest. In an effort to simplify matters Dr. Marcus Nadler says: "The task before the nation is not to remove the symptom [the outflow of gold from this country] but the cause [the adverse balance of payments]."
Mayor Wagner complained yesterday that he had been left out in the cold at Albany. Governor Rockefeller's fiscal program for the city, the Mayor said, was like "giving away ice in the wintertime."
A study of the office requirements of advertising agencies shows that executives and their assistants occupy only a shade less space than all of the office space used by the service departments.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that the British Government was powerless to prevent a merger, now under negotiation, involving four national newspapers and a score of magazines.
Samuel Baron is a fine flute player and he obviously likes to play lively and interesting music.
Mayor Wagner scored a victory over Tammany Hall yesterday as Edward R. Dudley, his choice for Borough President, was elected by a 4-to-2 vote of the Manhattan members of the City Council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Kennedy plans a two-pronged effort to increase the flow of foreign tourists to the United States.
THERE is probably no quarter in Manhattan that offers more stimulating variety of line, unusual and interesting goods than Greenwich Village.

Production of electricity in the nation set a record in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Output totaled 15,361,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 14,817,000,000 the week before and 14,417,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.
The State of New Jersey is planning the sale of $20,850,000 of water supply development bonds on March 7, according to State Treasurer John A. Kervick.
Your Jan. 25 editorial "A Strike Avoidance Plan" is an important contribution to thinking through a problem which, difficult and complex though it be, must be solved one way or another.

Away from Broadway since 1951, Sam Wanamaker will return in "Far Country." He will be co-starred with Kim Stanley and Steven Hill in Henry Denson's play, arriving March 22, perhaps at the Music Box. Mr. Wanamaker will portray Dr. Josef Breuer, who was associated with Dr. Sigmund Freud in the development of psychoanalysis.

The temperature equaled its lowest mark in nineteen years today with a reading of zero at 3 A.M. Even lower temperatures were considered a possibility, and the mercury was not expected to rise out of the teens during the day.
Special union concessions will enable "Roots," the British play by Arnold Wesker, to open March 6 in the new 299-seat playhouse, the Mayfair, which is in the heart of the Broadway theatre district.

News that the Kennedy Administration is forming a task force to coordinate policies on Latin America is interesting and encouraging. The problems of the hemisphere are among the most critical and important facing the new Administration. They are problems of enormous complexity and scope. The sooner some expert knowledge is put to work, some studies made and policies reviewed, the sooner the Government can act.
The eleven Metropolitan chapters of the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York, Inc., will hold a theatre party at the Feb. 14 performance of "Do Re Mi" at the St. James Theatre.

The board of directors of Spiegel, Inc., declared a stock dividend of 5 per cent on the common shares yesterday in addition to the usual quarterly cash dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share. The mail-order concern also reported that its sales and earnings set records in 1960.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Mr. and Mrs. Harton Semple of Sewickley, Pa., provided an upset today in the first round of the national mixed foursome amateur golf championship.

ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Negro students marched on downtown Atlanta today and placed picket lines in front of stores in a demonstration marking the first anniversary of sit-ins at segregated Southern lunch counters.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to authorize a record of $2,388,000,000 in state spending for the fiscal year beginning April 1.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Following are excerpts from the budget message delivered by Governor Rockefeller to the Legislature today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Manufacturing activity declined again in December, the Department of Commerce has reported. There were reductions in sales, new orders and inventories.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller, in analyzing revenues expected in the coming fiscal year, pointed out today that the yield from personal income taxes would not increase as much as it had in past years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Formation of Congressional group opposed to what it calls back-door spending of Federal funds was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The hair-breadth majority by which the House approved Speaker Rayburn's proposal to break the conservative blockade of legislation in the Rules Committee gave President Kennedy and the Speaker the power they sought.

PARENTS should help fill the gap created by the omission from textbooks of a "satisfactory" account of the Nazi persecution of Jews and other minority groups, in the opinion of the Anti-Defamation League, some educators and a psychologist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Kennedy is now clearly forcing the pace. Instead of letting it slack off, he is rushing it forward in an obvious effort to make the White House the master force of the Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller, expressing "deep concern" over the growing number of unemployed workers who are exhausting their jobless pay benefits, announced today that he would move to extend the benefits by thirteen weeks.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Lawyers for the New Rochelle Board of Education advised the board today to appeal a court ruling that it had maintained the Lincoln Elementary School as a segregated institution.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1 -- A tiny crack appeared today in the anti-United States facade that Communist China presents to the world.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- Dave MacLeod led Boston University to a 15-8 hockey victory over Dartmouth tonight at Boston Arena.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks lost a 20-point lead and then rallied behind Bob Pettit to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 137 -- 131, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

The former Packard Motors Building at 637 Central Avenue, Newark, and 2 to 8 Central Avenue, East Orange, at the Newark-East Orange. boundary line, has been sold by Columbia University. It is a three-story building containing 130,000 square feet of space and occupying the entire blockfront between Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson's debut in the Security Council today included a handshake and a brief chat with Valerian A. Zorin, the Soviet delegate.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 1 -- Karol Strelecki registered 18 points to lead Rutgers to a 74-73 basketball victory over Navy today.

A tower floor has been leased by the William J. Burns International Detective Agency in the office building under construction at 235 East Forty-second Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue. The agency also took street-floor space in the part of the building that forms an outlet on Forty-third Street.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- A bill that would grant tax incentives to private developers engaged in urban renewal projects was favorably received at a public hearing held here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The knotty question of control and development of the water riches of the 12,750-square-mile Delaware River Basin was finally settled at a top-level Federal-state meeting here today.

Plans for two city-aided cooperative housing developments for middle-income families were announced yesterday by the Housing and Redevelopment Board. One will be in Harlem and the other in the Coney Island area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb 1 -- Cary Grant, who eased past his fifty-seventh birthday last month, was wondering today how many more years he could squeeze out of his style of sophisticated comedy, which gives romance a priority over social issues.

Don't give up on the New York Rangers. They're still alive. The Blues showed so much fight last night at Madison Square Garden that they had the ponderous Chicago Black Hawks gasping for breath at the end.

MOST proud parents of new-born babes have had to submit to the agonizing experience of trying to settle on a name that the wonder child can carry gracefully for a lifetime. There are periods of indecision, of hesitation, of reappraisal, of fluttering back and forth over the master list. Eventually the plunge is made, for better or worse.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Army's basketball team extended its winning streak to nine with a 90-to-67 victory over Colgate today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- St. Lawrence Seaway traffic is creating a problem that threatens the profitable tourist and resort industry of Great Lakes States, Representative Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, said today.
A device has been developed that can time events in nuclear physics down to a fraction of a nanosecond. A nanosecond is a billionth of a second.
One of the untold stories of the dark days of World War II is about to be disclosed in an advertisement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Federal Reserve board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed, the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 25:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- In the winter of 1933 a New York boy and his father took a tour of colleges and were at Charlottesville at the time of an important boxing match. That was in the days when boxing was a major sport at the University of Virginia.
